File: Ahmad and Goparaju - 2017 - Land Evaluation in terms of Agroforestry Suitability, an Approach to Improve Livelihood and Reduce P.pdf
Input_Variables: Nutrient availability (soil data); Slope (ASTER DEM); Wetness (Landsat data); Rainfall (decadal annual rainfall data); Elevation (ASTER DEM)
Spatial_Method: Geospatial analysis using remote-sensing inputs (Landsat, ASTER DEM, decadal rainfall) to derive wetness, LULC, elevation, slope and rainfall, followed by a weighted multi-criteria overlay in ArcGIS 10.1 to produce nutrient availability and agroforestry suitability maps on 1 km grids, with proximity analyses to poverty, drainage and watershed used to identify priority areas.
Method_Validation: Proximity-based validation (proximity analysis to poverty, drainage and watershed)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Agroforestry suitability map (high; medium; low; 1 km × 1 km grids)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic aspects are framed through livelihoods and poverty, with outputs including a poverty map and analysis of proximity between high agroforestry suitability and high-poverty areas, indicating potential livelihood benefits, but no explicit economic metrics (ROI/NPV/Cost-benefit) or economic suitability scores are reported.
Narrative: Agroforestry was the NbS addressed through an agroforestry suitability mapping exercise in Palamu district, Jharkhand, India. The main inputs were Landsat data, ASTER DEM and decadal rainfall, used to generate wetness, land use/land cover (LULC), elevation, slope and rainfall maps; the LULC map was used to classify open land where disturbance vulnerability was high, and a nutrient-availability layer was included alongside slope, wetness, rainfall and elevation in the analysis. The spatial method was ArcGIS 10.1-based GIS integration using a weighted overlay, with weights assigned to each thematic layer to produce a high/medium/low agroforestry suitability surface at 1 km × 1 km spacing; outputs included the suitability surface plus a poverty map, a drainage map for the whole study area and a watershed map for one complete watershed. Validation relied on proximity analysis: high suitability grid proximity to high poverty ≈80% and to drainage ≈70%; about 60% of the watershed grid had high suitability proximity. Geographic scope: Palamu district, India; climate risk or economic considerations: economic (poverty) included; climate risk not explicitly stated.

File: Ahmad et al. - 2018 - Assessment of remote sensing and GIS application in identification of land suitability for agrofores.pdf
Input_Variables: Soil nitrogen map (Indian Institute of Soil Science, Bhopal); Soil phosphorus map (Indian Institute of Soil Science, Bhopal); Soil potassium map (Indian Institute of Soil Science, Bhopal); Soil organic carbon map (Indian Institute of Soil Science, Bhopal); Soil pH map (Indian Institute of Soil Science, Bhopal); Soil fertility status map (Indian Institute of Soil Science, Bhopal); Slope (ASTER DEM) (ASTER DEM); Wetness map (Landsat-8); NDVI map (Sentinel); LULC map (Sentinel); Temperature anomaly 2050 (NCAR GIS Program, RCP6)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis using weighted overlay, where themes such as soil fertility, slope, wetness and NDVI are assigned weights via pairwise comparison and combined to produce agroforestry suitability classes.
Method_Validation: Cross-evaluation with land use/land cover (LULC) categories.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Agroforestry suitability map (very high; high; moderate; low)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They treat climate hazards as a risk to NbS outcomes by noting that rising temperatures and extreme climate events could reduce agricultural performance, and they demonstrate this with a future climate-change scenario (2050 temperature anomalies) and projected yield declines linked to those hazards, integrated with the agroforestry suitability outputs.
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Samastipur district; Bihar | National: India
Narrative: The NbS addressed was agroforestry, with a GIS‑based spatial prioritisation to map agroforestry suitability in Samastipur district, Bihar, India. Key inputs included soil fertility status by integrating nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, organic carbon and pH maps from the Indian Institute of Soil Science; LULC from Sentinel‑2 (10 m); wetness from Landsat‑8; slope from ASTER DEM (30 m); NDVI from Sentinel; and 2050 temperature anomalies under RCP6 from the NCAR GIS program. The spatial method applied a GIS‑based weighted overlay, first combining soil fertility components with equal weight, then weighting four thematic layers (soil, slope, wetness, NDVI) by pairwise comparison to yield a final raster classified into four suitability classes (very high, high, moderate, low). Validation with LULC showed 86.4% of agriculture and 30.2% of open area in very high suitability; outputs included area statistics: Very high 1400.17 km2 (48.22%), High 662.88 km2 (22.83%), Moderate 677.31 km2 (23.32%), Low 163.64 km2 (5.63%). Climate risk was considered; economic aspects were not modeled. Geographic scope: Samastipur district, India (~2904 km2).

File: Ahmad et al. - 2020 - Quantification of the Land Potential for Scaling Agroforestry in South Asia.pdf
Input_Variables: Soil data (Harmonized World Soil Database); Elevation (GTOPO30); Slope (GTOPO30); Temperature (WorldClim); Precipitation (WorldClim); Aridity (Trabucco and Zomer 2009); Tree cover (2000) (Hansen et al. 2013); NDVI (MODIS); Land cover (Harmonized land cover Asia) (Tateishi et al. 2011); Irrigated area map Asia (IWMI); Cropland mask (VEGA 2000); Precipitation deficit area (2006–2015) (TerraClimate); Temperature and rainfall anomalies (2030) (NCAR GIS Program 2012)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria land suitability analysis using FAO 1976 guidelines; equal-weighted overlay of harmonized soil suitability, NDVI, climate/aridity, slope and tree cover; reclassification into suitability classes; zonal statistics and tree-cover hotspot analysis to identify priority agroforestry areas.
Method_Validation: Comparison with FAO forest cover data (Global Forest Resources Assessment 2010)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Agroforestry suitability map (classes: Not suitable; <25%; 25–35%; 35–45%; 45–55%; 55–65%; 65–75%; ≥75%); Agroforestry potential map within croplands (suitability classes: <30%; 30–50%; 50–70%; ≥70%)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: they frame climate hazards as a risk to the long-term viability of agroforestry by showing projected 2030 temperature and precipitation anomalies that could undermine future suitability and crop productivity, demonstrated through a hazard overlay of future climate maps with current deficit areas and a discussion of resulting viability challenges.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: the authors explicitly treat agroforestry as a climate-adaptation/mitigation NbS and target areas accordingly; they demonstrate this by overlaying projected 2030 climate anomalies (temperature and precipitation) with agroforestry suitability and tree-cover hotspot maps to prioritise areas where NbS can reduce climate risks and enhance resilience.
Narrative: Quantification of Land Potential for Scaling Agroforestry in South Asia addressed agroforestry as NbS. Inputs included land, soil, climate data from Harmonized World Soil Database; VEGA 2000 land cover; GTOPO30 DEM; MODIS NDVI (250 m); Hansen tree cover (2000); GLCP Asia land cover; WorldClim climate variables; aridity (Trabucco & Zomer 2009); precipitation deficit maps; and NCAR 2030 climate projections, evaluated at 10 km grids. The spatial method combined seven themes in ArcGIS with equal weights and FAO (1976) land-evaluation guidelines to produce an agroforestry suitability map, reclassifying into categories and analyzing cropland masks and slope/NDVI. Climate risk was addressed via NCAR 2030 projections; economic considerations were not described. Outputs included an agroforestry land-potential map and tree-cover hotspot maps at ~10 km resolution for South Asia (excluding Afghanistan; Maldives included). Results showed 69% of the area with 55%+ suitability; 73.4% land had 0% tree cover; climate projections indicated shifts by 2030.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Table 1 data sources include Harmonized World Soil Database (https://webarchive.iiasa.ac.at/Research/LUC/External-World-soil-database/HTML/SoilQualityData.html?sb=11); Climate data (WorldClim) (https://worldclim.org/bioclim); DEM (https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/); MODIS NDVI (https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/); Mean annual aridity (http://www.cgiar-csi.org/data/global-aridity-and-pet-database); Tree cover 2000 (https://earthenginepartners.appspot.com/science-2013-global-forest/download_v1.0.html); Harmonized land cover Asia (https://forobs.jrc.ec.europa.eu/products/glc2000/products.php); Irrigated Area Map Asia (https://waterdata.iwmi.org/applications/irri_area/); Prediction (2030) of temperature/rainfall anomalies (https://gisclimatechange.ucar.edu/); Present decadal precipitation deficit map (https://www.climatologylab.org/terraclimate.html); Supplementary data: Electronic supplementary material available online with the article (DOI: 10.1007/s42489-020-00045-0).

File: Baldwin et al. - 2022 - Geospatial Analysis and Land Suitability for “FloodWise” Practices Nature-Based Solutions for Flood.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Wetland Restoration and Creation; Dry Dams and Berms; Stream Restoration; Agroforestry; Afforestation
Input_Variables: Slope (Statewide 20-foot Digital Elevation Model (NC One Map); NC Floodplain Mapping Program; NC Department of Transportation); Hydric Soils (USDA gSSURGO); Low-Productivity Soils (USDA gSSURGO NCCPI); Cropland and Open Land (NLCD MRLC); High-Value Crops (Cropland Data Layer, NASS); Cropland Inundation (NASS Inundated Cropland); Floodplains (FEMA NFHL); HUC-12 Sub-watersheds (NCDEQ; USGS); Streams (National Hydrography Dataset, USGS); Parcels (NC One Map); Roads (NC DOT); Structures (NC Building Footprints; NC Flood Mapping Program); Solar Panels (US EIA); Communications Towers (DHS HIFLD)
Spatial_Method: ArcGIS Pro–based multi-criteria overlay workflow: identify Eligible Cropland by overlaying cropland/open land with exclusions for high‑value crops and infrastructure; select afforestation opportunities by intersecting low‑productivity soils (NCCPI < 0.33) with Eligible Cropland on single‑ownership parcels ≥5 acres; identify wetland restoration/creation by overlaying hydric soils and slopes ≤2% on single‑ownership parcels ≥5 acres; delineate water farming sites by excluding floodplains and selecting areas outside floodplains with mean slopes ≤2% and ≥5 acres; assess stream restoration by applying sinuosity and minimum length thresholds with riparian buffers and intersecting with parcel data; and dissolve/intersect results to yield priority NBS opportunity areas.
Method_Validation: Ground-truthing visits to specific properties and assessing their suitability for supporting FloodWise practices; Expert review or stakeholder validation via consultation with scientists and farm technical service providers.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Eligible Cropland map; Forest and Tree Planting opportunity areas (upland pine; lowland hardwood); Wetland Restoration and Creation opportunity areas; Dry Dams and Berms (Water Farming) opportunity areas; Stream Restoration opportunity areas (1000‑ft minimum; 500‑ft minimum)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors explicitly target NbS for flood mitigation as an adaptation to climate hazards by focusing on areas with flood-prone land and hurricane inundation to reduce climate-related flooding. They demonstrate this by mapping eligible cropland and FloodWise opportunity areas and stating that these results can be used to model potential flood-reduction impacts and prioritize sites for implementation.
Economics: Yes: Details - The OUTPUT analysis incorporates economic framing by using a cost-effectiveness criterion (a five-acre minimum) to ensure FloodWise practices are economically viable, and it discusses proposed financial incentives (payments and technical assistance) to landowners under the FloodWise program, also referencing prior work on costs, revenues, and cost-share payments, indicating that economic considerations underpin site selection and outreach.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Robeson County; Sub-national: North Carolina; Eastern North Carolina; North Carolina Coastal Plain; South Carolina; Columbus County; Jones County; Martin County; Edgecombe County; Duplin County; Cumberland County; Halifax County; Nash County; National: United States; Global: worldwide
Narrative: NbS addressed: FloodWise practices—wetland restoration, afforestation/agroforestry, water farming with dry dams/berms, and stream restoration—applied to flood mitigation in Eastern North Carolina, focusing Robeson County. Main inputs included ArcGIS Pro with the Statewide 20‑ft DEM for slope; NLCD land cover; Cropland Data Layer for crops and hurricane inundation; gSSURGO soils with NCCPI; hydric soils; parcels (NC One Map) with ownership; roads/structures buffers; FEMA floodplains (100/500‑year); and USGS hydrography. Method: GIS overlays in ArcGIS Pro, Raster Calculator to form an Eligible Cropland layer by excluding high‑value crops/infrastructure, then practice overlays (≤5 acres low‑productivity land for afforestation; wetlands on hydric soils ≤2% slope; water farming outside floodplains; stream restoration by sinuosity and minimum lengths). Validation relied on aerial imagery checks. Outputs: Robeson County maps at parcel‑scale suitable for site‑level prioritization; Eligible Cropland 208,718 ac; afforestation 67,787 ac; wetlands 27,716 ac; dry dams 3,932 ac; stream restoration 347,037 ft (1000 ft) and 511,339 ft (500 ft). Scope: Eastern North Carolina, Robeson County; transferable to similar counties. Climate risk/economics: included flood risk data and economic considerations (5‑acre minimum; FloodWise payments).
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data presented in Appendix A.

File: Brandt et al. - 2015 - How to target climate-smart agriculture Concept and application of the consensus-driven decision su.pdf
Input_Variables: Annual precipitation (Hijmans et al., 2005); Soil organic matter (Nachtergaele et al., 2012); Percentage of households with access to safe water sources (Government of Kenya, 2009; Wiesmann et al., 2014); Literacy rate (Government of Kenya, 2013); Female participation in economic activities (Government of Kenya, 2009; Wiesmann et al., 2014); Connectivity through transport infrastructure (Uchida and Nelson, 2009); Low nutrient capital reserves (Sanchez et al., 2003); Suitability of rainfed cereal crops (van Velthuizen et al., 2007); Methane and nitrous oxide emissions from livestock per kg protein (Herrero et al., 2013); Aridity index (Zomer et al., 2008); Percentage of cropland area (Fritz et al., 2015); Insurance premium rates for livestock mortality (Vrieling et al., 2014)
Spatial_Method: Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to elicit pairwise stakeholder preferences; Goal Programming (GP) optimization to derive consensus weights; Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) of standardized vulnerability and CSA layers using those weights; Spatial overlay with constraint masking to identify high-potential areas.
Method_Validation: Stakeholder validation via workshop re-elicitation using the identical PC questionnaire and post-workshop validation questionnaires (16 responses, ~50% of each group); cross-survey validation using two expert surveys with Wilcoxon signed-rank tests showing no significant median differences; spatial validation by comparing indices under majority, minority and most-balanced consensus scenarios and mapping areas of agreement/disagreement on CSA potential; iterative validation potential via repeated elicitation of preferences to test robustness of indices.
Tool_Source: targetCSA: A three-stage, consensus-driven decision-support framework that (i) gathers and structures stakeholder input on vulnerability indicators and CSA practices, (ii) employs analytic hierarchy process and a goal-programming optimization to derive consensus-based preferences and explore majority, minority, and balanced scenarios, and (iii) spatially aggregates these preferences with geospatial vulnerability and CSA data using a weighted linear combination to produce maps and indices of CSA potential for targeting climate-smart practices at national/regional scales (demonstrated in Kenya).
Output: CSA suitability map for selected practices (improvement of soil fertility; drought‑tolerant cereals; livestock GHG reduction; water harvesting; agroforestry; livestock insurance) [low/mid/high]; Climate‑change vulnerability index map [low/mid/high]; CSA potential maps (coupled vulnerability × suitability) under three consensus scenarios — majority; minority; most‑balanced trade‑off [low/mid/high]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They explicitly frame climate-change vulnerability as a risk that could undermine NbS (CSA) suitability and persistence by showing that high-vulnerability areas coincide with varying CSA suitability, threatening long-term effectiveness; they demonstrate this via a hazard overlay approach that combines spatial climate-vulnerability indicators with CSA-suitability maps, including scenario-based consensus assessments to identify robust versus fragile targeting.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors target climate-smart agriculture as an NbS to reduce climate vulnerability (adaptation) and GHG emissions (mitigation) and explicitly link targeting to high-vulnerability regions, demonstrated by spatially explicit vulnerability and CSA-suitability indices overlaid to produce CSA-potential maps under different consensus scenarios.
Geographic_Scope: National: Kenya; Sub-national: Turkana; Kitui; Wajir; Mandera; Western; Central; Northern; Eastern; North-Eastern
Narrative: The approach targeted climate-smart agriculture (CSA) as NbS, addressing CSA practices such as improvement of soil fertility and soil management, identification and distribution of drought-tolerant cereal crops, improvement of water harvesting and water management, agroforestry, and livestock-insurance–related measures. Main inputs were six vulnerability indicators and CSA practice proxies, derived from biophysical (annual precipitation, soil organic matter), social (percentage of households with access to safe water sources, literacy rate) and economic (female participation in economic activities, connectivity through transport infrastructure) dimensions; data came from Hijmans et al. (2005), Nachtergaele et al. (2012), Government of Kenya census/profiles (2009–2013), ArcGIS processing, and publicly available databases (FAO GeoNetwork, HarvestChoice, GEO-Wiki), resampled to ~10×10 km grids. The spatial method combined stakeholder preferences via Analytic Hierarchy Process and a goal-programming optimization to derive majority, minority and most-balanced consensus, then applied a weighted linear combination to jointly derive standardized vulnerability and CSA-suitability indices (masked for constraints) and CSA-potential maps at 10×10 km. Validation used two expert surveys (n=32, four groups) and a November 2014 workshop, with Wilcoxon tests showing no significant median differences (p>0.05); results indicated high vulnerability in the North and North-East and high CSA suitability in Western, Central, coastal and parts of Northern Kenya, with high CSA potential for CSA practices in Baringo, Mandera and Wajir; outputs comprise three consensus scenarios and maps at 10×10 km, enabling overlay of vulnerability with CSA suitability at national scale in Kenya, incorporating climate risk and economic considerations through the vulnerability indices.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.agsy.2015.12.011.

File: Castle et al. - 2025 - Mapping the social-ecological suitability of agroforestry in the US Midwest.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Alley cropping; Riparian buffers; Silvopasture; Windbreaks
Input_Variables: Soil erosion by water (GloSEM model); Soil erosion by wind (SSURGO wind erodibility index); Water quality (Nitrate Violation Index); Soil organic carbon sequestration potential (GSOCseq FAO); Soil drainage class (SSURGO; AgTiles); Frost-free period (SSURGO); Soil depth (SSURGO; STATSGO); Soil pH (SSURGO; STATSGO); Soil texture (0–25 cm) (SSURGO; STATSGO); Elevation (USGS 3DEP); Precipitation (PRISM); Set-aside conservation (NASS); Rotational grazing (NASS); Rented lands (NASS); Beginning farmers (NASS); Hired labor (NASS); Weighted net income for producers per acre (NASS; SSURGO); Cropland and pasture land use (USDA NASS CDL); Riparian buffers: 30 m buffers around waterways (NHD; CDL); Silvopasture: Pasture lands (USDA NASS CDL); Windbreaks: 10 m buffers around delineated fields (CSB)
Spatial_Method: Geospatial multi-criteria decision analysis using a weighted linear sum to combine environmental priority areas, tree growth suitability, social feasibility, and economic viability into suitability maps for agroforestry practices.
Method_Validation: Key informant interviews (expert/stakeholder validation); comparison of COMET-Planner carbon sequestration estimates with IPCC-based estimates and other studies to validate carbon storage potential.
Tool_Source: COMET-Planner: Used to estimate potential carbon benefits of expanding agroforestry at large geographical scales by calculating average GHG reductions (Mg CO2e per acre per year) for each county and each major practice, yielding an overall estimate (e.g., ~43 Mt CO2e y−1) to compare agroforestry with alternatives and inform policy; limitations include generalized, non-parcel-scale estimates. ; agroforestry suitability tool: A public Google Earth Engine app implementing the study’s geospatial multi-criteria decision analysis to map agroforestry suitability across the US Midwest, allowing users to select and weight environmental, social, and economic criteria for four practices (alley cropping, riparian buffers, silvopasture, windbreaks) and identify priority areas, with adaptability to other regions.
Output: Alley cropping suitability map (suitability classes); Riparian buffer suitability map (suitability classes); Silvopasture suitability map (suitability classes); Windbreak suitability map (suitability classes); Carbon sequestration potential map for converting top 5% most suitable agricultural lands to agroforestry (Mg CO2e yr−1 by practice; total ≈43 Mt CO2e yr−1)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors target the top 5% of lands most suitable for agroforestry to deliver climate mitigation benefits, and they demonstrate this by estimating CO2e reductions (about 43 Mt CO2e per year) from expanding agroforestry versus baseline, using a scenario-based prioritisation to show where mitigation gains are greatest.
Economics: Yes: Economic viability is embedded in the OUTPUT as an explicit Economic viability indicator (Indicator 4) in the four-criterion model, calculated from county-level net cash farm income per operation divided by average acres per operation and weighted by the NCCPI, integrated with environmental and social feasibility to yield the overall agroforestry suitability; results show spatial variation (low where agroforestry would compete with high-profit crops in Illinois, Iowa, southern Minnesota; higher where current systems are less profitable in Missouri, western Nebraska, Kansas, Nebraska, etc.), illustrated in Fig. 6 as county-level economic viability maps that inform prioritization and policy implications including the potential role of payments for ecosystem services.
Narrative: The study addressed agroforestry NbS practices—alley cropping, riparian buffers, silvopasture, and windbreaks—in the US Midwest. Key inputs included environmental priority criteria (soil erosion by water from the GloSEM NRCS 2019 100 m layer; wind erosion index from SSURGO; EPA nitrate violation index in HUC12 regions 2013–2017; soil organic carbon sequestration potential from FAO GSOCseq), tree-growth criteria (soil drainage from SSURGO/AgTiles at 30 m; frost-free period; soil depth, pH, and texture from SSURGO/STATSGO at 800 m; elevation from USGS 3DEP 10 m; precipitation from PRISM 4.6 km), social feasibility indicators (set-aside/conservation, rotational grazing, rented acres, new/beginning farmers, hired labor from NASS 2022), and economic viability (weighted net income per operation and NCCPI). The spatial method was a GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis using a weighted linear sum to normalize and combine indicators into four environmental/tree-growth/social/economic layers, with COMET-Planner estimating carbon effects and final four suitability maps plus an overall map; weights were literature/expert-informed. Validation used seven key informants; results indicated top 5% lands (18.3 million acres) could store 43 [29–58] Mt CO2e y−1, producing county-scale outputs constrained to cropland/pasture across twelve Midwestern states (IL, IN, IA, KS, MI, MN, MO, NE, ND, OH, SD, WI). Outputs include high-resolution maps and a public Google Earth Engine app; climate risk was not explicitly included, while economic considerations were.

File: Chuma et al. - 2021 - Suitability for agroforestry implementation around Itombwe Natural Reserve (RNI), eastern DR Congo.pdf
Input_Variables: Climate types (Beck et al., 2018); Elevation (DEM); Soil unity (SoilGrids.org/ISRIC); Land use and land cover (2015) (CCI/UCL-ELI); Slope (%) (DEM); Slope aspect (DEM); Euclidean distance to roads (RGC); Euclidean distance to rivers (RGC); Euclidean distance to villages (RGC); Euclidean distance to local aerodromes (RGC); RNI boundary (RGC)
Spatial_Method: Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) within a GIS (ArcGIS 10.7) to weight nine criteria by pairwise comparisons; Weighted Overlay of reclassified rasters (including Euclidean distances to roads, rivers, villages and airports, plus elevation, slope, aspect, climate and soils) to produce agroforestry suitability around the Itombwe Reserve.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR < 0.1)
Tool_Source: ArcGIS 10.7: Used as the GIS platform for all spatial analyses and data processing (e.g., raster reclassification, DEM-derived slope, aspect and elevation, and Euclidean distances to roads, rivers, villages and airports). ; ArcGIS ModelBuilder: Used to organize and automate the agroforestry suitability analysis workflow around the RNI (as depicted in Fig. 3). ; Weighted Overlay: Used to combine the AHP-weighted, reclassified criterion layers into the final four-class agroforestry suitability map via a linear additive model.
Output: Agroforestry suitability map around Itombwe Natural Reserve (Very high; High; Moderate; Low)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: South-Kivu; National: Democratic Republic of Congo
Narrative: The NbS addressed was agroforestry implementation around the Itombwe Natural Reserve (RNI) in South‑Kivu, eastern DR Congo. The main inputs comprised nine criteria including land use/land cover, slope (%), elevation (m), slope aspect, and Euclidean distances to roads, rivers, villages, and local aerodromes, plus climate types and soil unities, with data sourced from RGC shapefiles (RNI, territories, villages, roads, rivers, airports; https://rgc.cd/), a 30 m DEM and 2015 land cover from the UCL/ELI platform, soils from soilgrids.org, and climate inputs from Beck et al. (2018) among others, analyzed in ArcGIS 10.7. The spatial method combined these variables using Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) to assign weights via a 9×9 pairwise comparison (CI = 0.08, CR = 0.07) and then produced a Weighted Overlay in ArcGIS to yield a linear additive land-suitability index reclassified into four classes (Very high, High, Moderate, Low). Validation relied on internal consistency (CR < 0.1) with results showing Very high ~29.2% (~220,400 ha), High ~22.3% (~167,200 ha), Moderate ~34% (~258,400 ha), and Low ~14.5% (~114,000 ha) of the area, and district patterns—Very high suitability most in Hauts‑Plateaux ~62%, Kaziba ~66.3%, Minembwe ~34.2%, Mwenga ~8.9%. Outputs include suitability maps around the RNI at 30 m resolution and district-level distributions. The geographic scope covered seven districts around the RNI, within the eastern DR Congo where the RNI spans ~760,000 ha. Climate data were included as a criterion; explicit economic factors were not part of the MCDA.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The data used for the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

File: Ellis et al. - 2000 - A GIS-based database management application for agroforestry planning and tree selection.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Alley cropping; Shelterbelts or windbreaks; Silvopastoral; Riparian buffers; Forest farming
Input_Variables: Annual precipitation (Southeast Regional Climate Center); Minimum temperature (Southeast Regional Climate Center); Growing season (Southeast Regional Climate Center); Map unit ID (Florida Geographic Data Library, Geoplan, University of Florida); Soil composition (Florida Geographic Data Library, Geoplan, University of Florida); Soil texture (Florida Geographic Data Library, Geoplan, University of Florida); Soil drainage (Florida Geographic Data Library, Geoplan, University of Florida); Soil flooding (Florida Geographic Data Library, Geoplan, University of Florida); Soil hydric (Florida Geographic Data Library, Geoplan, University of Florida); Soil salinity (Florida Geographic Data Library, Geoplan, University of Florida); Minimum pH (Florida Geographic Data Library, Geoplan, University of Florida); Maximum pH (Florida Geographic Data Library, Geoplan, University of Florida)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based overlay of climate and soils spatial layers to derive site parameters; runtime SQL queries against a plant database to identify species adapted to those parameters.
Method_Validation: Expert review or stakeholder validation; Tested by agroforestry and forestry cooperative extension agents and planned evaluation by county extension agents, landowners and farmers in Florida.
Tool_Source: Florida Agroforestry Decision Support System (FADSS) : A GIS-enabled decision support tool designed to disseminate agroforestry information and aid landowners, farmers, and extension agents in planning agroforestry and selecting suitable tree/shrub/c crop species for a given site by linking climate and soils spatial data to a plant database and constructing run-time SQL queries based on site characteristics and management objectives to evaluate potential species and agroforestry systems and provide management options/results.
Output: NA
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: FADSS addressed four NbS agroforestry practices: alley cropping, silvopastoral, riparian buffers, and windbreaks/shelterbelts (forest farming excluded). The main inputs were GIS spatial layers and Florida soils from the Florida Geographic Data Library/Geoplan (MUID, texture, drainage, flooding, pH, salinity) and county climate data from the Southeast Regional Climate Center (annual precipitation, minimum temperature, growing season), plus a plant database with 500 records and more than 50 attributes from NRCS NPDC. The spatial method used a relational database linking spatial, soils, climate and plant data; run-time SQL queries were built from climate/soil parameters and management criteria using IF-THEN logic to select suitable species. Validation involved expert questionnaires and extension-agent testing; no quantitative results were reported. Outputs were SQL-driven tables listing suitable trees, shrubs and crops by system (e.g., alley cropping; silvopastoral) in Florida. Geographic scope: Florida; ecological, economic and management criteria included, with climate data informing selection and no climate-risk modelling described.
Contacts_Email: No email addresses found in the provided text.

File: Haile - 2024 - Land Suitability Evaluation for Agroforestry Using Geospatial Techniques in Genale Sub-basin Oromia,.pdf
Input_Variables: Soil Nitrogen (Oromia Rural Land Administration and Use Bureau soil laboratory data); Soil Potassium (Oromia Rural Land Administration and Use Bureau soil laboratory data); Soil Organic Carbon (Oromia Rural Land Administration and Use Bureau soil laboratory data); Soil Phosphorus (Oromia Rural Land Administration and Use Bureau soil laboratory data); Soil pH (Oromia Rural Land Administration and Use Bureau soil laboratory data); Mean annual rainfall (National Meteorological Agency of Ethiopia); Elevation (ASTER DEM); Slope (ASTER DEM); NDWI (Landsat 8/9)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based weighted overlay; RS-derived layers (NDWI/wetness) and thematic layers of elevation, slope, rainfall, and soil nutrients, with weights computed via Analytical Hierarchical Process (AHP) to produce a classified agroforestry suitability map (not suitable, less suitable, suitable, highly suitable).
Method_Validation: Field verification; Comparison with previously conducted field assessments/known NbS sites using Google Earth imagery; AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.05 < 0.1)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Agroforestry land suitability map (Highly suitable; Suitable; Less suitable; Not suitable)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Genale Sub-basin; Oromia Region; Bale Zone; Guji Zone | National: Ethiopia
Narrative: NbS practice addressed: agroforestry integrating trees with crops in Genale Sub-basin, Oromia, Ethiopia. Input variables/data sources: soil nutrient availability (N, K, organic carbon, P, pH) from Oromia soil laboratory data; mean rainfall from 15 meteorological stations (1990–2022, National Meteorological Agency); elevation and slope from a DEM; wetness via NDWI from Landsat 8/9; Landsat-based land-use/land-cover data; data from the Oromia Rural Land Administration and Use Bureau. Spatial method and combination: GIS and RS were combined with Analytic Hierarchy Process weighting; pairwise comparisons yielded weights (nutrient availability 0.345; slope 0.295; wetness 0.189; rainfall 0.105; elevation 0.065). A normalized weighted overlay produced a predictive agroforestry suitability map with four classes. Validation via field verification and Google Earth showed highly suitable 0.6% (19,072.80 ha); suitable 67.83% (2,193,368 ha); less suitable 30.8% (995,382 ha); not suitable 0.77% (24,841.60 ha) in Genale sub-basin (3,232,664 ha). Outputs at 30 m resolution; climate risk/economic considerations not included.
Contacts_Email: Email address not provided in the provided text.

File: Haris et al. - 2021 - Land suitability evaluation of crops that form agroforestry in tanralili district maros regency.pdf

Spatial_Method: Overlaying soil type, slope, geological, and land-use maps to produce land units; using a matching-system method to link soil/land characteristics with crop criteria for land capability and land suitability; and applying a simple limiting-factor approach to identify restricting factors for prioritization.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Land capability map for agroforestry placement (classes III, IV, VI, VII); Peanut land suitability map (actual: S3, N; potential: S2, S3); Sengon land suitability map (actual: S2, S3, N1; potential: S2, S3, N1)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors frame rainfall-driven erosion as a climate-related hazard and present agroforestry (peanuts with Sengon) as an NbS to reduce erosion. Narrative: NbS spatial prioritisation addressed agroforestry in Tanralili District, Maros Regency, evaluating crops that form agroforestry—peanuts and sengon. Main inputs were field surveys and soil sampling with laboratory analyses (pH, organic carbon by Walkley–Black, texture by hydrometer, CEC and bases, N, P, K, Ca, Mg, Na) plus overlays of soil types, slope, geology and land use to define 13 land units (10 sampled). File: Kiziridis et al. - 2026 - Agroforestry Optimisation for Climate Policy Mapping Silvopastoral Carbon Sequestration Trade-Offs.pdf
Input_Variables: Land cover (CLC 2018); Annual mean temperature (WorldClim 2.1); Temperature seasonality (WorldClim 2.1); Annual precipitation (WorldClim 2.1); Precipitation seasonality (WorldClim 2.1); Elevation (EU-DEM); Slope (EU-DEM); Aspect (EU-DEM); Topsoil organic carbon (TOC) (ESDB); Topsoil available water content (TAWC) (ESDB); Soil texture class (TTEXT) (ESDB); Median population age (Eurostat 2022); Population density (Eurostat 2022); Employment rate (ages 15–64) (Eurostat 2022)
Analysis_Resolution: 1 km2 (1 km x 1 km grid cells)
Spatial_Method: MaxEnt presence-only habitat suitability modelling to map silvopastoral suitability; a 20-year land-cover transition projection combined with a 4064-scenario threshold Pareto-front analysis to identify high-potential AOIs; knee-point efficiency selection to pick a best-balanced scenario; k-means clustering to define conservative/balanced/expansive regimes; and a GAM to assess how thresholds drive efficiency.
Method_Validation: Spatial block cross-validation; test AUC (0.736) with ΔAUCtrain–test = 0.044; omission rate at 10% training presence threshold (0.129); model selection via AICc; permutation importance; jackknife tests.
Tool: MaxEnt (Merow et al. 2013; Ecography) ; ENMeval (Muscarella et al. 2014; Methods Ecol. Evol.) ; inflection (https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=inflection) ; mgcv (https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=mgcv)
Tool_Source: MaxEnt: Used to model environmental suitability for silvopastoral systems across the Mediterranean using 4426 LUCAS presence points and a target-group background, producing a 0–1 continuous suitability map that serves as a key input for subsequent scenario analysis. ; ENMeval: Used to tune and evaluate candidate MaxEnt models by testing feature classes (LQ, LQH, H) and regularization multipliers (1–3) with spatial block cross-validation, selecting the best configuration via AICc. ; inflection: Used to identify the knee point on the Pareto-front efficiency curve with a curvature-based method (uik), providing the best-balanced trade-off point. ; mgcv: Used to fit a generalized additive model to quantify non-linear effects of threshold parameters and protection regime on efficiency, including testing two-way interactions and interpreting partial effects via model-based sums.
Output: Silvopastoral suitability map (continuous 0–1); Projected land‑cover allocation map after 20 years [Agroforestry, Forest, Woodland‑shrub]; Per‑pixel total carbon sequestration change map (vegetation + SOC + livestock) (annual Mg CO2 ha−1); NUTS2‑level total sequestration change map / hotspots (per‑region total/mean sequestration)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS is spatially targeted because silvopastoral expansion is pursued to maximize carbon sequestration and align with EU climate goals; the authors demonstrate this through a 4064-scenario Pareto-front analysis that maps mean and total sequestration gains and outputs regime maps and NUTS2-level summaries of sequestration potential.
Narrative: Silvopastoral agroforestry was NbS addressed in EU27 Mediterranean bioregion. Inputs were CORINE Land Cover 2018 for baseline eligibility; 14 predictors (WorldClim 2.1 BIO1, BIO4, BIO12, BIO15; EU-DEM elevation, slope, aspect; ESDB TOC, TAWC, TTEXT; Eurostat 2022 age, density, employment); 2022 LUCAS silvopastoral occurrences; 1 km in EPSG:3035; background 20,000 points. MaxEnt map produced; carbon stocks were modeled for vegetation, SOC, and livestock inputs additively, projected over 20 years with transitions to Agroforestry. Spatial prioritisation used a multi-objective framework yielding a Pareto front across 4064 scenarios, with 40 points; the highest mean sequestration was ~2.5 Mg CO2 ha−1 yr−1 and total sequestration ~107 Mg CO2 yr−1; knee point defining balance. Three regimes identified by k-means: conservative, balanced, expansive. Outputs included 1-km maps and NUTS2 aggregates of extent, patchiness CV, and sequestration; Spain and Greece hotspots. Climate predictors included; economic considerations via land-area penalties and policy regimes.

File: Marinis et al. - 2022 - The Rapid and Participatory Assessment of Land Suitability in Development Cooperation.pdf
Input_Variables: Elevation (ASTER GDEM v2); Slope (ASTER GDEM v2); Soil quality (Dorsale du Kivu Soil map)
Spatial_Method: Participatory elicitation with farmers and experts to score LUT–LCF combinations; GIS overlay of LCF maps to compute potential land suitability (averaging the three LCF scores and classifying into High/Medium/Low); accessibility analysis using cost-distance from roads with slope as the weight; final integration by overlay to derive the land suitability map.
Method_Validation: Expert/stakeholder validation of LUT–LCF scores; comparison with actual land use data/maps (remote-sensed/observed land use) to validate suitability; field verification / field visits.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Final land suitability maps for LUTs (Forestry, Manioc, Sorghum, Cattle grazing, Banana, Oil Palm, Bean) [High/Medium/Low]; Multiple-suitability map (areas suitable for multiple LUTs / multi-class); Forestry suitability vs actual land-use comparison map (match/mismatch for conservation/afforestation priorities); Agricultural and pasture suitability vs actual land-use comparison maps (crop and grazing match/mismatch for intervention prioritization)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis embeds economic framing by aiming to maximize socioeconomical returns and livelihoods, prioritizing areas where high land suitability aligns with current land use to improve efficiency of interventions (e.g., agroforestry and mixed production), but it does not provide explicit economic metrics (no ROI, NPV, cost-benefit, or economic suitability scores).
Geographic_Scope: Local: Katoyi Collectivity;Sub-national: Masisi;Sub-national: North Kivu;National: Democratic Republic of Congo
Narrative: The study addressed NbS in development cooperation through a participatory land-suitability assessment in Katoyi, Masisi, North Kivu, DRC, focusing on agroforestry and intercropping as NbS approaches; forestry was also a LUT. Input data comprised land capability factors: elevation and slope from ASTER GDEM v2 at 30 m, and soil quality from the Dorsale du Kivu soil map (1:500,000); climate proxies via elevation and an accessibility factor reflecting road logistics weighted by slope. Suitability scores (1–5) for seven LUTs—cattle grazing, banana, bean, manioc, oil palm, sorghum, forestry—were elicited from local experts/farmers and overlaid to produce Potential Land Suitability (PLS), then combined with accessibility to yield final Land Suitability (LS) via LSi = PLS × AC. Validation against land use showed forestry highly suitable over 99.6% (potential) but real suitability 64.6%; overall 67% congruent; outputs included 30 m resolution LS maps and hectares (e.g., 71,102 ha forestry). Area ~720 km2.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The data presented in this study are available on request from the corresponding author. The data are not publicly available due to credit restrictions.

File: Mendonça et al. - 2022 - Spatial indicator of priority areas for the implementation of agroforestry systems An optimization.pdf
Input_Variables: Geology (Geological Survey of Brazil); Pedology (Forestry Institute); Relief/slope (National Institute for Space Research); Land use (USGS EarthExplorer); Forest fragments (Authors production); Potential land use capacity (CDRS of São Paulo); Legal reserve (Environmental Registry System of the State of São Paulo)
Spatial_Method: Multicriteria spatial decision analysis (MDCA) with Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight environmental (geology, pedology, slope) and anthropogenic (land use/cover, forest fragments, potential land use capacity, legal reserve) factors; integration via map algebra in ArcGIS to generate the SIPA-AFS priority map under four scenarios; edge-effect buffers around forest fragments; and use of zonal statistics to analyze fragment distribution within priority classes.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency check: Consistency Index (CI) = 0.0433, below the 0.1 threshold.
Tool_Source: SIPA-AFS : A Spatial Indicator of Priority Areas for Agroforestry Systems; a spatial multicriteria decision analysis tool that integrates environmental factors (geology, pedology, slope) and anthropogenic factors (land use/land cover, forest fragments, land-use capacity, legal reserve) to produce a four-level priority map and guide landscape restoration and agroforestry deployment, enabling scenario comparison (SI, SII, SIII, SIV) and decision-making for targeting about 22,300 ha in the Mogi Guaçu Basin.
Output: Natural vulnerability map [Low / Average / High / Extreme]; Exploratory priority scenarios for AFS implementation (SI, SII, SIII, SIV) [Low / Average / High / Extreme priority]; Combined anthropogenic factors map (legal reserve + potential land‑use capacity + forest‑fragment buffers); Spatial Indicator of Priority Areas (SIPA‑AFS) — Final priority areas map [Low / Average / High / Extreme priority]
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Mogi Guaçu River Basin, São Paulo, Brazil
Narrative: The NbS addressed agroforestry systems (AFS) as an active ecological restoration strategy in agricultural landscapes, operationalized through the Spatial Indicator of Priority Areas to Agroforestry Systems (SIPA‑AFS) to reconcile environmental conservation with production in the Mogi Guaçu Basin, Brazil. Main inputs included environmental factors (geology from the Geología Map of São Paulo; pedology from the Soil Map of the State of São Paulo; relief/slope from a 30 m DEM from INPE) and anthropogenic factors (land use/land cover from Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS; forest fragments from Landsat 8; potential land use capacity from the Sustainable Rural Development Coordination raster; and legally protected areas/legal reserve from the CAR system), with data harmonized in ArcGIS and a 30 m resolution; data sources are cited in the study’s Table 1. The spatial method combined these factors in a multicriteria decision analysis (MDCA) using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) weights, aggregating into raster layers and calculating natural vulnerability Vu = 0.056G + 0.122S + 0.263Sl + 0.558AF and SIPA‑AFS = 0.056G + 0.122S + 0.263Sl + 0.558CF, via map algebra in ArcMap; four scenarios were explored (SI, SII, SIII, SIV) with landscape and sustainability approaches and buffering around forest fragments (50 m for II, 250 m for IV, 500 m for VII), producing a final 30 m resolution priority map projected in SIRGAS 2000. Validation used a consistency ratio (CI) of 0.0433 (<0.1); key result was identification of 22,300 ha of priority areas for restoration and agroforestry deployment across 9 municipalities at the river mouth. Outputs comprised a final SIPA‑AFS priority map at 30 m, plus scenario-specific maps (SI–SIV) and supporting maps of natural vulnerability, with the study area spanning roughly 2.65 million hectares in Baixo Mogi, São Paulo, Brazil. Climate risk was not explicitly included; economic considerations appeared through land use capacity and legal reserve factors integrated into the analysis.

File: Mendonça et al. - 2023 - Multicriteria spatial model to prioritize degraded areas for landscape restoration through agrofores.pdf
Input_Variables: Geology (Geological Map of the State of São Paulo, CPRM); Soil Type (Soil Map of the State of São Paulo, IF); Slope (DEM, INPE); Land Use (Landsat 8 OLI, April 2020); Forest Fragments (Landsat 8 OLI; manual vectorization); Potential Land Use Capacity (Potential Land Use Capacity Classes, São Paulo State); Protected Areas (Legal Reserves, Brazilian Rural Environmental System)
Spatial_Method: Multicriteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) via Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) in GIS (ArcMap); raster map algebra with reclassification; overlay/buffer analyses to combine environmental and anthropogenic factors into SIPA-AFS priority areas.
Method_Validation: Field verification / in loco validation of land use (in loco check); Sensitivity analysis; Expert/stakeholder validation (expert consultations with forest conservation specialists and local actors); AHP consistency check (CI < 0.1); Proximity-based validation via overlay/cross-tabulation with forest fragments.
Tool: SIPA-AFS (Spatial Indicator of Priority Areas to Agroforestry Systems) (Sci Total Environ. 2022; doi:10.1016/j.scitotenv.2022.156185)
Tool_Source: SIPA-AFS: A GIS-based multicriteria decision analysis tool that outputs a spatial priority map to guide agroforestry implementation by integrating natural vulnerability (geology, soil, slope) with anthropogenic factors (land use, forest fragments, potential land use capacity, protected areas) using Analytic Hierarchy Process weights, producing four priority levels (Low–Extreme) across four exploratory scenarios to inform restoration, resource allocation, PES policy, and territorial governance with a replicable workflow.
Output: Exploratory scenario I (ESI) priority map [Low, Medium, High, Extreme]; Exploratory scenario II (ESII) priority map [Low, Medium, High, Extreme]; Exploratory scenario III (ESIII) priority map [Low, Medium, High, Extreme]; Exploratory scenario IV (ESIV) priority map [Low, Medium, High, Extreme]; Spatial Indicator of Priority Areas for Agroforestry Systems (SIPA-AFS) final priority map [Low, Medium, High, Extreme]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: they treat climate change as intensifying erosion vulnerability and explicitly target agroforestry restoration in high‑vulnerability areas to enhance climate-related ecosystem services (water/soil conservation and carbon stock/uptake), demonstrated via a vulnerability-based scenario framework and a final SIPA‑AF priority map guiding NbS deployment.
Economics: Yes: The output analysis includes economic framing by incorporating Payments for Environmental Services (PES) and socioeconomic compensation concepts, integrating these into the SIPA‑AFS spatial indicator to guide agroforestry interventions and PES‑based policy/incentive contexts, thereby linking landscape restoration with economic livelihoods and governance considerations.
Narrative: The study addressed landscape restoration through agroforestry systems (AFS) within degraded agricultural landscapes. Main input variables and data sources included biophysical factors Geology (G), Soil type (S), and Slope (Sl) derived from the Geological Map of São Paulo (CPRM, 1:750,000), Soil Map of the State of São Paulo (IF, 1:100,000), and a 30 m DEM from INPE; anthropogenic factors—Land Use (LU) and Forest Fragments (FF) from Landsat 8 OLI (April 2020); Potential Land Use Capacity (PLUC) and Protected Areas (PA) from São Paulo’s PLUC system and Brazil’s Rural Environmental System, respectively. All data were rasterized to 30 m, reclassified, and integrated in ArcMap using a Multicriteria Decision Analysis framework with Analytic Hierarchy Process weights. The method combined environmental vulnerability V (from G, S, Sl) with four exploratory scenarios (ESI, ESII, ESIII, ESIV) by substituting LU/FF/PLUC/PA as additional factors, producing the SIPA-AFS final indicator via a Combined Factors layer and buffers around forest fragments. Validation used a pilot in the mouth of the Mogi Guaçu River Basin, Ribeirão Preto, Brazil; results showed 73% of vulnerable forest fragments located in medium–high natural vulnerability zones and 11% of fragments in high/extreme priority areas, with SIPA-AFS increasing priority areas by 9%. Outputs comprised a 30 m-resolution SIPA-AFS priority map (classified into Low, Medium, High, Extreme) plus intermediate V, ES, and CF layers; the geographic scope was the pilot area in São Paulo state, Brazil. Climate risk was not modeled as a separate layer, though erosion vulnerability and climate change were discussed, and economic considerations were included through PES relevance (LULC thresholds, landowner and governance demands).
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data will be made available on request.

File: Mushtaq et al. - 2023 - Multi-criteria land suitability assessment for mulberry-based agroforestry using AHP and GIS approac.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope (Bhuvan Cartosat-1 DEM, ISRO); Temperature (IMD; NASA POWER Data Access Viewer); LULC (Sentinel-2b imagery); Rainfall (IMD; NASA POWER Data Access Viewer); Soil texture (NBSS & LUP); Soil drainage (NBSS & LUP); Soil depth (NBSS & LUP); Soil pH (NBSS & LUP)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based multi-criteria land suitability assessment using Saaty’s Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to assign weights to criteria, followed by a raster-weighted overlay (weighted overlay/multi-criteria evaluation) to generate the suitability map.
Method_Validation: Field verification/ground-truthing via GPS-enabled field surveys and GPS-collected mulberry occurrence locations overlay on the suitability map; validation with satellite imagery and Sentinel-2b LULC mapping; comparison with current land use in the region as of 2020; AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.039); proximity-based validation by overlaying GPS field observations with the map
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Mulberry agroforestry suitability map (S1 highly suitable; S2 moderately suitable; S3 marginally suitable; S4 not suitable)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The study frames mulberry-based agroforestry as a NbS that can address climate change through adaptation and mitigation, and demonstrates this by explicitly using climate variables (temperature and precipitation) as criteria in a GIS-based multi-criteria suitability analysis and by producing climate-inclusive suitability maps that indicate where NbS deployment would most effectively address climate-related risks.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Anantnag district; Sub-national: Kashmir valley; Jammu and Kashmir; National: India
Narrative: Mulberry-based agroforestry in Anantnag district, Kashmir valley, India was addressed as the NbS. Key inputs included slope from CARTOSAT-DEM 2.5 m, climate layers (temperature and rainfall) from IMD and NASA Power with IDW interpolation, LULC from Sentinel-2b at 10 m, and soil properties (depth, texture, drainage, pH) from NBSS & LUP (2022). Data were augmented by on-site GPS surveys and expert input and processed in ArcGIS 10.4. An Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) weighted eight thematic layers—Slope, Temperature, LULC, Rainfall, Soil texture, Soil drainage, Soil depth and Soil pH—CR = 0.039; a raster-weighted overlay then produced a mulberry agroforestry suitability map classified per FAO into S1–S4 (S1 = highly suitable). Validation overlay used GPS locations. Results indicated 16.59% highly, 28.16% moderately, 40.29% marginal, and 14.96% not suitable. Outputs comprise the raster suitability map and related criterion maps; resolution aligned with 2.5 m DEM and 10 m Sentinel data. Climate variables were included; economic considerations were not explicitly modeled.
