Input_Variables: Annual mean temperature (Farzanpour et al., 2019); Total annual precipitation (Farzanpour et al., 2019); Global Aridity Index (Earth Resources Observation and Science Center/U.S. Geological Survey/U.S. Department of the Interior 1997); Global Reference Evapotranspiration (Global-ET0) (Earth Resources Observation and Science Center/U.S. Geological Survey/U.S. Department of the Interior 1997); Elevation (Didan, 2015); Slope (Didan, 2015); Aspect (Didan, 2015); Bulk Density topsoil (HWSD v1.2); pH topsoil (HWSD v1.2); Organic Carbon topsoil (HWSD v1.2); Texture topsoil (HWSD v1.2); Cation Exchange Capacity topsoil (HWSD v1.2); Bulk Density subsoil (HWSD v1.2); pH subsoil (HWSD v1.2); Organic Carbon subsoil (HWSD v1.2); Texture subsoil (HWSD v1.2); Cation Exchange Capacity subsoil (HWSD v1.2); Soil Drainage (HWSD v1.2); Available Water Capacity (HWSD v1.2); NDVI (ISCGM/Survey of India 2016); Forest Cover map (IFSR 2019); Distance from Roads (DMA 1992); Distance from Settlements (Global Map of India © ISCGM/Survey of India 2016); Distance from Drainage (DMA 1992)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis using weighted overlay to integrate climate, soil, topography, ecology and socioeconomic criteria (variables recoded to a common 1–5 scale, weights assigned by expert judgment), followed by a sensitivity analysis and ground-truth validation.
Method_Validation: Ground-truth validation via field-based GPS verification of agroforestry locations; Cross-validation using ground-based and literature-based information of existing agroforestry; Literature-based validation using published agroforestry locations; Sensitivity analysis of criterion weights.
Tool_Source: GAEZ v3.0 : Used as the soil component framework to derive five soil quality (SQ) layers from 12 HWSD/IIASA soil variables (topsoil and subsoil pH, organic carbon, texture, cation exchange capacity, bulk density, drainage, available water capacity), following the Global Agroecological Zoning methodology, and these SQ layers were then integrated via weighted overlay to create the soil suitability sub-model for agroforestry in the EIHR.
Output: Agroforestry suitability map for the Eastern Indian Himalayan Region (classes: Very good, Good, Moderate, Unsuitable/Restricted); Agroforestry suitability map for arable land in the Eastern Indian Himalayan Region (classes: Very good, Good, Moderate, Unsuitable)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: the authors frame agroforestry as a nature-based solution for climate change mitigation and adaptation and spatially target it by producing a climate-suitability map for agroforestry across the EIHR, showing substantial arable-land areas with very good to good climate suitability (indicating NbS-driven climate risk reduction and mitigation potential in their outputs).
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Eastern Indian Himalayan region;Arunachal Pradesh;Assam;Meghalaya;Nagaland;Manipur;Mizoram;Tripura;Sikkim;West Bengal;National: India;China
Narrative: Agroforestry was evaluated as a nature-based solution for landscape restoration and climate resilience in the Eastern Indian Himalayan region (EIHR). Key inputs encompassed climate (annual mean temperature, precipitation, reference evapotranspiration, aridity index) from WorldClim v2.1 (1970–2000), Global Aridity Index and Global ET0; soils from HWSD v1.2 and IIASA (pH, OC, texture, CEC, BD, AWC, drainage); topography (elevation, slope, aspect) from GTOPO30; ecology (NDVI 2019, forest cover 2019 from IFSR); and socioeconomic data (roads, settlements, drainage networks) from DMA 1992 and ISCGM 2016, at ~1 km resolution. Five criteria (climate, soil, topography, ecology, socioeconomic) with 24 sub-criteria were recoded to a 1–5 scale and combined using Weighted Overlay in GIS to form criterion sub-models, then merged into a final agroforestry suitability map; a sensitivity analysis tested weights. Validation used 65 GPS locations; 56 matched (~86%), nine in restricted zones. Outputs included a 1 km EIHR suitability map and state/arable-land distributions, with 60,523 km2 (~77%) arable land rated very good–good and 21,281 km2 (~27%) very good. EIHR spans northeastern India; climate and proximity to roads/settlements were included.

File: Palma et al. - 2007 - Integrating environmental and economic performance to assess modern silvoarable agroforestry in Euro.pdf
Input_Variables: Radiation (Yield-SAFE); Temperature (Yield-SAFE); Rainfall (Yield-SAFE); Soil depth (Yield-SAFE); Soil texture (Yield-SAFE); Climatic data (Metzger et al., 2005); Topographic data (Metzger et al., 2005)
Spatial_Method: Landscape suitability was identified by selecting 19 landscape test sites from a Europe-wide environmental classification based on climatic and topographic data; SAF alternatives were then evaluated on those sites using a multicriteria decision analysis with PROMETHEE outranking across land quality and share of land converted.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool: Yield-SAFE (Palma et al., 2007; Modelling environmental benefits of silvoarable agroforestry in Europe; doi:10.1016/j.ecoleng.2006.09.017); Farm-SAFE (Graves et al., 2005); Plot-SAFE (Burgess et al., 2004; Description of Plot-SAFE Version 0.3; Cranfield University, Silsoe, UK; Unpublished); RUSLE (Renard et al., 1997; Predicting Soil Erosion by Water: A Guide to Conservation Planning with the Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation; US Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Handbook 703); PROMETHEE (Brans & Vincke, 1985)
Tool_Source: Yield-SAFE: Predicts annual yields of trees and crops for SAF, providing input yields to Farm-SAFE’s economic analysis of SAF profitability (iNPV) under various government-support scenarios ; Farm-SAFE: Plot- and farm-scale cost–benefit economic model that uses Yield-SAFE outputs and financial data to compute profitability (infinite net present value) across six subsidy schemes ; Plot-SAFE: Not used in this study (listed as part of the SAFE suite) ; RUSLE: Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation model used to estimate soil erosion as an environmental criterion in the SAF assessment ; PROMETHEE: Outranking multicriteria decision analysis used to integrate environmental and economic criteria and rank SAF alternatives.
Output: NA
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis includes explicit economic outputs—infinite net present value (iNPV) across six CAP subsidy scenarios and Farm-SAFE profitability—integrated into the MCDA alongside environmental criteria by assigning equal weights (0.5) to economic and environmental groups, with results detailing iNPV_0, iNPV_04 and iNPV_05.x variants and how subsidies alter rankings, showing that economic performance interacts with environmental outcomes and that SAF profitability depends on land quality and tree density.
Geographic_Scope: Continental: Europe;National: Spain;National: France;National: The Netherlands;National: Switzerland;National: United Kingdom
Narrative: The NbS addressed were modern silvoarable agroforestry (SAF) in Europe. Main inputs included four environmental criteria (soil erosion modeled with RUSLE; nitrate leaching; carbon sequestration; landscape biodiversity) and an economic criterion (infinite net present value, iNPV), fed by Yield-SAFE–predicted tree–crop yields and climate/soil data (radiation, temperature, rainfall, soil depth/texture). Nineteen landscape test sites (LTS) of 4 km × 4 km were drawn from Spain, France and The Netherlands, with scenarios spanning two tree densities (50 and 113 trees ha−1), best/worst land quality, and 10% or 50% land converted. The spatial method was multicriteria decision analysis using PROMETHEE II; nine land-use alternatives were ranked by aggregating four environmental criteria (each 0.125) and iNPV (0.5). Validation used uni-criterion analyses; results showed SAF was preferable to the status quo under many subsidy schemes, particularly SAF on 50% of high-quality land in France; outputs included 114 decision matrices and country/LTS rankings at 4 km × 4 km.

File: Pinto et al. - 2019 - Spatial modelling of biodiversity conservation priorities in Portugal’s Montado ecosystem usi.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Rain-fed cereal crop rotation (fallow); Cattle extensification and regeneration of the open Montado; Improvement of the indigenous Montado forest; Rehabilitation of cork and chestnut tree stands
Input_Variables: CORINE land-cover map (CORINE Land Cover 2006); Montado habitat distribution (ICNF); Biodiversity feature data (22 species distributions) (ICNB bird atlas 2008; Silva & Pinto 2006 LIFE Natureza-Conservação das Populações Arborícolas de Águia de Bonelli em Portugal LIFE06NAT/P/000194; CEAI 2011; Cabral et al. 2008); Montado habitat density classes open Montado and dense Montado (ICNF); Economic opportunity costs by land-cover class (LCC) (Supplementary Table S3; yields and standard gross margins for each crop; local farmer interviews; literature; 2017 price levels)
Spatial_Method: MARZONE (Marxan with Zones) spatial conservation prioritization using simulated annealing to optimize the selection of 200×200 m planning units by balancing habitat/species targets against costs and boundary penalties across multiple agro-environmental and silvo-environmental measures.
Method_Validation: Robustness/sensitivity analysis using selection frequency across 100 MARZONE runs; Expert review / stakeholder validation with ICNF experts; Validation of input economic data (opportunity costs) through discussions with local farmers’ organizations.
Tool: MARZONE (Watts et al. 2009, Environmental Modelling and Software 24: 1513–1521)
Tool_Source: MARZONE: a Marxan-based land-use zoning tool that allows multiple conservation measures (zones) and their costs to be assigned to planning units and optimized to meet habitat/species targets at minimum cost via simulated annealing; in this study it integrated four measures (AEM_1, AEM_2, SEM_1, SEM_2) with their financial and opportunity costs, identified priority conservation areas inside and outside protected areas across 70,327 planning units of 200×200 m, and produced selection frequencies across 100 MARZONE runs (10 million iterations per run) to guide cost-effective spatial planning of Montado biodiversity policy.
Output: MARZONE priority map for AEM_1 (rain‑fed cereal crop rotation) [planning‑unit selection frequency; 10%, 20%, 30% targets]; MARZONE priority map for AEM_2 (cattle extensification & open Montado regeneration) [planning‑unit selection frequency; 10%, 20%, 30% targets]; MARZONE priority map for SEM_1 (improvement of indigenous Montado forest) [planning‑unit selection frequency; 10%, 20%, 30% targets]; MARZONE priority map for SEM_2 (rehabilitation of cork and chestnut tree stands) [planning‑unit selection frequency; 10%, 20%, 30% targets]; Spatial map of maximum opportunity costs for AEMs and SEMs (€/ha·yr)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: It includes economic outputs and framing in the OUTPUT by explicitly valuing opportunity costs and implementation costs; reports total economic costs (€ year−1) and financial costs (€ year−1) for each measure and target, shows cost-effectiveness/trade-offs, and discusses how economics (opportunity costs, payments to landowners) shapes prioritization and land-use outcomes.
Narrative: The NbS spatial prioritisation addressed agro-environmental measures (AEMs) and silvo-environmental measures (SEMs) within Portugal’s Montado agroforestry ecosystem, using Marxan with Zones (MARZONE) to design cost-effective conservation options. Key inputs included land-use maps (European CORINE land-cover), habitat and biodiversity data (Montado habitats; 22 species largely birds) with distributions from ICNF/ICNB bird atlas (2008) and LIFE Natura project data (Silva & Pinto 2006; CEAI 2011), supplemented by economic values for land uses (yields and standard gross margins; Fragoso & Marques 2007; 2017 price levels) and 25 × 25 m rasters aggregated to 200 × 200 m planning units (PUs) across 2860 km2 (70,327 PUs). MARZONE incorporated four measures (AEM_1, AEM_2, SEM_1, SEM_2) with costs and opportunity costs, solving a linear integer program via simulated annealing (10 million iterations, 100 repeats) and calibrating the boundary length multiplier and feature penalty. Validation used PU selection frequency; results showed SEM_2 most often selected, 74% of land protected at 30% targets, with AEM_2 about 27% and SEM_2 about 48% of selected PUs. Outputs were priority-area maps and cost estimates at 200 × 200 m resolution; the geographic scope was southeast Portugal, within Natura 2000 and national protected areas. Climate risk was not indicated as included; economic considerations (opportunity costs and payments) were central.

File: Seja et al. - 2022 - Integrated Analytical Hierarchical Process and Geographical Information System for Allocation of Com.pdf
Input_Variables: Digital elevation model (https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/); Soil map units (Msanya et al., 2001); Temperature (WorldClim) (https://www.worldclim.org/data/index.html); Rainfall (CHIRPS) (Funk et al., 2015); Soil Moisture Index (Saha et al., 2018); Land Surface Temperature (MODIS) (https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/); Soil Properties (Msanya, 2001); Elevation (Digital elevation model) (https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/); Slope (Digital elevation model) (https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based land-resource mapping using elevation-derived land mapping units; Analytical Hierarchical Process (AHP) to weight criteria from expert judgments; Weighted Overlay analysis in GIS to generate land-use suitability maps.
Method_Validation: Ground-truthing / field verification of land-use classification using GPS and Google Earth; Consistency Ratio check of AHP pairwise comparisons (CR ≤ 0.1)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Compatible land use allocation map (settlement; conservation agriculture; agroforestry; forest)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Uluguru Mountain slopes; Morogoro urban area; Tanzania
Narrative: The study addressed NbS practices by evaluating compatible land uses along the Uluguru Mountain slopes, focusing on conservation agriculture, agroforestry and forest land uses (with settlements integrated) to manage degradation and support long-term natural-resource use. Main input variables and data sources included elevation, slope, temperature, rainfall, soil properties, soil moisture index (SMI), and land-surface temperature (LST); data came from a digital elevation model (USGS earthexplorer), soil map units (Msanya et al. 2001), temperature (WorldClim), rainfall (CHIRPS via Funk et al. 2015), soil moisture/soil properties, and LST (USGS EarthExplorer) with Landsat 8 OLI imagery from 2020 at 30 m resolution. The spatial method combined GIS with Analytical Hierarchical Process (AHP): land resources were classified and mapped into five land mapping units by elevation (499–702 m, 702–882 m, 882–1094 m, 1094–1341 m, 1341–1772 m); AHP weights were derived from expert questionnaires (Saaty scale) and integrated with GIS using a weighted overlay. Validation included ground-truthing (25 points per class) and showed overall accuracy 85.6% and kappa 0.82; consistency ratios were kept under 0.1. Outputs comprised a compatible land-use map and unit-specific allocations, with areas of settlement 11.35 km2, conservation agriculture 33.32 km2, agroforestry 12.91 km2, and forest 8.72 km2 (plus 66.3 km2 listed for forest in the five-unit aggregation). The geographic scope covered the northern slope of Uluguru Mountain, Morogoro, Tanzania, spanning about 6,928 ha, with output data tied to 5 elevation-based land mapping units. Climate variables were included in the analysis, while economic considerations were incorporated via expert judgments on land-use feasibility.

File: Singh et al. - 2024 - Leveraging Remote Sensing and Nanotechnology to Overcome Barriers to Agroforestry Adoption by Small.pdf
Input_Variables: Land use (Landsat); NDVI (Multispectral data); Tree height (Drone imagery); Crown dimensions (Drone imagery); Aboveground biomass (LiDAR); Soil Organic Carbon (Satellite data); Soil Nutrient Distribution (Drone imaging); Microclimate (Satellite sensors, drone mapping); Phenology (Time-series satellite data); Moisture stress (Time-series satellite data); Pest/disease occurrences (Time-series satellite data); Temperature regimes (Time-series satellite data); Rainfall patterns (Time-series satellite data); Climate projections (Downscaled climate models); Extreme event risk zones (Remote sensing data); Farm locations (Satellite data); Transportation networks (Satellite data); Produce location (RF tracking)
Spatial_Method: Remote sensing-based land-use/land-cover mapping (satellite imagery, LiDAR, drone); GIS overlays of terrain, soil, drainage and farm boundaries for landscape-scale zoning and multi-criteria site suitability analysis to identify agroforestry priority areas.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: RUSLE : used to map soil erosion risk and potential soil loss across landscapes to inform agroforestry planning and soil conservation strategies in smallholder farm contexts; PROSAIL : used to remotely estimate rice growth parameters from multispectral imagery collected by fixed-wing UAVs, enabling crop status assessment within the agroforestry planning framework.
Output: Potential agroforestry adoption suitability map (potential sites for agroforestry adoption); Regional climate-risk / extreme-event risk zoning map (vulnerability hotspots for floods, droughts, landslides); Priority map for NbS interventions (sites for soil stabilization, drainage, shelters)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: Climate hazards are treated as risks that could threaten the suitability, persistence, and effectiveness of the NbS, and the authors demonstrate this through climate risk assessment that overlays hazard-prone zones, uses downscaled climate projections to create local risk profiles, and feeds risk-aware design and site selection (e.g., flood-prone adaptation and risk zoning).
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target NbS (agroforestry) to climate risks by generating climate risk profiles and extreme‑event risk zoning to map vulnerability hotspots and prioritize specific sites for adaptation interventions, thereby demonstrating this through risk profiling outputs and site prioritization guidance.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis includes economic framing with quantified metrics such as 45% yield increase from nanocomposite fertilizer, 30%+ nutrient-use efficiency gains, 30–50% reductions in pesticide doses, and 11–35% premium pricing for higher-quality outputs, plus discussions of establishment-cost reductions, profitability horizons, and market/finance mechanisms including payments for ecosystem services and blockchain-based payments.
Geographic_Scope: National: India; Continental: Asia; Continental: Africa; National: Myanmar; National: Vietnam; National: Germany; National: Canada; National: China
Narrative: NbS addressed: agroforestry systems that strategically combine trees/shrubs with crops as climate-smart NbS for smallholder livelihoods. Main inputs and data sources: high-resolution satellite imagery, LiDAR, aerial photography, drone imagery, multispectral/hyperspectral data and NDVI; land-use/land-cover maps; terrain, drainage and soil data; time-series Landsat/Sentinel data; downscaled climate projections. Spatial method and variable integration: GIS-based land-use mapping with multi-criteria overlays to identify optimum spatial-temporal arrangements, supported by landscape-scale zoning and siting analyses that fuse terrain and climate layers. Validation and results: the piece was a review with no new validation; it cited capabilities such as mapping intra- and inter-farm variability and climate-risk profiling enabling planning. Outputs and resolution: geospatial layers including farm-to-landscape suitability maps and micro-siting guidance, with satellite resolutions 10–60 m and drone detail. Geographic scope: global context with examples in Asia and sub-Saharan Africa; India and Myanmar cited. Climate risk and economic aspects were included; climate risk used time-series sensing.

File: Unger and Lakes - 2023 - Land Use Conflicts and Synergies on Agricultural Land in Brandenburg, Germany.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: agroforestry system; agri-photovoltaic systems; nonproductive area
Input_Variables: Area based on EU directive 92/43/EEC (State Office for Environment); Area based on EU directive 2009/147/EG (State Office for Environment); Nature reserves (State Office for Environment); Protected landscape areas (State Office for Environment); Biogas plants (Ministry of Economy, Labour, and Energy of Brandenburg); Combined heat and power plants (State Office for Environment); Digital map land value figures (BonaRes Data Center); Digital orthophotos 2018–2020 (State Survey and Basic Geodata Brandenburg); Digital orthophotos 2009–2012 (Geodata Brandenburg); Digital orthophotos 2001–2009 (Brandenburg State); Forestry map (Forestry Office); Ground-mounted photovoltaic systems (Ministry of Economy, Labour, and Energy of Brandenburg); Integrated Administration and Control System data (Environment, and Climate Protection); Legally effective development plans (State Office for Construction and Transport); Municipality boundaries (Geodata Brandenburg); Soil types (VDLUFA) (Mining, Geology, and Raw Materials); Wind turbines (State Office for Environment)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based spatial analysis in QGIS; visual interpretation of orthophotos combined with layers for ground-mounted photovoltaics, wind turbines, and biogas plants to delineate conflict areas; geometric delineation and buffering to quantify conflicts; overlay/intersection of IACS, soil, protected areas, forestry, and other land-use layers to identify synergy-potential areas using a parameter-based site-suitability approach.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Agricultural land with synergy-potential suitability map (agroforestry systems; agri‑photovoltaic systems; integrated nonproductive areas)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target NbS such as agroforestry, agro‑photovoltaic systems, and integrated nonproductive areas to advance climate adaptation and mitigation goals, treating climate protection as a driving objective in their outputs; they demonstrate this by mapping and identifying areas where these NbS can be established to reduce erosion and drought stress, enhance biodiversity, and contribute to climate protection targets.
Economics: Yes: The analysis incorporates economic considerations qualitatively—stakeholder interests include profitability from renewable energy (e.g., farmer income from agri-photovoltaics and renewable energy) and the discussion notes high investment costs for agroforestry and reliance on subsidies/payments for ecosystem services—but the OUTPUTs are spatial/area metrics (conflict and synergy areas in hectares) without explicit economic outputs (ROI, NPV, cost-benefit analyses, or economic suitability scores).
Geographic_Scope: Local: Berlin;Sub-national: Brandenburg;National: Germany;Continental: Europe;Global: World
Narrative: NbS practices addressed agroforestry (AFS), agricultural land with agri-photovoltaic systems (APS), and nonproductive areas (NPA) to generate land-use synergies on agricultural land. Main inputs included Brandenburg stats, a farmer survey (178 respondents; 118 usable), document analysis (103 articles, 7 court decisions, 32 position papers), and GIS data (orthophotos 2018–2020 at 0.2 m; IACS 2020 greening; PV, wind, biogas plants; forestry map 2021; soils; protected areas). The spatial method used a mixed-method GIS approach (QGIS) mapping conflicts and synergies: conflicts were delineated by land converted from agriculture by 2020 and planning areas; synergies identified using site criteria for AFS, APS, and NPA and mapped at parcel level. Validation triangulated multiple data sources; outputs were parcel-level GIS maps of conflicts and synergy-prone parcels for Brandenburg (29,654 km2; 132,895 ha of conflict area) at 0.2 m orthophotos. Climate protection and renewable energy economics were central to NbS focus.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: All data that support the findings of this study are included within the article and are available on request from the corresponding author.

File: Wotlolan et al. - 2021 - Land suitability evaluation for multiple crop agroforestry planning using GIS and multi-criteria dec.pdf
Input_Variables: Soil pH (SPC 2012a,b); Drainage (SPC 2012a,b); Elevation (Barker & Price 2012); Mean annual temperature (Barker & Price 2012); Mean annual rainfall (Barker & Price 2012); Land use (SPC 2012a,b)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based land-suitability analysis using MCDA with Analytic Hierarchy Process weights to convert edaphic/environmental criteria (soil pH, drainage, elevation, mean temperature and rainfall), slope filter, and land-use into binary suitability rasters, producing per-crop Land Suitability maps; and a Weighted Maximum model to optimise multi-crop distribution by weighting binary rasters and taking per-cell maximum, using either an Equitable Distribution scheme or AHP-derived benefit weights.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR < 0.1 threshold)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Land suitability maps for seven target crops (cutnut; breadfruit; lemon; sandalwood; tropical almond; Tahitian chestnut; vesi) [suitable areas]; Weighted Maximum crop allocation map (Equitable Distribution) [preferred crop allocation]; Weighted Maximum crop allocation maps by benefit (Food; Medicine; Economic; Maintenance; Other) [preferred crop per-benefit]
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic is included as a dedicated benefit type (Economic/market value); crop-specific AHP weights for the Economic benefit are provided (Breadfruit 0.129, Lemon 0.109, Sandalwood 0.284, Tropical almond 0.143, Tahitian chestnut 0.095, Vesi 0.161, Cutnut 0.078) and used in the Weighted Maximum MCDA to produce output maps and hectare allocations under the Economic benefit scenario alongside other benefits; no explicit ROI/NPV/Cost-benefit metrics are reported.
Narrative: The NbS addressed was agroforestry spatial planning in Fiji, specifically evaluating land suitability for seven target agroforestry crops in the Sigatoka Valley to guide multi-crop deployment. Main input variables and data sources included edaphic and environmental cultivation criteria drawn from the Species Profiles for Pacific Island Agroforestry library, plus GIS data on soil pH and drainage (1980/85 National soil survey, SPC), elevation (Landcare Research, NZ), mean annual temperature and rainfall (Landcare Research, 1970–2000, resampled to 25 m), and land use (SPC 1:50,000); the study area boundary encompassed the Sigatoka catchment (~224,700 ha) and used a 25 m cell resolution. The spatial method comprised two ArcGIS Pro 2.6 ModelBuilder models: Land Suitability (per crop) and Weighted Maximum (per-crop distribution). Variables were combined via binary raster reclassifications and conjunctive non-compensatory aggregation for Land Suitability, and by multiplying binary crop rasters by weights and taking per-cell maxima to resolve overlaps for Weighted Maximum; MCDA used Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight five benefit types (Food, Medicine, Economic, Maintenance, Other) based on seven experts, with additional AHP assessing Pacific-region importance. Validation used AHP-consistency ratios (CRs: 0.021–0.087) and produced crop-specific suitability maps; key results included tropical almond with 61,845 ha of suitable land and a total suitable area of 68,668 ha, with breadfruit and other crops driving Food-benefit maps, and Lemon not mapped in Food due to higher weights for Breadfruit. Main outputs were land-suitability maps for each crop and benefit-specific maps at 25 m resolution, over the Sigatoka catchment in Fiji. Climate data were included as inputs (mean annual temperature and rainfall) and economic considerations were embedded as one of the five MCDA benefit types.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: Software requirement: ArcGIS Pro version 2.6 or later; Data: A zipped folder containing Excel files for AHP calculations and ArcGIS Pro 2.6 project folder containing geodatabase with GIS data and ModelBuilder, available at https://doi.org/10.17632/txn9pj4nn4.1

File: Yadav et al. - 2024 - A Prototype Decision Support System for Tree Selection and Plantation with a Focus on Agroforestry a.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: alley cropping; forest farming; riparian buffers; silvopasture; windbreaks
Input_Variables: Tmax May (CHELSA-BIOCLIM+ Version 1.2); Tmax Jan (CHELSA-BIOCLIM+ Version 1.2); Bio1 (CHELSA-BIOCLIM+ Version 1.2); Bio12 (CHELSA-BIOCLIM+ Version 1.2); SOC (ISRIC Soil Grids); Sand (ISRIC Soil Grids); Bulk Density (ISRIC Soil Grids)
Spatial_Method: AHP-based GIS suitability analysis to map climate/soil-driven tree suitability; NMDS clustering of species based on climatic variables to inform grouping prior to mapping.
Method_Validation: NMDS-based clustering validation using NMDS stress value (0.1043) to assess reliability of the clusters.
Tool_Source: Tree PDSS: A prototype decision support system for tree selection and plantation in Punjab, India, built with R Shiny; it integrates ecological, social, and agro-commercial criteria and comprises three modules (tree selection tool, GIS-based tree suitability map using Analytic Hierarchy Process, and silviculture information) to aid evidence-based tree species choice, site suitability assessment, and management guidance for agroforestry, urban tree planning, and government programs, while promoting stakeholder involvement. ; vegan: Used to perform non-metric multidimensional scaling (NMDS) in R to visualize climate-based groupings of tree species using Tmax May, Tmax Jan, and Bio1, enabling identification of three clusters and informing the clustering/grouping of species for NMDS plots and subsequent GIS-based analyses.
Output: AHP-based tree species group suitability map [Group 1: temperate warm, clayey mixed soil; Group 2: temperate hot, sandy loam; Group 3: arid hot, sandy loam] (suitability classes: low–moderate–high)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: the NbS is spatially targeted to enhance climate resilience and carbon sequestration in Punjab, demonstrated by outputs that map climate-tolerant tree suitability and cluster species by climate to identify spatial priorities for NbS deployment.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis includes economic framing via the Index of Uses (commercial vs non-commercial agroforestry uses) embedded in the tree selection UI and outputs, linking species choices to agro-commercial uses, but it does not report monetary metrics such as ROI, NPV, or cost-benefit ratios.
Narrative: The study implemented a prototype decision support system (DSS) for tree selection and plantation focused on agroforestry and ecosystem services in Punjab, India. Main inputs included climate layers (Tmax May, TmaxJan, Bio1, Bio12) and soil variables (SOC, Sand, Bulk Density) from CHELSA-BIOCLIM+ v1.2 and ISRIC SoilGrids at 250 m, plus species/use data from Haryana Forest Flora, India Biodiversity Portal, and other regional sources. Spatially, an Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) within QGIS produced climate–soil suitability maps, using a pairwise comparison matrix (Tmax May weighted 0.44) and NMDS (vegan) clustering of Tmax May, Tmax Jan, and Bio1 into three groups, providing validation of the grouping. Outputs comprised raster suitability maps (values 3–8; with 1–2 excluded) at 250 m resolution and an online interface (Tree_PDSS) for Punjab’s 50,362 km2. Climate risk was addressed through climate variables; economic aspects were incorporated via an Index of Uses for agroforestry and urban applications.

File: d’Angelo et al. - 2000 - Mitigating land degradation in Mediterranean agro-silvo-pastoral systems a GIS-based approach.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope (DTM); Altitude (DTM); Aspect (DTM); Vegetation cover (Land cover); Rockiness (Soil); Stoniness (Soil); Soil depth (Soil); Soil texture (Soil); Structural stability (Soil); Base saturation (Soil); Water availability (Soil); Soil chemical-physical characteristics (Soil samples)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based weighted overlay model combining soil maps, a digital terrain model (slope, aspect, elevation) and pedological/vegetation variables to compute a cumulative Suitability Index and assign land-suitability classes for creating new pastures; plus an overlay analysis of 1955 and 1996 land-cover maps to identify degraded or threatened areas as priority for conservation.
Method_Validation: Comparison with traditional procedures based on pedological units; map accuracy assessment showing ~90% agreement.
Tool_Source: ARC Macro Language (AML) : used to automate classification procedures and restitution of the land suitability map.
Output: Land suitability map for creation of new pastures (S1: highly suitable; S2: moderately suitable; S3: marginally suitable; N1: currently unsuitable; N2: permanently unsuitable)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Orosei; Irgoli; Onifai; Sub-national: Sardinia; National: Italy
Narrative: The study addressed sustainable management of Mediterranean agro-silvo-pastoral systems in central eastern Sardinia by developing a GIS-based land-suitability scheme for creating new pastures. Inputs included land-cover maps (1955 and 1996) derived from aerial photos, SPOT-HRV data and CORINE; a 1:25,000 soil map and soil profiles classified by Soil Taxonomy; and a Digital Terrain Model from IGMI (1993) providing elevation, slope and aspect, plus layers for vegetation cover, rockiness, stoniness, soil depth and pedological characteristics. The spatial method computed variable-specific suitability coefficients with landscape-weighted functions, summed them into a cumulative Suitability Index SI (Cs, Cr, Cst, Cv, Ca, Csd, Cpc) and assigned classes; ARC Macro Language automated the classification. Validation against pedological-unit procedures yielded 90% accuracy for S1 and N2. Outputs included a land-suitability map for the Orosei municipality within a 20,900 ha study area. Climate risk and economic factors were not included.

File: Jawarneh et al. - 2025 - A Comprehensive Assessment of Rangeland Suitability for Grazing Using Time-Series Remote Sensing and.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: water harvesting measures; micro-water harvesting with native shrub planting
Input_Variables: Av. Soil Organic Matter (Soil sampling and laboratory analysis); Av. Soil moisture content (Soil sampling and laboratory analysis); Slope (%) (DEM-derived via ArcGIS Pro 3.4); Aspect (DEM-derived); Av. NDVI-based vegetation density (NDVI time series; Sentinel-2); Water accessibility (Euclidean distance to wadis)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) for criterion weights and Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) to fuse NDVI-based vegetation density from time-series Sentinel-2, interpolated soil moisture/organic matter via IDW, slope and aspect from a DEM, and water accessibility into a final grazing-suitability map.
Method_Validation: Field verification of the land-use map through multiple visits to the reserve; Expert review / stakeholder validation through extensive engagement with stakeholders.
Tool_Source: TerrSet : Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) module used to derive pairwise-comparison weights for MCDA; these weights were then applied in TerrSet’s Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) to generate the final grazing-suitability map.
Output: Rangeland grazing suitability map (highly suitable S1; moderately suitable S2; marginally suitable S3; not suitable N1)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: It includes economic framing via socioeconomic factors and livelihoods within the MCDA (stakeholder-driven AHP weights to generate the grazing suitability map), but there are no monetary economic outputs reported (no ROI, NPV, cost-benefit or economic suitability scores).
Narrative: An integrated grazing management framework (NbS) for Al-Khanasri Reserve prioritised rangeland grazing. Inputs included 43 soil samples (April–November 2021) for moisture, salinity, EC, TDS, pH, CaCO3, NO3, PO4, SO4, and organic matter; 250 above-ground biomass samples (April 2022); NDVI from six Sentinel-2 scenes (2016–2021) at 10 m; a 2021 land-use map; a 10 m DEM for slope and aspect; and water accessibility. The GIS-MCDA used Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) weights in TerrSet and Weighted Linear Combination to produce a grazing suitability map with S1–N1 classes. Inputs included OM, moisture, NDVI, slope, aspect, water access, with NDVI as vegetation density and soils interpolated by IDW. Validation included field verification of land use; outputs comprised factor maps and a 10 m resolution map showing 13.8% highly suitable, 24.4% moderately suitable, 39% marginal, and 22.8% not suitable across 455 ha (300 ha rangelands). Climate risk and economic considerations were excluded in the MCDA.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The original contributions presented in the study are included in the article, further inquiries can be directed to the corresponding author.

File: Moisa et al. - 2025 - Spatial land suitability modeling for livestock production for closing yield gaps in Western parts o.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope (ASTER DEM); Land surface temperature (Landsat OLI/TIRS 2022); Agro-ecological zone (ASTER DEM); Rainfall (National Metrological Agency); Land use/land cover (Landsat OLI/TIRS 2022); Proximity to streams (ASTER DEM); Proximity to roads (Ethiopian National Mapping Agency); Proximity to markets (Ethiopian National Mapping Agency)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria land suitability analysis using Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) with pairwise weights and a weighted overlay to classify suitability; rainfall spatial interpolation by IDW; proximity analyses for streams, roads and markets.
Method_Validation: LULC accuracy assessment and final result validation using Google Earth Pro; AHP consistency check (CR = 0.08, CR < 0.1 acceptable)
Tool_Source: IDRISSI Selva 17 : Used to perform the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) pairwise comparisons and compute the weights for the eight land-suitability criteria, enabling the weighted overlay and calculation of the final land-suitability index (including consistency checks for the matrix).
Output: Cattle land suitability map (highly suitable; moderately suitable; marginally suitable; not suitable); Sheep land suitability map (highly suitable; moderately suitable; marginally suitable; not suitable); Goat land suitability map (highly suitable; moderately suitable; marginally suitable; not suitable); Camel land suitability map (highly suitable; moderately suitable; marginally suitable; not suitable)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Western parts of Ethiopia; East Wollega Zone; Sibu Sire; Wayu Xuqa; Jimma Arjo; Nunu Kumba; Leqa Dulecha; Wama Hagelo; Oromia Region; Ethiopia
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was spatial land suitability modeling for livestock production aimed at closing yield gaps in the western parts of Ethiopia. The main inputs comprised eight factors—slope (DEM from ASTER via USGS EarthExplorer), land surface temperature and land use/land cover (LST and LULC from Landsat OLI/TIRS 2022 via USGS), agro-ecological zone (AEZ) from ASTER-derived data, rainfall (IDW interpolation from eight Ethiopian National Metrology Agency stations), distance to streams (ArcSWAT-generated drainage), and proximity to roads and markets (EMA data). Data were processed in ArcGIS 10.3, with LULC accuracy assessed in ERDAS Imagine 2015; weights were computed in IDRISI Selva 17; drainage networks were generated in ArcSWAT 10.3; Google Earth Pro aided final validation. The spatial method combined GIS with Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) for a multi-criteria evaluation, eight factors weighted by pairwise comparisons (Saaty 1–9) with a consistency ratio CR ≤ 0.08, at 30 m resolution; a Suitability Index SI = ∑ Wi*Xi yielded final classes of highly, moderately, marginally suitable, and not suitable. Outputs included species-specific maps and area statistics: cattle 66.1 km2 (1.6%) highly, 3504.3 km2 (86.5%) moderately, 430.2 km2 (10.6%) marginal, 48.6 km2 (1.2%) not suitable; sheep 25.8 km2 (0.6%) highly, 1449.3 km2 (35.8%) moderately, 2482.2 km2 (61.3%) marginal, 92.0 km2 (2.3%) not suitable; goat 315.3 km2 (7.8%) highly, 3115.3 km2 (76.9%) moderately, 612.3 km2 (15.1%) marginal, 6.4 km2 (0.2%) not suitable; camel 20.1 km2 (0.5%) highly, 2603.8 km2 (64.3%) moderately, 1360.3 km2 (33.6%) marginal, 65.0 km2 (1.6%) not suitable. The study covered six districts in the southwestern East Wollega zone, Oromia, Ethiopia, totaling 4049.2 km2 at 30 m resolution (8°30′–9°27′N, 36°15′–37°0′E). Climate variables (LST, rainfall) and infrastructure (roads/markets) were included; explicit climate risk modeling or economic impact analysis was not performed beyond these factors.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Available in the manuscript.

File: Mucida et al. - 2023 - Designing optimal agrosilvopastoral landscape by the potential for conservation use in Brazil.pdf
Input_Variables: Lithology (Geological map of Minas Gerais, Portal Geologia); Soil class (Soil map of Minas Gerais, UFV, 2010); Slope (SRTM elevation, NASA JPL, v3); Land use (MapBiomas Collection 5, 2019); Administrative boundaries (Minas Gerais, 2021); Watershed districts (IGAM, 2016); Municipal divisions (IBGE, 2020a)
Spatial_Method: PCU was computed in Google Earth Engine by weighting lithology, soil class, and slope (50% slope, 39% soil, 11% lithology) and combining them via map algebra and Analytic Hierarchy Process; the PCU raster was overlaid with MapBiomas 2019 land-use data to classify PCU≥3 as suitable for agrosilvopastoral or conservation use; the resulting map was intersected with administrative boundaries, watershed districts, and municipalities for spatial prioritization.
Method_Validation: Cross-evaluation with land use data (IBGE, 2019) showing good agreement between PCU and cultivated areas.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Potential for Conservation Use (PCU) map (PCU classes 1–5); Map of areas suitable for agrosilvopastoral use (PCU ≥ 3); PCU × MapBiomas land-use allocation map (suitable vs used areas; % used by PCU class); PCU aggregated map by watershed districts (mean PCU and % area PCU ≥ 3); PCU aggregated map by municipalities (mean PCU per municipality)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The outputs embed economics by (a) treating livestock and agriculture as economically significant land uses with quantified areas/percentages in outputs (e.g., livestock area and share in low PCU, Table 3); (b) discussing Payment for Environmental Services as a potential economic instrument to incentivize conservation and agrosilvopastoral expansion; (c) framing economic context in the discussion (e.g., municipalities’ GDP dependence and livelihood implications); however, no explicit monetary metrics (ROI/NPV/Cost–benefit/financial viability scores) are calculated in the results.
Narrative: NbS spatial prioritisation addressed agrosilvopastoral landscape design and conservation use in Minas Gerais, Brazil. Inputs included lithology from the Minas Gerais geological map, soil class from UFVJM (1:650,000), slope from SRTM v3 at 1 arc-second (~30 m), and 2019 MapBiomas land-use data, integrated with administrative boundaries (Minas Gerais 2021), watershed districts (IGAM 2016) and municipalities IBGE 2020a. The PCU index (1–5) combined slope 50%, soil 39%, and lithology 11% using Google Earth Engine and AHP. The PCU map was overlaid with MapBiomas to identify PCU≥3 areas for agrosilvopastoral or conservation use and aggregated by 12 divisions and 43 districts. The state average PCU was 3.5 (range 1.078–4.989); higher PCU occurred in west/northwest, lower in eastern/southern mountains; 0.44–98.02% of watershed areas met PCU≥3. Outputs include a 30 m PCU map and land-use suitability maps. Validation indicated good agreement with cultivation (IBGE 2019); climate risk and market distance were not included.

Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was agrosilvopastoral (agroforestry) land use. The main inputs comprised a 100‑layer geospatial data cube (soil classes, lithology, slope; climate from TerraClimate and WorldClim; water resources including 0–200 cm layers and HAND; morphology from SRTM; soil properties from EMBRAPA; road accessibility from IBGE), all rasterized to 30 m. Validation used field data from 70 points (44 for small‑scale, 26 for large‑scale). The spatial method employed a Random Forest (500 trees) in Google Earth Engine, trained with control points and organized into five information groups (N1–N5) that progressively added climate, water, morphology/edaphic, and accessibility layers, with Out‑of‑Bag error and variable importance assessed. Results showed small‑scale accuracy rising from 46–61% (N1–N2) to 100% at N5, and large‑scale from 48–53% (N1–N2) to 100% at N5. Outputs were 30 m resolution suitability maps for two watersheds (Rio Preto and Ribeirão Santana) in Minas Gerais, Brazil (~39.3k ha), with suitable‑area shares around 39% (N1) and 43% (N4). Climate risk was included via climate layers; economic considerations were reflected by separate small‑ vs large‑scale enterprise classifications.

File: Abram et al. - 2016 - Identifying Where REDD+ Financially Out-Competes Oil Palm in Floodplain Landscapes Using a Fine-Scal.pdf
Input_Variables: Forest above-ground carbon stock (MgC/ha) (Sabah Forestry Department data 2006/2007; field plots; OBIA carbon mapping); Oil palm above-ground carbon biomass (MgC/ha) (Morel et al., 2011); Oil palm suitability class (Full stand; Underproductive 50%; Underproductive 25%) (Abram et al., 2014); Forest type (Forest systems and forest types) (Table 1, Abram et al., 2016); Annual flooding period (Table 1) (Abram et al., 2016); Plot data (DBH, species, habitat, degradation) (Sabah Forestry Department 2006/2007; field data 2008–2011); Wood density (g/cm3) (World Agroforestry Centre Wood Density Database; Brown 1997); Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) (SPOT5/Landsat) (SPOT5 data 2007; 2009; Landsat TM 2006; 2009); Normalized Difference Moisture Index (NDMI) (SPOT5/Landsat) (SPOT5 data 2007; 2009; Landsat TM 2006; 2009); Soil Adjusted Vegetation Index (SAVI) (SPOT5/Landsat) (SPOT5 data 2007; 2009; Landsat TM 2006; 2009); Tasseled Cap transformation (Landsat TM) (Landsat TM imagery); Forest extent (generic) (Forest extent auxiliary layer) (SPOT5 imagery; Planet Action; 2010/2011); Land tenure type (Native Title; Country Land Title; State Land) (Abram et al., 2014; Abram et al., 2016); Unprotected forest extent (ha) (Abram et al., 2016)
Spatial_Method: Object-Based Image Analysis (OBIA) to classify carbon stocks from multi-temporal SPOT5/Landsat imagery using a CART classifier; ArcGIS 10.1 spatial overlay integrating carbon-stock maps with oil-palm suitability and REDD+ Net Present Value to identify priority unprotected-forest areas where REDD+ outcompetes oil palm.
Method_Validation: Classification accuracy assessment using an error matrix with overall accuracy and Kappa calculated on the second half of the plots (train–test split; 230 plots total, 115 training, 115 testing).
Tool_Source: eCognition Developer 8.7 : Used to perform stepwise Object-Based Image Analysis (OBIA) for carbon mapping by segmenting multi-source satellite imagery into meaningful “objects” (scale 15, spectral/texture features) and classifying them with a CART to assign carbon-stock classes, enabling separate eastern/western region carbon maps, manual object creation for Nipah/swamp low-carbon classes, and exporting/merging classifications into a continuous map to quantify landscape carbon stock.
Output: Predicted oil palm productivity map in unprotected forest (Full stand; Underproductive at 50%; Underproductive at ≤25%); Above‑ground forest carbon stock map (carbon classes: <50; 50–100; 100–200; 200–300; 300–400; >400 MgC/ha); Spatial allocation map of areas where REDD+ NPV > oil palm NPV (priority areas for REDD+, e.g. US $3 MgCO2e upfront payment scenario)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS (REDD+) is spatially targeted to floodplain forests to mitigate climate change by avoiding deforestation and preserving carbon stores; the authors demonstrate this by presenting spatial patterns of where REDD+ has higher net present value than oil palm under multiple carbon-price scenarios and by quantifying carbon stocks (MgC/MgCO2e) and the financing required to secure those areas.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis explicitly uses economic metrics, calculating Net Present Value (NPV) for REDD+ under multiple carbon-price scenarios (US$3, 7.8, 15, 30 MgCO2e) and two payment schemes (upfront vs staggered) over 25 years, applying discount rates (5, 8, 11, 14%), comparing REDD+ NPVs with oil-palm NPVs, reporting total REDD+ funds required and total MgC/MgCO2e secured, and spatially mapping where REDD+ outcompetes oil palm to reflect economic viability and payment-for-ecosystem-services framing.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Lower Kinabatangan floodplain; Sabah; Malaysia
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was REDD+ (payments for forest conservation) used to financially outcompete oil palm in floodplain landscapes by valuing avoided deforestation in the Lower Kinabatangan floodplain, Sabah, Malaysian Borneo. Main inputs included fine-scale forest carbon data from 230 plots (110 ha) across ten forest types, with DBH, species, habitat, and degradation recorded; carbon estimates derived from species wood density (Brown 1997; WHRC), allometric equations (Chave et al. 2005), and above-ground biomass calculations; unprotected forest area of 30,173 ha within a study region of 520,269 ha; 22 oil palm plots (0.25 ha each) across 11 age classes to define an oil palm reference carbon stock (52 MgC/ha); satellite imagery (SPOT5 10 m: 2007; 2009; Landsat TM 30 m: 2006; 2009; Planet Action SPOT5 2.5 m), OBIA in eCognition 8.7, and auxiliary forest extent layers; cadastral data on land titles. Spatial method combined OBIA-derived carbon maps with coarse economic models in ArcGIS 10.1, evaluating four carbon-price scenarios (US$3, 7.8, 15, 30 MgCO2e) under upfront vs staggered payment schemes over 25 years, to map where REDD+ NPV exceeded oil-palm NPV; validation yielded 86.9% overall accuracy (kappa 0.82) on 115 test plots. Outputs included landscape-scale carbon maps (six classes; mean 156 MgC/ha; total 4.71 Mt MgC unprotected; 50.21 Mt MgC total) and a predicted oil-palm productivity map, at a resolution tied to the forest/imagery data (unprotected forest extent 30,173 ha); geography covered the Lower Kinabatangan floodplain in Sabah, with the broader study region totaling 520,269 ha. Climate risk was not explicitly modeled; economic considerations were central, via NPV analyses and carbon-price sensitivity.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data used within the Excel sheets of the paper's Supporting Information files (S1 File and S2 File).

File: Borges et al. - 2017 - Systematic Planning and Ecosystem-Based Management as Strategies to Reconcile Mangrove Conservation.pdf
Input_Variables: Mangrove distribution (Giri et al., 2011); Protected areas (IUCN UNEP-WCMC, 2017); Site-specific climate change impacts (Godoy and Lacerda, 2015); Beach erosion (Ward et al., 2016); Port activities (Cunha, 2006; Ferreira and Lacerda, 2016a); Urbanization (Ferreira and Lacerda, 2016a); Geomorphological conditions (Souza Filho and Paradella, 2002); Hydrographic conditions (Souza Filho and Paradella, 2002); Vegetation patterns (Menezes et al., 2008); CBERS imagery (Santos et al., 2014); SPOT imagery (Santos et al., 2014); Landsat TM (Souza Filho and Paradella, 2002); RADARSAT-1 (Souza Filho and Paradella, 2002)
Spatial_Method: No explicit spatial analysis method is described; it advocates GIS-based information within a systematic conservation planning framework and notes tools such as Marxan and InVEST as potential approaches.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool: InVEST (Guerry et al., 2012) ; Marxan (Ball et al., 2009)
Tool_Source: InVEST : Not used in this study; cited as a potential modeling/decision-support tool to inform systematic planning and ecosystem-based mangrove management. ; Marxan : Not used in this study; cited as a potential decision-support tool for spatial conservation prioritization in mangrove planning.
Output: Mangrove distribution and protection-level map by macro-unit [North, Northeast, East, Southeast; protection classes: strictly protected, sustainable-use, forest-component-only, unknown]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They explicitly treat climate hazards as a risk to long-term mangrove-based NbS by noting sea‑level rise, erosion and climate-driven migration could threaten suitability and persistence, and they operationalize this in outputs by structuring planning around macro‑units defined by expected climate‑change effects and by calling for site‑specific climate impact information and monitoring to guide spatial planning.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: Climate change is treated as a driver that motivates targeting mangroves (NbS) for adaptation (coastal protection and landward migration to accommodate sea-level rise) and mitigation (carbon storage), demonstrated in their outputs by climate-aware macro-units and planning that identify landward-expansion areas and protected-area configurations to maintain NbS resilience under future climate conditions.
Economics: Yes: The output framing includes economic considerations via monetary and non-monetary valuation of mangrove ecosystem services and livelihoods, discusses economic trade-offs (e.g., shrimp-farming profits versus ecological damage) and the need for economic incentives in governance, but does not present explicit numeric economic outputs like ROI, NPV, or cost-benefit ratios in the results.
Narrative: NbS addressed: systematic planning and ecosystem-based mangrove management, treating mangroves as an integrated social–ecological system with multi-scale spatial planning and GIS synthesis to balance conservation and use. Main inputs and data sources: mangrove extent (Giri et al. 2011); protected areas (IUCN/UNEP-WCMC 2017); a four-macro-unit framework (North, Northeast, East, Southeast) informed by Knoppers (1999) and Ferreira & Lacerda (2016a,b); climate change and drivers (Godoy & Lacerda 2015; Ward 2016); geomorphology/hydrography (Souza Filho & Paradella 2002; Menezes 2008); satellite imagery (Landsat/CBERS/SPOT) and MADAM Bragança data. Spatial method and data fusion: national four-macro-unit classification based on social–ecological and climatic traits, with GIS overlays of distribution, protection, drivers and uses to inform policy. Validation: not reported. Key results: the four macro-units with distinct protection levels; North 66% sustainable-use, 15% strictly protected; Northeast ~66% unprotected; East large protected in sustainable-use areas, ~0.5% strictly protected; Southeast >20% strictly protected, ~33% inside environmental protected areas. Outputs: macro-unit map (Figure 1) and Table 1 at national scale; Bragança highlighted (6,516 km2, 4.3% of mangroves, >80% of Brazilian mangroves). Climate risk and economic considerations included via projections and shrimp/salt/fisheries uses.

File: Fagerholm et al. - 2019 - Place-based landscape services and potential of participatory spatial planning in multifunctional ru.pdf
Input_Variables: Landscape service benefits points (survey mapping data); Distance from home to landscape service benefits points (survey data); Kernel density surfaces of landscape service benefits (mapped landscape service benefits points); Nearest neighbor statistics of landscape service benefits (mapped landscape service benefits points); Moran's I analysis distances (Incremental Spatial Autocorrelation) (mapped landscape service benefits points); Satellite image map (Google Earth mosaic 2012–2014 high-resolution images); Minimum bounding convex hull of landscape service points (mapped data)
Spatial_Method: Spatial analysis identified priority areas by using GIS-based methods: nearest-neighbour analysis to detect clustering of mapped landscape-service sites; kernel-density estimation to identify hotspots via spatial intensity; Incremental Spatial Autocorrelation to determine Moran’s I at multiple distances, with study areas defined by the minimum bounding convex hull around service points.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: Incremental Spatial Autocorrelation : Used to assess how landscape service benefits are spatially autocorrelated by computing Moran’s I across increasing distance bands (300, 400 and 500 m), revealing peaks of clustering and informing interpretation of the spatial structure of mapped benefits.
Output: Kernel density hotspot map of provisioning landscape services (provisioning intensity); Kernel density hotspot map of cultural landscape services (cultural intensity); Kernel density map of fresh water sources (water-source density); Kernel density map of cultivation fields (cultivation intensity)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Iboya; Lulanzi; Tungamalenga; Southern Highlands; Tanzania
Narrative: NbS practice addressed: participatory mapping of landscape services (PGIS/PPGIS) to inform participatory spatial planning within Village Land Use Planning in three multifunctional rural landscapes in Tanzania’s Southern Highlands. Main inputs/data: semi-structured surveys (n=313) mapped 6117 provisioning and cultural landscape-service benefits; village socio-demographics (National Bureau of Statistics Tanzania); VLUP background maps and a 2012–14 Google Earth mosaic at 1:7500; and a landscape-service typology. Spatial method and combination: mapped points were analyzed in ArcGIS 10.5 and QGIS 2.18.4 using nearest-neighbour statistics, kernel-density surfaces (200 m cells; radii 300–500 m), Moran’s I, and cross-tabulations; study areas were defined by minimum bounding convex hulls. Validation and results: workshops with 97 participants and Kappa tests; provisioning sites concentrated around village centers with Iboya showing the largest extent (828–3769 ha) and cultural services displaying smaller, clustered extents. Outputs and resolution: GIS maps of provisioning, cultural and all services (200 m density) overlaid on VLUP maps at local scale for Iboya, Lulanzi and Tungamalenga. Geographic scope: Southern Highlands, Tanzania, three villages. Climate risk not included; economic aspects (income, livelihoods) were considered.

Narrative: The NbS addressed were community forest management in Nepal, focusing on sustainable, multi-use management within Shree Gyneshwar Community Forest (SGCF). Main inputs were six criteria and 44 indicators from sustainable forest management sets, with data from 12 stakeholder groups (n=71) gathered through meetings. SGCF spans 208 ha near Mangalpur VDC, Chitwan district, Nepal, with about 2300 households in a subtropical Terai context. Spatial prioritisation used a Multi-Criteria Analysis (MCA) with Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to evaluate four management strategies (MS I–IV) against six criteria (C1–C6). Weights were derived from rating, ranking, and pairwise comparisons and aggregated with the geometric mean; validation compared methods across groups. MS III was the best compromise; MS I best for policy framework (C1); MS II best for C3; MS IV best for C2/C4/C6. Outputs included group and priority scores for MS I–IV (e.g., MS III around 0.317–0.342). Climate risk was not included; C5 was considered.

File: Sahana et al. - 2022 - Assessment of suitable habitat of mangrove species for prioritizing restoration in coastal ecosystem.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: ecological mangrove restoration (EMR); community-based restoration approaches; ecological engineering; ecosystem design
Input_Variables: Elevation (Appendix 1); Slope (Appendix 1); Curvature (Appendix 1); Geomorphology (Appendix 1); TWI (Appendix 1); SPI (Appendix 1); NDVI (Appendix 2B); Level of flood inundation (Appendix 1); Mean tidal range (Appendix 1); Storm surge height (Appendix 1); NDMI (Appendix 1); Rate of erosion/accretion (Appendix 1); Water surface temperature (Appendix 1); Water salinity (Appendix 1); pH value (Appendix 1); Distance from water (Appendix 1); Drainage density (Appendix 1); NDWI (Appendix 2C); Soil texture (Appendix 2D); Soil salinity index (Appendix 2D); Soil fertility index (Appendix 2D); Sediment yield factor (Appendix 2D); Electronic conductivity (Appendix 2D); Vegetation soil salinity index (VSSI) (Appendix 2D); BIO1 (WorldClim); BIO2 (WorldClim); BIO3 (WorldClim); BIO4 (WorldClim); BIO12 (WorldClim); BIO15 (WorldClim); Distance from road (Appendix 2F); Road density (Appendix 2F); Distance from Settlement (Appendix 2F); Population density (Appendix 2F); Distance from crop field (Appendix 2F); Embankment density (Appendix 2F)
Spatial_Method: Ensemble habitat suitability modeling using ten machine-learning models in biomod2 to produce species-specific suitability maps; niche overlap analysis (Modified Hellinger I and Schoener’s D) using raster overlay in ArcGIS; grid-based restoration prioritization across 1 km grids using PCA-derived ranking and multi-criteria indicator scoring (positive/negative) to identify priority grids.
Method_Validation: 80/20 train–test split for model validation (and 75/25 intrinsic validation within models); intrinsic validation metrics (Cohen’s Kappa, TSS, ROC); extrinsic validation with Boyce Index on held‑out data (20%) to select models for the ensemble; field verification/ground-truthing of degraded areas and GPS-verified occurrence data; niche overlap analysis with PCA-based validation of species niches; independent validation dataset via BI; validation of input layers with Landsat-based LULC accuracy (confusion matrix and kappa for 1975 and 2020).
Tool_Source: biomod2 (CRAN) : Used to run an ensemble of 10 species distribution models for 18 mangrove species, generating final habitat suitability maps via a weighted-mean ensemble and evaluating models with Kappa, TSS, ROC and Boyce index before selecting the ensemble for restoration-prioritization mapping; MAXENT (Phillips et al., 2006 Ecography) : One of the ten machine-learning algorithms included in the biomod2 ensemble used to model habitat suitability/distribution of mangrove species from occurrence data and environmental predictors.
Output: Ensemble habitat suitability map for 18 mangrove species (classes: highly suitable; moderately suitable; slightly suitable; not suitable); Grid-based restoration priority map for Sundarban Biosphere Reserve (1‑km grids; 1,203 prioritized grids; 8 priority categories); Species niche‑overlap (grid‑based spatial similarity/dissimilarity)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: they frame climate-change–driven coastal hazards as a key risk that could undermine mangrove persistence and NbS restoration success, and demonstrate this by identifying climate hazards as major degradation drivers in their results and discussion and by incorporating hazard considerations into their degradation and restoration-prioritization outputs.
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: Nature-based solution targeted mangrove restoration in the Sundarbans Biosphere Reserve, India, by assessing habitat suitability for 18 mangrove species with an ensemble of 10 ML models in biomod2. The inputs encompassed 36 variables spanning topography, bioclimatic layers, environmental/water metrics, soil attributes and disturbance indicators, derived from Landsat land-cover maps (1975 MSS, 2020 OLI) and 1 km grid coverage over 5609 cells; occurrence data from GBIF, literature and 950 field samples (1560 after rarefaction) plus Landsat land-cover data. Ten models were validated with an 80/20 split; ensemble via weighted mean; models with >0.75 performance used; Boyce index confirmed ensemble (avg ROC/TSS/KAPPA ≈0.90). Outputs are four-class habitat maps at 1 km, with 36.6% highly suitable and 1203 restoration-priority grids in eight categories across SBR. Climate risk and economic factors were included via bioclimatic and disturbance variables.

Output: Suitability map for Constructed Wetlands (classes: most favorable, favorable, moderately favorable, less favorable, least favorable)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic considerations are embedded in OUTPUT via explicit cost- and efficiency-related site-selection criteria (prefer sites near settlements to reduce pumping costs, avoid embankments for lower pumping/operational costs, and avoid floodplains to maintain performance), and by framing cost-effectiveness as a guiding objective through AHP weights that emphasize land use and floodplains, with conclusions noting the results can inform economic aspects and priority siting for CWs.
Narrative: The NbS addressed were constructed wetlands for wastewater treatment in small settlements in Vojvodina. Key inputs included six criteria—distance from populated places, distance from recipient, land use (CORINE Land Cover), elevation relative to settlements, presence of embankments, and floodplains—derived from vector data (population, land cover, embankments, waterways) and SRTM 30 m elevation, with land use coded per CORINE (agricultural areas, forests, wetlands, water bodies); data were processed in QGIS 3.16.3. The spatial method combined GIS with Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP); six experts provided pairwise weights (Saaty scale), consistency checked (CR ≤ 0.20), and weights were aggregated by weighted geometric mean. Outputs were a five-class suitability map for CWs, with first class 1421 km2 (44%), second 1191 km2 (37%), third ~82 km2 (16%), and fourth–fifth ~82.35 km2 (3%), across 21,506 km2; Gložan CW aligned with favorable region. Climate risk was not included; economic considerations were embedded via proximity and gravity-discharge costs.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data available on request from the corresponding author.
Contacts_Email: pavel.benka@polj.uns.ac.rs; bosko.blagojevic@polj.edu.rs; nikola.santrac@polj.uns.ac.rs; andrea.salvai@polj.uns.ac.rs; milica.stajic@polj.uns.ac.rs; zemunac.rados@polj.uns.ac.rs; jovana.bezdan@polj.edu.rs; sanja.antic@polj.uns.ac.rs

File: Croeser et al. - 2021 - Choosing the right nature-based solutions to meet diverse urban challenges.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: rooftop pollinator habitats; constructed wetlands; hydroponic green facades; green roofs; restoration of urban streams; Floodable Parks; Cycle and Pedestrian Green Route; urban orchards; parklets
Input_Variables: NA
Spatial_Method: Baseline spatial analysis of key issues and strategic documents to nominate priority ecosystem services and identify suitable priority areas for NBS implementation.
Method_Validation: Sensitivity analysis; Expert review or stakeholder validation (interviews with city representatives)
Tool: Urban GreenUP NBS Selection tool (Croeser et al., 2021; doi:10.1016/j.ufug.2021.127337)
Tool_Source: Urban GreenUP NBS Selection tool : A multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) decision‑support tool used to select a palette of NBS for Renaturing Urban Plans across seven cities by evaluating 42 predefined NBS from the Urban GreenUP NBS Catalogue against two criteria—ecosystem-service benefits (benefit) and implementation capacity (difficulty) via expert elicitation, weighting up to four priority ecosystem services, aggregating scores into an overall ranking (O(NBSi) = sum Bk(NBSi) × w(Ck)), presenting top options per city area, and conducting sensitivity analysis and user feedback to inform co‑production and deployment.
Output: NA
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly frame climate adaptation/mitigation (reducing flood risk and urban heat island effects) as a rationale for NbS targeting, and demonstrate it by prioritising NbS against climate-relevant ecosystem services and presenting city-level MCDA rankings that foreground options best addressing these hazards.
Narrative: An MCDA was used to select NbS for urban challenges. NbS types came from Urban GreenUP’s 42‑NbS catalogue (green roofs, urban orchards, parklets, restoration of urban streams) to inform Renaturing Urban Plans in Liverpool, Medellín, Mantova, Quy Nhon, Valladolid, Izmir and Ludwigsburg. Inputs included baseline spatial analysis of priority ecosystem services (air quality, flood risk, heat island, urban renewal, open space, biodiversity, health and wellbeing) and two expert-elicited scores per NbS: Benefit and Difficulty. The tool aggregated scores by a weighted sum across two criteria: Benefits and Institutional Capability, with up to four priority services weighted (default 50/25/15/10). NbS were ranked; arboreal options often topped results, with top 15 published on a results page; scores were on a 0–100 scale. Validation used a sensitivity analysis (11 input manipulations; ρ) indicating robustness; outputs included NbS palette for each city area. Costs were excluded; climate considerations were captured through the ecosystem-services criteria.

File: Demesouka et al. - 2013 - Spatial UTA (S-UTA) – A new approach for raster-based GIS multicriteria suitability analysis and its.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope grid (Not specified); Distances from faults (Not specified); Lithology (Greek Institute of Geology and Mineral Exploration); Aquifers vulnerability (digitized maps provided by the Greek Institute of Geology and Mineral Exploration); Natura 2000 network areas (Natura 2000 network areas); Lakes and wetlands (Not specified); Distances from rivers (Hydrography dataset); Distances from streams (Hydrography dataset); Distances from coastline (Coastline dataset); Distances from settlements (Residential areas) (Not specified); Land-use type (Corine Land Cover Program, EEA 2012); Temperature (Mean minimum air temperature) (Gemitzi et al., 2007); Altitude/Elevation (Not specified); Distance from national and primary road network (Road network dataset); Distance from railway network (Railway network dataset); Distances from secondary road network (Secondary road network dataset)
Spatial_Method: Raster-based GIS multicriteria suitability analysis implemented as Spatial UTA (S-UTA): apply constraint/exclusion analysis to screen feasible sites; standardize criterion maps with marginal value functions; form a reference set of candidate locations and obtain an initial ranking; estimate criterion weights by solving the UTAII linear program; compute a continuous suitability index by the additive weighted sum of standardized maps.
Method_Validation: Sensitivity analysis; Post-optimality stability/consistency analysis (F indicator and Kendall’s s); Comparison with SAHP, SFAHP and equal-weights methods.
Tool: S-UTA add-in (ArcGIS v.9.2) (Demesouka et al., 2013; DOI:10.1016/j.jenvman.2013.03.035); SOLVER add-in (MS Excel) (Microsoft)
Tool_Source: S-UTA add-in (ArcGIS v.9.2) : A GIS extension that integrates the UTAII multicriteria decision framework with raster GIS to perform constraint analysis, construct marginal value functions, elicit decision-maker preferences, form the reference AR, and generate raster-based suitability indices and rankings for NSWT siting ; SOLVER add-in (MS Excel) : The optimization engine used to solve the linear programming problem in UTAII (weight estimation/under-overestimation) to derive criterion weights and produce the final suitability scores and AR rankings.
Output: S-UTA site suitability index map (centesimal classes); Spatial AHP suitability map (exact/eigenvector); Spatial AHP suitability map (approximate/row-sum); Spatial fuzzy AHP suitability map; Equal‑weights suitability map
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic considerations are incorporated in the OUTPUT analysis as part of the socioeconomic criteria that DM preferences weight via the UTAII framework, including cost considerations and transport-related costs (e.g., minimizing effluent transportation costs, high capital costs, and costs associated with distance from roads/receivers), which shape the final suitability rankings; however, there are no explicit economic metrics such as ROI, NPV, or cost-benefit values reported in the output—the economic influence is embedded in criterion maps and weights.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Rodopi; Evros; Xanthi; National: Greece; Multi-country: Bulgaria; Turkey
Narrative: Demesouka et al. applied Spatial UTA (S-UTA), a raster GIS multicriteria method, to identify NSWT sites such as stabilization ponds and constructed wetlands in Rodopi and Evros, Greece. The study used 12 criteria spanning land availability, environmental protection, socioeconomic and design factors, with lithology, land cover (Corine Land Cover, 2012), population (2001 census), Natura 2000, rivers, coastlines, faults, transport networks, aquifers, temperature variable. S-UTA proceeded by constraint analysis to produce a 6785 km2 area at 40 m resolution, defined AR of 24 candidate sites, and estimated criterion weights via a UTAII program to yield a continuous suitability index as a weighted sum of standardized maps. Validation compared S-UTA with SAHP, SFAHP and equal weights; Kendall’s s indicated consistency, and outputs included a raster suitability index map and AR rankings for Evros Rodopi. Climate risk and economic considerations were included via temperature and proximity to residential areas and transport networks.

File: Escalante et al. - 2014 - Economic Assessment of Opportunities for Managed Aquifer Recharge Techniques in Spain Using an Advan.pdf
Input_Variables: Geology of Spain, scale 1:200 000 (MMA, 2006); Control of nitrates in the groundwater network (Not specified); Vulnerable areas to nitrates (Not specified); Irrigated areas and source of water (Not specified); Concentric polygons around rivers and reservoirs (Not specified); Risk of flooding (Not specified); Tilt cartography (Not specified); Tagus-Segura aqueducts (Not specified); Quality of water: conductivity (Not specified); Mines into aquifers (MMA, 2006); Groundwater piezometric monitoring network (Not specified); Forest mapping for Spain, scale 1:50 000 (Not specified); Hydrogeological units (Not specified); Sewage treatment plants (Not specified); Detailed urban areas (Not specified); Marine intrusion control network (Not specified); Altitude (Not specified); Dry wetlands (Not specified); Watersheds with water surplus (Not specified); Distance from shore (Not specified); Dune systems (Not specified); Administrative boundaries (Not specified); Current MAR sites (Not specified)
Spatial_Method: An advanced GIS methodology based on a linear combination of map-layer attributes; a grades/weights system that scores and ranks 24 MAR devices across physiographic layers using training data from existing MAR sites.
Method_Validation: Training data from existing MAR sites overlay used to derive weights for features; comparison with two simpler methods.
Tool_Source: HydroGeoportal DINA-MAR: A map viewer that displays the MAR zoning and device-suitability results produced by the DINA-MAR GIS study, including the Favorable Device map and iso-cost overlays to aid decision-makers in Spain. ; DINA-MAP: The GIS analysis tool used within the DINA-MAR workflow to identify MAR zones across Spain by integrating up to 83 layers and 24 MAR devices, scoring and ranking devices per zone with a weights-based system.
Output: Map of MAR zones (areas suitable for Managed Aquifer Recharge); Favorable-device allocation map (most appropriate MAR device per MAR zone); Iso-costs choropleth map of total expected MAR costs (€/m3) [€0.08, €0.10, €0.20, €0.23, €0.58/m3]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They treat flood risk as a climate-related hazard that could limit MAR viability and explicitly incorporate it as a hazard overlay in their spatial scoring framework. This yields output maps (favorable MAR devices and MAR zones) that vary with risk levels, illustrating how climate hazards threaten NbS outcomes.
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT includes explicit economic analyses embedded in the GIS prioritisation, featuring investment ratios and costs (€/m3) for MAR devices, an iso-cost map of total expected costs (0.08–0.58 €/m3), an economic index (euros per m3 per year), and documented net savings versus dams (about 75% for superficial facilities, 50% for medium-deep wells, and 27% for deep boreholes), with these economic indicators integrated as weights in the MAR zone/device ranking, i.e., economic viability acts as a selection criterion.
Narrative: MAR (Managed Aquifer Recharge) was the NbS prioritisation focus addressing 24 MAR devices across the Iberian Peninsula and Balearic Islands. The inputs were 23 GIS layers of physiographic features (geology 1:200,000 MMA 2006; nitrates control; irrigated areas; watersheds; distance to coast; MAR sites), plus data on water origins (surface, groundwater, irrigation returns, treated/desalinated water) and economic data from Tragsa projects. The spatial approach used a GIS methodology based on a linear combination of map layers attributes, implemented as a grades/weights system (0–3) with an association matrix to score 24 devices per 1 km2 cell, trained against existing MAR sites; results produced MAR zones and a Favorable Device map in the HydroGeoportal DINA-MAR, and iso-cost overlay (€0.08–€0.58/m3). At 1 km resolution, about 16% of the area (≈67,000 km2) was suitable for MAR, implying aquifer storage >2.5 times dam storage; validation used two simpler methods; climate risk was not included; economic analysis.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: DINA-MAR website (http://www.dina-mar.es/); HydroGeoportal Visor cartográfico (http://sig3.tragsatec.es/visor_dina-mar/)

File: Rahman et al. - 2012 - A new spatial multi-criteria decision support tool for site selection for implementation of managed.pdf
Input_Variables: Land use (Table 1); Slope (topography) (Table 1); Infiltration rate (soil) (Table 1); Sub-surface impermeable layer thickness (Table 1); Groundwater depth (Table 1); Distance to groundwater pollution source (Table 1); Aquifer thickness (Table 1); Groundwater quality (chloride and nitrate) (Table 1); Residence time (Table 1); Distance to water source (Arade Dam) (Section 5.7)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based spatial multi-criteria decision analysis (SMCDA); constraint mapping to screen infeasible areas; AHP-based weighting of criteria and sub-criteria; standardization of maps; overlay with Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) or Ordered Weighted Averaging (OWA) to derive the suitability/priority map.
