Tool: Gabardine DSS (Rusteberg et al., 2008); Site Suitability Analysis Tool extension (Rahman et al., 2012, doi:10.1016/j.jenvman.2012.01.003); SMCDA tool (Rahman et al., 2012, doi:10.1016/j.jenvman.2012.01.003)
Tool_Source: Gabardine DSS: A GIS-based decision support system for artificial recharge (MAR) planning and management, within which the new SMCDA tool has been implemented as an innovative MAR planning tool. ; Site Suitability Analysis Tool extension: An ArcMap extension (ArcObjects/VB.Net) that embeds MCDA in GIS to support MAR site suitability analysis, offering constraint mapping, criteria hierarchy, standardization and weighting, and overlay (WLC/OWA) with default criteria and the option to add new criteria, stored in a geodatabase. ; SMCDA tool: A new GIS-integrated spatial multi-criteria decision analysis tool that combines AHP with WLC and OWA to guide MAR site selection through constraint mapping, criteria hierarchy, standardization/weighting, and overlay, includes built-in default criteria and sensitivity analysis, is non-site-specific/adaptive, and can be augmented with groundwater flow/transport modeling; implemented within Gabardine.

Climate_Benefit: Yes: The study targets MAR sites as an adaptation to drought and climate variability to reduce climate-driven water scarcity by storing water in wet years for use in dry years, and the authors demonstrate this with constraint and suitability mapping and a drought-focused case study identifying where MAR would be feasible to mitigate impacts.
Narrative: NbS addressed: MAR site selection as a solution for water resources. Main inputs: constraint and suitability criteria—land use, slope, infiltration rate, groundwater depth, distance to pollution sources, aquifer thickness, groundwater quality (chloride/nitrate), and residence time—derived from geology/geomorphology maps, soil data, aquifer transmissivity/storage, and proximity to water sources in Algarve, Portugal (Querença–Silves aquifer, 318 km2; catchment 114 km2). Spatial method and combination: a Spatial MCDA integrating AHP for criterion hierarchy with Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) or Ordered Weighted Averaging (OWA) overlays; criteria standardized to 0–1 and constraint maps produced by conjunctive screening. Validation and results: Algarve study showing robustness; outputs included constraint and raster suitability maps; 11.2% of area feasible; very good 1%, good 3.2%, moderate 6.4%, poor 0.6%. Outputs: raster maps and constraint masks for Algarve with zones I–IV. Climate risk/economics: drought context motivated MAR but explicit climate/economic inputs were not included, though future socio-economic criteria were discussed.

Input_Variables: Digital elevation model (Topographic data 1:100,000); Economic criteria buffer map (WWTP/road network buffers; derived from transport costs and elevation constraints); Water supply sources buffer map (Buffers around reservoirs, streams and potable wells); Population buffer map (Buffer around population agglomerations and isolated dwellings); Ecological reserve map (SPA of Cró protected area); Land use map (Corine Land Cover map; Portuguese Geographical Institute, 2009); Slope map (Derived from digital elevation model); Soil texture map (Soil texture data from official soil maps); Type of soil map (Soil type map; anthrosol, regosol, umbrisol, rocky soils); Road buffer map (Road network buffer)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria analysis; overlay of ten thematic maps (economic, environmental, technical) using Boolean map algebra (Raster Calculator) to produce a final suitability map for reclaimed water infiltration basins.

Tool_Source: Raster Calculator (ESRI) : used to perform Boolean/algebraic operations to overlay the ten thematic raster maps and generate the final suitability map for reclaimed-water infiltration.
Output: Final suitability map for reclaimed water infiltration (suitable / unsuitable)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic considerations are integrated into the OUTPUT through an economic criteria map (water transfer costs from the WWTP to infiltration sites and pumping costs) with thresholds (transport distance ≤8 km and elevation ≤15 m) to define an economic restriction area (7805 ha); this economic layer is overlaid with environmental/technical criteria to produce the final suitability map for reclaimed-water infiltration, yielding 1607 ha suitable, and the study notes agronomic use of reclaimed water is not profitable in this area, reflecting profitability framing.

Narrative: An NbS approach targeted aquifer recharge with reclaimed water from a wetland (HSSF-CW) in Beira Interior, Portugal. Ten GIS layers (elevation, land use, soils, slope, and buffers for economic, water sources and population, ecological reserve) plus base data from Military Maps 192–226 (1:25,000), SPA Cró, Corine Land Cover, and 21‑month Vila Fernando CW monitoring (BOD5, COD, TN, NH4-N, NO3-N, TP, TSS, EC, Na, Ca, Mg, Cl; pathogens; SAR) were used. The GIS method was multi‑criteria analysis using the algebra of maps (Boolean overlay of ten layers in ArcGIS 9.1) to yield a 10 m cell resolution suitability map. The study area covered 13,944 ha; 1,607 ha (12%) were suitable. Validation showed 21,500 m3 y−1 reclaim water and infiltration capacity ~133,000 m3 y−1; outputs were the suitability map and 1,607 ha, with four basins (~320 m2). File: Uuemaa et al. - 2018 - Identifying Feasible Locations for Wetland Creation or Restoration in Catchments by Suitability Mode.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope (LiDAR DEM; Environment Southland); Topographic Wetness Index (TWI) (DEM; SAGA GIS); Distance to streams (LiDAR-derived stream network; Jenson & Domingue; Strahler); Distance to roads (Orthophotos 30 cm; LINZ Southland & Central Otago Rural Aerial Photos; NZ Parcels)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation (MCE) with linear-weighted summation of standardized slope, topographic wetness index (TWI), distance to streams, and distance to infrastructure; LiDAR-derived terrain analysis (D8 flow direction/accumulation, Strahler stream order) to delineate streams and contributing areas for suitability mapping.
Method_Validation: Comparison with existing wetlands/known locations; Historical validation using Google Earth imagery showing past wetlands at site W5.
Tool: SAGA GIS (Conrad et al., System for Automated Geoscientific Analyses (SAGA) v. 2.1.4. Geosci. Model Dev. 2015, 8, 1991–2007; doi:10.5194/gmd-8-1991-2015)
Tool_Source: SAGA GIS : Used to calculate the topographic wetness index (TWI) from the LiDAR-derived DEM, with TWI values then deciled and converted to a 0–1 suitability input for the MCE-based wetland suitability map.
Output: Final wetland suitability map (suitability classes: >0.75 high, <0.5 unsuitable); Potential flow‑interception locations map (64 candidate in‑stream points); Delineated potential wetland polygons (6 modelled sites, flooded extents at 1 m impoundment, with area, average depth, water storage capacity)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Waituna Lagoon Catchment; Sub-national: South Island; National: New Zealand
Narrative: NbS addressed wetland creation or restoration to reduce diffuse nutrient pollution in Waituna catchment, NZ. The approach targeted in-stream wetlands. Inputs were a 1 m LiDAR DEM (Environment Southland) with sinks filled, orthophotos for infrastructure, and cadastral parcels; hydrology was derived from a D8 flow model and flow accumulation to delineate streams with drainage areas ≥5 ha in catchments ≥50 ha. Four criteria—slope (≤3°), topographic wetness index (TWI), distance to streams, and distance to roads—were standardised to 0–1 by quantiles and combined with equal weights in a GIS-MCE. Potential wetlands were delineated at flow-interception points and flooded area estimated with a 1 m impoundment. Outputs included a 1 m resolution suitability map, 14% highly suitable area (≈220 ha), 64 interception points, and six candidate wetlands (W1–W6) occupying 26.9 ha (1.7% of the 1,584.5 ha contributing area) with storage ≈203.9×10^3 m^3. Climate risk and economic costs were not included; validation advised.

File: Wang et al. - 2025 - Strategic deployment of nature-based solutions for urban flood management in high-density urban land.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Underground infiltration trenches/ponds; sand filter; Pervious paved surface; Bioretention cells; Tree box filter; Bioswales; Rain gardens; Green space; Retention ponds; Constructed wetlands
Input_Variables: NDVI (MOD13Q1v061 from NASA LPDAAC); BCD (AMAP); DEM (Resource and Environment Science and Data Center, China); Slope (Geographic remote sensing ecological network platform); RND (OpenStreetMap); ISP (Peng Cheng Laboratory); RD (Resource and Environment Science and Data Center, China); Heritage and Cultural Relics (Shenzhen Municipal People’s Government); Educational Facilities (AMAP); Vibrant community (AMAP); Transportation Facilities (AMAP); GDP (Resource and Environment Science and Data Center, China); Population (WorldPop); Civil Defense and Rescue Services (AMAP); Emergency Shelters (AMAP); Medical Services and Hospital (AMAP)
Spatial_Method: Spatial Multi-Criteria Evaluation (SMCE); Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP); Entropy Weighting (EW); game-theory-based combinatorial weighting to derive integrated scores and identify priority areas for NbS deployment.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency check (consistency of matrices)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Priority map for NBS implementation in Shenzhen (priority ranking −0.1 to 1.4); Scheme-specific suitability maps for “Area A” (Schemes I–IV; extents: I 8.40 km2; II 28.46 km2; III 16.19 km2; IV 16.38 km2)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS are targeted to reduce climate-related flood risks by focusing on high-risk urban sub-areas; the authors demonstrate this with exposure–vulnerability–adaptability risk maps and a priority map identifying where NbS should be implemented (Area A).
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis incorporates economic framing by using equivalent economic values (gains and losses) to evaluate NBS options and set priorities, integrating these with scheme feasibility and risk via AHP, EW and game-theory weightings to produce priority maps that guide resource allocation and highlight economic productivity co-benefits.
Narrative: NbS were applied to urban flood management in Shenzhen, Guangdong, China. The approach used satellite and GIS inputs: NDVI (MOD13Q1, NASA), DEM (RESDC), slope, road-network density (RND, OpenStreetMap), impervious surface percentage (ISP, Peng Cheng Laboratory), river-network density (RD, RESDC), and Building Congestion Degree (BCD, AMAP), plus vulnerability/adaptability indicators: heritage and cultural relics (Shenzhen government), educational facilities, vibrant communities, transportation facilities (AMAP/Gaode), GDP (RESDC), population density (WorldPop), and emergency shelters/hospitals. SMCE combined AHP and EW with game-theory weighting to derive weights and produce exposure, vulnerability, and adaptability maps; the risk score summed exposure and vulnerability and subtracted adaptability, yielding a prioritization map (−0.1 to 1.4). Outputs included a prioritization map and four NBS schemes (I–IV) over 8.40–28.46 km2, focused on Area A; resolutions: 30 m NDVI, 1 km RD/DEM, 10 m ISP. Validation used AHP consistency checks; key results: RD 26.6%, ISP 26.5% for exposure, and heritage 31.2%, shelters 58.0% for vulnerability/adaptability. GDP included; climate risk not explicitly modeled.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Supplementary data at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecolind.2025.113681; Data will be made available on request.

File: 2026 - (PDF) Spatial prioritisation for nature recovery with multiple options for habitat creation.pdf
Input_Variables: Ei (BNVC thresholds; Rodwell 2006); S (Supporting Information S1; correlative species distribution models using ad hoc records and habitat/microclimate predictors; downscaled to 100×100 m); Sij (Supporting Information S1; species–habitat matrix); Sj (Supporting Information S1; species distribution layers); Ciuv (Natural England 2024; Provisional Agricultural Land Classification); T (Supporting Information S1; Available tiles); U (Supporting Information S1; Unavailable tiles); X (Ebrel model; The Lizard case study); E (The Lizard case study; existing habitat layers; 10 habitat types); dj (Species-specific maximum dispersal distance; trait data)
Spatial_Method: Ebrel is a grid-based spatial prioritisation model that identifies suitable habitat creation areas by optimizing an objective H(X) across: F1 (cost function), F2 (spatial function), and G (biodiversity function incorporating dispersal via clustering); solved by simulated annealing.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: Ebrel : a spatial prioritisation model for nature recovery allowing multiple habitat options per land parcel; it evaluates, for a given action, the relative cost (F1), spatial cohesion/fragmentation (F2), and biodiversity gain (G) toward specified targets, then uses a simulated annealing optimization to minimize the objective H(X) = αF1(X) + βF2(X) + γg(X) across a grid of tiles, using inputs such as habitat opportunity layers E, existing habitat layers, species distribution layers, the species–habitat matrix S, cost layers C, and available/unavailable tile layers, while ensuring at most one habitat per tile and incorporating dispersal; demonstrated in The Lizard case study and implemented in Python with code available on Zenodo.
Output: Nature recovery allocation map for habitat creation (habitat types: acid grassland; broadleaved woodland; fen/marsh/swamp; heathland; neutral grassland; scrub; intertidal; coastal sand dunes; wet grassland; wet woodland)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis incorporates economic considerations via a cost function F1 (cost of habitat creation, Ciuv, tied to land value) and an objective H(X)=αF1(X)+βF2(X)+γg(X) that minimizes costs alongside spatial cohesion F2 and biodiversity G, producing outputs X with associated F1, F2, and H(X) (and F(X)=F1+F2) to illustrate trade-offs between cost, spatial cohesion, and biodiversity targets.
Geographic_Scope: Local: The Lizard; Sub-national: Cornwall; Isles of Scilly; England; National: United Kingdom
Narrative: Habitat creation for nature recovery (NbS) was addressed, in landscapes where multiple habitat types could be created within a land parcel, demonstrated on The Lizard, UK. Inputs included habitat layers E, species distributions, a species–habitat matrix S (nh×ns), cost layers C, and tiles T/U; action X is a binary array per habitat. In the case study, 34 species and 10 habitats were modelled, with distributions at 100×100 m from downscaled 1 km SDMs, and costs from Natural England (Provisional Agricultural Land Classification, 2024). Ebrel combines F1 (cost), F2 (aggregation with existing habitat E), and G (targets) into H, a weighted sum minimised by simulated annealing; G includes dispersal dj and clustering. Validation showed H(X) decreasing as targets were met, with outputs across iterations up to 200k; up to 10 habitats per location and 34 species. Outputs are 100×100 m action maps for The Lizard; climate risk not explicit, but costs included.

File: Alayan and Lakner - 2024 - Utilizing Comprehensive Criteria and Indicators for Post-Fire Forest Restoration in Spatial Decision.pdf
Input_Variables: Villages—Settlement—Roads—Restaurants-Shrines—Other Institutions and Local Facilities (Google Maps); Institutions and Local Facilities (Sentinel-2A; Copernicus Open Access Hub); LULC (USGS remote sensing data set resources); NDVI (UN-SPIDER Knowledge Portal); NBR (UN-SPIDER Knowledge Portal); Biodiversity Changes (Biomass/Carbon Sequestration) (UN-SPIDER Knowledge Portal); Soil erosion (Remote and traditional approaches); NDVI changes (Satellite Image) (UN-SPIDER Knowledge Portal); Settlement map (Sentinel-2 imagery; Google Earth); LU/LC Changes (USGS remote sensing data set resources)

Tool_Source: NA
Output: Final composite restoration suitability map (classes: well‑suited; moderately suitable; marginally suitable; not suitable) ; Criterion-specific suitability maps (economic; social; environmental; cultural & esthetic; infrastructural & educational; managerial & legal)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS is explicitly framed as reducing climate/fire risks and boosting resilience to climate change, demonstrated by SDSS-generated priority restoration maps and by simulating restoration scenarios to show how NbS decisions alter risk and outcomes.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis integrates economic considerations by treating the economy as one of the six criteria in the SDSS prioritization (economic weight ~36%), incorporating economic indicators such as restoration costs, economic benefits for local livelihoods and firms, and payments for ecosystem services, and reporting a quantitative insight that areas less suitable incur restoration costs over 32% higher than the benefits, with discussion of cost-effectiveness and economic viability embedded in the final suitability maps.
Narrative: NbS addressed: post-fire forest restoration prioritized via SDSS. Main inputs: six criteria (economic, social, environmental, infrastructural/educational, cultural/esthetic, managerial/legal) with 25 indicators; data included Sentinel-2A/10 m imagery (settlements, roads, LU/LC, NDVI, NBR), USGS LU/LC 2021, FAO LCCS, Google Maps, USLE-based soil erosion, and 21 local experts; ArcGIS 10.8; case study in Al-Ghab Plain, Syria (eastern slope, ~50 km, burnt area 4718 ha; study area ~20% of plain). Spatial method: MCA with AHP to weight criteria and DEMATEL to reveal inter-criteria relations; integrated in SDSS with four-stage workflow and weighted overlay to produce per-criterion maps and a final composite map, classified into four levels (N, S3–S1). Validation: data triangulation, external validation, and expert judgment; CI=0.07, CR=0.056. Outputs: criterion maps and a final four-class suitability map produced at 10 m Sentinel-2 resolution; results: 28% well-suited, 44% moderately; 3% unsuitable through 2023. Climate risk not explicit as a criterion; economic criterion top-weighted at 36%.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data available upon request from the corresponding author.

Tool_Source: NA
Output: Priority areas for forest restoration [restricted; very low; low; medium; high; very high]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS (forest restoration) is targeted to reduce climate-related erosion and protect water resources, with precipitation and proximity to drainage networks identified as key criteria, and the authors demonstrate this by producing a priority map showing higher restoration priority near drainage and near forest patches to mitigate sedimentation and erosion.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Minas Gerais; Rio Doce Basin (DO1); Rio Gualaxo; Mariana
Narrative: NbS addressed forest restoration in the Brazilian Atlantic Forest, mapped for the Rio Doce Basin DO1. Main inputs were precipitation from WorldClim, a drainage network, land-cover data (Carvalho et al. 2006) edited, a FEAM 2010 soil map, a DEM from ALOS PALSAR, and RapidEye imagery (5 m). The spatial approach combined five criteria—precipitation, proximity to drainage, proximity to forest patches, soil class, and slope—using a GIS-based MCDA with weighted linear combination (WLC); weights derived via Analytic Hierarchy Process (Saaty scale) and CR = 0.06. Spatial_Method: Spatial prioritization is performed by dividing the land base into management strata defined by species, age, site class, biogeoclimatic zone, and beetle attack severity, and solving a set of scenario-specific multi-criteria linear programs (compromise programming) to determine the optimal treatment mix across strata over the planning horizon.
Method_Validation: Expert review or stakeholder validation; Workshop-based review of scenarios with stakeholders.
Tool: GAMS (Brooke et al., 2004) ; CPLEX (IBM ILOG CPLEX Optimizer; https://www.ibm.com/products/ilog-cplex-optimizer) ; TIPSY (British Columbia Ministry of Forests and Range, 2007; https://www.for.gov.bc.ca/hre/gymodels/TIPSY/index.htm)
Tool_Source: GAMS : used as the modeling platform to formulate and solve the integrated multi-criteria forest planning problems (ScI-MCM and ScII-MCM) with the CPLEX solver; CPLEX : used as the optimization solver within GAMS to solve the linear programs and obtain compromise strategies across scenarios; TIPSY : used to generate yield table projections for stands, providing input data (e.g., merchantable volume) for the MCDA-based forest planning models.
Output: NA
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They treat climate change as a risk that could affect future forest composition and resilience, and demonstrate this by incorporating climate-change considerations into scenario development and MCDA, adding climate-adapted species options and evaluating scenarios under different climate assumptions to assess robustness and trade-offs.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly frame climate change and MPB disturbance risk as drivers to diversify species and plant climate-adapted trees (NbS-like adaptation), and demonstrate this in outputs by scenario-based prioritisation (Scenario II focused on forest health/diversification) with TreeD(x) as a criterion and reported shifts in species composition and harvest stability that indicate climate-resilient NbS planning.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis explicitly incorporates economic outcomes, using net present value/discounted net revenue (N(x) and N/NPV) as criteria alongside volume (V) and harvest-flow stability (FlowD); the two scenarios are compared by economic returns (e.g., CAD$1.186 billion NPV) and cumulative earnings, with MCDA optimizing for N(x)/NPV to balance economics with timber supply.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Quesnel; Sub-national: British Columbia; National: Canada
Narrative: The NbS addressed forest restoration after mountain pine beetle disturbance and diversification of the regional forest sector to build resilience in British Columbia, Canada. The main inputs included data for the Quesnel Timber Supply Area (TSA) (~2 million ha) with a model land base of 621,953 ha, stands older than 40 years, four predominant species, MPB infestation percentages, yield projections from TIPSY 4.1, and price/cost data from Table A1, within a 200-year planning horizon (decadal periods) and management strata defined by species, age and site. The spatial method coupled scenario planning with MCDA via two multi-criteria linear programs (ScI-MCM and ScII-MCM) using compromise programming to minimize weighted distances between current and target criteria. Outputs were compromise strategies S1 (Scenario I) and S2 (Scenario II), derived by solving for various weights with CPLEX/GAMS; results included N(x), V(x), FlowD(x) and TreeD(x) and species abundance tables (Table 4/5), at coarse spatial resolution over strata, with hectares allocated as x. The geographic scope was the Quesnel TSA in central interior BC, and the analysis allowed long-term comparisons and iterative stakeholder review. Climate risk was addressed via planting species adaptable to climate change, and economic considerations were explicit through net present value and harvest-volume criteria.

Spatial_Method: Species distribution modelling (SDM)/ecological niche modelling (ENM) using machine-learning algorithms (Random Forest; LightGBM; Artificial Neural Networks) with current forest presence and pseudo-absences and bioclimatic/topographic/remote-sensing predictors to map current and future suitable areas; overlay with LULC and land ownership to identify priority planting zones.

Output: Current forest suitability map (LightGBM, Landsat 9) [suitable / not suitable]; Suitable areas within private land (current suitability overlaid with land ownership) [suitable & private]; Future forest suitability maps (2021–2040; LightGBM; HadGEM3‑GC31‑LL, MRI‑ESM2‑0; SSP126/245/370/585) [suitable / not suitable]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: climate change is framed as a risk to long-term forest suitability and NbS effectiveness, demonstrated by scenario-based future suitability mapping under multiple CMIP6 SSP-RCP scenarios and cross-model comparisons that show how precipitation and temperature shifts alter suitable areas and necessitate adaptive management.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly frame forest restoration as a climate-adaptation and mitigation NbS, aiming to identify priority areas where NbS can sequester carbon and reduce climate risks, with outputs showing scenario-based future forest-suitability maps under SSP-RCP climates and discussions of carbon sequestration and REDD+-related mitigation benefits.
Geographic_Scope: Local: eThekwini Municipality; Sub-national: KwaZulu-Natal; National: South Africa
Narrative: The NbS addressed was forest restoration through reforestation/afforestation and urban greening in eThekwini. Inputs included WorldClim v2 bioclimatics (bio1, bio3, bio4, bio6, bio7, bio10, bio11, bio12, bio15), elevation and slope from SRTM, current forest distribution from JRC Global Forest Cover 2020, updated LULC and land ownership data, and remote-sensing indices from Landsat 9 and Sentinel 2A (NDVI, GNDVI, EVI, NDWI, MNDWI, SAVI, MSAVI, NDBI). Future suitability used CMIP6 projections under four SSP-RCPs (SSP126, SSP245, SSP370, SSP585) from HadGEM3-GC31-LL and MRI-ESM2-0; topography was omitted. The spatial method employed SDMs with RF, LightGBM, and ANN, using presence data from the forest map and pseudo-absences, 70/30 split, and ROC/AUC and confusion-matrix validation, with McNemar’s test and SHAP for variable importance. Outputs were 30 m maps; current suitability was about 30% of the area, and future SSP370 predicted 62.61% suitable. Climate risk was included via CMIP6 SSP-RCP; economic considerations included overlaying private land ownership.

File: Cannon et al. - 2020 - Simulating spatial complexity in dry conifer forest restoration implications for conservation prior.pdf
Input_Variables: Canopy cover (LANDFIRE); Canopy bulk density (LANDFIRE); Canopy base height (LANDFIRE); Canopy height (LANDFIRE); Fire behavior fuel model (FBFM) (LANDFIRE); Existing vegetation type (LANDFIRE); Fuel disturbance layers (LANDFIRE); Catchments (NHDPlus) (NHDPlus); 30 m DEM (USGS); Flow path length to nearest channel (30 m DEM) (USGS); Flow path length across pixel (30 m DEM) (USGS); Topographic wetness index (TWI) (Beven & Freer 2001; dynatopmodel); Solar radiation (growing season) raster (ArcGIS 10.3; Fu & Rich 2002); Soil moisture index (SMI) (Eq. 1; Brown et al. 2015; Battaglia 2018; Addington 2018); Rainfall erosivity (R) (Renard et al. 1997; RAWS data); Soil erodibility (K) (SSURGO; STATSGO); Slope length and slope factor LS (DEM-derived; USEPA & USGS 2012); Cover-management factor C (LANDFIRE 2016); Support practice factor P (Renard et al. 1997); Weather data (RAWS) (FireFamilyPlus 4.1)
Analysis_Resolution: Catchment-level (NHDPlus catchments; vector, 1010 catchments in the Upper South Platte Watershed).
Spatial_Method: GIS-based LANDFIRE/NHDPlus catchment screening (forest cover ≥75%, upper/lower montane zones, not Hayman-burned, ≥40.5 ha) to select 300 suitable catchments; RestSim restoration simulations within catchments to generate target canopy-cover distributions and derive ecological indicators (forest heterogeneity, fire vulnerability, erosion risk); prioritization by an equal-weight composite ranking across the three indicators.
Method_Validation: Calibration against limited field observations of post-fire sediment delivery ratio (SDR) by doubling the predicted SDR.
Tool: RestSim (https://github.com/jbcannon/landscape_restoration_simulator) ; FlamMap (Finney et al. 2019) ; FireFamilyPlus 4.1 (Bradshaw & McCormick 2000) ; dynatopmodel (Beven & Freer 2001) ; spatial_heterogeneity_metrics (https://github.com/jbcannon/spatial_heterogeneity_metrics)
Tool_Source: RestSim: used to simulate restoration of target forest structure and variability across catchments by elevation/moisture physiographic settings, generating gamma-based target canopy-cover distributions, applying silvicultural constraints, iteratively adjusting targets, and producing simulated fuelscapes for subsequent ecological modeling; FlamMap: used to quantify fire behavior and hazard for each management scenario under prescribed-fire and extreme-weather conditions, deriving an integrated fire-hazard index and potential large high-severity patches by combining burn probability with modeled fire behavior outputs; FireFamilyPlus 4.1: used to characterize extreme (97th percentile) fire weather conditions from RAWS data to parameterize extreme-fire-weather inputs for FlamMap simulations; dynatopmodel: used to compute the soil moisture index by generating the topographic wetness index and incorporating solar radiation to classify pixels as wetter or drier, informing RestSim canopy-cover targets by physiographic setting; spatial_heterogeneity_metrics: used to compute landscape-scale heterogeneity metrics (canopy-cover distributions across classes, large gap cover, landscape complexity, contagion index, RC2) from canopy rasters to evaluate spatial configuration and prioritization implications.
Output: Map of change in landscape complexity (Δ complexity) [FHR, RES]; Map of change in integrated fire hazard index [FHR, RES]; Map of change in expected post-fire sedimentation (Mg ha-1) [FHR, RES]; Catchment prioritization map (percentile rank of summed benefits) [FHR, RES]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target NbS (fuel hazard reduction and restoration) to lower climate-related wildfire risk and erosion, demonstrated by scenario-based prioritization and outputs that map catchments ranked by integrated fire hazard, largest high-severity patches, and predicted post-fire sediment delivery to show where risk reduction benefits are greatest.
Narrative: The NbS addressed dry-forest restoration and fuels reduction to increase structural heterogeneity and wildfire resilience. Key inputs were 30-m LANDFIRE layers for baseline canopy/fuel attributes, 1010 NHDPlus catchments (USEPA/USGS 2012) in the Upper South Platte watershed (300 analyzed; 41–5000 ha), physiographic zones (upper vs lower montane), topographic wetness, solar radiation, RAWS weather, and soil-erosion data. A three-scenario framework (UNT, FHR, RES) was applied, with RestSim generating canopy targets by physiography (lower montane: dry 16%, wet 20%; upper montane: dry 27%, wet 30%) and adjusting LANDFIRE fuels. Outputs at 30 m included canopy cover, large gaps, landscape complexity (Shannon index), contagion, integrated fire hazard, largest high-severity patch, predicted burn under prescribed fire, and post-fire erosion (RUSLE/SDR). Linear mixed models showed RES increased heterogeneity (LC 0.84) and produced comparable fire/erosion benefits to FHR; prioritization maps used equal weights; climate risk via prescribed/extreme weather; economic constraints not modeled.

File: Ceccarelli et al. - 2022 - Vulnerability mapping of 100 priority tree species in Central Africa to guide conservation and resto.pdf
Input_Variables: Bioclimatic variables (not specified); Cloud cover (VITO, 2020, 2021); Climatic extremes (VITO, 2020, 2021); Soil variables (Hengl et al., 2017); Terrain variables (Table S2); Presence data (RAINBIO; Dauby et al., 2016); Presence data (GBIF; Global Biodiversity Information Facility); Presence data (BIEN; Botanical Information and Ecology Network); Fire exposure (Fremout et al., 2020; Gaisberger et al., 2021); Habitat conversion exposure (Fremout et al., 2020; Gaisberger et al., 2021); Overexploitation exposure (Fremout et al., 2020; Gaisberger et al., 2021); Overgrazing exposure (Fremout et al., 2020; Gaisberger et al., 2021); Climate change exposure (Fremout et al., 2020; Gaisberger et al., 2021)
Spatial_Method: Ensemble species distribution modelling using multiple algorithms (random forest; MAXENT; GBM; GLMSTEP; GAMSTEP; MGCV; FDA; SVM; EARTH) with spatial cross‑validation and 45 predictor variables to produce present and future suitability maps; thresholded to presence–absence and combined with trait-based threat sensitivity to generate per‑species vulnerability maps, which are then aggregated to identify priority areas for in‑situ conservation, ex‑situ conservation, and restoration.
Method_Validation: Cross-validation with 5 folds using spatial blocks (blockCV); model performance assessed with cvAUC; sensitivity analysis to assess robustness of conservation/restoration maps to methodological decisions (exposure maps, trait weighting and missing traits).
Tool: BiodiversityR (Kindt, 2018; CRAN: https://cran.r-project.org/package=BiodiversityR) ; BlockCV (Valavi et al., 2019; DOI:10.1111/2041-210X.13107) ; Diversity for Restoration (D4R) (Fremout et al., 2021; DOI:10.1111/1365-2664.14079; Website: https://www.diversityforrestoration.org/)
Tool_Source: BiodiversityR : Used to perform ensemble distribution modelling by combining multiple algorithms (random forest, MAXENT, GBM, GLMSTEP, GAMSTEP, MGCV, SVM, EARTH) to predict present and future species distributions and generate suitability maps ; BlockCV : Used to implement spatially explicit, block-based cross-validation (5 folds) for robust model validation and cvAUC assessment ; Diversity for Restoration (D4R) : Integrated to provide location-specific information on suitable tree species and seed sources for restoration projects, guiding seed sourcing and restoration planning (currently Cameroon and Burkina Faso).
Output: Species-specific conservation and restoration priority maps (in‑situ conservation; ex‑situ conservation/assisted migration; active planting/assisted natural regeneration); Species-specific vulnerability maps (per threat: fire, habitat conversion, overexploitation, overgrazing, climate change; classes: zero/low/medium/high/very high); Multi‑species in‑situ conservation priority map (number of priority species per grid cell; within vs outside protected areas); Multi‑species active planting/assisted natural regeneration priority map (number of priority species per grid cell; converted vs non‑converted areas); Multi‑species ex‑situ conservation priority map (number of priority species per grid cell)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: climate change is treated as a threat that could undermine long-term NbS outcomes by reducing future suitability and persistence of priority tree species; the authors demonstrate this by integrating climate-change exposure into a threat-vulnerability framework to produce future vulnerability maps and by projecting areas that will become suitable or unsuitable under climate change, including best- and worst-case exposure scenarios.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: they explicitly target NbS actions based on climate-change vulnerability. They prioritize ex-situ conservation or assisted migration in areas with high climate-change vulnerability and in-situ restoration in areas with low climate-change vulnerability, with these decisions demonstrated through maps of vulnerability and conservation/restoration priority.
Geographic_Scope: Multi-country: Cameroon;Central African Republic;Chad;Republic of the Congo;Democratic Republic of the Congo;Equatorial Guinea;Gabon;São Tomé and Príncipe
Narrative: The NbS spatial prioritisation addressed restoration and conservation of 100 socio-ecologically important priority tree species in Central Africa, proposing actions for in-situ conservation, ex-situ conservation or assisted migration, and active planting or assisted natural regeneration. The main inputs included presence records from RAINBIO, GBIF and BIEN (filtered to reduce bias), 45 predictor variables (19 bioclimatic, 5 cloud cover, 6 climatic extremes from VITO, 10 soil variables from Hengl et al., and 5 terrain variables), with exposure maps at 30 arcsec and climate-change projections, and trait-based species sensitivities from 16 traits weighted to yield species-specific vulnerability; pseudo-absences used a target-group approach. The spatial method combined ensemble distribution modelling (up to nine algorithms via BiodiversityR; cross-validated with 5-fold spatial blocks using blockCV; thresholding to presence–absence where sensitivity equals specificity) to derive vulnerability as exposure multiplied by sensitivity, including current threats (fire, habitat conversion, overgrazing, overexploitation) and future climate exposure. Validation yielded a mean cvAUC of 0.81 (0.64–0.96; seven species below 0.70), with average high-to-very-high vulnerability across distributions of 34% and 60% medium-to-high vulnerability to at least one threat; outputs comprise species-specific vulnerability maps and summary maps for in-situ, ex-situ and restoration actions at 5 arcmin resolution (with exposure at 30 arcsec) across Central Africa (30 countries; 0°W–35°E, 15°S–25°N), including an online platform and downloadable data. Climate risk was included as a threat; no explicit economic considerations were reported.

File: Chen et al. - 2021 - Evaluating suitability of land for forest landscape restoration A case study of Three Gorges Reserv.pdf
Input_Variables: Altitude (Geospatial Data Cloud, Chinese Academy of Sciences); Slope (Geospatial Data Cloud, Chinese Academy of Sciences); Aspect (Geospatial Data Cloud, Chinese Academy of Sciences); Land Use and Land Cover 2018 (Land Resources Bureau of Zigui County); Soil Depth (Second-class inventory base of forest resources in the Three Gorges Reservoir area, Forestry Science Data Center, Chinese Academy of Forestry); Soil Type (Geography Institute of the Chinese Academy of Sciences); Nutrient Status of Soil (Nanjing Soil Institute)
Spatial_Method: Matter-element analysis-based land suitability assessment implemented in GIS; indicator weights determined by Analytic Hierarchy Process; final suitability classes derived from distances to classical/segment fields and comprehensive correlation; overlay with 2018 land-use data to exclude immovable land uses.
Method_Validation: Expert review/validation by a local forestry bureau expert; AHP weighting validated through consistency check with 20 questionnaires meeting consistency requirements.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Forest landscape restoration suitability map (Suitable; Moderately suitable; Unsuitable)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Zigui County; Sub-national: Hubei; National: China
Narrative: NbS addressed: forest landscape restoration (FLR) to restore degraded lands in Zigui County, Three Gorges region. Inputs were six biophysical indicators—altitude, slope, aspect, soil depth, soil type, and soil nutrient status—derived from LULC 2018 (Zigui Land Resources Bureau), DEM 30 m (Geospatial Data Cloud, CAS), soil data (Nanjing Soil Institute; CAF Forestry Data Center), soil types (CAS). The spatial method combined matter-element analysis with GIS; indicator weights were set via analytic hierarchy process using 20 expert questionnaires; per grid cell, classical and segment fields were defined, distances computed, and Kj calculated to classify cells as suitable, moderately suitable, or unsuitable. Three rasters K1–K3 were produced and merged by maximum, then overlaid with LUCC to identify restoration lands. Validation used local forestry bureau opinion; results: 101.39 km2 suitable (59.71%), 67.98 km2 moderately suitable (40.04%), 0.42 km2 unsuitable (0.25%). Outputs included Zigui maps in SW Hubei; climate risk criteria were not included.

File: Crouzeilles et al. - 2020 - Achieving cost‐effective landscape‐scale forest restoration through targeted natural regeneration.pdf
Input_Variables: Proximity to forest (Supporting Information); Proportion forested in county (Figure S2) (Supporting Information); Landscape conditions (Supporting Information); Soil properties (Supporting Information); Climate (Supporting Information); Topographic relief (Supporting Information); Past disturbance intensity (pasture and sugarcane) (Supporting Information); MapBiomas land use/cover (MapBiomas Collection 3) (MapBiomas); Potentially restorable land area (county-level) (Supporting Information)
Spatial_Method: 30-m resolution time-series remote-sensing analysis identified past natural regeneration (1996–2015) and mapped restorable land by excluding areas with active restoration or forestry; county-scale natural-regeneration potential was modeled with Random Forest regression as a function of environmental and socioeconomic drivers; pixel-scale occurrence was modeled with Random Forest classification; k-fold cross-validation validated both models; four scenario-based spatial prioritizations using a ≥50% probability threshold and low/medium/high opportunity-cost categories identified suitable/priority areas for restoration.
Method_Validation: k-fold cross-validation (k=10) for both county-scale Random Forest regression and pixel-scale Random Forest classification; validation metrics include Pearson’s r correlation between predicted and observed county regeneration proportions (0.91) and pixel-scale prediction accuracy of 76.9%.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Predicted county-level proportion of area able to spontaneously regenerate (2016–2035); Pixel-scale (30‑m) probability map of natural regeneration potential (probability; >50% threshold used); Restoration allocation/prioritization maps showing areas with >50% regeneration potential under four opportunity‑cost scenarios [low, medium, high, maximum]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS is spatially targeted to maximize climate-mitigation outcomes by focusing on areas with high natural-regeneration potential, and the authors demonstrate this via scenario-based prioritization that estimates up to 2.3 GtCO2 sequestered and US$90.6 billion in cost savings under four regeneration scenarios, alongside biodiversity and fragmentation benefits.
Economics: Yes: It includes economic outputs—costs and benefits—by estimating total restoration costs and opportunity costs and reporting cost savings (e.g., up to US$90.6 billion, a 76% reduction) across scenarios, thereby framing natural regeneration as a cost-effective option and mentioning payments for ecosystem services as a policy mechanism.
Narrative: Targeted natural regeneration (including assisted natural regeneration) was the NbS addressed for landscape-scale forest restoration in the Atlantic Forest of Brazil. Main inputs were 30-m resolution remote sensing and MapBiomas land-use data (1996–2015) plus drivers related to landscape, soils, climate, topography and past disturbance from agriculture and sugarcane; Random Forest models were used to predict regeneration. County-level RF regression (n=3,350) explained 80.2% of variation and predicted 2.80 Mha could regenerate 2015–2035; pixel-level RF classification (balanced 10,000-pixel sample) achieved 76.9% accuracy. Predictions of regeneration potential over the next 20 years were made for four scenarios, including a maximum-potential and three cost-based tiers by opportunity cost (<US$1,289; <US$2,577; <US$5,155 ha−1 year−1). Validation employed 10-fold cross-validation (county r=0.91; pixel accuracy 76.9%). Outputs comprise spatially explicit 30-m maps, 3,350 county estimates, and costs and benefits (US$90.6B saved; 2.30 GtCO2 sequestered). Geographic scope: 75.5 M ha deforested Atlantic Forest; climate risk not explicitly included; economic considerations embedded.

File: Delevaux and Stamoulis - 2021 - Prioritizing forest management actions to benefit marine habitats in data‐poor regions.pdf
Input_Variables: land use/land cover 2010 (SPC); Coral Allen Atlas habitat maps (Allen Coral Atlas); Coral Millennium habitat maps (Millennium Coral Reef Mapping Project); topography (InVEST SDR); soils erodibility (InVEST SDR); rainfall erosivity (InVEST SDR); depth (marine water quality model) (Delevaux et al., 2018a); wind (marine water quality model) (Delevaux et al., 2018a); currents (marine water quality model) (Delevaux et al., 2018a); bathymetry (marine data) (Delevaux et al., 2018a); road networks (OSM 2019)
Spatial_Method: Linked ridge-to-reef spatial prioritization: InVEST SDR quantified sediment export from land-use change scenarios; a marine water-quality/TSS model mapped habitat exposure; outputs were overlaid with two global marine habitat maps (Allen Coral Atlas and Millennium) to identify downstream watersheds contributing to exposed habitats; a watershed prioritization score Pw was computed as a weighted average of habitat area exposed to TSS change by watershed; results under deforestation and restoration scenarios were classified into priority categories and buffered for management.
Method_Validation: Cross-map validation using two global marine habitat maps (Allen Coral Atlas and Millennium) with reported R2 values (0.7 under deforestation, 0.2 under restoration) and significance testing of changes with SigDiff (α = 0.10); uncertainty buffering (100 m) around priority areas to account for data uncertainty.
Tool_Source: InVEST SDR (Hamel et al., 2015) : used to quantify changes in sediment export from watersheds to the coast under different land-use scenarios, based on topography, soil erodibility, and rainfall erosivity, producing sediment export (t/year) that feeds the linked marine water quality model and informs ridge-to-reef watershed prioritization.
Output: Watershed prioritization map for forest protection (combined Allen Atlas + Millennium) [low/medium/high]; Watershed prioritization map for forest restoration (combined Allen Atlas + Millennium) [low/medium/high]; Priority land-area allocation maps within prioritized watersheds for targeted conservation/restoration (100‑m buffer around grid cells with significant sediment export change); Marine habitat exposure to change in total suspended solids (TSS) map (coral/algae; seagrass) [area (ha) exposed]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: the study treats climate-change resilience as a driver for targeting forest conservation/restoration to reduce land-based sediment delivery and improve coastal water quality for marine habitats, demonstrated by scenario-based prioritization linking deforestation/restoration to changes in sediment export and habitat exposure, and by producing prioritized watershed maps showing where NbS interventions would most mitigate climate-related stress on coral reefs and seagrass.
Narrative: NbS practice addressed: forest conservation and restoration actions to benefit marine habitats via ridge-to-reef management in Vanuatu. Inputs: a 2010 land-use map (SPC); rainfall erosivity, soil erodibility, topography; InVEST SDR (v3.9) to quantify sediment export at 30 m; a marine water quality model (depth, wind, currents) to estimate sediment; habitat maps from Allen Coral Atlas and Millennium Coral Reef Map used to derive habitat exposure (Atlas includes coral/algae and seagrass; Millennium focuses on coral reef habitat). The study covered 412 watersheds across 11,663 km2 on 17 islands. Spatial method: four-component ridge-to-reef prioritization combining land-use scenarios (deforestation and restoration), SDR-derived sediment export, and linkage to habitat exposure; Pw = sum_i Hwi x Fwi / nw, rescaled to 0–100, with a 100 m buffer. Outputs: a linked land-sea decision-support tool and prioritization maps for watersheds. Validation: R2 = 0.70 for deforestation and 0.20 for restoration. Climate/economic: not included; no SDR calibration or costs assessed.

File: Fahrudin et al. - 2024 - Optimizing afforestation and reforestation strategies to enhance ecosystem services in critically de.pdf
Input_Variables: Deforestation (Global Forest Watch); Impervious Surface (IM); Land Cover (MODIS LULC); NDVI (Landsat NDVI); EVI (EVI composite); GPP (MOD17A2H.006); LAI (LAI); Water Content (Open Land Map); ET (MOD16A2GF.061); ABG (WHRC ABG); BGB (WCMC BGB); Elevation (NASA SRTM); Slope (NASA SRTM); Aspect (NASA SRTM); Precipitation (CHRIPS); Temperature (MOD11A1.006); Wind Speed (ERA-5); Road Network (BIG-RI); Population Density (WorldPop); AOD (MCD19A2.006); Land-Use Planning (Belitung Government)
Spatial_Method: MCA with a weight-overlay approach (equal weights) to synthesize ES, wildfire susceptibility and environmental-pressure indicators into a priority index; a Random Forest-based wildfire susceptibility model; and a linear-regression analysis of long-term environmental-pressure trends to guide afforestation/reforestation targeting.
Method_Validation: Train-test split (70/30) with ROC/AUC validation for the wildfire susceptibility model; Comparison/validation of ES outputs against official spatial-planning classes (validation with government spatial planning maps).
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Afforestation and reforestation priority maps (low/medium/high); Multi-ecosystem service (total ES) map (very-low/low/moderate/high/very-high); Carbon sequestration (CS) map; Biodiversity maintenance/protection (BMP) map; Freshwater supply (FWS) map
Climate_Barrier: Yes: Climate hazards such as wildfires and long-term environmental pressure from warming and degraded air quality are treated as risks that could jeopardize NbS outcomes; they demonstrate this by integrating hazard indicators with ecosystem-service models to produce a hazard-aware afforestation/reforestation priority index and maps.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The study targets afforestation and reforestation to deliver climate-change mitigation through carbon storage and climate regulation. This is demonstrated by priority-area mapping that integrates the climate-regulation (CS) component with other ecosystem services to show where NbS yields carbon benefits and reduces climate risks.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Belitung Island; Belitung Regency; East Belitung Regency; Bangka Belitung Islands Province
Narrative: The NbS addressed afforestation and reforestation on Belitung Island, Indonesia. Key inputs included remote-sensing data on deforestation (Global Forest Watch, Hansen et al. 2013), impervious surface (Gong et al. 2020), MODIS LULC, Landsat NDVI/EVI, FPAR, LAI, GPP, Open Land Map water content, MODIS ET, biomass (WHRC, WCMC), fire hotspots, elevation, precipitation (CHIRPS), land-surface temperature (MODIS), wind (ERA5), roads, population (WorldPop), AOD, land-use planning data. The spatial method combined a multi-criteria analysis with equal weights to synthesize provisioning (freshwater supply), regulatory (climate regulation via carbon storage) and support (biodiversity) ES, then integrated wildfire susceptibility (random forest with 70/30 train/test; AUC = 0.858) and environmental-pressure trends. Outputs included afforestation (150,887.8 ha; 31.01%) and reforestation (80,203.58 ha; 16.48%), with priority classes (low/moderate/high) across sub-districts, and 300 m ES maps; provisioning covered 432,646.02 ha of 458,500 ha. Scope: Belitung Island; climate risk was included via CS and pressure indicators; economic considerations were not included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The data product for afforestation and reforestation priority index and additional datasets generated during the study are available from the corresponding author A.D.S (anjar@itb.ac.id) upon reasonable request.

File: Fan et al. - 2024 - Suitability assessment for forest landscape restoration based on species diversity conservation.pdf
Input_Variables: Land cover type (The U.S. Geological Survey); Total nitrogen (National Earth System Science Data Center); Total phosphorus (National Earth System Science Data Center); Total potassium (National Earth System Science Data Center); Available potassium (National Earth System Science Data Center); Alkali-hydrolysis nitrogen (National Earth System Science Data Center); Available phosphorus (National Earth System Science Data Center); pH (National Earth System Science Data Center); Soil Quality Index (SQI) (National Earth System Science Data Center); Slope (°) (The geospatial data cloud); Patch area (km2) (The national forest inventory data); Patch distance (m) (The national forest inventory data); Patch shape (The national forest inventory data); Landscape shape index (LSI) (The national forest inventory data)
Spatial_Method: Matter-element analysis integrated with Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) weighting applied to GIS-derived raster indicators (land cover type; soil quality index calculated via PCA/MDS with a weighted sum; patch area; patch distance to natural secondary forests with buffers; landscape shape index; slope) to identify and map suitable/priority FLR areas.
Method_Validation: Field verification / ground-truthing of land cover classification (60 plots); Land cover classification accuracy assessment (overall accuracy 98.62%, Kappa 0.98) using ground truth; AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.0355) for weight validation; Expert scoring to determine AHP weights (30 forestry experts)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Forest landscape restoration suitability map (Suitable; Moderately suitable; Marginally suitable; Unsuitable)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Saihanba Nature Reserve; Sub-national: Hebei Province; Inner Mongolia; National: China
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was forest landscape restoration (FLR) aimed at conserving species diversity in the Saihanba Nature Reserve, Hebei Province, China. Key inputs included land cover type classified from Landsat 8 (USGS GLOVIS) data (2020; accuracy 98.62%, KAPPA 0.98 from 60 ground-truth plots in August 2022), a soil quality index (SQI) derived from seven soil factors (total nitrogen, total phosphorus, total potassium, available potassium, alkali-hydrolysis nitrogen, available phosphorus, and pH) using PCA to construct a minimum data set and a weighted SQI via a weighted-sum model, topography (slope) from a DEM, and landscape-structure metrics (patch area, patch distance with buffers of 300, 750, 1,000, and 2,000 m, patch shape index). Data sources included the National Earth System Science Data Center, geospatial data cloud, ENVI 5.1, ArcGIS 10.2, and the national forest inventory (2021); all rasters were CGCS2000_GK_Zone_20 projected. The spatial method was a matter-element analysis with weights determined by AHP (CR = 0.0355) to combine indicators into four FLR suitability classes; outputs comprised a suitability map and area statistics, with 519.20 km2 identified as suitable (55.55%), plus 161.72 km2 moderately suitable, 223.96 km2 marginally suitable, and 29.74 km2 unsuitable, at a raster resolution tied to the Landsat-based inputs (30 m). Validation used ground-truth land-cover verification (60 plots) yielding 98.62% overall accuracy and a Kappa of 0.98. The study area spans 929.97 km2; climate risk and economic considerations were not explicitly included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The raw data supporting the conclusions of this article will be made available by the authors, without undue reservation.

File: Gopalakrishna et al. - 2024 - Optimizing restoration A holistic spatial approach to deliver Nature’s Contributions to People with.pdf
Input_Variables: Climate NCP (Cook-Patton et al., Mapping carbon accumulation potential from global natural forest regrowth); Biodiversity value NCP (IUCN Red List habitat/AOH targets for forest-dependent mammals); Societal NCP (Nature-dependent people: Mapping human direct use of nature for basic needs across the tropics); Elevation preferences (Matt Lewis dataset); Biophysical forest suitability (Existing land uses constrain climate change mitigation potential of forest restoration in India); Current land uses and covers (Existing land uses constrain climate change mitigation potential of forest restoration in India); AOH targets (IUCN Red List habitat-based AOH protocol); Socioeconomic data SHRUG (Asher et al., SHRUG open data platform)
Spatial_Method: Systematic conservation planning implemented as a mixed‑integer linear programming (MILP) optimization (via the prioritizeR R package) to identify optimal restoration areas under multi‑NCP targets; spatially map restoration suitability at 10×10 km resolution using biophysical suitability and land‑use constraints; compute biodiversity (AOH‑based) and societal NCP targets from mammal habitats and human reliance data to drive the optimization.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool: prioritizeR (prioritizr: Systematic Conservation Prioritization in R (Version 7.0.1, R package, 2021))
Tool_Source: prioritizeR : Implemented MILP optimization for systematic conservation planning to identify optimal restoration-area configurations that maximize multi-NCP delivery (climate NCP, biodiversity value NCP, and societal NCP) under area constraints by minimizing the weighted shortfall between NCP targets and delivered NCP.
Output: Optimal restoration priority map (carbon‑centric plan); Optimal restoration priority map (biodiversity‑centric plan); Optimal restoration priority map (people‑centric plan); Optimal restoration priority map (integrated multi‑objective plan)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS is spatially targeted to maximize climate change mitigation by prioritizing areas with high carbon sequestration potential, and the authors demonstrate this by comparing carbon-centric, biodiversity-centric, and integrated plans and showing that integrated plans deliver the majority of climate NCP (carbon sequestration) across the restoration area.
Narrative: NbS practice addressed: forest restoration in India to deliver multiple Nature’s Contributions to People (NCP): climate change mitigation, biodiversity value, and societal NCP. Main inputs: climate NCP quantified as carbon sequestered in the first 30 years of natural forest regrowth; biodiversity NCP as the proportion of 56 forest-dependent mammals for which habitat targets are met; societal NCP as the number of people relying on forests for livelihoods, energy, and housing; restoration area 3.88 Mha at 10 × 10 km; biophysical suitability and current land uses defined eligible areas; data sources included IUCN Red List AOH targets, SHRUG population data, and carbon accumulation references. Spatial method: MILP optimization using prioritizeR to minimize weighted shortfall across four plans (carbon-, biodiversity-, people-, integrated) under an area budget. Validation and results: integrated plans delivered on average 83.3% climate NCP, 89.9% biodiversity NCP, and 93.9% societal NCP; biodiversity-centric plan achieved 100% biodiversity NCP within 17% restoration area. Outputs: optimal restoration area maps, NCP accumulation curves at 1% increments, and equity distributions. Geographic scope: India nationwide, 3.88 Mha, 10 × 10 km, including Western Ghats, NE India, and Eastern Ghats. Climate risk and economic considerations included via climate NCP targets and restoration-area budget, with distributional equity assessed.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Zenodo (10.5281/zenodo.10676360); Supplementary data files: https://www.pnas.org/lookup/suppl/doi:10.1073/pnas.2402970121/-/DCSupplemental

File: Hernández-Romero et al. - 2022 - From Forest Dynamics to Wetland Siltation in Mountainous Landscapes A RS-Based Framework for Enhanc.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: spontaneous vegetation regeneration; vegetated buffer strips
Input_Variables: LULC (Landsat LEDAPS; Sentinel-2 iCOR); Wetlands (Sentinel-2 mosaic corrected by iCOR; fieldwork and photo-interpretation); Slope (DEM LiDAR; CNIG); Topographic Wetness Index (TWI) (DEM LiDAR); NDVI (Landsat; Sentinel-2); NDMI (Sentinel-2); AWEInsh (Sentinel-2); GNDVI (Sentinel-2); LS (DEM-derived); GEP (NetMap); SRN (Synthetic River Network; DEM); Forest gain rate (LULC maps 1989–2019; external validation data)
Spatial_Method: RS-based LULC and wetlands mapping via SVM from Landsat/Sentinel-2; NetMap-based erosion-potential modelling (GEP and LS) with deposition/wetland overlay; InVEST-based future forest scenario (BAU) generation; multi-criteria overlay to identify priority areas for forest conservation/restoration to reduce erosion and sedimentation.
Method_Validation: Field verification/ground-truthing through in situ field campaigns (2017–2021), GPS reference points and Google Street View validation; LULC and wetland mapping accuracy assessment (86% and 61%, respectively); External validation against independent forest-change data (1989–2019 forest gain) for the future scenario; Sensitivity analysis of NDVI to ensure spectral consistency across Landsat/Sentinel-2 time series.
Tool: InVEST (Natural Capital Project; https://naturalcapitalproject.stanford.edu) ; NetMap (Benda, L.; Miller, D.; Andras, K.; Bigelow, P.; Reeves, G.; Michael, D. NetMap: A new tool in support of watershed science and resource management. For. Sci. 2007, 53, 206–219)
Tool_Source: InVEST: Used as the Proximity-Based Scenario Generator to create a 2049 BAU future forest extent by converting grasslands and shrublands to a merged FOR category (BLF+CNF) starting from forest edges, thereby projecting future forest cover for erosion and wetland analysis. ; NetMap: Used to identify potential erosion, sediment production, transport and deposition areas by applying the Generic Erosion Potential index and LS factors, delineating erosion sources, transport paths, and deposition zones tied to wetlands.
Output: Priority map for forest conservation and restoration to reduce wetland siltation (classes: very high / high / medium / low); Future LULC allocation map showing 2049 potential forest extent (allocation of FOR); Erosion-source priority map (areas with GEP > 0.50 upstream of wetlands)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Cantabrian Cordillera; Sella catchments; Cares catchments; Deva catchments; Picos de Europa National Park; Spain
Narrative: The NbS approach addressed conservation and restoration of natural forests on hillslopes and riparian zones to reduce soil erosion and enhance sediment filtering, thereby lowering wetland siltation in Cantabrian Mountains. It integrated time-series Landsat 5/7/8 and Sentinel-2A/B imagery with in situ data from 2017–2021 (field campaigns, PNOA photo-interpretation, 1,821 points, 141 wetlands) and topographic data (5 m LiDAR DEM, slope, and TOPographic Wetness Index). LULC and wetlands were mapped per pixel with a supervised SVM; a 1989–2019 change matrix and a 2049 BAU scenario from InVEST Scenario Generator (SSH/GRA proximity) were combined with NetMap erosion potential (GEP) and a deposition mask in a multi-criteria analysis to locate priority NbS sites. Validation yielded LULC 86% and wetlands 61%, with a forest gain rate of 2 ha/year; outputs include 1989/2019/2049 LULC maps at 30 m and erosion and wetland layers over 2,485.20 km2 in Spain. Climate risk and costs were not modeled.

File: Hu et al. - 2020 - Mapping the potential of mangrove forest restoration based on species distribution models A case st.pdf
Input_Variables: bio_01 (WorldClim); bio_02 (WorldClim); bio_03 (WorldClim); bio_04 (WorldClim); bio_05 (WorldClim); bio_06 (WorldClim); bio_07 (WorldClim); bio_08 (WorldClim); bio_09 (WorldClim); bio_10 (WorldClim); bio_11 (WorldClim); bio_12 (WorldClim); bio_13 (WorldClim); bio_14 (WorldClim); bio_15 (WorldClim); bio_16 (WorldClim); bio_17 (WorldClim); bio_18 (WorldClim); bio_19 (WorldClim); Etopo1 (NOAA); LD (Geomorphometric and Gradient Metrics Toolbox); CTI (Geomorphometric and Gradient Metrics Toolbox); sbdare (not specified); sst1 (NASA MODIS-Aqua Level-3); sst2 (NASA MODIS-Aqua Level-3); sst3 (NASA MODIS-Aqua Level-3); sst4 (NASA MODIS-Aqua Level-3); sst5 (NASA MODIS-Aqua Level-3); sst6 (NASA MODIS-Aqua Level-3); sst7 (NASA MODIS-Aqua Level-3)
Spatial_Method: MaxEnt presence-only SDM; GARP presence-only SDM; then constrain predicted suitability with land-use/land-cover data and compute a restoration potential index (RPI = Si × Ti) to identify restorable/priority areas.
Method_Validation: Train-test split validation with AUC/ROC (75% training, 25% testing); comparison with 361 existing mangrove restoration projects to assess alignment; direct model comparison between GARP and MaxEnt (MaxEnt preferred); expert validation of land-use/land-cover transfer coefficients via a questionnaire of 10 experts.
Tool_Source: MaxEnt : Used to model mangrove habitat suitability and potential distribution using presence-only data, producing a probability-of-occurrence map (0–1), evaluating with AUC, and providing the final, more accurate distribution/restoration-potential predictions (e.g., about 16,800 ha restorable area) that best matched known mangrove patterns;
Output: Mangrove habitat suitability map (MaxEnt) [high/medium/low]; Restoration Potential Index (RPI) map of potentially restorable areas (MaxEnt; RPI 0–1; restorable >0.5)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: National: China; Sub-national: Zhejiang; Fujian; Guangdong; Guangxi; Hainan
Narrative: NbS addressed: mangrove restoration as a nature‑based solution for coastal protection and ecosystem services. Main inputs: 3839 mangrove occurrence points (remote sensing and on‑site surveys); 1 km environmental data including bioclimatic variables, SST metrics, elevation, CTI, and substrate from WorldClim, NASA MODIS‑Aqua, and ETOPO1; 2018 land‑use/land‑cover from RESDC; ESRI imagery for patch interpretation. Spatial method and combination: two presence‑only SDMs, GARP and MaxEnt; 75% of data used for training and 25% for testing; MaxEnt AUC 0.953 and GARP 0.882; restoration potential index (RPI) computed as RPI = S_i × T_i using LULC‑based transfer coefficients; grids with RPI > 0.5 designated restorable and overlaid with 361 restoration projects. Validation and results: MaxEnt outperformed GARP; northern limit around 28°27′–28°35′ N; nationwide restorable areas 16,800 ha (MaxEnt) versus 420,800 ha (GARP) after excluding extant mangroves; about 75% of potential areas lost to land use. Outputs and resolution: 1 km RPI map across Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi, and Hainan. Geographic scope: coastal mainland China (18°10′–29°30′ N). Climate predictors included; economic considerations via LULC transfer coefficients; no explicit climate‑risk or cost analysis.

File: Matos et al. - 2019 - Protected areas and forest fragmentation sustainability index for prioritizing fragments for landsc.pdf
Input_Variables: Land-use/land-cover map (SPOT images 2009; SMA-CPLA); Road network (SPOT images 2009; SMA-CPLA; on-screen digitizing); Rivers network (SPOT images 2009; SMA-CPLA; on-screen digitizing); Urban areas (SPOT images 2009; SMA-CPLA; on-screen digitizing); AREA (Landscape metrics derived from land-use map; ArcGIS 10.1 with VLate 2.0); SHAPE (Landscape metrics derived from land-use map; ArcGIS 10.1 with VLate 2.0); ENN (Landscape metrics derived from land-use map; ArcGIS 10.1 with VLate 2.0)
Spatial_Method: Forest Sustainability Index (FSI) based on landscape metrics AREA, SHAPE and ENN (calculated from a land-use/land-cover map in ArcGIS/FRAGSTATS; metrics normalized to a 1–7 scale, weighted 60% AREA, 10% SHAPE, 30% ENN, and summed to identify priority forest fragments for landscape restoration).
Method_Validation: Ground-truth validation of the land-use/land-cover map using a confusion matrix and Kappa coefficient with 80 ground-control points.
Tool: Forest Sustainability Index (FSI) (DOI:10.1080/24749508.2019.1696266) ; FRAGSTATS v4 (McGarigal, Cushman, Ene) http://www.umass.edu/landeco/research/fragstats/fragstats.html
Tool_Source: FSI: A weighted, normalized forest patch index combining AREA, SHAPE, and ENN to identify priority fragments for landscape restoration and to guide restoration planning to improve connectivity around Capão Bonito National Forest. ; FRAGSTATS v4: Not used in this study; landscape metrics were computed with ArcGIS (V-Late 2.0) and analyzed in R, so FRAGSTATS did not contribute to the analysis here.
Output: Forest Sustainability Index (FSI) priority map of forest fragments for landscape restoration
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Capão Bonito National Forest; Sub-national: São Paulo; Southeast Brazil; Intervales State Park; Carlos Botelho State Park; Angatuba Ecological Station; National: Brazil
Narrative: The NbS addressed forest restoration to improve landscape connectivity around Capão Bonito National Forest (CBNF) and its surroundings in São Paulo, Brazil (total area 74,575 ha; CBNF 4,773.83 ha; surrounding area 69,790.65 ha within a 10 km buffer). Main input variables and data sources included a land-use/land-cover map produced by supervised classification of SPOT 2.5 m images (2009) with 80 ground control points (global accuracy 93.41%; native-forest accuracy 99.14%; kappa 0.89) and auxiliary layers for rivers, roads, and urban areas. The spatial method computed landscape metrics at landscape and patch scales, including AREA, SHAPE, CORE, and ENN, with CORE/TCAI derived using a 30 m edge; metrics were tested for correlation. The Forest Sustainability Index (FSI) was formed as FSI = IxAREA + IxSHAPE + IxENN, with relative weights AREA 60%, SHAPE 10%, ENN 30%, after normalizing to 1–7 bytes. Outputs included a priority-fragment map for restoration (largest patches 103–1176 ha) validated via a confusion-matrix approach, at 2.5 m SPOT resolution over the CBNF and its 10 km buffer; climate risk and economic considerations were not included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The datasets used and/or analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

File: Meza-Mori et al. - 2022 - Spatial Analysis of Environmentally Sensitive Areas to Soil Degradation Using MEDALUS Model and GIS.pdf
Input_Variables: Parent material (Amazonas Ecological Economic Zoning, ZEE-A); Slope (ASTER DEM, USGS LPDAAC); Soil organic matter content (LABISAG UNTRM field sampling); Soil texture (USDA textural classification; field sampling); Aridity index (WorldClim 1 km); Erosivity (WorldClim 1 km); Aspect (ASTER DEM); Drought resistance (Pravalie et al. 22); Erosion protection (Pravalie et al. 22); Vegetation cover (Sentinel-2 imagery); Agricultural intensity (Salvati & Bajocco 2019); Landslides (INGENMET mass movement susceptibility map)
Spatial_Method: MEDALUS method implemented in GIS to identify environmentally sensitive areas by computing four quality indices (CQI, SQI, VQI, MQI) from 12 parameters and deriving ESAI as the fourth-root geometric mean of these indices to map priority/critical areas.
Method_Validation: Field verification / ground-truthing; Thematic accuracy assessment (kappa = 92%) for the land-cover classification used in ESAI calculation.
Tool: MEDALUS (Manual on Key Indicators of Desertification and Mapping Environmentally Sensitive Areas; Kosmas, Kirkby & Geeson; Medalus Project; 1999; Available online: http://www.comap.ca/kmland/display.php?ID=253&DISPOP=VRCPR)
Tool_Source: MEDALUS: The methodology used to identify, map, and quantify environmentally sensitive areas to soil degradation in Florida district (Amazonas, Peru) by computing SQI, CQI, VQI, and MQI, combining them into ESAI (the fourth-root product) to classify land into Non-affected, Potential, Fragile, and Critical categories and to inform restoration proposals.
Output: Environmentally Sensitive Areas (ESAI) suitability map [Non‑affected (N); Potential (P); Fragile (F1–F3); Critical (C1–C3)]
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Florida district, Amazonas, Peru; Sub-national: Bongará Province; Amazonas, Peru; National: Peru
Narrative: The NbS spatial prioritisation addressed ecological restoration in Florida district, Amazonas, Peru, using MEDALUS and GIS to map environmentally sensitive areas to soil degradation (ESAI) and to support five restoration NbS: organic manure production, cultivated and improved pastures with livestock management, native forest restoration, reservoirs on upper hills, and adoption of new technologies. Main inputs included four quality indicators (SQI, CQI, VQI, MQI) built from 12 parameters: SQI from parent material, slope, soil organic matter and soil texture; CQI from aridity index, erosivity and aspect; VQI from drought resistance, erosion protection and vegetation cover; MQI from agricultural intensity and landslides, with data sources such as ASTER DEM, WorldClim 2 climate data, Sentinel-2 imagery, INGENMET mass-movement susceptibility, ZEE-A, and field SOM samples (LABISAG), all at 30 m resolution for a 222.40 km2 area. The spatial method computed SQI, CQI, VQI and MQI by geometric means (SQI: ^1/4; CQI and VQI: ^1/3; MQI: ^1/2) and ESAI = (SQI×CQI×VQI×MQI) ^1/4, mapped in QGIS with index correlations in ArcGIS. Validation relied on in situ observations and field consistency, with ESAI identifying 2.96% as critical, 48.85% fragile, 15.48% potentially endangered, and 30.46% not threatened; outputs included ESAI and constituent indicator maps at 30 m resolution. The study area was Florida district (222.40 km2) in Amazonas, Peru. Climate risk and economic factors were included through CQI and MQI, respectively.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The data used to support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon request.

File: Molin et al. - 2018 - A landscape approach for cost‐effective large‐scale forest restoration.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: unassisted natural regeneration; assisted natural regeneration; ecological restoration plantations; riparian restoration
Input_Variables: Slope (Supporting Information Table S2); Distance to watercourses (Supporting Information Table S2); Distance to forest remnants (Supporting Information Table S2); Soil type (Supporting Information Table S2); Hydrographic network (Supporting Information Table S2); Forest type (Supporting Information Table S2); Rainfall (Supporting Information Table S2); Altitude (Supporting Information Table S2); Population density (Supporting Information Table S2); Rural population density (Supporting Information Table S2); Municipal GDP (Supporting Information Table S2); Road network (Supporting Information Table S2); Urban spots (Supporting Information Table S2); Predominant land uses (Supporting Information Table S2); Land cover 2000 (Landsat 5 TM) (Supporting Information Table S2); Land cover 2010 (Landsat 5 TM) (Supporting Information Table S2); Croplands (Landsat 5 TM) (Supporting Information Table S2); Native forest (Landsat 5 TM) (Supporting Information Table S2); Commercial tree plantations (Landsat 5 TM) (Supporting Information Table S2); Water bodies (Landsat 5 TM) (Supporting Information Table S2); Pastures (Landsat 5 TM) (Supporting Information Table S2); Perennial crops (Landsat 5 TM) (Supporting Information Table S2)
Spatial_Method: Weight-of-evidence Bayesian modeling to map per-pixel natural regeneration probability from biophysical and socio-economic drivers; Dinamica EGO cellular-automata landscape-dynamics modelling to simulate restoration costs and outcomes across the study area; scenario-based cost-effectiveness prioritization analysis comparing cost-reduction, riparian, and random strategies in three landscape units.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: Dinamica EGO: a discrete-type landscape dynamics model based on cellular automata used for geospatial analysis to simulate landscape changes and estimate spatial probabilities of natural forest regeneration, integrating biophysical and socio-economic drivers to inform restoration cost-effectiveness across the Piracicaba basin.
