Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT includes economic framing and outputs such as restoration costs (implementation costs, fencing, and land opportunity costs) and total costs in USD per hectare and cumulatively over the restoration target, a 10-year horizon with 10.5% discount applied to land rents, and cost‑effectiveness metrics (USD per ton of CO2 sequestered and USD per unit gain in landscape connectivity), plus comparative cost savings for different prioritization scenarios (e.g., 19.6%–34.8% total restoration cost reductions and specific dollar savings), thereby integrating economic viability and monetary outcomes into the output.
Narrative: The NbS addressed was landscape-scale forest restoration in Brazil’s Atlantic Forest, focusing on cost-effective restoration to increase carbon stocking and landscape connectivity through natural regeneration and restoration planting. Key inputs included Landsat-derived land‑cover maps for 2000 and 2010 (30 m pixels, seven classes), biophysical layers (soil type, hydrography, forest type, rainfall, slope, altitude) and socio‑economic layers (population density, rural population density, municipal GDP, road network, urban areas, predominant land uses), restoration costs (Ministério do Meio Ambiente 2017), land rental costs from official sources, and carbon and connectivity metrics (70 Mg C ha−1 aboveground stock; Integral Connectivity Index). A Bayesian weight‑of‑evidence model assessed drivers of natural regeneration, and the Dinamica EGO cellular‑automata model simulated regeneration probability (0–100%) across three 40,000 ha landscape units, with three restoration scenarios (cost‑reduction, riparian, random) targeting 15,000 ha. Outputs were maps of 2010 land cover, regeneration probability, restoration costs, land‑opportunity costs, and total costs at 1:50,000 with 30 m pixels; cost‑effectiveness for carbon and connectivity showed substantial savings under cost reduction (e.g., 19.6–34.8% across LUs; 20.9% when opportunity costs were included). The study covered the Piracicaba river basin (~12,500 km2). Climate risk was not explicitly included; economic costs and carbon stocking were.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data available via Zenodo https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.1256029

File: Morán‐Ordóñez et al. - 2022 - Multi-objective forest restoration planning in Costa Rica Balancing landscape connectivity and ecos.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Natural regeneration; Assisted forest regeneration; Passive restoration; Forest plantations; Coffee agroforestry systems
Input_Variables: Bio1 (WorldClim 2.0); Bio7 (WorldClim 2.0); Bio12 (WorldClim 2.0); Bio13 (WorldClim 2.0); Forest cover (%) per ha (2012 forest map of Costa Rica, SIREFOR; filled from 2005 map); Current land cover map (Volcanica Central Talamanca Biological Corridor official land cover map; Canet-Desanti 2016); Seed-dispersal habitat suitability (MaxEnt SDMs for 47 frugivorous birds; Appendix S1); Ecotourism habitat suitability (MaxEnt SDMs; Appendix S1); Carbon storage potential (InVEST Carbon Storage and Sequestration model; v3.7.0; Sharp et al. 2018); Carbon storage per ha by land cover (Vallet et al. 2016); Total added value per ha by land use (Coffee plantations, Pastures, Crops) (Vallet et al. 2016); Bird occurrence data (GBIF; eBird Observational Dataset) (GBIF; eBird Observational Dataset)
Analysis_Resolution: 1 hectare (planning units; each restoration unit is 1 ha, i.e., 0.01 km2)
Spatial_Method: Habitat suitability for seed dispersal and ecotourism was mapped with MaxEnt SDMs; carbon storage potential was mapped with InVEST; priority restoration areas were identified with Marxan spatial prioritization to maximize ecosystem-services provision and connectivity under multiple land-opportunity-cost scenarios and a connectivity penalty.
Method_Validation: Ten-fold cross-validated AUC for MaxEnt SDMs; Expert validation comparing target-group vs random background (target-group background validated as better); Selection of models with cross-validated AUC > 0.7 for downstream analysis.
Tool: Marxan (Ball et al., 2009) ; InVEST (Sharp et al., 2018) ; MaxEnt (Phillips et al., 2006; Phillips & Dudík, 2008)
Tool_Source: Marxan: spatial prioritization tool used to identify priority forest-restoration areas across the Volcanica Central Talamanca Biological Corridor to maximize forest-related ecosystem services (seed dispersal, ecotourism) and carbon storage while increasing connectivity, under scenarios that include or ignore land-use opportunity costs; InVEST: carbon storage/sequestration model used to quantify carbon storage potential and estimate potential changes in sequestration if non-forested areas were restored; MaxEnt: species distribution modeling used to map habitat suitability for 62 frugivorous bird species to derive subrogates for seed-dispersal and ecotourism services that feed into the prioritization.
Output: Restoration priority/allocation maps (Marxan best‑solution and selection‑frequency maps) [scenarios: Equal, Homog, Heter30/Heter50/Heter100; targets 0.01–20%]; Carbon sequestration potential map (InVEST: potential per‑ha carbon change if non‑forested areas restored); Seed‑dispersal potential map (stacked habitat‑suitability of 47 frugivorous bird species; current land cover); Ecotourism (birdwatching) potential map (stacked habitat‑suitability of 47 frugivorous bird species; assuming all non‑forest areas restored)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: they treat forest restoration as a NbS aimed at climate-change mitigation by prioritizing carbon sequestration, and demonstrate this by explicitly including carbon storage as an ecosystem service target in their planning and by tying restoration outcomes to Costa Rica’s decarbonization goals and PES incentives.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis explicitly embeds economics by treating land-use opportunity costs as the costs in Marxan’s objective function (OF = Cost_i + SPF*Feature Penalty_j + Connectivity Penalty_i) and by exploring Equal, Homog, and Heterogeneous cost scenarios, reporting monetary outputs such as total restoration costs in Millions of Colons (sum of opportunity costs for the selected restoration units) and showing how costs shift with scenario/targets, plus discussion of economic framing through Payments for Environmental Services (PES) and potential carbon-market incentives as factors that could affect viability and implementation.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Volcanica Central Talamanca Biological Corridor (VCTBC), Costa Rica; Local: Turrialba National Park; Barbilla National Park; Tapantí National Park
Narrative: The NbS addressed were landscape-scale forest restoration across the Volcanica Central Talamanca Biological Corridor (VCTBC) in central Costa Rica, aiming to boost forest connectivity and ecosystem-service provisioning (seed dispersal, ecotourism, and carbon storage). Key inputs included MaxEnt models for 62 frugivorous birds (47 with AUC > 0.7) derived from GBIF/eBird data and WorldClim bioclimatic variables, forest-cover predictors and a 2012 Costa Rica forest map, InVEST carbon storage outputs, and 51,852 ha of restoration-eligible land uses; ecosystem services were mapped at 1 ha resolution and planning units were 1 ha across a corridor of about 115,000 ha. Data sources cited included Canet-Desanti 2016 and Vallet et al. 2016. The spatial prioritization used Marxan to maximize three ESS (seed dispersal, ecotourism, carbon storage) and connectivity, testing Equal, Homog, and heterogeneous (Heter; 30/50/100% elevation-based) cost scenarios with 100 runs per scenario and a calibrated connectivity penalty. Validation relied on ten-fold cross-validation (AUC > 0.7 for 47 species) and expert assessment; all 95 ESS targets were achieved. Outputs were Marxan best solutions and 1 ha-resolution priority maps across the ~115,000 ha corridor, with land-use proportions varying by scenario. Economic considerations via opportunity costs were incorporated in the cost scenarios, and carbon storage provided climate-relevant information.

File: Niemeyer et al. - 2019 - Planning forest restoration within private land holdings with conservation co-benefits at the landsc.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Natural regeneration; Assisted natural regeneration; Active restoration based on tree planting
Input_Variables: Forest cover (Supplementary Materials); Land use (Supplementary Materials); Stream network (Supplementary Materials); Land slope (Supplementary Materials); Slope orientation (Supplementary Materials); Land curvature (Supplementary Materials); Counties division (Supplementary Materials); Probability for natural regeneration (Crouzeilles et al., Under review); Rural Environmental Registry (Supplementary Materials); APP along rivers (Law N° 12.651/2012); Legal Reserve (LR) (Law N° 12.651/2012); Forest remnants size (Patch attribute) (Supplementary Materials); Distance between forest remnants (Distance attribute) (Pascual-Hortal & Saura, 2006); Dispersal thresholds (poor 10 m; intermediate 700 m; good 3000 m) (Crouzeilles et al., 2010; 2014; Almeida-Gomes et al., 2016); Restoration implementation costs (Onda Verde NGO); Opportunity cost (Net Present Value for agricultural crops and livestock) (IBGE 2014; Conab 2016; EMBRAPA 2004; IEA 2016; Cepea 2016); Discount rate (8% per year) (Main rural credit lines in Brazil); Time horizon (20 years) (Native Vegetation Protection Law); 10-km buffer around REBIO Tingua (Niemeyer et al., 2019); Initial forest cover (Low 13%; Medium 24%; High 44%) (Niemeyer et al., 2019)
Spatial_Method: Multi-criteria spatial prioritization using the Integral Index of Connectivity (IIC) to quantify habitat availability across 1-ha planning units within a 10-km buffer around the Tingua reserve; calculation of environmental debts and transition costs; assessment of each unit’s contribution to habitat availability (DIIC); prioritization under five strategies (minimize opportunity cost; minimize transition cost; maximize habitat availability; maximize habitat-availability-to-transition-cost ratio; random); and 20-year restoration simulations to evaluate cost-effectiveness.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Restoration allocation/priority maps for NbS placement by strategy (minimize opportunity cost; minimize transition cost; maximize habitat availability; maximize habitat‑availability-to‑transition‑cost ratio; random) [classes: current forest; restored forest; restorable areas; non‑restorable]
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: They incorporate economic outputs and framing in the OUTPUT analysis, reporting costs and cost‑effectiveness (opportunity and transition costs, restoration implementation costs, all in USD), using Net Present Value (NPV) for rural activities with an 8% discount rate to estimate opportunity costs, total transition costs ranging from about US$34.7 million to US$100 million, and cost‑effectiveness as IIC/US$, while structuring restoration prioritization around economic criteria (Minimize opportunity cost, Minimize transition cost) alongside ecological targets.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Tingua Biological Reserve buffer zone (REBIO Tingua), Brazil; Sub-national: Rio de Janeiro; National: Brazil
Narrative: NbS addressed: restoration on private lands to deliver conservation co-benefits at landscape scale in Atlantic Forest; aligned with Native Vegetation Protection Law. Three 10,000-ha landscapes within REBIO Tingua’s buffer were analyzed at 1-ha planning units, with initial forest cover 13–44%. Inputs included forest cover, land use, streams and slope/aspect/curvature, county divisions, probability of natural regeneration, and Rural Environmental Registry data (IBGE ’14; Conab ’16; EMBRAPA ’04). A seven-step framework calculated habitat availability via the Integral Index of Connectivity (IIC) for three dispersal capacities (poor 10 m, intermediate 700 m, good 3000 m). Five strategies were tested, including random; Step 7: 10 restoration events over 20 years with TC = OC + (1−PNR) × RIC. Kruskal–Wallis showed differences (p<0.05); results indicated up to 12× habitat gain vs random and savings up to US$4.5 million. Outputs: 1-ha priority units, restoration IIC, cost-effectiveness for landscapes in Rio de Janeiro; climate risk not included; economic costs embedded.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2019.135262

File: Orsi and Geneletti - 2009 - Identifying priority areas for Forest Landscape Restoration in Chiapas (Mexico) An operational appr.pdf
Input_Variables: Distance from ecological corridors (Biosphere Reserves and ecological corridor maps; Corredor Biologico Mesoamericano); Distance from existing forest (Land cover map from LANDSAT ETM imagery 1999–2000; UNAM & INEGI); Distance from protected areas (Biosphere Reserves and ecological corridor maps; Corredor Biologico Mesoamericano); Tree species richness (Elevation and aspect heterogeneity derived from elevation data; DEM-derived); Distance from agricultural fields (LANDSAT ETM land-use maps; UNAM & INEGI); Distance from roads (LANDSAT ETM land-use maps; UNAM & INEGI); Distance from urban areas (LANDSAT ETM land-use maps; UNAM & INEGI); Risk of soil erosion (Slope, rainfall and soil type data; derived from the land cover map); Land cover map (LANDSAT ETM imagery; UNAM & INEGI); Poverty map (Indice de Marginacion; CONAPO 2005)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based spatial multicriteria analysis to produce two-factor suitability maps (B and F) via value-function scoring; thresholding of B and F to extract contiguous priority areas; analysis of landscape configuration with edge density and mean shape index to design and compare reforestation options.
Method_Validation: Sensitivity analysis; Validation of geomorphology as a proxy for tree species richness by comparing the proxy map with a map of faunistic richness.
Tool: DEFINITE (Janssen et al., 2003); FRAGSTATS (McGarigal et al., 2002)
Tool_Source: DEFINITE: Used to perform non-spatial multicriteria analysis and conduct a sensitivity analysis to evaluate and compare reforestation options across ecological and socioeconomic criteria under different weighting scenarios; FRAGSTATS: Used to compute landscape fragmentation metrics (edge density and mean shape index) to assess how reforestation options affect fragmentation and patch morphology.
Output: B-factor suitability map (need-for-reforestation / biodiversity priority); F-factor suitability map (feasibility/“restorability” suitability); Reforestation options map (14 alternative spatial allocation maps of priority reforestation sites); Frequency/core map of reforestation options (selection frequency / shared “reforestation core” areas); Best reforestation option map (Option 10 allocation; thresholds B=0.64, F=0.69)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis includes economic aspects by incorporating a Land use conversion cost and livelihood/poverty considerations as part of the socioeconomic criteria, integrated through a 0–1 scoring multicriteria framework that ranks reforestation options (with hectares and criterion scores as outputs); monetary metrics (ROI/NPV/monetary cost-benefit) or payments for ecosystem services are not reported.
Narrative: The NbS addressed was Forest Landscape Restoration (reforestation) in Chiapas, Mexico, identifying priority landscape-scale sites to conserve biodiversity and improve livelihoods. Inputs included ecological criteria (distance to ecological corridors, to existing forest, to protected areas; proxy tree richness via geomorphology; soil erosion risk) and socioeconomic criteria (distance from agricultural fields, roads, urban areas; poverty/Indice de Marginacion from CONAPO; feasibility). Data sources encompassed LANDSAT ETM vegetation/land-use maps (1999–2000), PEOT Chiapas, biosphere reserves La Sepultura and El Triunfo, ecological corridor/land-use layers, and CONAPO poverty data, all at 30 m resolution. The spatial method was a raster-based multicriteria approach: scores were transformed to 0–1 value functions and aggregated into two maps, B (biodiversity need) and F (restorability), which were crossed via threshold pairs (b,f) to define contiguous reforestation options. Fourteen options (15,059–16,141 ha) were evaluated under three weight sets using ILWIS 3.3 and R; sensitivity (10% perturbations, 10,000 iterations) showed robust rankings, with option 10 best under balanced and option 9 best under socioeconomic. Outputs included 30 m B/F maps (0–0.95 and 0–1), 14 options, a core-area frequency map (~28,000 ha total; ~7,000 core) and a poverty layer for Frailesca (~18,500 km2). Climate risk not included; economic considerations present via poverty and land-use costs.

Narrative: An expert-panel Delphi approach was used to identify forest restoration priorities as an NbS for biodiversity conservation. The NbS addressed restoration prioritisation. Inputs from literature and expert opinion yielded 389 criteria and 669 indicators, later reduced to 20 biodiversity criteria (B) and 18 feasibility criteria (F); 345 for B and 324 for F. Data sources included GIS literature; UNEP-WCMC FRIS and ReForLan. The Delphi recruited 37 participants in round one and 30 in round two, followed by a face-to-face meeting in Salta, Argentina to finalise results. Face-to-face meeting shortlisted 22 indicators (14 B, 8 F). The spatial method proposed mapping indicators with GIS, then summing standardized indicators to produce two outputs (B and F) yielding maps of tens to hundreds of km2. The study drew on a sample from Europe, North America and Latin America; climate and economic indicators were included, though socio-economic criteria were not carried forward.

File: Phua and Minowa - 2004 - A GIS-based multi-criteria decision making approach to forest conservation planning at a landscape s.pdf
Input_Variables: Riparian vegetation (not specified)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria decision-making using compromise programming to integrate forest conservation priority maps with a calculated separation distance; clustering analysis to identify potential conservation areas and delineate potential new protected areas.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Forest conservation priority map; Delineated potential new protected area polygons (359 ha neighboring Kinabalu Park; 4,361 ha west of the park; group of 11 polygons totaling 2,050 ha); Green-corridor linkage map between proposed protected areas and Kinabalu Park
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: The NbS addressed was forest conservation planning as a nature-based solution in Kinabalu area, Sabah, Malaysia. Key inputs referenced preferences, criteria and indicators, notably riparian vegetation, but specific data sources were not listed. The spatial approach used a GIS-based multi-criteria decision making framework with compromise programming to fuse forest conservation priority maps from decision groups via a calculated separation distance, and a clustering analysis to identify potential conservation areas for delineating new protected areas. Validation approach was not described. Key results identified two polygons adjacent to Kinabalu Park and a group of 11 polygons totaling 2050 ha in western Kinabalu Park, with recommendations to include a 359 ha polygon and a 4361 ha area as new protected areas and to construct a green corridor; riparian protection was emphasized. Outputs included priority maps and polygon delineations at hectare-scale; geography: Kinabalu area, Sabah, Malaysia. Climate risk or economic considerations were not included.

File: Poccard-Chapuis et al. - 2021 - Mapping Land Suitability to Guide Landscape Restoration in the Amazon.pdf
Input_Variables: Soil texture (Laurent et al. [44]); Slope (TOPODATA [59]); River network (Pimentel et al. [57]); Floodplain (HAND model [60–62]); Ravines (Pereira et al. [58], Pimentel et al. [57]); Groundwater influence (Primary data)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based, rule-based spatial overlay in ArcGIS that integrates four biophysical layers (soil texture, flood risk from HAND, hydrographic network, and slope) to delineate land suitability classes on a 30 m grid using an attribute‑based decision rule set and the Union tool.
Method_Validation: Field verification / ground-truthing
Tool: HAND model (Rennó et al., 2008); DINAMICA (Soares-Filho et al., 2002)
Tool_Source: HAND model : Floodplain mapping and flood risk delineation by computing Height Above the Nearest Drainage from a DEM to identify flood-prone areas for inclusion in land suitability mapping; DINAMICA : An automated cell-based landscape dynamics model (derived from DINAMICA) used to simulate and explore spatially explicit land-use change scenarios (forest, agriculture, pasture) to understand landscape dynamics and inform restoration planning.
Output: Land suitability map (classes: Plateau; Valley slope; Floodplain; Escarpment; Ravines); Municipal landscape restoration zoning map (classes: Agricultural intensification; Forest restoration)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: Climate hazards are treated as a risk that could limit NbS outcomes by shaping where landscape restoration and agricultural intensification are feasible, i.e., influencing land-suitability categories; the authors demonstrate this by integrating hazard information such as flood risk into the suitability framework and by noting that risk maps are reshaped by biophysical events like fire or drought, constraining NbS deployment in the output.
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was landscape restoration in the Brazilian Amazon, focusing on organizing landscape uses to couple agricultural intensification with forest restoration and associated ecosystem services, based on a fine-scale land-suitability map for Paragominas. Main inputs included biophysical layers (soil texture from Laurent et al. 2015; slope from TOPODATA/Embrapa classes; floodplain via HAND; river network from Pimentel et al. and Pereira et al.), and land-use/ socioeconomic data (deforestation from INPE/PRODES; forest cover from mapbioma.org; pasture and mechanized agriculture from MapBioma and Gibbs et al. 2015; land tenure from SEMAS-PA SICAR; remoteness from authors), all harmonized to a 30 m grid and managed in ArcGIS. The spatial method built four maps (soil texture, slope, floodplains, hydrography) and combined them into a single land-suitability map using defined attribute rules to delineate five classes (Valley slope, Plateau, Floodplain, Escarpment, Ravines), with a 10 m HAND-based adjustment for flood-prone areas and a Union-based integration into a 30 × 30 m geodatabase. Validation relied on field surveys with farmers and ground checks, plus cross-analysis with land use, deforestation, and tenure data, showing that Plateau areas (753,028 ha; 38%) dominated agricultural intensification, while Floodplain, Escarpment, and Ravines were prioritized for forest restoration; overall deforestation declined after 2012 in most classes, with slower reductions on the plateau. Outputs comprise a five-class land-suitability map at 30 m resolution, embedded in a broader spatial database including land use, remoteness, and tenure, and a municipal zoning/land-restoration planning tool (Figure 6). Geography is at the municipal scale of Paragominas, Pará, Brazil (study area 19,342 km2). Climate risk was not explicitly modeled beyond hydrological floodplain mapping, while economic considerations were integrated via land tenure, remoteness, deforestation patterns, and agricultural market dynamics.

File: Rajaonarivelo and Williams - 2022 - Remote Sensing-Based Land Suitability Analysis for Forest Restoration in Madagascar.pdf
Input_Variables: Land use/Land cover (Landsat 8 OLI 2021; USGS HDX); Distance from protected areas and forest patches (Protected areas data; forest patches from LULC); Distance from settlements (Landsat 8 OLI; Google Earth Madagascar—Geofabrik); Distance from roads (Geofabrik Madagascar); Soil erosion (RUSLE-based erosion map; CRU rainfall data; FAO Global Soil Data; Elevation); Rainfall (CRU Database); Global Soil Data (FAO Database); Elevation (ASTER GDEM; NASA Earthdata)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multicriteria land suitability analysis that integrates five spatial criteria (distance to protected areas/forest patches, land cover class, distance to settlements, distance to roads, and soil erosion risk via RUSLE), reclassifies each criterion to four suitability classes, and combines them with equal ecological and socio-economic weights to identify priority restoration areas.
Method_Validation: Accuracy assessment for LULC classification using a confusion matrix (Producer’s Accuracy, User’s Accuracy, Overall Accuracy) with a Kappa of 0.85; Cross-check of the suitability results with the Madagascar National Strategy on Forest Landscape Restoration (expert/stakeholder validation)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Forest restoration suitability/priority map (S1 highly suitable; S2 moderately suitable; S3 marginally suitable; N not suitable)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They treat climate-related soil erosion risk as a hazard that can limit restoration feasibility and performance by including an erosion-prone criterion in the suitability model and demonstrating its impact with an erosion-risk map that shifts areas into not or less suitable classifications, thereby identifying erosion-prone zones as constraints on NbS outcomes.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target NbS (forest landscape restoration) to reduce climate-related risks by restoring in erosion-prone areas to stabilize soils and protect watershed services, and they demonstrate this through a multicriteria prioritization that maps and selects highly suitable restoration areas tied to soil erosion risk and proximity to forests, illustrating potential risk reduction and ecosystem-service benefits.
Economics: Yes: Economic aspects are integrated through a socioeconomic (SE) factor in the output analysis, balanced with ecological criteria (weights 0.5 and 0.5); SE criteria include settlements, roads, and soil erosion, with explicit justification that greater distance from settlements and roads reduces restoration costs and improves feasibility, thereby shaping the final suitability map and restoration priority decisions.
Narrative: The NbS addressed was forest landscape restoration (FLR) in Madagascar, identifying priority restoration areas within the Mahavavy watershed to enhance forest cover and ecosystem services. Main inputs included a 30 m resolution land use/land cover map derived from Landsat 8 OLI (2021) and settlement mapping (Landsat 8 OLI with Google Earth reference), roads from Geofabrik, protected areas and forest patches, elevation from ASTER GDEM, soil data from FAO Global Soil Data, and rainfall data from the CRU dataset, plus boundary data for Ambilobe District and the Mahavavy watershed. The spatial method was a GIS-based multicriteria analysis: five criteria were mapped, reclassified to four suitability classes (S1–N), and combined with equal ecological (distance to protected areas/forest patches, LULC, soil erosion) and socio-economic (distance to settlements, distance to roads) weights (total ecological 0.50, socio-economic 0.50) to produce a final suitability map; soil erosion was computed with the Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation (RUSLE) using R, K, LS, C, and P factors. Validation included an accuracy assessment of the LULC map (overall accuracy 87.1%, Kappa 0.85) and cross-checking results with Madagascar’s National Strategy on Forest Landscape Restoration; key results showed 143,680.14 ha (27.91%) highly suitable, 159,127.63 ha (30.91%) moderately suitable, and 137,031.23 ha (26.62%) not suitable within a total assessed area of 514,789.2 ha. Outputs comprised criterion maps and a final 30 m resolution suitability map for priority restoration areas in the Mahavavy watershed (northwestern Madagascar). Climate risk was not explicitly modeled, though soil erosion (an erosion/climate-related process) was included; economic considerations were represented by the settlements and roads criteria.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Publicly available datasets were analyzed in this study. This data can be found here: https://data.humdata.org; https://download.geofabrik.de/africa/madagascar.html; https://data.apps.fao.org/map/catalog/srv/eng/catalog.search#/metadata/446ed430-8383-11db-b9b2-000d939bc5d8; https://crudata.uea.ac.uk/cru/data/hrg/

File: Ribeiro et al. - 2020 - A spatially explicit index for mapping Forest Restoration Vocation (FRV) at the landscape scale App.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Natural regeneration; Assisted natural regeneration; Afforestation (forest plantation with native trees for conservation/biodiversity); Agroforestry systems
Input_Variables: Favourability to natural regeneration (Nunes et al., 2017); Priority for conservation (MMA, 2006); Mean Patch Size (FBDS, 2017); Land use: forest (FBDS, 2017); Connectivity Metrics (P2, 2017); Area under restoration initiatives (ha) (UFV, 2018; FBDS, 2017); Number of restoration projects (UFV, 2018; FBDS, 2017); Number of nurseries (UFV, 2018; FBDS, 2017); Riparian APP and Recharge Areas (MMA, 2006); Institutional capacity to produce AFSs (UFV, 2018); Production systems based on fruits and coffee (PAM - IBGE, 2016); Production systems based on Maize and beans (PAM - IBGE, 2016); Rural Population in small-scale farming (IBGE, 2016); Land Use transitions (CSR, 2012); Land use classes in 2012-2030 (CSR, 2012); Altimetry (ASTER, NASA); Slope (ASTER, NASA); Protected areas (Percentage of municipality covered by protected areas all types) (MMA, 2006)
Spatial_Method: Spatially explicit multicriteria modelling in Dinamica EGO; PCA-based reduction of variables; integration of biophysical, climatic, landscape and socio-institutional layers (APPs and LR, riparian recharge areas, slope/accumulation flow, ENN connectivity, land-use history, precipitation) to produce 900 m2 pixel-based favourability maps for natural regeneration, afforestation with native species and agroforestry systems; application of a 5×5 window for accumulation and distance-weighted influence to allocate priority areas.
Method_Validation: Stakeholder workshops and expert meetings (stakeholder validation); calibration of the natural-regeneration favourability model; no field verification/ground-truth validation was performed (acknowledged as needing field validation).
Tool: Dinamica EGO (http://csr.ufmg.br/dinamica/) ; Otimizagro (Soares-Filho et al., 2016; https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0152311) ; FRAGSTATS (McGarigal, Cushman & Ene, 2002; FragStats: Spatial Pattern Analysis Program for Quantifying Landscape Structure, Gen Tech Rep PNW-GTR-651)
Tool_Source: Dinamica EGO: A spatially explicit modelling tool used to integrate biophysical and socio-economic layers and to generate maps (e.g., slope, flow-direction, and cumulative-flow) for deriving natural-regeneration favourability and other FRV layers. ; Otimizagro: A land-use transition simulator used to project 2012–2030 transitions across 229 municipalities, providing data on future land-use changes to inform the FRV analysis, especially the Agroforestry Systems modality. ; FRAGSTATS: A landscape pattern analysis package used to compute landscape metrics (e.g., mean patch size, connectivity/ENN) from the LULC map to quantify landscape structure and feed into FRV variables.
Output: Vocation for Natural Regeneration (favourability map; classes low–high; medium–high ≥50); Vocation for Afforestation with Native Species (conservation priority map; classes low–high); Vocation for Agroforestry Systems (AFS priority map; classes low–high); Integrated Forest Restoration Vocation (FRV) priority/allocation map by modality (natural regeneration / conservation afforestation / agroforestry)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis incorporates economic considerations by explicitly embedding socio-economic and institutional factors into the FRV, linking restoration choices to livelihoods and income (e.g., agroforestry and smallholder involvement) and grounding decisions in observed investment scales (roughly US$300 million for 40,000 ha, i.e., about R$1.2 billion) and production-system data, thereby framing restoration modality selection around economic livelihoods and investment context.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Rio Doce basin; Minas Gerais; Espírito Santo; National: Brazil
Narrative: The study addressed forest restoration as a Nature-based Solution by developing a Spatially Explicit Forest Restoration Vocation (FRV) index to map three restoration modalities: natural regeneration (passive), afforestation with native species for conservation, and agroforestry systems (AFSs). The main inputs comprised a 114‑variable database at 30 m pixel (900 m2 cells), drawn from sources such as the Brazilian Forest Code (APPs and Lands of Permanent Preservation; LR), protected areas (MMA 2006), riparian APP and recharge areas, landscape metrics from FBDS and FRAGSTAT, slope/altitude from ASTER, land-use transitions (2012–2030), precipitation, ENN connectivity, production systems (beans/coffee), rural population (IBGE 2016), nurseries and cooperatives, NGOs, and municipal production data (Otimizagro, PAM‑IBGE 2016; EMATER). Spatially explicit modelling in Dinamica EGO combined these via four steps, including PCA reduction and three FRV sub-indices (natural regeneration, afforestation, agroforestry), producing 0–100 favourability maps (reclassified to 1–10) at 30 m resolution, with a 5×5 window to identify accumulation areas and landscape connectivity to inform policy. Validation relied on stakeholder workshops (12 meetings; 5 workshops); results indicated 3.2 Mha with medium–high natural-regeneration favourability, 38% of anthropized areas suitable for passive restoration, and about 4.3 Mha deeply degraded needing active restoration, supporting a plan to invest ~US$300 million (R$1.2 billion) to restore 40,000 ha (0.05% of the basin). Outputs include FRV maps and three modality maps at 30 m, enabling monitoring and landscape-scale planning across the Rio Doce basin (229 municipalities; ≈86,725 km2) in SE Brazil; climate risk was incorporated via annual precipitation in regeneration favourability, and economic/institutional considerations (rural population, production systems, institutional capacity) were embedded to reflect livelihoods and governance.

File: Schroth et al. - 2009 - Towards a climate change adaptation strategy for coffee communities and ecosystems in the Sierra Mad.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Promote traditional coffee shade; Restore degraded, flood-prone and ecologically sensitive areas; Develop and implement a comprehensive fire management plan; Increase water efficiency in coffee production and processing; Promote agricultural diversification; Carry out zoning of vulnerability and adaptation needs; Make crop insurance available to small producers; Test new coffee varieties; Strengthen community organization and capacity building
Input_Variables: BIO1 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO2 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO3 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO4 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO5 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO6 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO7 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO8 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO9 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO10 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO11 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO12 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO13 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO15 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO16 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO18 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005); BIO19 (WorldClim, Hijmans et al. 2005)
Spatial_Method: MAXENT crop suitability modeling using downscaled climate surfaces from 15 GCMs to map present and 2050s suitability for Coffea arabica; ensemble analysis with model agreement and 95% CIs and coefficient of variation; overlay with observed coffee farm locations to identify priority suitability areas.
Method_Validation: Model agreement across 15 GCMs; 95% confidence intervals around the mean suitability change; coefficient of variation (CV) among models; Tukey’s outlier test used to exclude two divergent models; overlay/validation against observed coffee farm locations (COMCAFE data) to assess present suitability predictions.
Tool_Source: MAXENT: A maximum-entropy modeling approach used to relate present Arabica coffee farm locations (6629 sites, altitude >500 m) to 17–18 bioclimatic variables, downscaled GCM climate surfaces from 15 models to predict future suitability (2050s) across 1-km grids, producing probability maps and assessing uncertainty (model agreement, 95% CI, CV) to infer altitudinal shifts and key climatic drivers of suitability changes.
Output: Modeled Arabica coffee suitability change map (present vs 2050s) [high suitability >60% / low suitability <40%]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: climate hazards are treated as a risk that could undermine the feasibility and long-term performance of shade-coffee NbS by reducing future suitability and increasing livelihood volatility; the authors demonstrate this through scenario-based future suitability projections, hazard framing of extreme events, and a risk-driven adaptation plan (zoning, crop insurance, diversification).
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors explicitly target climate-hazard zones for NbS-based adaptation by proposing zoning of vulnerability and adaptation needs to identify areas where shade, forest restoration, and diversification can reduce climate risks. They demonstrate this through risk-based zoning outputs and by citing evidence that complex shade reduces hurricane-related landslide damage on coffee farms.
Economics: Yes: Economic framing is integrated in the OUTPUTs, with emphasis on profitability/viability of smallholder coffee under climate change, market risk, and livelihoods; the analysis proposes economic instruments and diversification (PES, crop insurance, forest payments, complementary income sources) as adaptation outputs, and cites monetary references (US$85/quintal viability threshold, hurricane losses ~US$4 million, total damages ~21 billion pesos) to ground decisions, though it does not report ROI/NPV/ cost-benefit ratios or explicit economic suitability scores.
Narrative: The NbS addressed was maintaining biodiversity-friendly shade coffee landscapes in the Sierra Madre de Chiapas, Mexico. Inputs included 6629 Arabica farm locations (>500 m) from COMCAFE, 19 bioclimatic variables (BIO14 excluded) from downscaled GCMs, WorldClim baseline (1950–2000) and 2050s projections from 15 GCMs (A2a) at 1km. The spatial method used MAXENT to relate current farm locations to climatic variables and project to the 2050s, with ensemble mean across models and forward regression for variable importance; Divergent models (NCAR-PCM1, BCCR-BCM2.0) were removed after Tukey’s test. Outputs were 1 km resolution suitability maps for present and 2050s, with high-suitability area (>60%) falling from 265,400 ha to 6,000 ha within 2.36 million ha Sierra Madre. Agreement, 95% CIs, CV among models were reported. Climate risk was included; economic aspects were addressed in adaptation options and profitability. Geographic scope: Sierra Madre de Chiapas, Mexico.

File: Schulz and Schröder - 2017 - Identifying suitable multifunctional restoration areas for Forest Landscape Restoration in Central C.pdf
Input_Variables: Elevation (IGM 1990); Slope (IGM 1990); Cosine of Aspect (IGM 1990); Sine of Aspect (IGM 1990); Potential Insolation (IGM 1990); Distance from Rivers (IGM 1990); Topographic Wetness Index (TWI) (IGM 1990); Topographic Position Index (TPI) (Guisan et al. 1999); Bioclimatic variables (WorldClim; Hijmans et al. 2005); Distance to Cities >20,000 inhabitants (INE 2003); Distance to villages and towns <20,000 inhabitants (INE 2003); Distance to Primary Roads (IGM 1990); Distance to Secondary Roads (IGM 1990); Land Cover 1985 (Schulz et al. 2010); Land Cover 1999 (Schulz et al. 2010); Land Cover 2008 (Schulz et al. 2010); Soil Erodibility (CONAMA 2002); Rainfall Erosivity (CONAMA 2002); Streams (IGM 1990); Permanent Bareland (1985, 1999, 2008; Schulz et al. 2010); Permanent Lentic Water (2008; Schulz et al. 2010); Existing Forest (2008 Land Cover; Schulz et al. 2010); Built-up Areas (2008 Land Cover; Schulz et al. 2010)
Spatial_Method: Habitat suitability modeling (logistic regression) to predict restoration suitability and regeneration potential; spatial multi-criteria analysis (SMCE) to map multifunctional hotspots by overlaying restoration/regeneration feasibility with three potential forest functions (habitat, erosion prevention, carbon storage) and applying spatial constraints to identify priority restoration and regeneration areas.
Method_Validation: Sixfold bootstrapped internal cross-validation (sixfold bootstrapping with 10,000 bootstrap samples); ROC AUC values: restoration suitability = 0.84, regeneration potential = 0.82.
Tool: InVEST 2.5.3 and InVEST 3 (Natural Capital Project 2013) (http://www.naturalcapitalproject.org/InVEST.html); Linkage Mapper 1.0.3 (McRae and Kavanagh 2011) (www.circuitscape.org/linkagemapper); Conefor 2.6 (Saura and Tornè 2009) (www.conefor.org); GUIDOS 1.4 (Vogt 2012) (http://forest.jrc.europa.eu/download/software/guidos/)
Tool_Source: InVEST 2.5.3: Used to estimate potential erosion prevention by running its soil loss/sediment retention module (USLE-based) on the land-cover data to map how restoration would reduce soil erosion; InVEST 3: Used to map potential carbon sequestration/storage via its carbon storage/sequestration module, comparing current land cover carbon stocks with restoration scenarios; Linkage Mapper 1.0.3: Used to identify least-cost corridors between forest components, feeding into corridor planning after connectivity components were identified; Conefor 2.6: Used to evaluate the connectivity contributions of core patches and connecting links via the integral index of connectivity (IIC) to select important network components for restoration planning; GUIDOS 1.4: Used to process MSPA-derived outputs (node and link files) after applying MSPA to the forest–non-forest map, including handling edge effects, to characterize structural connectivity.
Output: Multifunctional restoration areas (allocation map); Multifunctional regeneration areas (allocation map); Potential carbon sequestration map (sequestration potential, Mg C ha^-1); Potential erosion prevention map (soil erosion reduction potential); Potential habitat connectivity map (corridors/core areas)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They frame climate change as a risk that could limit long-term restoration success by shifting suitable habitats beyond the historical patterns used to drive their maps, and they demonstrate this by discussing no-analogue future climates and recommending climate-change–aware analyses alongside their outputs.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors explicitly target restoration to maximize carbon sequestration (mitigation) alongside other NbS benefits like erosion prevention and habitat functions, aligning with REDD+ and CBD targets, and they demonstrate this through maps of potential carbon storage and restoration suitability, showing multifunctional hotspots where restoration feasibility and carbon benefits coincide.
Narrative: NbS: Forest Landscape Restoration in Central Chile identified multifunctional restoration and regeneration areas to strengthen habitat function, carbon storage, erosion prevention, and connectivity. Main inputs included 30 m rasters for elevation, slope, aspect (cos/sin), insolation, distance to rivers, TWI, and TPI; 18 WorldClim bioclimatic variables (Hijmans et al. 2005); land-cover maps from 1985, 1999, and 2008; and socio‑economic distances to cities (>20,000) and towns (<20,000) plus roads, based on 12,888 samples. The spatial approach used two logistic regression models to predict restoration suitability (AUC 0.84) and regeneration potential (AUC 0.82), with spatial constraints; three function maps were integrated via spatial multi‑criteria analysis under four weighting schemes to locate multifunctional hotspots (M) and coldspots. Outputs included 50,375 ha of designated restoration areas (3.8% of 13,175 km2), with 37,320 ha restoration‑feasible and 12,557 ha regeneration‑feasible; hotspots totaled 123,805 ha (9.4%) at 30 m. Central Chile was the study region; climate predictors were used, and carbon sequestration was included as a function.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: R-code in Data S1 and Data S2 (supplementary materials); Data: Data S1 and Data S2 supplementary data files available in Supporting Information at http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ecs2.1644/full

File: Silva et al. - 2017 - PRIORITY AREAS FOR FOREST CONSERVATION, AIMING AT THE MAINTENANCE OF WATER RESOURCES, THROUGH THE MU.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope (DEM - IGC topographic map 1:10,000; Piedade); Flow accumulation (DEM - IGC topographic map 1:10,000; Piedade); Aspect (DEM - IGC topographic map 1:10,000; Piedade); Land-use / land-cover (SPOT 2.5m 2010; SMA-CPLA); Watershed limits and drainage network (DEM-derived from IGC topographic map 1:10,000)
Spatial_Method: Multicriteria evaluation (MCE) using a Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) of normalized criteria maps (slope, flow accumulation, aspect, land-use/land-cover) with weights derived from pairwise comparisons (AHP) in a GIS, and Pearson correlation used to evaluate factor contributions to the priority map.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.0078 < 0.1); Pearson correlation validation between the priority map and criterion maps using a 500-point stratified random grid.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Priority areas for forest conservation (very high, high, medium, low, very low)
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: The NbS addressed were forest conservation aimed at maintaining water resources in two micro-watersheds (W1: 549 ha; W2: 598 ha) in Piedade, southeast São Paulo, Brazil. Main inputs were slope, flow accumulation, aspect, and land-use/land-cover derived from a 2.5 m SPOT map (2010) and a 1:10,000 DEM (IGC); maps were normalized to 0–1. AHP-based weighted linear combination (WLC) was used to multiply each factor by its weight and sum to a priority score; weights: land-use 0.4159, slope 0.3846, flow accumulation 0.1257, aspect 0.0738. Validation used a 500-point stratified grid with Pearson correlation. Results: W1 had 14.4% very high and 26.6% high; W2 had 16.6% very high and 29.2% high; highest levels accounted for 41% (W1) and 45.8% (W2). Outputs were two 2.5 m-resolution priority maps, classified into five levels. Geographic scope encompassed the Piedade municipality in São Paulo state, with the two watersheds. Climate risk or economic considerations were not included.

File: Souza et al. - 2021 - Spatial targeting approach for a payment for ecosystem services scheme in a peri-urban wellhead area.pdf
Input_Variables: Rural properties boundaries (CAR, 2018a); Road network (ANTT 2017; IBGE 2017b); Hydrography (Costa et al., 2018); Geology (Costa et al., 2018); Soils (Costa et al., 2018); Land cover and land use (Costa et al., 2018); Geodynamics processes (Costa et al., 2018); Accelerated erosion potential (Costa et al., 2018); Potential for aquifer contamination (Costa et al., 2019); PPA and LR areas (CAR database)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multicriteria evaluation (MCE) using a weighted linear combination (WLC) of standardized criteria with weights derived from Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP), including Boolean constraints and a one-at-a-time sensitivity analysis, to produce priority maps for forest restoration; these maps are then overlaid with land-use opportunity-cost data to identify high-priority, low-cost PES sites.
Method_Validation: Sensitivity analysis (One-At-a-Time weight variation); AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.02 < 0.10); Cross-tabulation of factor maps against the WLC priority classes and environmental characteristics to verify concordance with land-use/hydrological features.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Priority areas for forest restoration (very low / low / medium / high / very high); Opportunity cost (reference payment) map by rural property (US$.ha−1.year−1); Priority areas for PES implementation with reference payment values by property (target areas, payments US$.year−1)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT integrates economics by overlaying MCE results with economic valuations, reporting NPV and EAE for land uses, reference PES payments (US$ per ha per year) and total annual PES outlay, plus total annual value of agricultural production (≈US$3.28 million) to identify high-hydrological-value areas at low opportunity cost and quantify compensation to landowners.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Feijão River watershed (FRW);São Carlos;São Paulo;Brazil
Narrative: NbS addressed were forest restoration to conserve hydrological services through PES in Feijão River watershed, SP. Inputs included environmental criteria tied to erosion and water resources (proximity to surface water, forest patches, urban areas and roads, erosion potential, aquifer contamination risk) and land-use data from CAR, roads (ANTT/IBGE), hydrography, geology, soils and GeoEye land cover; data were standardized to 0–1 at 10 m and georeferenced to SIRGAS2000/UTM 23S. The GIS-based multicriteria evaluation used Weighted Linear Combination; seven factors weighted via AHP (CR 0.02) and aggregated with constraints to yield five priority levels. Validation used CR<0.10 and a sensitivity analysis; results: 25.6% of eligible areas very high priority and 37.3% high (63% combined), covering 898.27 ha (3.7%) and 99 rural properties, with PES payments of US$52,018.08 per year. Outputs included a 10 m priority map and payments; climate risk not modeled; economic considerations via opportunity costs and PES payments were included.

File: Stephan et al. - 2020 - Local ecological niche modelling to provide suitability maps for 27 forest tree species in edge cond.pdf
Input_Variables: DEM (Lebanese Army Geographical Department); IMI (Hill shade; Curvature; Flow Accumulation; Available water holding capacity); PDIR (Slope from DEM; Folded Aspect from DEM); EQ (Cumulative Annual Precipitation; Mean of Minimum Temperature of the Coldest Month; Mean of Maximum Temperature of the Hottest Month); CC (Cloud rasters); DFS (DEM); Tmin (WorldClim 1970-2000); P (Isohyets); Tmax (WorldClim 1970-2000)
Spatial_Method: Ecological Niche Modelling (ENM) using MaxEnt on presence-only data to generate suitability maps for 27 tree species, evaluated with AUC and predictor-contribution analyses.
Method_Validation: AUC evaluation of model robustness; Jack-knife test of variable importance; Likelihood of occurrence (LOC) values and LOC50 area validation
Tool_Source: MaxEnt : A presence-only species distribution modeling tool used to generate logistic suitability maps (likelihood of occurrence) for 27 tree species by contrasting presence data with background points; its performance was evaluated with AUC, and variable importance assessed via jackknife tests to identify the most influential predictors for each species, informing local-scale reforestation and conservation planning.
Output: Suitability maps for 27 native forest tree species (likelihood-of-occurrence classes; LOC and LOC>0.5 areas)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They treat climate change as a risk to NbS by showing that future climate scenarios could shrink or shift the suitable ranges of the studied species, potentially jeopardizing reforestation success, and they demonstrate this through scenario analyses with multiple climate pathways and future suitability maps to guide management.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: the study treats forest restoration/conservation as NbS to reduce climate risks and contribute to climate change mitigation, and it demonstrates this with scenario-based prioritisation under future climate conditions and by producing suitability maps to guide where NbS actions will most effectively reduce risk.
Narrative: The NbS spatial prioritisation addressed local-scale reforestation and forest management in Lebanon by producing suitability maps for 27 forest tree species to guide conservation and restoration. Key inputs included 13,837 presence records from two field sources and WorldClim predictors (1970–2000) such as annual precipitation, Tmin, Tmax, EQ, DEM (10 m), distance from the sea, cloud cover (May–July), and IMI components reduced to slope, aspect and AWC; data from CNRS soil maps and the Lebanese Army Geographic Department, plus a 2018 survey, at 30 m resolution. MaxEnt v3.4.1 was run in two fits (full predictors, then a second omitting PDIR/IMI and adding aspect, slope and AWC) with background cells defined by Lebanon. Validation used AUC (values >0.5, many >0.9; max 0.994 for Quercus cedrorum). Outputs were species-specific suitability maps and LOC (>0.5) areas, LOC50 ranging 3,543–174,139 ha, informing restoration priority at national scale. Climate predictors were included; economic considerations were not.

File: Strassburg et al. - 2020 - Global priority areas for ecosystem restoration.pdf
Input_Variables: Current land use and cover (ESA CCI); Original ecosystem type (CLULC; TEOW; GLWv2.0); Converted lands (ESA CCI land cover product); Terrestrial Ecoregions of the World (TEOW); Gridded Livestock of the World v2.0 (GLW v2.0); Planning units (4.96 × 4.96 km) (Methods); Potential carbon stock per hectare by native vegetation type per ecoregion (maps 1,3,4 from ref. 26); Pre-settlement carbon stock (HYDE); Delta biomass carbon stock (ref. 26); Delta soil carbon stock (HYDE); Elevation ranges and habitat preferences (IUCN Red List; BirdLife); Area of Habitat (AOH) per species (IUCN Red List; BirdLife); Species distributions (IUCN Red List; BirdLife); Present net value of agricultural commodities (IMPACT; SSP2-NoCC); Equilibrium prices for commodities (IMPACT; GAEZ); Stocking rates (Gridded Livestock of the World v2.0); Cropland yield gaps (rainfed) (GAEZ); Pasture yield gaps (GAEZ); Animal yield per country (IMPACT)
Spatial_Method: PLANGEA—a multicriteria optimization framework using linear programming to allocate restoration across ~5.6 million planning units, optimizing biodiversity benefits, climate-change mitigation and costs across 1,200 scenarios.
Method_Validation: Validation of estimated original ecosystem type using data from 1992–2015 (RMSE 6.73% across five land-cover types); Comparison with previous carbon-stock studies/maps showing very high agreement (Extended Data Fig. 10); Sensitivity analysis with future land-use change (Extended Data Fig. 9).
Tool: PLANGEA (Nature 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2784-9) ; R Symphony (Hornik et al., SYMPHONY in R; http://R-Forge.R-project.org/projects/rsymphony/)
Tool_Source: PLANGEA: A multicriteria optimization framework that uses linear programming to identify global restoration priority areas by jointly optimizing biodiversity, climate-change mitigation, and costs, estimating current converted lands, restoration benefits, and costs, and simulating 1,200 area-target scenarios across terrestrial biomes. ; R Symphony: The software used to obtain exact solutions to PLANGEA’s linear programming problem, serving as the R interface to the SYMPHONY solver for solving the optimization.
Output: Global priority areas for restoration (priority percentiles: top 5%, 10%, 15%, 20%, 30%, 40%, 55%, 70%, 85–100%); Biodiversity benefit map (avoided extinctions per ha); Climate‑mitigation benefit map (potential carbon sequestration per ha / Gt CO2); Cost map (opportunity + restoration implementation costs, US$ per ha)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The study explicitly targets NbS (ecosystem restoration) for climate-change mitigation, and its outputs quantify climate benefits with long-term CO2 sequestration estimates and scenario-based multicriteria prioritization (e.g., up to 335 ± 35 Gt CO2 sequestered and comparisons across biodiversity, climate, and multiple-benefit targets).
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis explicitly includes economic framing and outputs, treating costs as an optimization criterion, estimating restoration costs plus opportunity costs (foregone agricultural profits) as net present value (NPV) per planning unit, reporting costs in US$ per hectare, showing cost-effectiveness improvements (up to ~13-fold) when optimizing for biodiversity, climate and costs, and using carbon prices to assess cost coverage, i.e., incorporating economics via NPVs, $/ha costs, and cost-effectiveness ratios in the outputs.
Geographic_Scope: Global: Brazil; Australia; Netherlands; Spain; United Kingdom; United States; Switzerland; Philippines; Canada; Argentina; Austria; Poland
Narrative: The NbS addressed was large-scale ecosystem restoration of lands converted from natural ecosystems across terrestrial biomes. Key inputs included current converted areas and their original ecosystem types (OET) from ESA CCI CLULC maps (1992, 2015) and an OET map; potential long-term carbon stocks from three maps in ref. 26; biodiversity benefits from extinction-debt reductions for 20,319 species (IUCN Red List, BirdLife); elevation/habitat data; foregone agricultural profits from IMPACT (SSP2-NoCC) and restoration costs; yields and yield gaps from GAEZ and Gridded Livestock World; planning units of 4.96×4.96 km (≈2,500 ha) at 300 m CLULC; and ecoregions for extrapolation. PLANGEA, a multicriteria linear-programming framework, optimized across 1,200 global scenarios for biodiversity, climate mitigation and costs, producing priority maps (top 5%–100%), per-hectare costs and carbon, at 5×5 km globally (−80°–80°, −180°–180°). Validation yielded RMSE 6.73% for original vegetation; restoring 15% could avoid 63±4% extinctions and sequester 299 Gt CO2. Climate and economic considerations were included via carbon sequestration and foregone agriculture.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: R codes developed for and used in this analysis are available upon request from the corresponding author (R Symphony used: http://R-Forge.R-project.org/projects/rsymphony/); Data: All input datasets are available from the references cited; publicly available ones include GAEZ: http://www.fao.org/nr/gaez/en/; HYDE: ftp://ftp.pbl.nl/hyde/; SoilGrids: https://files.isric.org/soilgrids/latest/data/; IUCN species data: https://www.iucnredlist.org/resources/spatial-data-download; ESA-CCI Landcover: https://www.esa-landcover-cci.org/; Harmonized Land-Use Database for 2050: https://luh.umd.edu/data.shtml; All output datasets generated during the current study are available from the corresponding author upon request.

File: Uribe et al. - 2014 - Integrating Stakeholder Preferences and GIS-Based Multicriteria Analysis to Identify Forest Landscap.pdf
Input_Variables: Distance from Crops (governmental agencies); Human density (governmental agencies); Distance from roads (governmental agencies); Distance from urban (governmental agencies); Marginalization index (CONAPO); Distance from forest (governmental agencies); Risk of erosion (governmental agencies); Slope of terrain (governmental agencies); Insolation (governmental agencies); Distance from rivers (governmental agencies); Constraint layer: urban, existing forest and water zones (governmental agencies)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multicriteria decision analysis (MCDA) using SMCE in ILWIS to standardize and weight criteria, create factor and constraint raster layers, compute per-pixel suitability with weighted linear summation, apply thresholds to select restoration areas, and aggregate stakeholder maps to identify priority restoration areas.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Overall combined priority-area map for Forest Landscape Restoration (priority levels: selected by 4, 3, or 2 stakeholder groups); Academic-group restoration priority map (most suitable sites); Governmental-group restoration priority map (most suitable sites); NGO-group restoration priority map (most suitable sites); Public-group restoration priority map (most suitable sites)
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: The NbS addressed was Forest Landscape Restoration (FLR) in the Upper Mixtec region, Oaxaca, Mexico. Main input variables consisted of ten criteria spanning environmental and socioeconomic dimensions (e.g., distance from forest, distance from crops, distance from roads, distance from urban settlements, marginalization index, rate of land use change, risk of erosion, slope, insolation, and distance from rivers), with data sourced from government agencies, a SPOT’05 (30 m) classified image, INEGI geoestadística data, and the CONAPO marginalization index; a constraint layer excluded urban, existing forest and water zones. The spatial method used was GIS-based multicriteria decision analysis (MCDA) via the SMCE module in ILWIS 3.6, standardizing criterion scores to 0–1, weighting by a rank-order method, and aggregating with a weighted linear sum; restoration options were identified by thresholding, requiring 152,000 ha and removing patches <0.54 ha, yielding five stakeholder maps plus an overall priority map. Validation relied on 54 stakeholder interviews; results showed an overall priority area of 151.22 km2 (1.35%), with highest-priority patches concentrated in the southeast. Outputs included five 30 m resolution maps (pixel 30 m; 900 m2 units); the final map reflected concordance across four groups. The study area analyzed totaled 11,347.83 km2 (97.56%), within a 11,631 km2 study region; final priority areas were 87.8% in the south. Climate risk was not explicitly included; economic considerations were incorporated via the marginalization index and related socioeconomic criteria.

File: Valente and Vettorazzi - 2008 - Definition of priority areas for forest conservation through the ordered weighted averaging method.pdf
Input_Variables: Proximity to forest patches (This study); Proximity among forest patches with larger core area (This study); Proximity to surface water (This study); Distance from roads (This study); Distance from urban areas (This study); Vulnerability to erosion (This study)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based ordered weighted averaging (OWA) within a multicriteria evaluation, with criterion importance weights derived from participatory technique and AHP and order weights, to identify and map priority areas for forest conservation (with a sensitivity analysis).
Method_Validation: Sensitivity analysis
Tool_Source: IDRISI Kilimanjaro: Implemented the ordered weighted averaging (OWA) method in a GIS to define priority areas for forest conservation, aggregating multiple criteria with participatory/AHP-derived weights to produce a range of alternative land-use suitability maps and support sensitivity analysis.
Output: Priority areas for forest conservation (OWA-derived suitability/priority map — range of alternative strategies including WLC)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Corumbataí river basin; São Paulo; Brazil
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was defining priority areas for forest conservation to increase regional biodiversity in the Corumbataí river basin, central-eastern São Paulo, Brazil (≈170,000 ha). Main inputs included GIS layers representing proximity to forest patches and to larger-core patches, proximity to surface water, distance from roads and urban areas, and erosion vulnerability; criterion importance weights were derived via Participatory Technique and structured with the analytic hierarchy process (AHP). The spatial method used was a GIS-based ordered weighted averaging (OWA) approach, with two sets of weights—relative criterion importance and order weights—specified to generate a range of alternatives, and variables aggregated by OWA in IDRISI Kilimanjaro after defining the criteria set. Validation and key results came from a sensitivity analysis that showed coherence among the criterion weights and order weights, and indicated surface water was not important. Outputs were priority-area maps for forest conservation produced for the basin; spatial resolution was not specified. Climate risk or economic considerations were not included.

File: Valente et al. - 2021 - A multicriteria evaluation approach to set forest restoration priorities based on water ecosystem se.pdf
Input_Variables: Proximity to spring (drainage network; Mello et al., 2018b); Slope (DEM; IGC 1:10,000); Soil erodibility (Soil map; Silva & Alvares, 2005); Topographic index (DEM; SAGA Wetness Index); LULC (SPOT-derived LULC maps; Mello et al., 2018b); Constraints map (generated for the study)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based multicriteria evaluation (MCE) using the Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) method, with criteria defined via Participatory Technique and weights from pairwise comparisons (AHP), criteria standardized to a 0–1 scale, and constraint-adjusted aggregation to identify high/medium/low priority areas for forest restoration.
Method_Validation: Expert/stakeholder validation; AHP consistency ratio (CR = 0.026) check; Cross-evaluation with land-use/land-cover (LULC) categories via cross-tabulated comparison with landscape characteristics (LULC, slope, soil types, proximity to drainage network); External validation across two watersheds with different forest-cover patterns to test applicability
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Priority map for forest restoration based on water ecosystem services (High; Medium; Low)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: the NbS (forest restoration) is targeted to boost water ecosystem services to buffer climate-related water risks, and the authors demonstrate this with priority-area maps for restoration in agricultural watersheds intended to sustain water yield/quality under projected climate-change impacts.
Economics: Yes: Economic framing is embedded—the model aims to optimize areas for forest restoration to support payment for ecosystem services programs and the cost-benefit mindset is invoked in discussion, but the output analysis itself yields PES-focused priority maps without explicit economic metrics (no ROI/NPV/cost-effectiveness values) in the results.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Sorocaba;Sub-national: São Paulo state;Sub-national: Sarapuí river basin;National: Brazil;Global: worldwide
Narrative: Valente et al. addressed forest restoration as a nature-based solution to enhance water ecosystem services in agricultural watersheds, with PES as the programmatic aim. Five criteria—proximity to springs, slope, soil erodibility, topographic index, and LULC—were defined via a Participatory Technique with six experts; data included SPOT-derived LULC (2.5 m), a DEM/drainage network, soils maps (IGC 1:10,000; Mello et al. 2018b) and a constraints layer. A Weighted Linear Combination was applied after standardizing criteria to 0–1 with linear fuzzy functions (LULC inverted); weights (fw) came from Saaty pairwise comparisons (CR=0.026; springs 0.348, erodibility 0.208, slope 0.208, index 0.129, LULC 0.106). Validation used cross-comparison for two watersheds, W1 and W2 in the Sarapuí basin, SP, Brazil; high priority areas lay within 200 m of rivers and slopes >40%, yielding shares of high/med/low of 26%/45%/24% (W1) and 24%/39%/21% (W2) at 5 m resolution. Climate risk not included; PES context noted.

P Filtering coefficient for Barren land (0.05) (IDEM 2002); P Filtering coefficient for Shrub/Scrub/Herbaceous (0.50) (IDEM 2002); P Filtering coefficient for Hay/Pasture (0.25) (IDEM 2002); P Filtering coefficient for Cultivated Crops (0.25) (IDEM 2002); InVEST Documentation); Discount rate (%) (InVEST Documentation); Soil Productivity ai (0.68) (IDEM 2002); Woodland Influence bi (0.8) (IDEM 2002); Property Tax Rate si (0.98–3.09) (STATSINDIANA 2015); Forest Land Fi ($/ha) (Hoover 2010)
Analysis_Resolution: 12-digit HUC12 subwatershed scale (subwatershed unit of analysis)
Spatial_Method: InVEST nutrient retention model in GIS to estimate nutrient retention at the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) scale; spatially explicit estimation of acquisition and opportunity costs in ArcGIS; ROI-based prioritization of subwatersheds for private forest enrollment; scenario-driven targeting of contaminated watersheds and river forks.
Method_Validation: Calibration to observed annual streamflow at gauging stations using Nash–Sutcliffe efficiency (E) to assess predictive power; validation of predicted in-stream phosphorus concentrations against IDEM Fixed Station Monitoring data, with predictions within the 95% confidence interval; and sensitivity analysis evaluating robustness with ±5–20% changes in precipitation (PCPN) and evapotranspiration (AET).
Tool: InVEST Water Purification Nutrient Retention model (InVEST Documentation https://naturalcapitalproject.org/invest/)
Tool_Source: InVEST Water Purification Nutrient Retention model: Estimates the nutrient retention service provided by vegetation and soil by intercepting nonpoint nutrient pollutants and purifying water resources; operates on an annual average basis using GIS raster data; consists of two phases—Phase 1 computes annual water yield per cell with the InVEST Hydropower Water Yield model, Phase 2 computes nutrient export and retention per cell using land-use–specific export and filtration coefficients and sums results to the subwatershed scale; outputs include biophysical nutrient export and retention values and spatially explicit retention maps used to evaluate changes in nutrient retention under hypothetical forest conservation scenarios and to monetize benefits for ROI; requires inputs such as DEM, precipitation, evapotranspiration, land-use/land-cover, root-restricting layer, plant available water content, watershed boundaries, and biophysical tables with nutrient export coefficients, filtration coefficients, and nutrient removal valuation.
Output: Private forestland availability and CFW scenario allocation map (eligible private forest; current CFW; Scenario 1 contaminated-watershed expansion; Scenario 2 river-forks expansion); Spatial economic benefits of nutrient retention (P & N; present-value benefits per subwatershed for Scenarios 0/1/2); Spatial conservation ROI map (subwatershed-level ROI; positive vs negative ROI for baseline Scenario 0)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: they treat climate variability as a risk by performing a climate sensitivity analysis that perturbs precipitation and evapotranspiration and report how the nutrient-retention benefits and ROI change, indicating climate hazards could constrain NbS effectiveness.
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT includes economic framing and outputs—nutrient-retention benefits are monetized to produce total economic benefits and unit-area values, acquisition costs and forgone opportunity costs are incorporated, and ROI is computed as (B − (Ca+Co))/(Ca+Co) using a 5% discount over 15 years; across three scenarios (mean and high nutrient removal values) the study reports total economic benefits from about 2.17 to 10.15 million USD, total costs roughly 4.67 to 11.03 million USD, unit-area benefits up to about 22,716 USD/km2, and ROI values that can be positive (e.g., around 0.2–1.2) or negative depending on scenario and nutrient-value assumptions, illustrating how economic viability varies with spatial targeting and costs.
Geographic_Scope: Local: White River Basin;Sub-national: Indiana;National: United States
Narrative: 1) NbS addressed: private forest conservation for water purification under Indiana’s Classified Forest and Wildlands (CFW) Program. 2) Main inputs/data: InVEST nutrient retention model with a 30 m DEM (USGS NED), PRISM precipitation, MODIS AET, NLCD 2006 land cover (reclassified by ownership), SSURGO RD/PAW soils, 12-digit HUC subwatersheds (452) in the White River Basin; export coefficients (Reckhow 1980); nutrient removal values (USEPA 2008); IDEM in-stream N and P data; acquisition and forgone-revenue data (si, Fi, Ai, Pi, Ri) from IDEM/STATSINDIANA. 3) Spatial method used and how variables were combined: a spatially explicit ROI framework using InVEST to estimate nutrient retention under current and hypothetical CFW enrollments; costs in ArcGIS; ROI = (B − (Ca + Co))/(Ca + Co) across three scenarios: baseline 1127 km2; Scenario 1 447 km2; Scenario 2 875 km2. 4) Validation approach and key results: NSE calibration against gauge data; mean nutrient-retention benefits: Scenario0 $2.17 M, Scenario1 $5.56 M, Scenario2 $4.70 M; Scenario1 ROI positive, Scenario2 negative. 5) Main outputs produced and their resolution: subwatershed ROI maps at 12-digit HUC across WRB (29,370 km2, 452 subwatersheds) plus total/unit biophysical and economic metrics over 15 years. 6) Geographic scope (scale and location): WRB, Indiana. 7) Whether climate risk or economic considerations were included: climate sensitivity analysis on PCPN/AET (±5–20%) and costs including acquisition and forgone agricultural revenues.

File: Wang et al. - 2025 - Where to restore Connectivity forest for spatial prioritization in forest landscape restoration.pdf
Input_Variables: HCVF-baseline (HCVF-dataset); HCVF-model-probabilities (HCVF-model); Forest-type data (NLCD)
Spatial_Method: Overlay of the HCVF baseline, HCVF-model probability, and NLCD forest data to delineate Connectivity Forests outside the baselines (threshold ≥0.4); stepwise nesting of CF classes (≥0.9 to ≥0.4); and assessment of landscape connectivity via circular moving-window Green Infrastructure (GI) density (3-km and 1-km radii) to identify restoration hotspots (GI density ≥20%).
Method_Validation: Field data validation (external field data showing that restoration areas delineated by the CF approach spatially align with HCVF tracts identified by the County Administrative Board).
Tool_Source: HCVF model: A national-scale probabilistic model predicting 1-ha resolution likelihood that a forest stand has high conservation value, used to define the HCVF baseline and to identify Connectivity Forests outside recognized HCVFs, enabling spatial prioritization of restoration hotspots and expansion of the conservation network to bolster landscape-scale connectivity.
Output: Connectivity Forest priority map (CF classes ≥0.9, ≥0.8, ≥0.7, ≥0.6, ≥0.5, ≥0.4; nested HCVF expansion scenarios); Change in Green Infrastructure (GI) density map (HCVF baseline → stepwise CF insertions; all forest and by spruce/pine/deciduous); Areas with GI density ≥20% map (baseline vs post‑CF insertion; habitat functionality gains); Restoration hotspots allocation map (CF patches adding GI density ≥20% with 3‑km buffer)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Vindelälven River watershed, Sweden; National: Sweden
Narrative: The study applied a Nature-based Solutions approach called connectivity forests (CFs) to guide forest landscape restoration and strengthen green infrastructure in boreal Sweden. Key inputs were the High Conservation Value Forest (HCVF) baseline at 1-ha resolution (18% of forest area) and a HCVF-model predicting probability, together with NLCD forest types (spruce, pine, deciduous) across Vindelälven watershed (1.3 million ha). CFs were defined as forests outside the HCV baseline with HCVF-model probability ≥0.4 and divided into six classes (≥0.9 to ≥0.4). The approach overlaid HCV baseline, HCVF-model, and NLCD, then nested CF classes atop the baseline and assessed changes in green infrastructure (GI) density using a circular moving window (3-km) with a 5-km buffer; GI-density ≥20% defined restoration hotspots. Validation cited HCVF tracts. Outputs included ~130,500 ha CFs across 1.3 million ha and 9,506 restoration hotspots totaling 100,672 ha. Climate risk not explicitly modeled; economic considerations balanced restoration with ongoing wood production.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: The article does not report any new code; Data: Data reported in this article will be shared by the lead contact upon request.

File: Wills et al. - 2022 - A practice-led assessment of landscape restoration potential in a biodiversity hotspot.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Passive regeneration; Vine cutting; Herb/shrub cutting; Lantana removal; Firebreak cutting; Grass cutting; Framework planting; Soil improvement and nurse planting; Planting native vegetation; Assisted natural regeneration (ANR)
Input_Variables: Current AGB (Landsat reflectance data); Maximum AGB (WorldClim v2 climate predictors); AGB deficit (Derived from current AGB and maximum AGB); SWIR1 (Landsat); NIR (Landsat); Dissimilarity_Red (Landsat-derived); Dissimilarity_NIR (Landsat-derived); Dissimilarity_SWIR1 (Landsat-derived); Land Cover (Landsat-derived); Moist forest (Land Cover); Savanna spectrum (Land Cover); Floodplain (Land Cover); Agro-ecological mosaic (Land Cover); Elevation (SRTM); Slope (SRTM); Aspect (SRTM); Mean Diurnal Range (WorldClim v2); Isothermality (WorldClim v2); Driest Quarter Mean Temperature (WorldClim v2); Temperature Seasonality (WorldClim v2); Warmest Quarter Precipitation (WorldClim v2); Maximum Water Deficit (WorldClim v2); Distance to intact habitat (GIS-derived); Distance to roads (GIS-derived); Distance to disturbed habitat edges (GIS-derived); Governance (WDPA); Envelope uncertainty maps (EUMs).
Spatial_Method: Predict current AGB from Landsat bands and texture using a random forest model and upscale to 25 m; derive maximum potential AGB from climate-based modelling and compute AGB deficit as restoration potential; apply a rule-based framework (landcover, elevation, degradation via AGB deficit, and distance to intact habitat/edges) to assign restoration methods per pixel; estimate per-pixel biomass gains and costs to generate cost-effectiveness maps; incorporate ecological uncertainty with envelope uncertainty maps and identify top 25% cost-effective sites within protected areas as restoration priority areas.
Method_Validation: 10-fold cross-validation with three repeats linking satellite data to field-derived AGB; a 4:1 train–test split (156 training plots, 39 test plots) for validation using field plots; identical cross-validation and calibration used to validate the climate-based maximum AGB model.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Restoration potential (AGB deficit) map; Restoration methods/allocation map (passive regeneration; assisted natural regeneration; planting); Biomass gain map (AGB gain — 5-year and full-recovery); Cost-effectiveness map (Mg AGB per US$100 — 5-year and full-recovery); Restoration priority map (top 25% cost-effectiveness — priority 1 & 2)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: climate hazards are treated as a risk that could limit restoration feasibility and long-term outcomes. The authors demonstrate this with a hazard overlay of climate-modelling ecological uncertainty and by comparing restoration potential across pessimistic, realistic and optimistic scenarios to screen out high-risk areas.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS is explicitly targeted for climate-change mitigation by prioritizing restoration to maximize carbon sequestration, and the authors demonstrate this through scenario-based prioritisation that identifies the top cost-effective sites for biomass gain (5-year and full-recovery horizons) and by showing how climate constraints define the maximum achievable AGB (carbon) across the landscape.
Economics: Yes: It includes economic outputs and framing in the OUTPUT analysis—direct restoration costs and cost-effectiveness are quantified, with costs per hectare per year (US$), AGB gains per hectare (Mg AGB ha−1), and cost-effectiveness ratios (Mg AGB per US$100 spent), evaluated across 5-year and full-recovery investment horizons, yielding ROI-like insights and identifying the top 25% cost-effective sites, with governance (PA vs NPA) and land-cover influences and even accounting for opportunity costs.
