Narrative: The study addressed forest landscape restoration as the NbS, focusing on passive regeneration, assisted natural regeneration (ANR) and planting native vegetation in the Udzungwa–Kilombero Landscape, Tanzania (53,000 km2). Key inputs and data sources included field-based above-ground biomass (AGB) measurements from 195 plots (17,983 woody stems) to derive current AGB, Landsat red/near-infrared/SWIR bands with texture indices, 2015 Google Earth Engine imagery, landcover, elevation/slope/aspect, distance to intact habitat/roads, and WorldClim v2 climate variables (19 predictors) used to model maximum AGB; six climate predictors (mean diurnal range, isothermality, driest quarter temp, temp seasonality, warmest quarter precip, maximum water deficit) were retained for upscaling current and maximum AGB. The method combined a four-step spatial prioritization (deficit mapping, method selection, biomass gain estimation, costs and cost‑effectiveness) using random forests with 10-fold cross‑validation to link satellite data to AGB, plus a regional AGC→AGB biomass gain model; costs and scenarios (5 years vs full recovery) yielded cost‑effectiveness maps. Validation showed R2 = 0.49, RMSE = 8.86 for current AGB and R2 = 0.75 for maximum AGB; results indicated 77.7% (4.14 Mha) of the landscape had restoration potential, with 80.5% of deficit restorable passively or via ANR. Outputs included current AGB maps, maximum AGB maps, AGB deficit, restoration methods, costs and cost‑effectiveness maps at 25 m resolution (aggregated to hectare) across the 53 000 km2 study area, with top‑25% cost‑effective sites concentrated in protected areas and moderately degraded moist forest/savanna; ecological uncertainty (climate modelling) affected 10.9% (0.58 Mha), and 3.34% of the landscape (178,000 ha) had both ecological certainty and top cost‑effectiveness across scenarios. Climate risk was incorporated via envelope uncertainty maps, and economic considerations were integral through explicit restoration costs and cost‑effectiveness.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: https://bit.ly/3KO5Hgz; Data: Dryad DOI https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.nk98sf7wr; Figshare https://bit.ly/3QkIrrI

File: Nepal et al. - 2023 - Wildfire Risk Assessment for Strategic Forest Management in the Southern United States A Bayesian N.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Prescribed fire; enhancement of fuel reduction program
Input_Variables: Fuel Load (LANDFIRE FCCS Fuelbeds 2022); Burn Probability (Wildfire Risk to Communities project); Flame Length Exceedance (Wildfire Risk to Communities project); Structure/Population Density (Kondo et al. 2022; Gaither et al. 2015); Social Vulnerability (Kondo et al. 2022; Gaither et al. 2015); Tmax3yr (MACAv2-METDATA); RHmin3yr (MACAv2-METDATA); SPEIrecent (SPEI drought index); Watershed Importance (HUC-12) (Forests to Faucets 2.0); Total Forest Carbon Stock (Forests to Faucets 2.0); Land Use/Land Cover (Gould et al. 2023); Biodiversity (Gould et al. 2023)
Spatial_Method: Spatial Bayesian network modeling on a 1000-hectare hexagon grid to estimate per-hexagon wildfire risk and risk reduction potential; factor analysis to derive key landscape predictors (from 73 variables); firescape classification to contextualize spatial risk patterns.
Method_Validation: Expert elicitation with feedback on parameter plausibility and provisional spatial outputs; Sensitivity analyses using Netica.
Tool_Source: Netica: Used to build and run the wildfire-risk Bayesian Network, providing a GUI to construct the network structure and CPTs, run model analyses on large spatial datasets (Netica 6.07), and perform sensitivity analyses; the full model is shared as a Netica file.
Output: Spatial map of expected wildfire risk; Spatial map of potential risk reduction from prescribed fire (capacity to reduce risk); Prioritization/suitability map for fuel‑reduction/prescribed‑fire implementation; Map of relative utility/benefit of fuel reduction for reducing risks to people and ecosystem services
Climate_Barrier: Yes: climate hazards are treated as a risk driver that could constrain NbS performance (changing climate increases hazardous fire potential and limits prescribed-fire use), demonstrated by incorporating climate anomalies and drought indices into a Bayesian network and by performing scenario analyses comparing risk under enhanced fuel-reduction versus business-as-usual in a changing climate.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: they target landscapes where climate-driven wildfire hazard is highest by integrating climate anomalies into the risk framework, and demonstrate NbS relevance through risk and risk-reduction outputs that identify where enhanced fuel-reduction/prescribed-fire interventions can most effectively reduce risk under alternative scenarios.
Economics: Yes: Details The output stage includes economic framing via a utility node that quantifies the value of risk outcomes under decision options (enhanced fuel-reduction vs. business as usual), embedding economic considerations in the risk-reduction analysis and enabling a cost‑effectiveness perspective, with outputs providing probabilistic risk and potential reduction linked to management actions, but it does not present explicit monetary metrics (no ROI, NPV, or cost‑benefit figures).
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Southern United States;Southeastern United States
Narrative: Prescribed fire was the NbS prioritized to reduce wildfire risk in Southern United States. The approach used 73 spatial variables describing social vulnerability, fire dynamics/history, forest properties, watersheds, biodiversity, climate. Aggregated to 1000-ha hexagons with ≥25% forest cover in 13 states. Key data sources included LANDFIRE FCCS fuelbeds, seven fire-risk datasets, MACAv2-METDATA climate downscaling, SPEI drought index, and RPA climate data. A Bayesian Network (Netica 6.07) linked variables via conditional probabilities; expert elicitation informed structure; factor analysis yielded eight factors, four feeding BN. Outputs were probabilistic wildfire risk estimates and the potential for risk reduction through fuel reductions under management scenarios, mapped at 1000-ha resolution. Validation used expert feedback; results showed high risk in coastal plains and interior highlands, with reduction capacity tied to fuel load. Climate risk was included via three-year anomalies and drought indices; economic considerations via social vulnerability indicators. Geographic scope encompassed Southeast U.S. at landscape scale.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: Netica BN model file (full model) available on Zenodo; Data: Zenodo data set titled "Wildfire Risk Assessment for Strategic Forest Management in the Southern United States: A Bayesian Network Modeling Approach" (Nepal et al. 2023).

File: Nocentini et al. - 2024 - Complex burn prioritization models as a decision-support tool for managing prescribed fires in large.pdf
Input_Variables: TSLF in prairie ecotype (Fire perimeters 1948-2022; Smith III et al., 2015; Malone, 2019); TSLF in marsh ecotype (Fire perimeters 1948-2022; Smith III et al., 2015; Malone, 2019); TSLF in pine rocklands ecotype (Fire perimeters 1948-2022; Smith III et al., 2015; Malone, 2019); Wildland-urban interface (WUI) (ENP roads, buildings, trails, and campsite perimeters; Barrow and National Park Service Southeast Region Geospatial Resources, 2022); Protection of cultural and archeological resources (Stutts, 2014; National Register of Historic Places); Protection of recreational resources (Barrow and National Park Service Southeast Region Geospatial Resources, 2022); Protection of endangered fauna species: Cape Sable seaside sparrow (USFWS, 2023); Protection of endangered fauna species: Florida leafwing butterfly and Bartram's scrub-hairstreak (USFWS, 2023); Protection of endangered fauna species: bonneted bat (USFWS, 2023); Protection of endangered fauna species: black rail (USFWS, 2023); Protection of endangered fauna species: snail kite (USFWS, 2023); Control of invasive plant species: old world climbing fern (Ruiz et al., 2021); Control of invasive plant species: willow (Salix caroliniana) (Ruiz et al., 2021); Control of invasive plant species: paperbark tree (Melaleuca quinquenervia) (Ruiz et al., 2021); Control of invasive plant species: Australian pine (Casuarina equisetifolia) (Ruiz et al., 2021); Control of invasive plant species: cattail (Typha spp.) (Ruiz et al., 2021); Hydrologic conditions (mean surface water depth derived from surface water stages; mean depths; South Florida Water Management District, 2023; DEM USGS, 2019); Oligotrophic status (soil phosphorus concentration map; Scheidt et al., 2021; Nocentini et al., 2021b; Nocentini & Kominoski, 2021); Size of burn unit (Table 1); Complexity of burn unit (Table 1)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based, multi-criteria spatial decision-support approach implemented in ArcGIS Pro that converts all inputs to a 50 m raster; derives hydrologic conditions by empirical Bayesian kriging of surface-water depth (and dryness from DEM), estimates oligotrophic soil phosphorus by kriging; constructs buffers around roads, buildings, trails, and cultural/archeological resources; and integrates weighted criteria (time since last fire, WUI, protection of cultural/recreational resources, endangered fauna habitats, invasive species control, hydrologic conditions, oligotrophic status, burn-unit size/complexity) into per-pixel burn-priority scores via Model Builder.
Method_Validation: 50-year simulation of prescribed-fire management under two scenarios (S1, S2) to derive simulated mean fire return intervals, then comparison of simulated FRIs to literature-based target FRIs using Pearson’s correlation (r2 = 0.88; p = 0.02).
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Burn prioritization score map (50 m grid) [scores 0–71]; Burn prioritization scores averaged to burn‑unit polygons [scores 6–62]; Simulated 50‑year prescribed‑fire perimeters (annual simulated burn perimeters 2023–2072)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: the NbS (prescribed fire) is spatially targeted to reduce wildfire hazards near urban areas, demonstrated by including a Wildland-Urban Interface criterion with 2.5 km buffers around roads/buildings (and 200 m around trails/campsites) and producing 50 m burn-priority maps with scenario-based prioritization (S1/S2) to optimize fire return intervals that protect people and infrastructure while conserving habitats.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Everglades National Park (Florida, USA); Sub-national: Florida; National: United States
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was prescribed-fire management to maintain fire-driven ecosystem processes in Everglades National Park (ENP) wetlands (marshes, prairies, and pine rocklands) while protecting human life and infrastructure. Main inputs included (i) time-since-last-fire (TSLF) calculated from ENP fire perimeters (1948–2022; Smith III et al. 2015; Malone 2019); (ii) 50 m rasterized criteria on WUI buffers (2.5 km around roads/buildings; 200 m around trails/campsites) and cultural/recreational resources; (iii) endangered-fauna habitats (Cape Sable seaside sparrow, Florida leafwing butterfly, Bartram’s scrub-hairstreak, bonneted bat) and other infrastructure; (iv) hydrologic conditions via mean surface-water depth from 69 SFWMD stations, Kriging with a DEM (USGS 2019) to classify dry/intermediate/wet; (v) oligotrophic soil phosphorus maps (Scheidt et al. 2021; Nocentini et al. 2021); (vi) burn-unit size/complexity; all data converted to 50 m grids from sources including Ruiz et al. 2021 vegetation map, Malone 2019 fire perimeters, USFWS 2023 critical habitats, Barrow/NPS SER GIS resources 2022, Stutts 2014, DBHYDRO 2023. The spatial method combined criteria in ArcGIS Pro 3.0.3 (Model Builder) into a weighted, score-based burn-prioritization framework, with Time-Since-Last-Fire contributing 30% of the maximum pixel score (overall maximum 100) and other criteria carrying defined weights, producing 50 m prioritization grids (0–71) and burn-unit-averaged scores (6–62). Validation simulated 50 years (2023–2072) under two scenarios (S1, S2); S2 best matched targets, with r2 = 0.88 and RMSE = 1.11, and mean FRIs for marshes, prairies, and pine rocklands of 9.9 ± 1.7, 7.3 ± 1.9, and 4.0 ± 0.7 years, respectively, plus habitat-specific FRIs (e.g., Cape Sparrow 7.4 ± 1.5 years). Outputs included a 50 m grid map of prioritization scores for target ecotypes and a burn-unit-summarized map, with mean burned surface during validation of 607 ± 510 km2 y−1 (S1) and 716 ± 501 km2 y−1 (S2). Geographic scope was ENP (~4,000 km2) in South Florida; climate/hydrology were incorporated via hydrologic criteria, and economic considerations were included as a finite annual burn-cap (400 km2) and two resource-limited scenarios.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: All data used are publicly available from cited sources (Ruiz et al. 2021; Malone 2019; U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service 2023; Barrow & National Park Service Southeast Region Geospatial Resources 2022; Stutts 2014; U.S. Geological Survey 2019; South Florida Water Management District 2023).

File: Rodrigues et al. - 2022 - Integrating geospatial wildfire models to delineate landscape management zones and inform decision-m.pdf
Input_Variables: Human-caused fire ignition probability (EGIF; MAAyMA, 2015; Costafreda-Aumedes et al., 2017; Leone et al., 2003); Distance to paved roads (Costafreda-Aumedes et al., 2017; Leone et al., 2003); Distance to forest tracks (Costafreda-Aumedes et al., 2017; Leone et al., 2003); Distance to walking trails (Costafreda-Aumedes et al., 2017; Leone et al., 2003); Wildland-Urban Interface (WUI) (Costafreda-Aumedes et al., 2017; Leone et al., 2003); Wildland-Agricultural Interface (WAI) (Costafreda-Aumedes et al., 2017; Leone et al., 2003); Distance to power lines (Costafreda-Aumedes et al., 2017; Leone et al., 2003); Residential buildings footprints (BTN25) (IGN, 2018; IGN, 2015); Surface fuel types (Scott and Burgan, 2005); Fuel moisture content (Bradshaw and Borchers, 2000); Temperature (hourly weather records from automatic weather stations); Wind speed (hourly weather records from automatic weather stations); Number of active fires in the last 24 h (EGIF; MAAyMA, 2015)
Spatial_Method: Used Random Forest to map fire occurrence probability; Random Forest to map initial-attack success probability under baseline and extreme weather; FlamMap-based fire spread simulations to derive wildfire transmission to communities (Minimum Travel Time and Node Influence Grid); combined these into a two-dimensional cross-tab of occurrence × IA to delineate Wildfire Management Zones (Zone I–IV) and downscale within zones for management prescriptions.
Method_Validation: 10-fold cross-validation of the fire occurrence RF model (AUC); caret-based evaluation of initial-attack success under baseline and extreme weather scenarios (AUC values reported)
Tool_Source: FlamMap : Used with the minimum travel time (MTT) algorithm to model fire spread and simulate 10,000 fire events, deriving transmission pathways and exposure (e.g., buildings exposed) via a Node Influence Grid. ; caret : Used to calibrate, train and evaluate binary random forest models for wildfire occurrence and initial attack success in R, employing cross-validation and AUC performance metrics.
Output: Regional wildfire management zones map [Zone I: Comprehensive management; Zone II: Human ignition prevention; Zone III: Intensive fuels management; Zone IV: Fire reintroduction]; Local fireshed and intervention-priority map (Bages County) [exposed buildings per pixel; main fire pathways; exposure percentiles 60th & 80th]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: The authors treat climate hazards as a risk that could undermine the effectiveness of wildfire management NbS, noting that extreme heat and drought can overwhelm initial-attack capacity and enhance fire transmission; they demonstrate this by comparing outputs under base versus extreme weather scenarios and by discussing future climate projections that more frequent extremes will challenge the proposed WMZ zoning and risk-reduction strategies.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They target landscape areas for NbS‑level wildfire risk reduction (prevention, prescribed burning/fuel treatment, and fire‑adapted planning) in anticipation of climate‑driven extreme fire weather, and demonstrate this with scenario‑based prioritisation that combines fire occurrence and initial‑attack success to produce risk‑reduction maps and identify high‑priority zones.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Bages County; Sub-national: Catalonia; National: Spain
Narrative: The NbS spatial prioritisation delineated wildfire management zones (WMZs) to reduce risk in Mediterranean landscapes by integrating wildfire occurrence, IA success and transmission. Inputs included 40 m rasters for fire occurrence from RF models using EGIF data and 1998–2015 fires; IA success from a 40 m RF model using visibility, accessibility, fuel types, temperature and wind plus suppression demands; FlamMap transmission simulation (40 m; 10,000 events); BTN25 housing footprints 23,440 structures; Node Grid of pathways. Workflow estimated ignition probability, modeled IA under baseline, merged ignition and IA under conditions, and zoned results into WMZs (Zone I Comprehensive management, Zone II Ignition prevention, Zone III Intensive fuels, Zone IV Fire reintroduction) with downscaling. Validation with 10-fold CV yielded AUC ≈0.75±0.03 for occurrence and ≈0.73±0.02 for IA; outputs are 40 m maps, including WMZs in Catalonia (northeastern Spain) and Bages. Climate risk was included via hazard-weather scenarios; IA modeling incorporated suppression-demand (resource constraints).

File: Rodríguez-Fernández et al. - 2025 - Participatory multi-criteria decision analysis to prioritize management areas that help suppress wil.pdf
Input_Variables: Wildfire resistance indicator (Ferreira et al., 2015); Rate of spread (FlamMap, Finney 2006); Hazard map (ICNF, n.d.-b); Potential large fires map (ICNF, n.d.-b); Canopy cover (local datasets); Above ground biomass (local datasets); Resprouters (local datasets); Shrubs biomass (local datasets); Crown base height (local datasets); Accessibility for fire trucks (local datasets); Slope (Agência para a Modernização Administrativa, n.d.); In touch with fire breaks (ICNF, n.d.-a); Distance to water point (ICNF, n.d.-a); Distance to urbanized areas (Direção-Geral do Território, 2020); Aspect (Agência para a Modernização Administrativa, n.d.); Conservation corridors (ICNF, n.d.-c); Population density (Eurostat, 2021); Territories with potential for large fires (ICNF, n.d.-b); Short-term danger map of rural fires (ICNF, n.d.-b)
Analysis_Resolution: Management units (MUs); MU-level analysis using 2,429 management units.
Spatial_Method: Participatory GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis (AHP-weighted criteria) implemented in the EMDS/CDP framework within ArcGIS Pro, incorporating GIS-derived sub-criteria (including FlamMap-based fire behavior variables) across 2,429 management units to produce spatial priority maps.
Method_Validation: Consistency Ratio (CR), Spearman’s rank correlation (S), and Euclidean distance (ED) with a consensus convergence algorithm for participant inputs; Agreement analysis between individual stakeholder prioritizations and the group (average match 4.79 out of 8); Sensitivity analysis with ±10% weight perturbations (42 scenarios) using Mean Absolute Deviation (MAD); Visual validation of high-priority areas via satellite imagery, documented in a stakeholder video.
Tool_Source: FlamMap : used to estimate two fire behaviour variables using available biometric information, predominant wind directions, and the Portuguese fuel model; EMDS : implemented the MCDA decision model across 2,429 afforested management units to generate per-criterion priority maps and a final composite map (EMDS integrated within ArcGIS Pro and applying the CDP-developed MCDA), and to evaluate stakeholder performance using consistency measures; CDP : built the hierarchical MCDA structure (goal, criteria, sub-criteria), organized the model’s solution, and provided the weighting framework whose outputs were fed into EMDS/ArcGIS Pro.
Output: Fuels priority map (Very Low, Low, Moderate, High, Very High); Suppression drivers priority map (Very Low, Low, Moderate, High, Very High); Potential for extreme fires priority map (Very Low, Low, Moderate, High, Very High); Vulnerability priority map (Very Low, Low, Moderate, High, Very High); Final composite management priority map (Very Low, Low, Moderate, High, Very High)
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: The study addressed wildfire prevention and suppression through nature‑based fuel management within a participatory MCDA framework. The main inputs combined 2,429 afforested management units (MUs) within the Vale do Sousa CSA (28,941 ha) using data from forest inventories and public spatial layers, including ICNF maps (hazard maps, territories with large fires, firebreak networks, water points), FlamMap fire-behavior outputs, canopy cover, above‑ground biomass, resprouters, shrubs biomass, crown base height, slope, proximity to firebreaks, water points, roads, urban areas, aspect, and population density (Eurostat, ICNF, DGTerritório). The spatial method implemented a hierarchical MCDA (AHP) in the Ecosystem Management Decision Support/CDP system, producing four criterion maps (Fuels, Suppression drivers, Potential for extreme fires, Vulnerability) and a final composite map by aggregating weighted sub-criteria; weights were adjusted by participant CR, ED, and Spearman S, with group consensus used to generate 5-class priority maps (Jenks breaks) at MU resolution. Validation involved visual satellite checks, agreement analysis (average 60% match; 4.79/8), and a ±10% weight sensitivity test (MAD up to 0.00425; 3.2% of MUs changed class). Outputs comprise spatial priority maps at MU level with five classes, and area‑based summaries (Very High 1.2%, High 7.9%, etc.), using ArcGIS Pro and EMDS. Geographic scope was northwestern Portugal’s Vale do Sousa (CSA), centered on 2,429 MUs across 28,941 ha; climate risk was represented via fire behavior/future extreme-fire maps, while explicit economic considerations were not included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The original contributions presented in the study are included in the article/Supplementary material (https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/ffgc.2025.1654107/full#supplementary-material)

File: Sakti et al. - 2022 - Spatial Prioritization for Wildfire Mitigation by Integrating Heterogeneous Spatial Data A New Mult.pdf
Input_Variables: Administration data (BIG); Night light (VIIRS); Land surface temperature (MODIS TERRA); Population (WorldPop); Precipitation (CHIRPS); Drought (KBDI); Wind speed (ERA5); Accessibility to Cities 2015 (Oxford Malaria Atlas project); Tropical forest (PHTF) (GLAD, University of Maryland); Global Forest Change (USGS); Global biomass carbon density maps (NASA ORNL DAAC); WCMC biomass carbon density (UNEP–WCMC); WHRC pantropical national level carbon stock dataset (WHRC); Burned area (FireCCI51) (ESA); Burned area (MCD64A1) (NASA); NO2 (Sentinel-5P/ESA); SO2 (Sentinel-5P/ESA); CO (Sentinel-5P/ESA); Mining area (FWI); Palm oil plantation area (FWI)
Spatial_Method: Index-based overlay of wildfire susceptibility (WSI), carbon stock (CSI), and carbon emission (CEI) data, harmonized to 1 km and summed to form a wildfire priority index (WPI) classified by quantiles; and emerging hotspot analysis to assess spatiotemporal deforestation patterns for validation.
Method_Validation: Emerging hotspot analysis to validate spatiotemporal deforestation patterns; consistency assessment by comparing hotspot results with the wildfire priority model.
Tool: Emerging Hot Spot Analysis (Esri ArcGIS Pro documentation, https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/tool-reference/space-time-pattern-mining/learnmoreemerging.htm)
Tool_Source: Emerging Hot Spot Analysis: Used to evaluate spatiotemporal patterns of burned-area/deforestation by binning location and time and applying Getis-Ord Gi* with the Mann–Kendall trend test on GFC data (MCD64A1 and FireCCI51) for 2010–2019; each bin yields a Z and p, identifying emerging hotspots and coldspots, and it was applied to annual deforestation data from Global Forest Watch 2010–2020 to compare with the wildfire priority model as a consistency check.
Output: Wildfire susceptibility map (very-low, low, medium, high, very-high); Carbon stock map (carbon stock index, tons/ha); Carbon emission index map (CEI, 5 classes); Wildfire mitigation priority map (WPI: high, medium, low); Emerging burned-area hotspot map (hotspot/coldspot/oscillating)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: Climate hazards are treated as a risk that could compromise the long‑term effectiveness of wildfire mitigation by linking climate-driven fire weather to the prioritization outputs, and the authors demonstrate this by incorporating climate indicators (drought, temperature, rainfall, wind) into the wildfire susceptibility and carbon-emission models and by proposing future climate-scenario analyses to evaluate mitigation performance under changing climate conditions.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They frame climate hazards (rising temperatures, drought, and wildfire risk) as the driver of the problem and target high-risk forest areas to deploy NbS-based mitigation (REDD+-style conservation/restoration) to reduce emissions and protect carbon stocks, demonstrated through a wildfire-priority framework that integrates hazard, carbon-stock, and emission indicators into a priority map and is discussed as guiding REDD+ implementation and land-use policy decisions.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis incorporates economic framing by linking wildfire mitigation priorities to REDD+ program implementation and payments for ecosystem services, and by reporting overlap of high-priority areas with oil palm and mining lands, signaling economic land-use implications and PES relevance in policy recommendations.
Geographic_Scope: National: Indonesia; Sub-national: Sumatra; Kalimantan; North Maluku; Papua; Jambi; Riau; South Sumatra; Lampung; West Kalimantan; Central Kalimantan; East Kalimantan; Maluku; Southeast Sulawesi; Merauke
Narrative: This study addressed wildfire mitigation as an NbS for Indonesian tropical rainforests, with REDD+ relevance. It formulated a prioritization using indices: wildfire susceptibility (WSI), carbon stock (CSI), and carbon emission (CEI). WSI summed five factors—drought (KBDI), precipitation (CHIRPS), wind (ERA5), population, and accessibility—classified 1–5, then aggregated. CSI pooled four carbon-stock datasets (WHRC above-ground, Global Above-ground, Global Below-ground, NASA/WCMC) to a 500 m grid and computed mean and variation. CEI relied on Sentinel-5P gas emissions (CO, NO2, SO2) via an Air–RGB model, then linked with land-surface temperature, night lights, and population; data were resampled to 1 km. The three indices were integrated as WPI = WSI + CSI + CEI and classed by quantiles into high/medium/low. Validation against deforestation showed 379,516 km2 in high priority (Sumatra, Kalimantan, North Maluku), with 19.5% deforested; 5.2% and 3.9% overlapped with oil palm and mining areas. Outputs include a 1‑km wildfire map and hotspot analysis.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The datasets generated during and/or analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

File: Wang et al. - 2025 - Multi-objective spatial optimization of forest fire monitoring networks An integrated GIS-MCDM fram.pdf
Input_Variables: Altitude (DEM/TIN); Slope (DEM-derived); Land-cover type (Land cover data); Solar radiation (Solar radiation data); Mean annual temperature (Annual average temperature data); Wind speed (Weather data); Distance from rivers (Water system data); Distance from roads (Road network data)
Spatial_Method: FUCOM-based weighting of evaluation indicators; GIS-based weighted overlay analysis to generate a suitability map (excluding restricted areas such as lakes and farmland); extraction of optimal monitoring-point locations from the suitability classes.
Method_Validation: Comparative analysis with the existing monitoring layout (Pareto solution vs current layout); Consistency Ratio (CR) checks for the AHP judgment matrices (CR values < 0.1 across schemes); Sensitivity analysis of the monitoring radius Rmax.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: NA
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic costs are a core OUTPUT objective (f3) with construction and operation costs Ce and Co, minimized under a budget constraint Cmax; costs are integrated via normalization and a weighted-sum fitness using AHP-derived weights, and results include currency-based outputs (economic cost in CNY) and quantified reductions (e.g., from 2.198×10^6 to 2.146×10^6 CNY, ~10.2% reduction) plus discussions of cost-effectiveness across Pareto-optimal schemes.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Shanxi Province, China;Yangquan City, Shanxi Province, China
Narrative: NbS spatial prioritisation targeted deploying forest fire monitoring points to strengthen early warning and risk management. Inputs included eight indicators—altitude, slope, land cover, solar radiation, mean temperature, wind speed, distance from rivers and roads—derived from GIS layers (DEM, DOM, land-cover data, weather data, boundaries, water systems, villages) with lakes and farmland excluded; 268 km2 Shanxi area ranged 700–1370 m. A GIS–MCDM–IGA framework normalized with Mu = 268 km2, budget 25 million CNY, max distance 20 km, combining f1 = coverage, f2 = road distance, f3 = cost with f2/f3 inverted. Weights from AHP; FUCOM improved input weighting. An integer-encoded IGA with adaptive differential evolution and elitism produced Pareto fronts and 200 optimal points. Validation against GA/PSO showed faster convergence and higher-quality solutions; coverage rose 18.6% to 1.795×10^8 m2, road distance fell 50% to 1.064×10^4 m, and cost declined 10.2% to 2.146×10^6 CNY. Outputs include optimized schemes and GIS visualization for Shanxi.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: All relevant data are within the paper and its Supporting information files.

File: Aduana-Alcantara et al. - 2023 - Mangrove Land Suitability Assessment Using Weighted Linear Combination A Case Study of La Union Pro.pdf
Input_Variables: Elevation (ASTER Global Digital Elevation Map); Slope (ASTER Global Digital Elevation Map); Air Temperature (Global Solar Atlas); Precipitation (WorldClim)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multicriteria analysis using Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) in ArcMap, integrating raster layers of elevation, slope, precipitation, and air temperature with equal weights to produce mangrove suitability classes.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Mangrove land suitability map for La Union Province (classes: unsuitable, marginally suitable, moderately suitable, highly suitable)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS is explicitly targeted for climate-change mitigation and coastal hazard adaptation, and the authors demonstrate this by producing mangrove suitability outputs that identify four priority sites for rehabilitation, thereby operationalizing climate-resilience in the NbS planning.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: La Union Province;Aringay;Bangar;Sto. Tomas;City of San Fernando;Agoo;Balaoan;Bauang National: Philippines;Vietnam;Indonesia;Australia;Papua New Guinea;Malaysia;Iran;Saudi Arabia
Narrative: The NbS addressed were mangrove rehabilitation and reforestation along La Union Province coastline. The main inputs were elevation and slope from the ASTER GDEM, and bioclimatic factors—air temperature from the Global Solar Atlas and precipitation from WorldClim—at 30-arc second resolution; La Union spans about 1,497 km2. The spatial method used was a GIS-based Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) in ArcMap, combining layers with S = sum Wi Xi, where Xi is the class score and Wi the weight; weights were assumed equal. Validation: no field validation was described; ground truthing was emphasized. Key results identified four suitable sites along the coast within Bangar, San Fernando, Aringay, and Sto. Tomas; Agoo, Balaoan, and Bauang were not reflected due to data resolution. Outputs included a mangrove land suitability map (30 s) and four sites. Geographic scope: provincial scale, La Union, Philippines. Climate risk was included via temperature and precipitation; economic factors were not.

File: Al‐Huqail et al. - 2024 - An ML-Based Ensemble Approach for the Precision Classification of Mangroves, Trend Analysis, and Pri.pdf
Input_Variables: NDVI (Landsat 8 OLI 2023; Landsat Collection 1 Tier 1); NDWI (Landsat 8 OLI 2023; Landsat Collection 1 Tier 1); LST (Landsat 5-8 thermal bands; Landsat Collection 1 Tier 1); τNDVI (Kendall tau-b; Landsat 5-8 time series 1991–2023); τNDWI (Kendall tau-b; Landsat 5-8 time series 1991–2023); τLST (Kendall tau-b; Landsat 5-8 time series 1991–2023)
Spatial_Method: Generalized additive model (GAM) using NDVI, LST, NDWI and their Kendall tau-b trends to derive a normalized suitability score for mangrove plantation; Moran’s I analysis to assess spatial clustering of the suitability.
Method_Validation: Independent accuracy assessment using independent test samples with confusion matrix metrics (OA, producer and user accuracy, KC); 60/40 train–validation split for ML mangrove classification with stratified random sampling; 10-fold cross-validation for GAM to assess robustness; Visual validation with high‑resolution Google Earth imagery and NDVI overlay; Comparison with the Global Mangrove Watch (GMW) dataset; Moran’s I analysis to assess spatial clustering of the suitability.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Mangrove plantation suitability map (classes: not suitable; moderately suitable; highly suitable)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They frame climate change as a threat to mangrove viability and long-term restoration success, and they demonstrate this by integrating climate-related environmental predictors and their long-term trends into a site-suitability assessment to screen NbS outcomes under climate-driven constraints.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: the NbS is spatially targeted to reduce climate risks by restoring mangroves to bolster coastal protection and carbon sequestration, and the authors demonstrate this through a spatial prioritization of mangrove reforestation areas (e.g., a group with high suitability) and by framing the outputs as supporting climate mitigation and adaptation actions for coastal resilience.
Narrative: NbS addressed: mangrove conservation and priority reforestation to enhance coastal protection and resilience along the Asir coast, Saudi Arabia. Inputs and data sources included Landsat data (Landsat 8 OLI 2023; 1991–2023 Landsat 5–8), spectral indices (NDVI, NDWI, SR, GCVI) and LST, elevation from ASTER GDEM, 37,682 ML training/testing pixels (60/40), 399 reference points, Google Earth Engine, and Global Mangrove Watch for comparison. The spatial method and data fusion used an ensemble classification of mangrove vs non-mangrove with RF, SVM, and XGB and majority voting, coupled with NDVI/NDWI and elevation masking; outputs were at 30 m resolution, yielding mangrove area 14.69 km2 distributed across groups a–e (2.46, 4.48, 2.37, 4.55, 0.83 km2). A GAM-based reforestation suitability analysis integrated 2023 NDVI, LST, NDWI and their Kendall’s tau-b trends with weights (NDVI=3); adj R2=0.89 and R2=0.91, with 77% of Group e highly suitable. Validation used OA 91.3% and KC 0.83, plus a 10-fold CV and Moran’s I for clustering. Scope: Asir coast (≈200 km × 10 km). Climate variables included; no economic analysis.

File: Alevizos and Barillé - 2023 - Global ocean spatial suitability for macroalgae offshore cultivation and sinking.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: ocean afforestation; macroalgae open-ocean mariculture and sinking (MOS)
Input_Variables: GEBCO bathymetry (https://www.gebco.net/data_and_products); Distance to nearest port (https://globalfishingwatch.org); N:P ratio (Froehlich et al., 2019); Marine Protected Areas (UNEP-WCMC, 2019); Hydrothermal vents (InterRidge, http://vents-data.interridge.org); Submarine cables (ArcGIS Hub, https://hub.arcgis.com/maps); Major shipping lanes (Benden, 2022); Important Marine Mammal Areas (IUCN MMPATF, 2022)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based spatial multi-criteria evaluation (SMCE) approach that scores global layers with Gaussian functions for bathymetry (target 1500–3500 m), distance to port, and nutrient ratio, applies thresholds to delineate MOS- and sink-suitable areas, and uses exclusion buffers around sensitive features (MPAs, hydrothermal vents, submarine cables, major shipping lanes, marine mammal areas) to produce the final suitability maps.
Method_Validation: Comparison with other studies/maps
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Global MOS suitability map (macroalgae offshore cultivation + sinking); Global sink-only suitability map (macroalgae sinking-only)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: climate hazards such as storms are described as factors that could reduce MOS biomass growth and CO2 removal efficacy, threatening suitability and persistence, and the authors demonstrate this through discussion of environmental variability effects on biomass and by presenting scenario-based assessments of MOS feasibility under climate-goal scenarios.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS is explicitly targeted for climate-change mitigation through CO2 removal (MOS), and the authors demonstrate this with scenario-based prioritisation and global/EEZ-scale MOS- and sink-suitable area maps that quantify potential CO2 removal and its relevance to 2100 climate targets.
Economics: Yes: Economic aspects are integrated in the OUTPUT analysis through economic feasibility framing—distance to port (Gaussian scoring) and depth/industrial constraints are included in MOS/sink suitability criteria, with discussion of costs, energy footprints and potential economic pathways, though no explicit economic metrics (ROI, NPV, cost-benefit, etc.) are reported in the output maps.
Geographic_Scope: Global: world; Philippines; China; France; Canada; United States; Norway; Denmark; Brazil; New Zealand; Russia; Iceland; Ecuador; Chile; Portugal; Japan; Ireland; Australia; Mauritania; Spain; Jamaica; South Korea; Algeria; Cuba; India; Indonesia; Fiji; Papua New Guinea; Micronesia; Solomon Islands; Vanuatu; North Korea; United Kingdom
Narrative: NbS spatial prioritisation addressed macroalgae offshore cultivation and sinking (MOS) for ocean carbon dioxide removal. Main inputs were geospatial layers including GEBCO bathymetry, distance to port, N:P ratio, Marine Protected Areas (WDPA), hydrothermal vents, submarine cables, shipping lanes, and Important Marine Mammal Areas (IUCN MMPATF); sources included GEBCO, Froehlich 2019, UNEP-WCMC 2019, InterRidge, ArcGIS hub, Zenodo, and IUCN 2022. A GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation converted inputs into suitability scores with Gaussian functions (e.g., bathymetry m=2500, s=1000; distance to port m=300, s=600; N:P m=30, s=20) and applied binary exclusions; potential MOS and sinking areas were distinguished, with a sequestration horizon 1000 m and a depth filter of 1500–3500 m. Validation was not described. Outputs consisted of suitability maps totaling 10.8M km2 for MOS and 32.8M km2 for sinking, and MOS within EEZs ~4.8M km2 and sinking within EEZs ~18.4M km2. The scope was global; port-distance reflected logistics; climate-risk layers were not explicit.

File: Blanco‐Sacristán et al. - 2022 - Mangrove distribution and afforestation potential in the Red Sea.pdf
Input_Variables: AMT (WorldClim); MDRM (WorldClim); IBIO (WorldClim); TS (WorldClim); MTWM (WorldClim); MTCM (WorldClim); TARBIO (WorldClim); MTWeQ (WorldClim); MTDQ (WorldClim); MTWaQ (WorldClim); MTCQ (WorldClim); AP (WorldClim); PWM (WorldClim); PDM (WorldClim); PS (WorldClim); PWeQ (WorldClim); PDQ (WorldClim); PWaQ (WorldClim); PCQ (WorldClim); Elevation (ALOS DSM); SSTmean (NASA MODIS-Aqua Level-3); SSTmin (NASA MODIS-Aqua Level-3); SSTmax (NASA MODIS-Aqua Level-3); SSTrange (NASA MODIS-Aqua Level-3); SSS (Bio-Oracle); PARmean (Bio-Oracle); PARmax (Bio-Oracle); pH (Bio-Oracle); Clay (OpenLandMap); Bulk (OpenLandMap); Texture (OpenLandMap); Sand (OpenLandMap)
Spatial_Method: MaxEnt presence-only species distribution modeling using environmental and soil variables to identify suitable mangrove restoration/afforestation areas; CART-based supervised classification of Sentinel-2 imagery (NDVI) to map current mangrove extent and delineate priority areas.
Method_Validation: Cross-validation (10 replicates) with MaxEnt (75% training, 25% testing) and ROC/AUC evaluation; CART classification validation via confusion matrices (user, producer, overall accuracies) with 20 splits; cross-sensor validation by comparing Sentinel-2 mangrove maps with Landsat 8 results; validation by comparison with existing mangrove extent maps from previous studies.
Tool: MaxEnt (Phillips et al., 2004) ; CART (Breiman et al., 1984)
Tool_Source: MaxEnt : Used to map the potential distribution of Red Sea mangroves and identify afforestation sites by modeling presence-only mangrove occurrences (5000 centroids) against a 32-variable environmental/soil dataset with 10,000 background points, via the dismo MaxEnt implementation in R, producing a 0–1 suitability map (AUC = 0.86) and enabling estimation of current and potential carbon sequestration (with 10-fold cross-validation). ; CART : Used to map current mangrove extent from Sentinel-2 imagery by applying a Classification and Regression Tree using NDVI and eight Sentinel-2 bands at 10 m, with 420 points per class across 20 random splits, achieving high accuracies (~97.6% overall) and producing high-resolution mangrove extent maps (also contrasted with Landsat‑8 results).
Output: Potential mangrove afforestation suitability map (occurrence probability >0.5; classes: low/medium/high)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors treat mangrove restoration as a climate adaptation/mitigation NbS and target areas with high potential for carbon sequestration; they demonstrate this by using MaxEnt to map suitable sites for restoration and by quantifying current and potential mangrove carbon sequestration rates (Mg C yr−1) by country.
Narrative: The NbS addressed were mangrove afforestation/restoration along the Red Sea for climate mitigation and coastal protection. Main inputs included Sentinel-2 imagery at 10 m for current mangroves (≈98% accuracy) and NDVI, plus a 32-variable bioclimatic/soil dataset from WorldClim, ALOS DSM, NASA MODIS SST, Bio-Oracle, and OpenLandMap; 5,000 presence centroids and 10,000 background points. Spatial method: current extent mapped with CART at 10 m; potential distribution modeled with MaxEnt (75/25 train/test; 10-fold CV; AUC 0.86) using the 32 variables after removing non-contributors and retaining non-collinear pairs (r<0.8). The MaxEnt output (>0.5) was resampled to 10 m to yield 410.9 km2 potential and 175.3 km2 current mangroves (S2), with per-country totals. Validation showed mangrove-class accuracy ≈98% (S2) and overall 97.6%; soil variables explained ≈91% of potential distribution. Outputs include 10 m maps; carbon sequestration estimates: current 1034 ± 181 Mg C yr−1 and potential 2424 ± 423 Mg C yr−1; no economic analysis. Geographic scope: Red Sea region. Climate risk addressed via carbon sequestration; economic considerations were not analyzed.

File: Burke et al. - 2023 - Spatially targeting national-scale afforestation for multiple ecosystem services.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Working with Natural Processes; Natural Flood Management
Input_Variables: Carbon sequestration rate (Bathgate 2011; Randle & Jenkins 2011); Yield class (Bathgate 2011); Accumulated temperature (Bathgate 2011); Continentality (Bathgate 2011); Aspect (Bathgate 2011); Moisture deficit (Bathgate 2011); Moisture regime (Bathgate 2011); Nutrient regime (Bathgate 2011); Flood mitigation potential (Environment Agency WWNP; Hankin 2017); Distance to river mouth (derived from WWNP; Hankin 2017); Recreation value (£/km2/a) (Day & Smith 2016; Day 2017); Physical constraints (Burke 2021); Environmental constraints (peat and bog) (Burke 2021)
Spatial_Method: Normalize each ecosystem service layer (carbon sequestration, recreation, flood mitigation) to 0–100; compute the mean across the three services to create a combined ecosystem service value (CESV); identify priority cells using a richest‑cells intensity hotspot approach and select the top CESV cells within each planning unit; remove unsuitable areas using constraint maps.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool: ORVal (Day & Smith, 2016); Ecological Site Classification (ESC) model (Bathgate, 2011)
Tool_Source: ORVal: A statistical recreation demand model used to estimate visitation and monetary welfare values for a hypothetical new woodland site (1 km2) centered in each grid cell, thus quantifying recreation benefits; Ecological Site Classification (ESC) model: Used to predict the yield class (forest productivity) of woodland in each grid cell for Sitka Spruce and Beech, which is then converted via lookup tables to annual carbon sequestration rates (averaged over the first 100 years) to build the carbon sequestration layer.
Output: Combined ecosystem-services value (CESV) suitability map (normalized 0–100); Carbon sequestration potential map (tCO2e/km2/yr); Recreation welfare value map (£/km2/yr); Flood mitigation potential map (normalized index 0–100); Afforestation allocation maps (planting scenarios: national, regional, county, district, parish, random)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors explicitly target nature-based solution afforestation to deliver climate-mitigation (carbon sequestration) and climate-adaptation (flood mitigation) benefits and demonstrate this via scenario-based spatial prioritisation across scales that quantify and compare carbon sequestration and flood-mitigation outputs.
Economics: Yes: Economic aspects are included in the OUTPUT by monetizing recreation (ORVal) to £/km2/year and deriving a combined ecosystem services value (CESV) with equal weights across three services; carbon and flood outputs remain in physical or normalised index units, and the paper also discusses economic framing in terms of land-conversion costs and net-value (costs vs benefits) considerations for planning, though no ROI, NPV, cost‑effectiveness ratios, or explicit payments for ecosystem services are reported.
Geographic_Scope: National: England; Regional: England; County: England; District: England; Parish: England
Narrative: The NbS addressed was afforestation for multiple ecosystem services in England. Inputs included 1 km2 grid cells; climate and soil data fed the Ecological Site Classification to predict yield classes for Beech and Sitka Spruce, with carbon sequestration from lookup tables; recreation valued with the ORVal model; flood mitigation from the WWNP dataset. Planting densities were 70 ha Beech and 30 ha Spruce. The spatial method used an intensity approach: normalised service layers (0–100) were averaged to yield a Combined Ecosystem Services Value (CESV), then the richest cells were selected within units; five scales plus baseline. 8,400 cells (840,000 ha) for national planting were identified. Validation absent. Results showed carbon sequestration broadly invariant; recreation and flood mitigation more variable, with flood mitigation differences exceeding 200% between parish and national scales. Outputs were CESV maps at 1 km2 and ES metrics. England; climate and economy included via carbon and recreation values.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apgeog.2023.103064.

File: Busch et al. - 2024 - Cost-effectiveness of natural forest regeneration and plantations for climate mitigation.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Passive natural regeneration; Assisted natural regeneration
Input_Variables: Implementation costs of natural regeneration (World Bank project documents; peer-reviewed and grey literature); Implementation costs of plantation (World Bank project documents; peer-reviewed and grey literature); Opportunity costs of reforestation (World Bank Living Standards Measurement Studies via FAO RuLIS; MapSPAM; FAO GLW); Most likely plantation genus (Spatial Database of Planted Trees; World Resources Institute); Carbon accumulation in natural regeneration (Cook-Patton et al. 2020; Bukoski et al. 2022); Carbon accumulation in plantations (Bukoski et al. 2022)
Spatial_Method: Constructed 1 km resolution spatial layers of implementation and opportunity costs, carbon accumulation (natural regeneration and plantations) and likely plantation genus; applied geographic suitability and proximity buffers to delineate suitable areas; used machine learning to assign the most likely plantation genus and Chapman–Richards growth-based carbon projections; and built marginal abatement cost curves to determine the least-cost reforestation method per cell and map priority areas.
Method_Validation: Sensitivity analyses
Tool_Source: NA
Output: More cost-effective reforestation method map (classes: natural regeneration, plantation; 1 km); Abatement cost map — natural regeneration (US$ per tCO2; 30‑yr, 5% discount; areas feasible for natural regeneration; 1 km); Abatement cost map — plantation reforestation (US$ per tCO2; 30‑yr, 5% discount; areas feasible for plantations; 1 km); Carbon accumulation map — natural forest regeneration (tC ha−1; 30‑yr, time‑discounted 5%; 1 km); Carbon accumulation map — plantations including harvested wood products (tC ha−1; 30‑yr, time‑discounted 5%; 1 km)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target NbS (reforestation) for climate-mitigation, mapping where natural regeneration or plantations yield carbon benefits and lower abatement costs, and present 30-year marginal abatement cost curves and country/region carbon-accumulation outputs to demonstrate mitigation outcomes.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT includes economic aspects—abatement cost (US$ per tCO2) for natural regeneration and plantations; marginal abatement cost curves; implementation and opportunity costs; net revenue from wood products; scenarios where plantations are profitable without carbon payments; and it aggregates these over 30 years with a 5% discount rate (Faustmann rotation) to derive cost-effectiveness.
Geographic_Scope: Global: 138 LMICs; Brazil; China; Mexico; India; Myanmar; Colombia; Indonesia; Thailand; Democratic Republic of the Congo; Venezuela; Malaysia; Ethiopia; Cuba; Ecuador; Paraguay; Dominican Republic; Honduras; Gabon; Afghanistan; The Gambia; Pakistan; Palau; Zimbabwe
Narrative: The study addressed natural forest regeneration and plantations as NbS reforestation options for climate change mitigation. It built six key spatial inputs on 1 km grids across 138 low- and middle-income countries: implementation costs of natural regeneration and of plantation reforestation, each with data from 355 observations across 99 documents; opportunity costs of reforestation based on land rent and household surveys; a most likely plantation genus (e.g., 45.5% eucalyptus, 14.5% Cunninghamia, 11.9% Populus, 11.0% Acacia, 9.4% Pinus, 4.7% Tectona, 1.7% Shorea); and carbon accumulation for natural regeneration and for plantations (with harvested wood products). Carbon-storage estimates used data for aboveground, belowground and soil pools, plus wood-product storage, over 30 years and discounted at 5%. The spatial method employed machine learning regression to map the six inputs, combined them to produce marginal abatement cost curves (MACCs) at 1 km resolution, and, for each cell, selected the more cost-effective method (natural regeneration, plantation, or both) using equations that layered costs, carbon gains, and wood-product revenues, with suitability screens ( Griscom 43; 5 km seed-source buffers; 40 km plantation buffers) and additionality filtering. Validation drew on 355 project observations and extensive sensitivity analyses; results showed median abatement costs of US$23.80 tCO2 for natural regeneration (IR US$3.60–79.70) and US$23.00 tCO2 for plantations, with 31.4 GtCO2 potential below US$50 tCO2 when using the cheaper method at each site; 46% of suitable area favored natural regeneration and 54% plantations, across 593 Mha. Outputs include MACCs for natural regeneration, plantations and the joint option at 1 km resolution, with regional and country-level summaries; the study constrained reforestation potential to 10.1% of land area deemed suitable, excluding mangroves and non-viable lands, across 12 biomes in LMICs. Geographic scope was global but limited to 138 LMICs; carbon-price–driven results were framed as 30-year horizons (2020–2050) with 5% discount, not including external costs or climate-risk effects on growth. The analysis did not model climate risk impacts and treated economic factors as central, noting limitations such as growth under climate change and wood-demand feedbacks.

File: Cruz-Bello and Sotelo-Ruiz - 2013 - Coupling Spatial Multiattribute Analysis and Optimization to Identify Reforestation Priority Areas.pdf
Input_Variables: Erosion (SEMARNAT-COLPOS 2003; Van Lynden 1997); Land use and land cover (INEGI 2009); Position in the watershed (SWAT); Soil type (INEGI 2004); Slope (DEM); Precipitation (National Meteorological System)
Spatial_Method: SMART (simple multiattribute rating technique) to identify and rank restoration attributes; GIS-based raster data layers for those attributes; 0–1 integer programming optimization to select zones that maximize reforestation benefits within budget.
Method_Validation: Ground-truth validation of land use/land cover data; Ground-truth validation of Landsat ETM–based land use interpretation.
Tool_Source: SMART: Used to identify and rank the attributes important for prioritizing reforestation, elicit expert weights (0–100) for each attribute, transform ratings to a standardized scale, and generate a spatial priority score for each pixel to feed the optimization (weights aggregated by geometric mean and normalized). ; LingoH: Used to solve the 0–1 integer programming optimization that selects reforestation zones to maximize environmental benefit within a fixed budget, implementing the model and enforcing the binary and budget constraints.
Output: Reforestation priority map (very low; low; moderate; high; very high); Optimization-selected reforestation allocation map (selected; not selected — 17,059 ha selected)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic considerations are embedded in the OUTPUT analysis through a cost-constrained optimization—cost per hectare US$110 and a total annual budget of US$1,875,152 determine the set of areas (17,059 ha) selected as reforestation priorities, with results shown by priority category (very low to very high) under the budget.
Narrative: An integrated spatial prioritisation approach addressed reforestation (tree restocking) in Estado de México, Mexico (22,555 km2). The main inputs were six attributes—erosion, land use/land cover, position in the watershed, soil type, slope, and precipitation—derived from SEMARNAT-COLPOS 2003 erosion data (ASSOD), INEGI land cover (1:250,000), edaphologic maps (1:50,000), SWAT-based watershed delineation from a DEM, and precipitation interpolated from the National Meteorological System; data were resampled to 100 m (1 ha per pixel). SMART gathered weights from 14 specialists (Table 1) and y = sum xi bi; results were categorized into five classes using Weber–Fechner cuts, with Gower residuals assessing attribute contributions. Pixels were aggregated into 108,930 zones (2,255,500 pixels) for 0–1 integer programming in LingoH to maximize environmental benefit under US$1,875,152 (US$110/ha), selecting 17,059 ha. Outputs include 100 m priority maps; Very high priority covered 644,642 ha (28.6%), and 96% of the state ranged from moderate to very high priority. Precipitation and budget provided climate/economic context.

File: Dubovyk - 2013 - Multi-scale targeting of land degradation in northern Uzbekistan using satellite remote sensing.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Afforestation of degraded cropland; Elaeagnus angustifolia L. plantations; Tree windbreaks; Shelterbelts
Input_Variables: Change in land use (Machwitz et al. 2010); Uncultivated land (Machwitz et al. 2010); Soil bonitation I (Ramazonov and Yusupbekov 2003); Soil bonitation II (Ramazonov and Yusupbekov 2003); Soil bonitation III (Ramazonov and Yusupbekov 2003); Soil bonitation IV (Ramazonov and Yusupbekov 2003); Canal density (ZEF/UNESCO Khorezm project database; Mott-MacDonald 2011); Collector density (ZEF/UNESCO Khorezm project database; Mott-MacDonald 2011); Water use (Mott-MacDonald 2011); Slope (ZEF/UNESCO Khorezm project database; Mott-MacDonald 2011); Groundwater table (Ibrakhimov et al. 2007); Groundwater salinity (Ibrakhimov et al. 2007); Proximity to canals (ZEF/UNESCO Khorezm project database; Mott-MacDonald 2011); Proximity to collectors (ZEF/UNESCO Khorezm project database; Mott-MacDonald 2011); Proximity to pumps (ZEF/UNESCO Khorezm project database; Mott-MacDonald 2011); Proximity to roads (ZEF/UNESCO Khorezm project database; Mott-MacDonald 2011); Proximity to settlements (ZEF/UNESCO Khorezm project database; Mott-MacDonald 2011); Proximity to water bodies (ZEF/UNESCO Khorezm project database; Mott-MacDonald 2011)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based multi-criteria decision-making (MCDA) framework combining expert knowledge, fuzzy logic, and a weighted linear combination to produce a suitability map for afforesting degraded irrigated cropland with Elaeagnus angustifolia.
Method_Validation: Field verification / ground-truthing; Cross-evaluation with land use/land cover categories; Evaluation of change map
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Suitability map for afforestation with Elaeagnus angustifolia on degraded irrigated cropland; Vegetation‐trend (land degradation) map from MODIS ΣNDVI (classes: high / medium / low negative trend, other); Parcel‐based vegetation‐cover decline map from Landsat (classes: decreased / unchanged); Land‐degradation risk map from spatial logistic regression (probability/risk classes)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They justify afforestation of degraded cropland as NbS for climate change mitigation (carbon sequestration) and adaptation to climate-driven water scarcity, and demonstrate this through a regional land degradation risk map and parcel-scale land-suitability maps for afforestation to guide NbS deployment.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis includes economic framing—afforestation is framed as a means to improve rural livelihoods and realize biomass production and carbon sequestration benefits, integrated in the spatial decision support via a multi-criteria evaluation that includes socio-economic factors (population density, land use, infrastructure) with biophysical criteria to map land suitability for rehabilitation.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Khorezm Province; Sub-national: Autonomous Republic of Karakalpakstan (Southern Karakalpakstan; SKKP); National: Uzbekistan
Narrative: NbS addressed afforestation of degraded irrigated cropland with Elaeagnus angustifolia L. in northern Uzbekistan (Khorezm and SKKP). Inputs included 250 m MODIS NDVI (2000–2010) for LD via ΣNDVI trend; Landsat TM data for vegetation decline; 2001–2009 LULC maps; ancillary data on groundwater table and salinity, canal/collector densities, water use, population density; field validation of 828 plots in 2011. The approach combined trend analysis to map degradation, relational analysis linking LD to biophysical/socioeconomic factors, spatial logistic regression to produce an LD risk map at 250 m, and a GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation using expert knowledge, fuzzy logic, and weighted linear combination to map suitability for afforestation. Validation showed 93% Landsat agreement with LD trend map; 23% (94,835 ha) degraded; key drivers: GWT, land-use intensity, soil quality, slope, GWS. Outputs: LD risk map (250 m) and a 30 m vegetation decline map. Climate risk acknowledged; afforestation livelihoods considered but no explicit economic inputs.
Contacts_Email: No email address found in the provided text.

File: Dubovyk et al. - 2014 - Land Suitability Assessment for Afforestation with Elaeagnus Angustifolia L. in Degraded Agri.pdf
Input_Variables: Irrigation water use Khorezm (regional irrigation water supplies, 2000-2010); Irrigation water use SKKP (regional irrigation water supplies, 2000-2010); Proximity to canals Khorezm (Irrigation canals network data); Proximity to canals SKKP (Irrigation canals network data); Canal density Khorezm (Irrigation canals network data); Canal density SKKP (Irrigation canals network data); Proximity to collectors Khorezm (Irrigation collectors network data); Proximity to collectors SKKP (Irrigation collectors network data); Collector density Khorezm (Irrigation collectors network data); Collector density SKKP (Irrigation collectors network data); Groundwater table Khorezm spring (Ibrakhimov et al., 2007; 2011); Groundwater table Khorezm summer (Ibrakhimov et al., 2007; 2011); Groundwater table Khorezm autumn (Ibrakhimov et al., 2007; 2011); Groundwater table SKKP spring (Ibrakhimov et al., 2007; 2011); Groundwater table SKKP summer (Ibrakhimov et al., 2007; 2011); Groundwater table SKKP autumn (Ibrakhimov et al., 2007; 2011); Groundwater salinity Khorezm spring (Khamzina et al., 2006a; 2006b); Groundwater salinity Khorezm summer (Khamzina et al., 2006a; 2006b); Groundwater salinity Khorezm autumn (Khamzina et al., 2006a; 2006b); Groundwater salinity SKKP spring (Khamzina et al., 2006a; 2006b); Groundwater salinity SKKP summer (Khamzina et al., 2006a; 2006b); Groundwater salinity SKKP autumn (Khamzina et al., 2006a; 2006b); Slope Khorezm (DEM-derived); Slope SKKP (DEM-derived); Cropland degradation map (MODIS 250m time series, 2000-2010; Dubovyk et al., 2013a)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation incorporating fuzzy membership functions and an Ordered Weighted Averaging/weighted linear combination of expert-weighted criteria, with the resulting suitability map overlaid onto a cropland degradation map to identify priority areas for afforestation.
Method_Validation: Sensitivity analysis (omitting one criterion at a time) to test weight/criterion importance with map comparisons (R2 values); Comparison of equal-weight WLC and expert-weight WLC suitability maps; Attempted validation using in situ crop distribution data (not possible in this study)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Afforestation suitability map for Elaeagnus angustifolia on degraded irrigated cropland (continuous 0–1; suitable >=0.5)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Khorezm Province; Southern Karakalpakstan; Amudarya River Basin (lower Amudarya River Basin), Uzbekistan; National: Uzbekistan
Narrative: NbS addressed: afforestation of degraded irrigated croplands with Elaeagnus angustifolia L. in the lower Amudarya River Basin, Uzbekistan, as agroforestry/reclamation. Main inputs included performance data from eight experimental sites; suitability criteria from the ZEF/UNESCO database; a 250 m MODIS cropland degradation map (2000–2010); and district-level data on irrigation water supply (2000–2010), proximity/density of irrigation canals and drains, groundwater table depth (spring–fall), groundwater salinity, and slope, reprojected to ED 1950 UTM 41N. The GIS-based MCE combined fuzzy logic with a weighted linear combination (OWA), using expert-derived weights (rank 1–5). Validation used leave-one-criterion-out sensitivity tests and comparison of equal- vs expert-weight WLC (Khorezm R2 0.93, SKKP 0.89; irrigation water R2 up to 0.98). Outputs were a continuous 0–1 suitability map; 75,287 ha (18%) of degraded cropland deemed suitable; overlaid with MODIS degradation map; district statistics. Scope: Khorezm and Southern Karakalpakstan, Uzbekistan; area 662,042 ha, 410,000 ha irrigated. Climate risk via irrigation water variability; no explicit economic criteria.

File: Gupta et al. - 2024 - Optimizing land use for climate mitigation using nature based solution (NBS) strategy a study on af.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Farm forestry; Silvoarable systems; Hortipasture; Agri-horti; Silvopasture; Sole pasture
Input_Variables: Land Cover (Glob Cover ESA); Slope (SRTM USGS); Soil Moisture (Sentinel-2); NDVI (Sentinel-2); Region Boundary (GAUL FAO)
Spatial_Method: A raster-based Multi-Criteria Evaluation (MCE) that integrates land cover, slope, soil moisture, and NDVI to identify suitable afforestation areas.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Afforestation suitability map (Overall suitability: 2=highly suitable, 1=least suitable, 0=not suitable); Spatial carbon sequestration potential map (Amla: ~0–8.2 tCO2e/ha/yr by suitability class; low–high); Spatial carbon credit potential map (carbon credits ~0–0.03 tCO2e/ha/yr by suitability class; low–high)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They describe desertification, drought, and other climate hazards as threats to the long-term viability and effectiveness of afforestation and carbon sequestration in Rajasthan, and they demonstrate this by discussing temperature and wind anomaly indicators and desertification trends alongside the suitability results, framing hazard contexts as potential limits to NbS performance and resilience in their results and conclusions.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly frame afforestation as an NbS to mitigate climate change and support adaptation to desertification in Rajasthan. They demonstrate this by producing area-specific afforestation suitability assessments and calculating species-specific carbon sequestration and carbon credits, illustrating climate-risk reduction and mitigation outcomes.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT integrates economic aspects by quantifying carbon sequestration potential and translating it into carbon credits (Cseq = Σ Si × Ai × R; carbon credits = CO2e ÷ 1000; one credit = 1 tCO2e) using the Verified Carbon Standard framework, and explicitly discusses carbon-market monetization and socio-economic benefits to local communities, including potential livelihoods and employment benefits; it references past economic impacts related to forest changes (e.g., $214.57 million losses vs $17.19 million in potential sequestration) but does not present a full ROI/NPV or cost‑benefit analysis within this study.
Narrative: The study addressed afforestation as a Nature-based Solution (NbS) for climate change mitigation in Rajasthan, India. It used Sentinel-2 imagery (cloud-filtered), Glob Cover (ESA), SRTM-based slope (USGS), NDVI, and Sentinel-2-based soil moisture, delineating Rajasthan with the GAUL boundary (FAO). A Multi-Criteria Evaluation (MCE) merged land cover, slope, soil moisture and NDVI to produce per-pixel suitability scores, excluding slope >15°, soil moisture <0.1 and NDVI <0.3. Validation was not described. Results suggested about 40% of Rajasthan was suitable for afforestation, with potential carbon sequestration 2–8 tCO2e ha−1 yr−1; species rates included Neem 5, Khejri 10, Rohida 15, Ber 20, and Amla 25 tCO2e ha−1 yr−1. Outputs comprised 30 m resolution suitability maps, and carbon sequestration and carbon credit estimates calculated by Cseq = Σ(Si × Ai × R), 1 credit = 1 tCO2e, over ~342,239 km2.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The datasets collected and/or analyzed during the current investigation can be obtained from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
Contacts_Email: shruti.kanga@cup.edu.in; suraj.kumar@mygyanvihar.com; saurabhkr.gupta@mygyanvihar.com; gowharmeraj@g.ecc.u-tokyo.ac.jp; saurabh.singh@mygyanvihar.com; bhartendu.sajan@mygyanvihar.com; kumar@iges.or.jp; rakeshsingh.soi@surveyofindia.gov.in; sunil22phd@cup.ac.in; varun9686@gmail.com

File: Hossain et al. - 2003 - Remote Sensing and GIS Applications for Suitable Mangrove Afforestation Area Selection in the Coasta.pdf
Input_Variables: Soil texture (Soil Resources Development Institute, Bangladesh); Tidal area (Landsat TM image 12 February 1999); Soil pH (Soil Resources Development Institute, Bangladesh); Soil salinity (Soil Resources Development Institute, Bangladesh); Existing land use patterns (field investigations; government offices and local people)
Spatial_Method: ISODATA unsupervised classification; Maximum Likelihood supervised classification; weighted and scored land suitability assessment (three classes: most suitable, moderately suitable, not suitable) based on soil type, soil pH, soil salinity, tidal area and existing land use to identify suitable mangrove afforestation areas.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: ENVI : Used as the image processing software to analyze Landsat TM imagery and perform both unsupervised (ISODATA) and supervised (ROI-based, parallelepiped and Maximum Likelihood) classifications to derive the land-use/land-suitability map for mangrove afforestation.
Output: Land suitability map for mangrove afforestation [Most suitable; Moderately suitable; Not suitable]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They explicitly describe cyclone-driven hazards, siltation and wave action that threaten survival and long-term viability of mangrove plantations, and discuss potential sea-level rise altering zonation; they demonstrate this through reported survival rate variability (10%–90%), losses to siltation/wave action, and discussion of climate-change–driven changes to suitability and zonation.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS (mangrove afforestation) is positioned to reduce cyclone- and storm surge–related risks along the coast, and the authors demonstrate this via a land-suitability map that identifies the most suitable areas (2,146 ha) for mangrove planting to function as a protective shelter belt.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Cox's Bazar district; National: Bangladesh
Narrative: The study addressed mangrove afforestation along Cox’s Bazar coast as a Nature-based Solution to mitigate cyclones. Inputs included Landsat TM imagery (12 Feb 1999) to locate mudflats; 1:10,000 topographic maps (Survey of Bangladesh, 1999); 1:50,000 soil maps (Soil Resources Development Institute, 1996/1999); a digitized study-area map; and field data from 50 plots. A GIS-based land-suitability assessment weighted five criteria (soil texture 30, tidal area 30, soil pH 10, soil salinity 10, land use 20) and scored three levels (3/2/1), with Maximum Likelihood classification. Ground truth from 50 plots yielded RMS error 0.49, less than one 30 m pixel. Outputs included a land-suitability map at ~30 m resolution, classifying areas as most suitable (2,146 ha), moderately suitable (1,605 ha) and not suitable (1,524 ha). Geographic scope was Cox’s Bazar district, southeastern Bangladesh (lat 21°15'–22°N, lon 91°45'–92°15'E). Cyclone protection motivated the study; climate risk and economic factors were not explicit inputs.

File: Jusoff - 2008 - Geospatial Information Technology for Conservation of Coastal Forest and Mangroves Environment in Ma.pdf
Input_Variables: Soil Fertility (ECOCROP database); Drainage (ECOCROP database); Texture (ECOCROP database); Depth (ECOCROP database); pH (ECOCROP database); Slope (Topography map); Cloud Cover (Satellite imagery); Snow Cover (Satellite imagery); Soil Moisture (Satellite imagery); Topography (Topography map); Basin Boundary (Geographical boundary map); Road Network (Ways network); Land Use/Land Cover (Land use/land cover map)
Spatial_Method: Boolean method-based site suitability analysis; Fuzzy method-based site suitability analysis; GIS-based overlay and multiplication of environmental factor maps to identify suitable mangrove planting areas and to express degrees of suitability via fuzzy memberships.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: IDRISI for Windows (Clark Labs) : Used as the GIS/RS software to implement fuzzy and Boolean site suitability analyses for mangrove reforestation; it provides fuzzy membership functions (Sigmoidal, J-Shaped, Linear and User-defined) and enables layering, overlaying and multiplying thematic maps to derive suitable planting sites and compare Boolean vs fuzzy classifications.
Output: Mangrove site suitability map — Boolean (suitable / unsuitable); Mangrove site suitability map — Fuzzy (continuous suitability 0–1 / classes poor–high); Proposed forest land‑use allocation map (proposed forest land use plan)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic framing is present—the paper notes that land-use decisions depend on physical and economical factors and that costs are significant for mangrove afforestation, indicating economic viability considerations in selection—but there are no explicit economic outputs or metrics (no cost-benefit, ROI, NPV, etc.) reported; outputs are suitability maps derived from environmental data with embedded economic considerations.
Narrative: NbS addressed mangrove reforestation and coastal forest management in Malaysia, focusing on sustainable site selection for mangrove planting. Key inputs included GIS/RS layers (topography, basin boundary, road network) and ecological factors (soil fertility, drainage, texture, depth, pH), dynamic RS variables (cloud cover, soil moisture), FAO ECOCROP data, stakeholder interviews, and historical land-use/land-cover maps for 1973, 1987, 1993 and 1998. The approach combined two spatial methods: Boolean (0/1) and fuzzy (0–1) logic. Overlay of factor maps followed by multiplication with limitation maps produced suitable-site outputs; in the fuzzy method, membership functions (Sigmoidal, Linear, asymmetrical second degree, S) and a minimum operator were used. Validation comprised a Boolean–fuzzy comparison (Figure 6) with no field validation reported; major outputs were maps of suitable mangrove sites, land-use/land-cover maps, changes between 1987–1993 and 1993–1998, and a proposed forest land-use plan. Scope: Malaysia’s coastal mangroves; economic factors were considered; climate risk not explicitly modeled.

File: McVicar et al. - 2007 - Developing a decision support tool for China's re-vegetation program Simulating regional impacts of.pdf
Input_Variables: Landuse/Land Cover (Shen, 1991); Percent Woody Cover (Shen, 1991); Land Limits (Shen, 1991); DEM (Hutchinson, 2004a); Slope (Hutchinson, 2004a); Aspect (Hutchinson, 2004a); Precipitation (ANUSPLIN interpolated surface from 58 stations; 21-year average) (McVicar et al., 2005a); Pan Evaporation (Epan) (McVicar et al., 2005a); Re-vegetation Area Dataset (McVicar et al., 2005b); Target Level (Re-vegetation Area Dataset) (McVicar et al., 2005b); Land Limit Type (Re-vegetation Area Dataset) (McVicar et al., 2005b); Vegetation Suitability Dataset (McVicar et al., 2005b); Catchment Boundaries (SedNet) (Wilkinson et al., 2004); County Boundaries (Li et al., 2005b)
Analysis_Resolution: 100 m for the first two analysis functions; county-level (catchment) for the third (113,000 km2 Loess Plateau study site).
Spatial_Method: GIS overlay with a Boolean suitability assessment to map per-cell suitability for 38 woody species; and a DEM-based downhill-buffer approach identifying steep-slope/gully zones and defining 100 m-wide priority areas downhill from SSG boundaries within defined target areas.
Method_Validation: Local calibration against observed runoff using 36 hydrology stations (minimising the difference between simulated and measured runoff); validation via comparison of actual vs modelled mean annual evapotranspiration and runoff shown in crossplots (1:1 lines).
Tool_Source: ReVegIH : A bilingual decision-support tool used to (1) identify priority/target re-vegetation areas and suitable species at 100 m resolution, and (2) simulate the average-annual hydrological impacts (evapotranspiration and runoff) of afforestation scenarios in the Loess Plateau, at catchment/county scale, using a steady-state aerial-weighted ET model driven by 21-year climate averages to enable scenario comparison and runoff-reduction assessment.
Output: Re-vegetation suitability and priority map (100 m) [target levels: trees / shrubs / grasses; priority zones]; Species suitability map (100 m) [38 woody species: suitable / not suitable]; Average annual streamflow impact map (catchment/county) [runoff reduction: Ml, %]
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Loess Plateau; Sub-national: Coarse Sandy Hilly Catchments (CSHC); Sub-national: Yellow River Basin; Sub-national: North China Plain; Sub-national: Shaanxi Province; National: China
Narrative: The NbS addressed was re-vegetation/afforestation under China’s Grain for Green and Sloping Land Conversion programs, operationalized in a decision support tool called ReVegIH to prioritise where to undertake re-vegetation and to simulate hydrological impacts on average annual streamflow in the Loess Plateau. Key inputs and data sources included 21-year average meteorology (precipitation from 58 stations 1980–2000 interpolated with ANUSPLIN and pan evaporation; 21-year averages and trends), a 1986 1:500,000 Land Use/Land Cover map resampled to 100 m, a 100 m ANUDEM DEM, 42 catchments and county boundaries, a 100 m re-vegetation area dataset (target level and land-limit type, WUF/WUFA), vegetation suitability for 38 woody species, and 36 hydrology stations for calibration (1980–2000). The spatial method used a regional aerial-weighted evapotranspiration model (steady-state) that combined area-averaged precipitation, ET, and potential ET with land-use Change via Zhang et al.’s hydrology–landuse framework; w2 was locally calibrated as a function of percent non-forested area and dryness index, and computations were performed at catchment or county level, with 100 m resolution for the first two functions and catchment/county aggregation for the hydrology output. Validation used crossplots against 36 stations (1980–2000) showing improved fit after local calibration; four scenario runs in Ansai County yielded runoff reductions of 14.1%, 13.4%, 6.6% and 6.3% across 20.0%, 19.1%, 9.4% and 8.9% area. Outputs comprised ET and runoff at catchment/county scale, with two 100 m resolution layers for land-use/vegetation and 500 m for precipitation/pan evaporation, enabling 100 m precision maps of priority re-vegetation areas over the Loess Plateau’s Coarse Sandy Hilly Catchments (CSHC; ~112,728–113,000 km2). Climate risk and economic considerations were not included in the core steady-state model (climate trends discussed separately; economic analysis deferred to future work).

File: Nyeko - 2012 - GIS and Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis for Land Use Resource Planning.pdf
Input_Variables: NDVI (Landsat 7); Elevation (SRTM); Rainfall map (gauge measurements; Kriging); Settlement (Landsat 7, 2001); Road network (Landsat 7, 2001); Population density (Census 2002); Reference land use (2001 land cover map)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis using Weighted Linear Combination to derive suitability scores from raster criteria; weights derived from the Analytical Hierarchy Process.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR < 0.1 threshold)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Afforestation suitability map (suitability classes 1–5); Land-use scenario maps (6 scenarios; forest cover per scenario: 7.5%, 37.5%, 4.6%, 23.2%, 42.9%, 2.6%)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Northern Uganda;Sub-national: Aswa basin;National: Uganda
Narrative: The study addressed afforestation and agricultural land-use expansion as NbS-like strategies in the Aswa basin, Uganda (12,225 km2).
