Inputs included NDVI from Landsat 7; elevation from SRTM DEM; rainfall mapped by Kriging from 40 gauges; settlement and road networks digitized from 2001 Landsat 7; population density 2002; a 2001 reference land-cover map; and a stream network from DEM. A GIS–MCDM approach used Weighted Linear Combination (S_k = sum w_i x_k,i) with weights via Analytical Hierarchy Process; maps were re-scaled to a 1–8 raster. Validation relied on AHP consistency checks (CI and CR for forest were 0.006/0.004 and 0.07, both <0.1). Outputs were suitability maps and land-use-change maps generating ten treatments (six unique scenarios) across eight land-use classes; afforestation ranged 4.6–42.9% and agriculture 6.2–53.7% of the basin. Resolution: raster maps with eight categories. Climate risk was addressed in the rationale; rainfall served as a criterion; no explicit economic considerations were included.

File: Penny et al. - 2023 - Analysis of potential nature-based solutions for the Mun River Basin, Thailand.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Furrows; Small farm ponds; Subsurface floodwater harvesting systems; Oxbow lake reconnections; Living weirs; Agroforestry
Input_Variables: Slope (ALOS-JAXA); Elevation (ALOS-JAXA); Land Use Type (Land Development Department); Mean rainfall (Khadka et al. 2022); Drainage Density (Distance from Mun River); Soil Types (Harmonised World Soil Database)
Spatial_Method: MCDA-GIS framework employing a raster-based weighted overlay of six driving factors (slope, elevation, land-use type, rainfall, drainage density, soil type) reclassified by Jenks natural breaks with equal weights to map flood hazard; applied to land-use change scenarios (FOR, CROP, WET, and combinations) to identify priority areas for NBS.
Method_Validation: Validation against observed flood events (2004–2022): 136 flood locations plotted on the flood hazard map and validated by extracting raster cell values with ArcMap Sample tool (independent test dataset).
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Scenario flood-hazard maps (Observed; BAU; FOR; CROP; WET; NBS1; NBS2; NBS3) [Very low–Very high hazard]; Flood-hazard change/reduction maps (BAU/Observed vs NBS scenarios) [Decrease/Increase in hazard class]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They treat climate hazards as a risk that could undermine NbS effectiveness, showing that near-future climate raises flood hazard under BAU and that different NbS (especially in combination) mitigate or change future hazard outcomes, demonstrated through hazard maps and scenario comparisons across observed, BAU, and NbS scenarios.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target areas to reduce flood risk under near-future climate change, and demonstrate this with scenario-based hazard mapping comparing baseline/BAU to single and combined NbS deployments, showing reductions in high-hazard areas.
Narrative: The NbS addressed wetlands, re/afforestation and changing crop types to mitigate flood and drought hazards in the Mun River Basin, northeast Thailand, including three NbS combinations: NBS1 FOR+WET, NBS2 FOR+CROP, and NBS3 FOR+WET+CROP. Main inputs included six raster layers (slope, elevation; land use; soil types; drainage density; mean rainfall) plus climate for 2021–2050 under SSP5‑8.5 from eight CMIP6 HighResMIP models. The method was MCDA‑GIS, where layers were reclassified to 1–5 by Jenks, equally weighted six factors in ArcMap, and combined by a weighted sum to produce flood-hazard maps; LU scenarios were used to assess hazard reduction. Validation used 136 flood locations with ~90% alignment. Results showed single NbS modestly reduced hazard, while NBS3 yielded the largest reduction (12% drop in very low and 11% in very high hazard vs BAU, ~15% of area with decreased hazard). Outputs were raster flood-hazard maps at basin scale; climate risk was included; economic aspects were not.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data cannot be made publicly available; readers should contact the corresponding author for details.

File: Richert et al. - 2011 - A method for linking results from an evaluation of land use scenarios from the viewpoint of flood pr.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: afforestation; Ecological transformation of spruce forests into forests which correspond to potential natural vegetation
Input_Variables: Biotope types (field mapping; aerial photographs; ArcView GIS 3.2); Endangered species (LfUG 1999a Red list of ferns and seed plants); Land use and/or vegetation types (digital maps) ; Soil types or geological formations (Soil Conceptional Map 1:25 000 Saxony); River network (not stated); Digital elevation model (DEM) (not stated); Slope (DEM); Porosity (Soil properties) (Soil Conceptional Map 1:25 000 Saxony); Soil storage capacity (Soil properties) (Soil Conceptional Map 1:25 000 Saxony); Saturated hydraulic conductivity (Soil properties) (Soil Conceptional Map 1:25 000 Saxony); Root depth (Soil properties) (Soil Conceptional Map 1:25 000 Saxony); Precipitation (WBS-FLAB); Discharge (WBS-FLAB); Map of runoff components (WBS-FLAB)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based fine-scale mapping of biotope types (1:2500) with a conservation-value scoring system; landscape-metrics analysis using FRAGSTATS (SHDI, MPS, IJI) to identify high-priority patches and connectivity.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool: WBS-FLAB (Peschke et al., 1999) ; FRAGSTATS (McGarigal & Holmes, 2000) ; Vlate (Vector-based Landscape Analysis Tools Extension for ArcGIS – SPIN project, 2001–2004) ; WASIM-ETH (Pöhler, 2007)
Tool_Source: WBS-FLAB : expert system used to identify runoff generation processes and assess the hydrological situation to locate areas at risk of runoff in the catchment ; FRAGSTATS : grid-based landscape pattern analysis program used to calculate the Interdispersion/Juxtaposition index (IJI) to infer habitat network connectivity and border contacts between biotope types ; Vlate : ArcGIS-based tool used to compute landscape metrics SHDI (Shannon diversity index) and MPS (mean patch size) for selected biotope types ; WASIM-ETH : precipitation-runoff model used to simulate discharge and evaluate potential discharge reductions under land-use change scenarios, supporting hydrological interpretation
Output: Biotope conservation-priority map (evaluation classes 1–5); Runoff-generation map showing areas dominated by fast vs slow runoff components (fast/slow); Land-use scenario allocation maps (pres, grass, nat, flood, comb) [land-use classes: coniferous forest; deciduous forest; extensive grassland; arable land; settlement]
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Weissbach sub-basin; Weisseritz basin; Saxony; Germany
Narrative: The study addressed nature-based solutions for flood prevention and nature conservation by evaluating land-use scenarios in a mountainous agricultural landscape. NbS practices included transforming arable fields into extensively used grasslands (e.g., mountain meadows), ecological transformation of forests (to potential natural vegetation), afforestation, restoration of watercourses, and preserving high-conservation biotope types while excluding changes in settlements. Primary inputs were fine-scale biotope-type maps (69 types) for the Weissbach sub-basin (7.4 km2) at 1:2500, field and aerial data, topography, soils/geology, river network and DEM, endangered species lists, plus landscape metrics (SHDI, mean patch size, IJI) using ArcView GIS 3.2 and FRAGSTATS; hydrology relied on the WBS-FLAB runoff-generation expert system. The spatial method combined two parallel assessments—nature-conservation (biotope-value and landscape metrics) and hydrological (fast versus slow runoff)—into a normalised, weighted synthesis to compare four scenarios (grass, nat, flood, comb). Validation compared results with present state, showing nat/flood/comb improving both aims; outputs include 1:2500 biotope maps, scenario maps, land-use proportions, and final scores, at the 7.4 km2 Weissbach scale. Climate risk or economic considerations were not included.

File: Şenol et al. - 2025 - GIS-Based Multi-Criteria Analysis for Urban Afforestation Planning in Semi-Arid Cities.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope (SRTM DEM); Aspect (SRTM DEM); Elevation (SRTM DEM); LST (Landsat 8); Solar Radiation (SRTM DEM); Flow Accumulation (SRTM DEM); Distance to Roads (OpenStreetMap); Distance to Settlements (OpenStreetMap); Land Cover Suitability (Sentinel-2)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based MCDA using AHP weights to integrate nine ecological and infrastructure criteria; and a deep learning-based land cover classification (U‑Net CNN) to create an exclusion mask that removes unsuitable areas from the suitability analysis.
Method_Validation: Confusion-matrix based accuracy assessment (OA; Kappa; Producer’s PA and User’s UA; Precision, Recall, F1) using stratified reference points from CORINE 2018, high-resolution imagery, and manually annotated ground-truth points; Independent evaluation ensuring no training tiles were used; AHP consistency check (CR = 0.044, below 0.10)
Tool: Land Cover Classification using Deep Learning (Esri; ArcGIS Living Atlas of the World); Classify Pixels Using Deep Learning (Esri; ArcGIS Pro)
Tool_Source: Land Cover Classification using Deep Learning: Used to produce a 15-class CORINE-based land cover map from Sentinel-2 imagery by applying Esri’s pretrained deep learning model (from ArcGIS Living Atlas) to identify ecologically suitable vs. unsuitable areas, serving as a binary exclusion/constraint layer in the GIS-based MCDA afforestation analysis (OA 83.7%, κ 0.81). ; Classify Pixels Using Deep Learning: Used within ArcGIS Pro to run the pretrained .dlpk model on Sentinel-2 data to generate the LULC map (15 CORINE classes) without retraining, providing the LULC input that is exclusionary for afforestation planning and feeds the MCDA; four input bands (R, G, B, NIR) were used in the classification.
Output: Afforestation suitability map (highly suitable; suitable; moderately suitable; unsuitable)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target afforestation as a climate adaptation/mitigation NbS in urban areas to reduce heat stress and bolster resilience, and demonstrate this by producing a final afforestation suitability outcome that pinpoints peripheral zones where cooling benefits and adaptation potential are maximized.
Narrative: The NbS addressed was urban afforestation planning as a nature-based solution to mitigate heat in Şanlıurfa, Türkiye. Nine input layers included topography (SRTM 30 m; slope, aspect, elevation), Land Surface Temperature from Landsat 8 (USGS EarthExplorer), solar radiation, flow accumulation, land cover from a Sentinel-2 Level-2A deep-learning classification (15 CORINE categories; Copernicus Open Access Hub), and proximity to roads and settlements (OpenStreetMap), with an exclusion mask. A GIS-based MCDA with AHP weights used Weighted Linear Combination to yield a four-class map (0.75–1.00 highly suitable; 0.50–0.75 suitable; 0.25–0.50 moderately suitable; 0.00–0.25 unsuitable) with a constraint mask. Validation reported OA 83.7% and Kappa 0.81; Scrublands Precision 76%, Open Land 81%. The MCDA identified 192.06 km2 acceptable and 151.33 km2 highly suitable within ~450 km2, concentrated in NE and SE peri-urban zones. Geographic scope encompassed Şanlıurfa’s Eyübiye, Haliliye, Karaköprü and adjacent areas; climate risk was addressed via LST/UHI; economic factors were not included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Sentinel-2 data from Copernicus Open Access Hub (https://dataspace.copernicus.eu/), Landsat 8/9 data from USGS EarthExplorer (https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/), OpenStreetMap vector data (https://www.openstreetmap.org)

File: Teng et al. - 2022 - Identifying prioritized afforestation types in ecologically vulnerable zones of Northern China consi.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: shrub afforestation on bare land; afforestation on bare land; afforestation on grassland; shrub afforestation on grassland; tree afforestation on grassland; shrub planting on grassland; grassland restoration; grassland rehabilitation
Input_Variables: Land use type (RESDC 30 m); Soil type (RESDC 30 m); Aridity (Wu et al., 2021); Slope (DEM); Elevation (DEM)
Spatial_Method: Water erosion assessment with RUSLE and wind erosion assessment with RWEQ to map ecologically vulnerable zones; MaxEnt habitat suitability modeling to identify suitable afforestation areas for trees and shrubs; overlay of vulnerable zones and suitable areas to delineate potential afforestation regions; scenario-based prioritization across four goals to identify prioritized afforestation types.
Method_Validation: Comparison with the distribution of existing forests and shrubs (consistency with known locations); Validation of wind erosion modeling using the 137Cs tracing technique (adopting the evaluation method and parameters from Chi et al., 2019).
Tool: MaxEnt (Zhu and Qiao, 2016) ; RUSLE (Fu et al., 2011; Yi et al., 2015) ; RWEQ (Chi et al., 2019)
Tool_Source: MaxEnt: identify potential suitable afforestation regions by predicting the potential distribution/suitability of tree and shrub habitats (forests/shrubs) in Northern China; RUSLE: assess water erosion intensity and compute the annual erosion modulus from monthly calculations; RWEQ: evaluate wind erosion intensity and derive the annual wind erosion modulus for ecologically vulnerable zones (with validation using Cs tracing).
Output: Ecologically vulnerable zones (HWAE, HWIE, HWA&IE); Suitable afforestation areas (HST; MST&HSS; MSS); Potential afforestation regions (vulnerability × suitability combinations); Prioritized afforestation type maps under four scenarios [S1: minimize WC; S2: maximize CS; S3: maximize CS in humid & minimize WC in arid; S4: maximize SC & SF]; Spatial carbon sequestration (CS) and water consumption (WC) maps
Climate_Benefit: Yes: they explicitly target afforestation NbS in ecologically vulnerable zones to reduce water consumption (adaptation) and increase carbon sequestration (mitigation), and demonstrate this through scenario-based prioritization that compares CS, WC, SC and SF across regions to reveal climate-relevant benefits.
Narrative: NbS-based afforestation identified prioritized tree/shrub types and grassland restoration to reduce water consumption and boost carbon sequestration in Northern China. Inputs included erosion-based vulnerability (RUSLE for water erosion; RWEQ for wind erosion), aridity index, NDVI, soil/land-use data, DEM and snow depth from CMA, TPDC, RESDC and NASA MODIS; Harmonized World Soil Database data; resampled to 1 km. MaxEnt estimated forest/shrub habitat suitability; suitable areas were overlaid with vulnerable zones to define potential afforestation regions. ArcGIS 10.6 with Zonal Statistics extracted mean CS, WC, SC and SF by vegetation type across 35 districts in 13 provinces. Four scenarios guided prioritization: minimize WC; maximize CS; maximize CS in humid and minimize WC in arid; and maximize SC and SF. Validation used 54 plots with 137Cs (R2=0.89). Outputs included 1-km maps and area totals (HWAE 0.31; HWIE 1.37; HWA&IE 0.04; HST 0.85; MST&HSS 0.68; MSS 0.46) million km2. Climate risk addressed via aridity zoning; no explicit economic assessment.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data will be made available on request; Supplementary data available online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecolind.2022.109734.

File: Προδρόμου et al. - 2025 - Remote-Sensing-Based Prioritization of Post-Fire Restoration Actions in Mediterranean Ecosystems A.pdf
Input_Variables: Fire severity (Sentinel-2); Fire history (Dosis et al., 2023); Tree density (Copernicus Land); Land cover (Corine Land Cover/ ESA World Cover (GEE)); Slope (85,101); Elevation (SRTM (GEE)); Aspect (66,86); Precipitation (CHIRPS (GEE)); Temperature (MODIS (GEE))
Spatial_Method: AHP-based multi-criteria decision analysis (GRESTO Index) implemented in Google Earth Engine that standardizes nine criteria (elevation, slope, aspect, land cover, tree density, dNBR burn severity, fire frequency/history, mean temperature, precipitation) and aggregates them with weights via a weighted linear summation to map restoration priority.
Method_Validation: Comparison with Department of Forests restoration actions; Accuracy assessment using a stratified random sample of 1000 points with a confusion matrix (OA, precision, recall, F1); Multi-class ROC analysis with AUC per class; AHP consistency check (CR = 0.07); Sensitivity analysis of weights (One-At-A-Time).
Tool_Source: GRESTO Index : A geospatial, AHP-based decision-support tool developed to prioritize post-fire restoration actions in Cyprus by integrating nine indicators (fire severity, tree density, land cover, fire history, slope, elevation, aspect, precipitation, temperature) to produce a three-class restoration priority map (low/medium/high); implemented on Google Earth Engine for scalable, cloud-based analysis; validated against Department of Forests actions with 80.9% overall accuracy, 0.70 recall for high priority, and 0.79 AUC; uses the formula GRESTO = 3.8×SLOPE + 2.6×ELEVATION + 2.6×ASPECT + 29.4×dNBR + 10.1×FIRE FREQUENCY + 16.9×LAND COVER + 6.2×LST + 6.2×PRECIPITATION + 22.4×TREE DENSITY to guide cost-effective restoration planning and identify high-priority zones (24% high, 66% medium, 10% low), with sensitivity analysis confirming robustness.
Output: GRESTO reforestation priority map [low; medium; high]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: they frame wildfire risk and climate-driven variability (burn severity, fire frequency, mean temperature and precipitation) as constraints that influence restoration feasibility and effectiveness, embedding them as key criteria in the GRESTO Index and demonstrating their impact via the AHP weights and a sensitivity analysis that highlights hazard-related factors as major drivers of prioritization outcomes.
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis is framed by economic considerations—cost-effectiveness and economic impact are discussed, with explicit figures for reforestation/monitoring costs (EUR 1,532,387 and EUR 1,350,952.4) and Cyprus’ wildfire costs (EUR 18.6 million in 2021; about EUR 15 million/year forest budget) and a stated aim of cost-effective restoration planning; however, the RN output itself is an AHP-weighted ecological prioritization without explicit economic metrics (no ROI/NPV/CEA values reported in the output).
Geographic_Scope: Local: Solea; Sub-national: Nicosia district; National: Cyprus
Narrative: NbS addressed: post-fire restoration prioritization in the Mediterranean, demonstrated with the GRESTO Index for Cyprus. Main inputs and data sources: nine indicators—fire severity (Sentinel-2 dNBR, 10 m; pre-fire 18 Jun 2016, post-fire 28 Jun 2016), tree density (Copernicus Land), land cover (Corine/ESA World Cover via GEE), fire history/frequency (EFFIS; Sentinel-2 dNBR), slope, elevation, aspect (SRTM), mean temperature (MODIS), and precipitation (CHIRPS). Spatial method and combination: Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) weights (fire severity 29.4%; tree density 22.4%; land cover 16.9%; fire history 10.1%; precipitation 6.2%; temperature 6.2%; slope 3.8%; elevation 2.6%; aspect 2.6%), then a weighted linear sum RN to yield a three-class (low/medium/high) priority map. Validation and results: 1000 stratified samples vs Department of Forests actions; OA 80.9%, high-priority recall 0.70, AUC 0.79; sensitivity analysis showed robustness. Outputs and resolution: a prioritized three-class raster for the Solea area (102.96 km2) with the GRESTO equation. Geographic scope: Solea, Nicosia district, Cyprus. Climate factors included (temperature, precipitation); economic criteria were not used.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data are contained within the article.
Contacts_Email: maria.prodromou@eratosthenes.org.cy; christodoulos.mettas@eratosthenes.org.cy; marios.tzouvaras@eratosthenes.org.cy; k.themistocleous@eratosthenes.org.cy; d.hadjimitsis@cut.ac.cy; igitas@for.auth.gr; com.ca@frederick.ac.cy; epampots@gmail.com

File: Bai et al. - 2018 - Developing China’s Ecological Redline Policy using ecosystem services assessments for land use plann.pdf
Input_Variables: Carbon storage and sequestration (InVEST 3.2.0); Water storage (InVEST 3.2.0); Water purification (InVEST 3.2.0); Soil conservation (InVEST 3.2.0); Soil erosion (DEM; soil characteristics; rainfall; vegetation cover; management factor); Desertification (Humidity index; days with wind >6 m s−1; soil texture; vegetation cover; evapotranspiration/rainfall); Salinization (groundwater mineralization; topography); Habitat quality (InVEST habitat quality model); Ecosystem services hotspots (InVEST 3.2.0); Ecologically fragile hotspots (Delphi method); Biodiversity hotspots (InVEST habitat quality model); Stakeholder opinions (Survey data); LULC maps (2005; 2014) from multitemporal aerial images (0.5 m); Rainfall (11 monitoring stations; local data); GDP (Shanghai Statistical Yearbook); Population density (Shanghai Statistical Yearbook); Distance to main rivers (ArcGIS 10.0); Distance to roads (ArcGIS 10.0); Distance to railways (ArcGIS 10.0); Distance to ports (ArcGIS 10.0); Distance to airports (ArcGIS 10.0)
Spatial_Method: InVEST models were used to map ecosystem services hotspots and biodiversity hotspots; a Delphi expert-judgement process identified ecologically fragile hotspots; hotspots were defined as the top 10% of each indicator; overlays of ES hotspots, ecologically fragile hotspots and biodiversity hotspots were summed (overlaps counted once) to produce optimal ecological redline areas at a 50 m grid, mapped in ArcGIS.
Method_Validation: Kappa coefficient validation of CLUE_S model results (Kappa = 0.92); ROC validation of logistic regression models predicting LULC (ROC > 0.7); credibility validation of hotspot thresholds by relating ES/biodiversity/ecologically fragile hotspots to total ES production, vulnerable areas and suitable biodiversity habitat (local-expert/stakeholder validation).
Tool: InVEST 3.2.0 models (InVEST +VERSION+ User’s Guide; The Natural Capital Project) ; FRAGSTATS (McGarigal, Cushman & Ene; https://www.umass.edu/landeco/research/fragstats/fragstats.html)
Tool_Source: InVEST 3.2.0 models : Used to estimate ecosystem services and biodiversity hotspots (carbon storage/sequestration, water storage/yield, water purification (nitrogen retention), soil conservation/retention) and habitat quality, map ES hotspots, and quantify ES outputs at multiple scales to ground Shanghai’s Ecological Redline Policy across 2014 and future scenarios; parameterized with local data and LULC inputs to compare policy-relevant scenarios (S1–S4) and to assess ES tradeoffs and synergies. ; FRAGSTATS : Used to compute landscape-level metrics (connectivity index and fragmentation index) to evaluate changes in landscape composition/configuration across scenarios and assess how ES delivery and biodiversity potential respond to ERP-driven zoning.
Output: Ecosystem‑services hotspots (top 10% ES production); Ecologically fragile hotspots (top 10% vulnerability to soil erosion/desertiﬁcation/salinization); Biodiversity hotspots (top 10% suitable habitat); Targeted ecological redline areas (selected ERAs — 1,098 km2); Scenario maps of ecosystem‑service change (spatial % change in carbon sequestration; water conservation; nitrogen retention; soil retention)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: Climate hazards are treated as risks that could threaten NbS outcomes by making ecologically fragile areas vulnerable to climate-driven stressors (notably sea-level rise on Chongming Island). The authors demonstrate this by identifying ecologically fragile hotspots and integrating them with ES and biodiversity hotspots, and by comparing ES outcomes under alternative 2040 scenarios with and without the ERP, showing how the policy could sustain ES under climate-related pressures.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target NbS-based ES (including carbon sequestration for climate-change mitigation and erosion control for adaptation) by defining ecological redline areas to maximize these benefits; they demonstrate this via scenario-based prioritisation, showing the ERP increases carbon sequestration and other ES relative to a development scenario.
Narrative: Developed China’s Ecological Redline Policy (ERP) for Shanghai using ecosystem-services (ES) assessments to identify ecological redline areas (ERAs). The NbS addressed included ES-based protection, biodiversity hotspots, and ecologically fragile hotspots, incorporating landscape structure and stakeholder opinions. Key inputs included ES hotspots (carbon storage/sequestration, water storage, water purification, soil conservation), ecologically fragile hotspots (soil erosion, desertification, salinization) and biodiversity hotspots (habitat quality); data derived from 0.5 m aerial LULC maps for 2005 and 2014, InVEST 3.2.0, DEM, rainfall/runoff/ET, pollution export/filtration coefficients, Delphi input, and surveys (N=849). The spatial method overlaid top 10% hotspots across ES, fragility, and biodiversity (resolution 50 m) to generate ERAs, refined via district negotiations, yielding 1098 km2 (16%) of Shanghai. Validation used CLUE_S (Kappa=0.88) and ROC >0.7; four 2040 scenarios assessed ES, with FRAGSTATS showing CI and FI changes. ERP increased ES flows; outputs were ERA maps and 2040 scenario maps at 50 m for Shanghai Municipality.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: All relevant data are available upon request from the authors.

File: Bentrup and Kellerman - 2004 - Where should buffers go Modeling riparian habitat connectivity in northeast Kansas.pdf
Input_Variables: National Land Cover Dataset (Vogelmann et al., 2001; USGS); Stream network (US Census Bureau TIGER); Orthophotos (USCS); Road data (Kansas Department of Transportation)
Spatial_Method: GIS-guided connectivity assessment (CIS-based method) using NLCD 30 m data to reclassify land cover as riparian vegetation; identify patches ≥0.1 ha and gaps >0.16 km to delineate a connectivity zone; buffer streams by Horton–Strahler order (first-order 80 m total, second-order 100 m, third-order 120 m) to locate where riparian buffers should be implemented.
Method_Validation: Accuracy assessment by comparing the critical gaps identified in the connectivity assessment with digital orthophotos of the same area.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Riparian connectivity/prioritization map identifying critical gaps for riparian buffer implementation (classes: critical gaps; existing riparian remnants/connectivity zone)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic framing is included; the output discussion references cost-share program resources, notes the economic benefit of converting riparian areas to cropland, and aims to maximize benefits by aligning buffer planning with agricultural production, while also mentioning suitability assessments for growing commercially valuable specialty products in buffers, though no explicit quantitative economic metrics (ROI/NPV, cost-benefit, etc.) are reported.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Soldier Creek watershed; Northeast Kansas; Western Corn Belt ecoregion; Kansas; United States
Narrative: The NbS addressed was restoring wildlife connectivity with riparian buffers in Soldier Creek watershed, Kansas. Inputs included 30‑m NLCD (Vogelmann et al., 2001) reclassified to riparian vegetation, a 1:100,000 TIGER stream network (U.S. Census Bureau), topography, census, soils, land cover, wetlands, road data from KDOT, and 1‑m orthophotos for validation. A GIS-based CIS method identified riparian remnants ≥0.1 ha and a connectivity zone, with a dispersal threshold of 0.16 km to define critical gaps. Stream buffers by Horton–Strahler order were 40 m per side for first-order (80 m total), 50 m for second-order (100 m total), and 60 m for third-order (120 m total). Outputs comprised maps of riparian remnants, the connectivity zone, and critical gaps at ~30 m NLCD resolution for a 500 km2 study area in the western Corn Belt. Validation indicated ~81% accuracy; 126 km (22%) of 574 km stream length were critical gaps. Climate risk or economic considerations were not included.

File: Bestari et al. - 2023 - Placement Location Mapping for Nature-based Solutions in Flood Vulnerable Areas as a Disaster Manage.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: porous pavements; riparian zones; detention basins; inland wetlands
Input_Variables: Precipitation (CHIRPS); Slope (DEMNAS); Elevation (DEMNAS); Landuse (Bantul Development Planning Agency); Soil type (Bantul Development Planning Agency); Landform (Bantul Development Planning Agency); Distance to River (Bantul Development Planning Agency); Actual flood data (Bantul Regional Disaster Management Agency); Historical flood data (Bantul Regional Disaster Management Agency); Hydromorphological Landscape Unit (BPBD Bantul)
Spatial_Method: Spatial Multi-Criteria Evaluation (SMCE) in ILWIS to compute flood vulnerability by scoring and weighting multiple parameters; subsequent GIS overlay of SMCE results with Hydromorphological Landscape Unit (HLU) floodplain maps in ArcGIS to identify suitable NbS priority areas.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Flood vulnerability map (High / Medium / Low); Actual and potential hydromorphological landscape unit (HLU) floodplain map (Actual; Potential); HLU vs flood vulnerability overlay map (comparison of actual/potential HLU with vulnerability classes); Nature-based solution location recommendation map (porous pavement; riparian zone; detention basin; inland wetland)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Bantul Regency; Sub-national: Special Region of Yogyakarta; National: Indonesia
Narrative: Placement Location Mapping for NbS in Flood Vulnerable Areas in Bantul Regency addressed flood risk by proposing NbS deployments—porous pavements, riparian zones, detention basins, wetlands. Inputs were rainfall data from CHIRPS, slope and elevation from DEMNAS, land use, soil type, distance to river from Bantul Development Planning Agency, and actual and historical flood data from BPBD. A Spatial Multi-Criteria Evaluation (SMCE) was implemented in ILWIS and the results overlaid with Hydromorphological Landscape Unit (HLU) floodplain maps; ArcGIS performed the overlays. Validation consisted of classifying flood vulnerability into high, medium, and low based on the overlays. Key results showed floodplain HLU of 3,233.63 ha, with actual floodplain 2,570.14 ha and potential 1,046.76 ha, and NbS placements prioritized at Opak–Oyo confluence, produced as NbS Location Recommendation Map highlighting four NbS types. Study area: Bantul Regency, Indonesia, at Opak–Oyo confluence. Climate risk was included via rainfall/flood data; economic considerations were not discussed.

File: Chan et al. - 2006 - Conservation Planning for Ecosystem Services.pdf
Input_Variables: Biodiversity (Various sources); Carbon storage (97–99); Flood control (100–103); Forage production (104); Pollination (105,106); Recreation (101,102); Water provision (NASA Ames Research Center processing of climate station data for 1996–2000 (2005), TOPS)
Analysis_Resolution: 500 ha planning units (approximately 2.24 km × 2.24 km grid).
Spatial_Method: MARXAN optimization on 500-ha planning units within stratification units, using feature-based targets (biodiversity and six ecosystem services) and a suitability/cost layer to maximize coverage and identify priority networks of sites.
Method_Validation: Comparison with existing biodiversity blueprints; service correlation analysis (Pearson’s r) with significance; network overlap analysis (best networks) with expected overlap and G-tests for goodness of fit; robustness check by running MARXAN 20 times per service; irreplaceability similarity analysis
Tool: MARXAN (Ball IR, Possingham HP, Watts MJ, 2000; MARXAN v1.8.2: Marine Reserve Design Using Spatially Explicit Annealing, a Manual)
Tool_Source: MARXAN: An optimization tool used to identify cohesive networks of planning units that meet predefined feature targets (for biodiversity and six ecosystem services) while maximizing overall suitability; applied to the Central Coast ecoregion, with 20 replicate runs per service to sample alternative networks, producing a best-solution network (targets + suitability) and a summed-solution network for irreplaceability to compare biodiversity-focused versus ecosystem-service networks and assess overlaps, trade-offs, and potential side benefits.
Output: Biodiversity priority/allocation map (best MARXAN network; summed‑solution irreplaceability); Carbon storage benefit and priority map (tons stored per planning unit; best MARXAN network); Flood control benefit and priority map (flood‑mitigation score per planning unit; best MARXAN network); Crop pollination benefit and priority map (pollination value for crops per planning unit; best MARXAN network); Water provision benefit and priority map (precipitation–evapotranspiration surplus per planning unit; best MARXAN network)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly treat carbon storage as climate-change mitigation and flood control as climate adaptation, and demonstrate this by prioritizing networks to maximize these two NbS benefits and reporting target achievement for carbon storage and flood control across stratification units, illustrating how NbS locations align with or trade off biodiversity goals.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT includes economic framing/outputs by using value-based benefit functions for six services (carbon storage, crop pollination, recreation, water provision, flood control, forage production) integrated into MARXAN to reflect demand; it reports economic-like metrics such as Added Land and Added Cost (based on service-specific suitability) alongside Biodiversity Benefit and Biodiversity Benefit Ratio to gauge cost-effectiveness, and discusses economic valuation and payments for ecosystem services in the framing, though it does not present monetary ROI/NPV/explicit cost-benefit totals.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Central Coast ecoregion of California;United States of America
Narrative: The NbS spatial prioritisation approach integrated biodiversity conservation with six ecosystem services—carbon storage, flood control, forage production, outdoor recreation, crop pollination, and water provision—in California's Central Coast ecoregion, using MARXAN v1.8.2 to identify 500-ha planning units. Key inputs included feature definitions for each service, stratification units across environmental gradients, targets, and suitability costs; data included carbon biomass, flood-control attributes, forage-production values, pollination, recreation, and water (precipitation minus evapotranspiration; Calwater 2.2a, NASA TOPS 1996–2000). MARXAN was run 20 times per service; outputs comprised best networks, a summed-solution network, and maps of seven services at 500-ha resolution across 11,272 planning units, plus scenario comparisons (Biodiversity, Non-biodiversity, All, Strategic). Validation used Pearson correlations and overlap tests; results showed weak overall correlations (mean r ≈ 0.08; carbon–water r = 0.58) and that the Strategic network reduced negative associations and met targets more effectively. Climate-regulation and economic-demand aspects were incorporated via carbon, water, recreation, and crop/pollination values.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: MARXAN v1.8.2 (optimization software); Data: Protocol S1 supplementary information DOI 10.1371/journal.pbio.0040379.sd001

File: Elkadiri et al. - 2023 - Spatial Optimization of Conservation Practices for Sediment Load Reduction in Ungauged Agricultural.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: natural riparian vegetation; planted riparian buffers; existing riparian vegetation
Input_Variables: Slope (TN LiDAR; TopAGNPS); Drainage area (TopAGNPS; LiDAR); Hydrologic soil group (Web Soil Survey; NRCS); Erodibility factor (K) (NASIS; NRCS); Impervious depth (Impervious depth; NASIS); Specific gravity (Specific gravity; NASIS); Clay content (Clay; NASIS); Silt content (Silt; NASIS); Sand content (Sand; NASIS); Land use/land cover (Crop Data Layer; CDL) (CropScape/NASS); Dominant land use classes (CDL; CropScape/NASS); Crop yield (County-scale crop yields; USDA-NASS); One-year farming practices (RUSLE2; NRCS); Daily precipitation (NOAA; NOAA); Daily min/max temperature (NOAA; NOAA); Dew point (AgGEM; NRCS/AgGEM); Sky cover (AgGEM; NRCS/AgGEM); Wind speed (AgGEM; NRCS/AgGEM); Solar radiation (AgGEM; NRCS/AgGEM); Water bodies delineation for sediment basins (Google Earth/ESRI base maps; Google Earth/ESRI); Sediment basin area (AGWET; AGWET); Barrier height (AGWET; AGWET); Upstream drainage area (AGWET; AGWET); Riparian buffer location (AGBUF; AGBUF software); Buffer vegetation type (AGBUF; AGBUF software); Potential maximum sediment trapping efficiency (AGBUF; AGBUF software); Riparian buffer widths (10/30/60 m) (AGBUF; AGBUF software); Existing riparian vegetation delineation (LiDAR canopy classification; Jones 2022) (Jones et al. 2022).
Spatial_Method: GIS-based field-scale localization and characterization of conservation practices (riparian buffers and sediment basins) using AGBUF/AGWET outputs integrated with AnnAGNPS; hotspot-targeting by classifying sub-catchments into sediment-yield classes (mean, mean±SD, >high, >very high) and ranking sub-catchments by sediment yield per unit area relative to drainage area to identify priority locations.
Method_Validation: TopAGNPS flow-network validation by comparing outputs to high-resolution imagery and GIS layers to avoid pseudo-dams; Calibration/validation of sediment basins by delineating 57 basins from high-resolution imagery and tuning AGWET weir heights to match their observed surface areas.
Tool: AnnAGNPS (Yuan, Locke, Bingner. J. Soil Water Conserv. 2008, 63, 542–551) ; AGBUF (Momm, Bingner, Yuan, Kostel, Monchak, Locke, Gilley. J Environ Qual. 2014, 43, 1736–1753) ; AGWET (Momm, Bingner, Yuan, Kostel, Monchak, Locke, Gilley. Trans. ASABE 2016, 59, 1345–1357) ; TopAGNPS (Garbrecht, Martz. IAHS Proc.-Int. Assoc. Hydrol. Sci. 1996, 235, 169–174; Garbrecht, Martz. J. Hydrol. 1997, 193, 204–213)
Tool_Source: AnnAGNPS: A watershed-scale model used to evaluate long-term effects of farming and conservation practices on water quality in ungauged agricultural watersheds; represents the watershed as sub-catchments (AnnAGNPS cells) linked to reaches and simulates erosion, runoff, sediment detachment/transport/deposition, and pollutant loads under detailed management schedules to quantify sediment load reductions from CPs. ; AGBUF: AGNPS Buffer Utility (AGBUF) used to calculate potential maximum sediment trapping efficiency for riparian buffers within AnnAGNPS cells via GIS data (buffer location, width, vegetation, slope, drainage area) and then convert to actual sediment trapping using daily flow, enabling characterization of riparian buffers across multiple scenarios. ; AGWET: AGWET (AGNPS Wetland Feature) used to delineate and characterize constructed sediment basins (area, barrier height, vegetation, upstream area) and iteratively determine appropriate weir heights to match observed basin areas, providing basin morphologies for AnnAGNPS inputs. ; TopAGNPS: TopAGNPS used for topographic preprocessing (LiDAR-based DEM processing) to subdivide the watershed into reaches and sub-catchments and enforce realistic surface flow routing, yielding the discretization (12,573 sub-catchments and 5,047 reaches).
Output: Riparian buffer opportunity map — agricultural fields classified by sediment-yield class (All; >medium; >high; >very high); Riparian buffer sediment-trapping-efficiency map (sub-catchment level; buffer widths 10 m, 30 m, 60 m; 16 scenarios); Priority sub-catchment map — ranked ratio of accumulated annual sediment-yield per unit area vs accumulated drainage area
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: North Fork Forked Deer River watershed; Sub-national: West Tennessee; Sub-national: Tennessee; Sub-national: Mississippi River Basin; National: United States
Narrative: NbS conservation practices addressed were riparian buffers, sediment basins, crop rotations, and Conservation Reserve Program. Inputs included the AnnAGNPS model with GIS; LiDAR topography (1 m, resampled to 3 m); NOAA climate data (2008–2018) with AgGEM; soils from Web Soil Survey (NASIS via NITA) and CropScape CDL (2008–2018) with USDA-NASS county yields; RUSLE2-based management schedules; riparian buffers via AGBUF and basins via AGWET. North Fork Forked Deer River watershed (631.31 km2; six HUC-12s) was partitioned into 12,573 AnnAGNPS sub-catchments. The spatial method fused GIS field-scale CP localization with AnnAGNPS simulations; 33 scenarios (buffer widths 10, 30, 60 m across 16 locations plus baseline) and 4135 crop rotations were evaluated. Validation used an ungauged-watershed setting, showing riparian buffers most effective and reductions of 38–48% vs baseline. Outputs included sediment-load reductions at 3 m buffer resolution within 12,573 sub-catchments; climate data informed modeling; economic trade-offs with productive-area loss addressed via a multi-objective function.

File: Feng-xia and Liu - 2010 - Applications of remote sensing and GIS to the assessment of riparian zones for environmental restora.pdf
Input_Variables: Landsat TM image (Landsat); DEM (10 m resolution) (DEM); Stream/river networks (DEM-derived hydrography); Water bodies (DEM-derived vector water bodies); 1999 land cover map (1999 land cover data); 30 m land cover data (30 m land cover map); Grand River watershed boundary (Grand River watershed boundary); Subbasin boundaries (Subbasin boundaries); Cropland in buffers (Landsat TM land cover map; DEM-derived buffers); Buffer widths (25, 50, 75, 100, 125, 150, 175, 200 m) (Buffer width design scenarios); GPS-based ground-truth points (GPS-based ground-truth points)
Spatial_Method: Supervised Landsat TM land-cover classification; DEM-derived stream networks with multi-width buffer generation (25–200 m) via proximity analysis; cropland within buffers quantified by subbasin and relative buffer cropland proportion used to rank restoration priority.
Method_Validation: Field verification / ground-truthing (GPS-based ground-truth points)
Tool_Source: PCI Geomatica V9.1 : Used to perform all image processing for the Landsat TM data analysis, including supervised land‑cover classification with a maximum-likelihood classifier, generation and rasterization of riparian buffers (converted to 5 m resolution) and related GIS operations to estimate cropland in buffers across subbasins.
Output: Cropland in buffers by subbasin (25, 50, 75, 100, 125, 150, 175, 200 m); Spatial distribution of croplands in buffers by subbasin (25–200 m buffers); Percentage of cropland in buffers over total buffer area by subbasin (priority ranking)
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: Riparian buffer restoration in agricultural watersheds was the NbS addressed. Inputs were a Landsat TM image (June 20, 2004; 30 m), a 10 m DEM for water networks, 500 training samples across 11 Grand River subbasins, and a 1999 land-cover map; classifications used an ML classifier yielding 14 classes, later aggregated to agriculture, open water, and other land use, with overall accuracy 81.75% and Kappa 0.7761. The spatial method employed a catchments-based framework: eight riparian buffer widths around streams (25–200 m) were generated, rasterized to 5 m, and overlaid with cropland data resampled to 5 m to inventory farmland within buffers by subbasin; a linear relationship between buffer width and cropland area was observed for prioritization. Outputs included 5 m buffer grids, land-cover maps, and cropland inventories by subbasin for the Grand River (Ontario, Canada; 11 subbasins). Climate or economic data were not included (economic considerations discussed for future integration).

File: Funk et al. - 2018 - Identification of conservation and restoration priority areas in the Danube River based on the multi.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: reconnection of sidearms; removal of artificial bank material; abandonment of intensively used agricultural land in floodplains and their conversion into natural habitats; abandonment of agricultural polders; restoration of stagnant water bodies
Input_Variables: urban (Copernicus land use/land cover data, EEA 2015b); agriculture (Copernicus land use/land cover data, EEA 2015b); riparian_zone_extents (Potential Riparian Zones dataset, EEA 2015b); navigation1 (Classification of European Inland Waterways, Economic Commission for Europe, 2012); navigation2 (Fairway and Danube, 2014; Fairway, 2016); hydropower (Joint Danube Survey 2, ICPDR); bankstabilization (Schwarz, 2014); planform (Schwarz, 2014); erosiondeposition (Schwarz, 2014); engineeringstructures (Schwarz, 2014); flooding (Schwarz, 2014); connectivity (Schwarz, 2014); Bombina (EU Habitats Directive); Gym_bal (EU Habitats Directive); Gym_sch (EU Habitats Directive); Lutra (EU Habitats Directive); Misgurnus (EU Habitats Directive); Rhodeus (EU Habitats Directive); Triturus (EU Habitats Directive); Zin_str (EU Habitats Directive); Zin_zin (EU Habitats Directive); Haliaeetus (EU Habitats Directive); Alcedo (EU Habitats Directive)
Spatial_Method: Bayesian networks to quantify driver–pressure–biodiversity and ecosystem-service status across 10 km river reaches; K-means clustering to group reaches by multi-functionality; compromise programming (multi-objective optimization) to identify high-priority restoration/conservation sites; ArcGIS-based gap/overlay analysis with Natura 2000 to assess alignment.
Method_Validation: 10-fold cross-validation of the Bayesian networks (with repeated cross-validation); bootstrapping to estimate link importance and network uncertainty; ArcGIS-based gap/overlay analysis with Natura 2000 to assess alignment; comparison of identified high-priority restoration/conservation sites with existing Natura 2000 sites and with sites where restoration is already planned or ongoing (external validation); qualitative validation showing the model outputs align with established ecological knowledge.
Tool_Source: ARIES: Used to quantify essential ecosystem services (pollination, recreation, flood regulation) along the Danube floodplain; provides ecosystem-services models (pollination supply/demand, ESTIMAP-inspired recreation, flood regulation) whose outputs are normalized (0–1) and aggregated per river reach to feed the multi-criteria optimization. ; bnlearn: Used to learn Bayesian networks from driver–pressure–biodiversity data to model causal links between drivers, pressures and biodiversity status indicators; implemented in R with bnlearn, using score-based structure learning and bootstrapping to derive driver–pressure–biodiversity networks that feed the final predictive networks and integrate with ARIES outputs.
Output: River‑floodplain cluster map (4 classes: multi‑functional/conservation; rheophilic/river & recreation restoration; stagnophilic/floodplain & multiple‑ES restoration; reduced multi‑functionality/high flood‑regulation mitigation); Multi‑functionality priority map (distance‑to‑ideal; high vs low remaining multi‑functionality); Reversibility priority map (distance‑to‑ideal; high vs low restoration reversibility); Semi‑natural‑area opportunity map (percent semi‑natural area adjacent to river; high vs low restoration opportunity); Restoration priority/allocation map (prioritized river segments under compromise scenarios — e.g., top 15% restoration target; scenarios: seminatural, compromise1–5, reversibility)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic considerations are embedded in the OUTPUT through cost-minimization in the multi-objective optimization, where restoration costs are reduced by prioritizing semi-natural areas and sites with high remaining multi-functionality, implemented via compromise programming with three objectives (multi-functionality, reversibility, semi-natural area) and minimizing distance to an ideal point.
Narrative: Conservation and restoration of river–floodplain reaches along the Danube were addressed as NbS to enhance multi-functionality and reconnect hydrological processes. Inputs combined biodiversity indicators for 11 protected species modeled with Bayesian networks (drivers: urban, agriculture, navigation class; pressures: bank stabilization, planform, erosion/deposition, engineering structures, flood connectivity, connectivity) with Natura 2000 data, Copernicus land use/land cover, Potential Riparian Zones, and Danube Survey 2 hydro-morphology; ecosystem services (pollination, recreation, flood regulation) were modeled with ARIES and aggregated on 10 km reaches (N=395 driver–pressure links; ~200 Natura 2000 sites). The four-step framework included modelling inputs, clustering reaches by multi-functionality (K-means; four clusters), seven compromise-programming restoration scenarios, and integration with gap analysis. Validation used 10-fold cross-validation (mean posterior error 0.21–0.32; 50 bootstraps). Outputs include biodiversity SI, ES maps, scenario-based priority lists at 10 km resolution across the Upper, Middle and Lower Danube; restoration costs informed reversibility and semi-natural-area criteria; climate risk not explicitly included.
Contacts_Email: andrea.funk@boku.ac.at; javier.martinez@bc3research.org; florian.borgwardt@boku.ac.at; daniel.trauner@boku.ac.at; kjbagstad@usgs.gov; stefano.balbi@bc3research.org; ainhoa.magrach@bc3research.org; ferdinando.villa@bc3research.org; thomas.hein@boku.ac.at

File: Larsen et al. - 2023 - RIPARIANET - Prioritising riparian ecotones to sustain and connect multiple biodiversity and functio.pdf
Input_Variables: Riparian areas (NetMap; DEM); Riparian forest conservation gradient (CLC18; Copernicus Riparian Zones); Land-use and land-cover changes (Sentinel-1; Sentinel-2; Landsat 5 TM; Landsat 8 OLI); Riparian habitat types (EUNIS level-3); NDVI (Sentinel-2; Landsat); fPAR (Sentinel-2; Landsat); LAI (Laliberté et al. 2019); Vegetation maps (various sources); Orthophotos (various sources); Field surveys (rapid assessment protocols); Climate data (regional/global climate datasets); Topography data (DEM; slope); Soil properties (soil maps); Copernicus Riparian Zones (Copernicus Land Monitoring Service); Natura 2000 protected areas (Natura 2000)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria analysis within a Systematic Conservation Planning framework to identify riparian hotspots and rank river reaches using prioritisation algorithms (R prioritiser); and connectivity-gap analysis using graph-theory (GuidosToolbox and igraph) to map core/corridor riparian areas and rank connectivity hotspots.
Method_Validation: Ground-truthing / ground-proofed riparian mapping (field verification); Validation of field methods (protocols and methods) with preliminary assessments of microbial analysis, pesticide quantification and bat detection; Comparison with ecological hotspots identified in A2.4 and protected areas (Natura 2000) for protection-gap validation; Validation against pan-European Copernicus Riparian Zones products for EU-scale validation
Tool_Source: NetMap : will be used to define virtual river networks and riparian areas for each study basin by applying a DEM to map river, riparian and terrestrial surfaces and their biophysical connections across the landscape, enabling selection of 45 river reaches across catchment size classes and riparian forest conservation gradients for subsequent field and modelling work.
Output: Ecological hotspot prioritisation map (ranked riparian segments; top 10–20 hotspots); Riparian network connectivity map (core / corridor classes; segment contribution ranking); EU-scale riparian connectivity and conservation gap-analysis map (protected vs. potential connector areas)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: Climate change is described as a threat to riparian areas, and NbS in riparian networks are framed to deliver climate regulation, flood mitigation, and thermal buffering; the authors demonstrate this through GIS-based multi-criteria hotspot prioritisation and connectivity/gap analyses to guide protection and restoration actions.
Economics: Yes: Economic aspects are integrated as an economic-benefit criterion in the multi-criteria prioritisation of riparian segments, with explicit consideration of balancing environmental vs. economic benefits and CAP eco-incentives (subsidies), guiding selection and policy-relevant outputs.
Narrative: RIPARIANET addressed the Nature-based Solution of prioritising riparian ecotones as blue-green infrastructure to sustain and connect biodiversity and ecosystem functions in river networks. It drew on remote-sensing and GIS data (Sentinel-1/2, Landsat 5/8; Copernicus land-cover data (CLC18); Copernicus Riparian Zones; DEMs; climate and soils), in situ biodiversity and stressor information (bats, microbial communities, river metabolism, plastics, pesticides) and stakeholder input. Spatially, a GIS-based multi-criteria approach within Systematic Conservation Planning was applied, using NetMap delineation, riparian-gradient classification and prioritisation with the prioritiser R-package; 10–20 riparian segments per basin were hotspots and at least 45 river reaches were selected per case study for fieldwork. Validation included method validation and verification; outputs encompassed riparian maps, models, and EU-wide connectivity and gap analyses, delivered as maps, shapefiles, rasters, NetCDF and an interactive web-GIS. Six basins span Boreal to Atlantic; climate data and CAP eco-schemes informed economic considerations, and thermal loading represented climate risk.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: GitHub repositories hosting codes and software pipelines; Data: Dryad, GBIF, Freshwater Metadata Journal, Portuguese RepositóriUM, GEO BON data, and European Nucleotide Archive for molecular sequences.

File: Li et al. - 2025 - Development and Application of a Multi-scale Framework for Evaluating Floodplain Restoration Suitabi.pdf
Input_Variables: DEM (FABDEM); 土地利用 (国家资源数据库); NDVI (国家资源数据库); 人口分布 (国家资源数据库); 断面数据 (流溪河流域管理办公室与广州水务局); 流量数据 (流溪河流域管理办公室与广州水务局); 流域边界数据 (流溪河流域管理办公室与广州水务局); 土壤数据 (国家青藏高原科学数据中心); 地下水埋深 (中国地质环境监测地下水位年鉴); 地表水质量 (GB 3838-2002); 湿地 (广州市碧道建设实施方案; 天地图 SHP); 与碧道距离 (广州市碧道建设实施方案; 天地图 SHP); 旅游点距离 (天地图 SHP); 永久基本农田排除 (广州市从化区国土空间总体规划（2021—2035）); 耕地占比 (GIS-derived); 坡度 (DEM-derived); 河流功率 (HEC-RAS)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria spatial analysis integrating HEC-RAS hydraulic simulations with multi-scale indicators; entropy-weighted aggregation; Kriging interpolation for socio-economic layers; Jenks natural breaks classification to identify high-restoration-suitability floodplain sites.
Method_Validation: HEC-RAS model calibration/validation against observed hydrological data (monthly flow data from Liuxi River basin and water-level data from Taiping station; water-level calibration errors: 17 cm for steady-state and 3 cm for flood conditions); Case-study validation of the framework in the Liuxi River Basin identifying nine high-restoration-suitability floodplains and demonstrating restoration benefits (e.g., 7.7% reduction in flood peak; 56.52 hm increase in suitable habitat).
Tool_Source: HEC-RAS : used to build a 1D unsteady flow hydrodynamic model of the Liuxi River basin, calibrate with observed water levels/flows, simulate flood inundation extents, depths and velocities under different scenarios (no-dam condition, one-year and hundred-year floods), and derive hydrologic indicators to support the floodplain restoration suitability assessment.
Output: Ecological restoration suitability index (ERSI) map [very suitable; relatively suitable; moderate; less suitable; unsuitable]; Social‑ecological suitability map [very suitable (66.60–<91.57); relatively suitable (58.37–<66.60); moderate (49.85–<58.37); less suitable (41.62–<49.85); unsuitable (16.65–<41.62)]; Final priority floodplain allocation map (9 high‑priority floodplains); Indicator‑species suitability maps — water depth classes (0–<1.93 m; 1.93–<3.66 m; 3.66–<5.74 m; 5.74–<8.17 m; 8.17–12.6 m) and flow velocity classes (0–<0.66 m/s; 0.66–<1.3 m/s; 1.35–<2.20 m/s; 2.20–<3.68 m/s; 3.68–8.38 m/s); Spatial habitat gain map for indicator species (increased suitable habitat area — one‑year flood: +56.52 hm²; hundred‑year flood: +28.89 hm²)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS targets floodplains to mitigate climate-related flood risks. The authors demonstrate this by coupling HEC-RAS flood simulations with GIS to identify high-suitability floodplains and quantify hazard reductions (a 7.7% lower flood peak) and ecological gains (56.52 ha more suitable habitat) under different flood scenarios.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis incorporates economic framing by including local socio-economic indicators (proximity to tourism sites, land use, community factors) within the ERSI/entropy-weighted multi-criteria framework to identify high-recovery floodplains, and notes costs and stakeholder inputs as part of the considerations; however it does not report explicit economic metrics (cost-benefit, ROI, NPV, cost-effectiveness, etc.) or monetary valuations, instead using qualitative/relative socio-economic scores as part of the decision, not monetary outputs.
Narrative: The study treated floodplain restoration as a nature-based solution to reduce flood risk and restore habitats in the middle–lower Liuxi River Basin near Guangzhou. It integrated FABDEM DEM, land use, NDVI, population data, soils (National Tibetan Plateau Scientific Data Center, 90 m), and SHP features for wetlands, river corridors, and tourism from Guangzhou plans and Tianditu; cross-sections, discharge and basin boundaries came from the Liuxi River Basin Management Office and Guangzhou Water Authority. Social indicators were included. Using GIS and HEC-RAS, a multi-scale indicator framework was built, rasters were resampled to 30 m, and ERSI weights were computed by entropy. Three screening conditions—terrain constraints, ERSI, and local socio-economics—identified 9 high-suitability floodplains in a 69.2 km reach of a 1321 km2 basin. Validation showed 17 cm steady and 3 cm flood water-level errors; post-restoration, peak fell 7.7% and habitat area rose 56.52 hm. Outputs comprise 9 floodplain locations at 30 m resolution; climate risk not explicit; economic factors included.

File: Semmens and Ancona - 2019 - Monarch Habitat as a Component of Multifunctional Landscape Restoration Using Continuous Riparian Bu.pdf
Input_Variables: Stream network (NHDPlusV2); Cropland Data Layer (USDA/NASS); Headwater areas (NHDPlusV2); Subsurface drainage percentage (Sugg 2007); Erosion rate (USDA-NRCS 2018); Sediment trapping efficiency (buffer width) (AI Mitigation 2009; Meyer et al. 1995; Yuan et al. 2009; Hawes and Smith 2005; Dillaha et al. 1986); Milkweed density upland grassland (Thogmartin et al. 2017a); Milkweed density CRP wet soils (Thogmartin et al. 2017a); Milkweed density CRP dry soils (Thogmartin et al. 2017a); Crop yields/prices (USDA/NASS 2016 Quick Stats); Pollination benefits values per crop (Kleijn et al. 2015)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based approach: delineate streams (NHDPlusV2; orders 1–5), generate buffer zones around channels with three widths (30 m per side, 100 m per side, and a variable-width scheme by stream order), intersect buffers with Cropland Data Layer to identify non-cropland areas within buffers for potential milkweed restoration, and constrain these priority areas by headwater watershed delineation from DEM pour-points to limit service areas.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Riparian buffer allocation map (buffer scenarios: 30 m; variable‑width [80 m for 1st‑order, 100 m for 2nd‑order, 120 m for 3–5th order]; 100 m)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: It includes economic outputs and framing via a cost-benefit analysis comparing the monetary value of ecosystem-services (water quality, pollination, sediment retention) to lost agricultural revenue, using 2016 USD, reporting cost-benefit ratios for the three riparian-buffer scenarios (30-m: 1:1.98; Variable-width: 1:0.57; 100-m: 1:0.45), calculating gross and net crop values with a 10% farm-profit margin, thereby incorporating profitability and payment-for-ecosystem-services considerations into the output.
Narrative: An NbS approach assessed monarch habitat restoration via continuous riparian buffers around rivers and streams in the Upper Midwest. Key inputs included the NHDPlusV2 stream network (orders 1–5; ephemeral streams excluded), the CDL (91 classes; 30 m), state headwater percentages and drainage tiles (Sugg 2007; USDA data), an upland erosion rate of 7.21 t ha−1 yr−1 (USDA-NRCS 2018), and sediment-trapping efficiencies by width (61–97%). Milkweed densities used were 7.64, 151.65, and 277.1 stems ha−1 (Thogmartin et al. 2017a); pollination benefits followed McGlynn (2009). Three ArcGIS buffer scenarios were applied: 30 m per side; 100 m per side; and a variable-width scheme (80/100/120 m by order). Buffers overlaid with CDL to estimate cropland within buffers and milkweed gains, with headwater reductions. Outputs: three buffer maps, milkweed potential 238M–1.02B stems (target 1.3B), and 2016 USD valuations. Geography IA, MN, MI, WI, northern IL/IN/OH (~846k km2; cropland ~353k km2). Validation not described; climate risk not included; 30 m buffers yield 1:1.98 cost-benefit.

File: Witing et al. - 2022 - Riparian reforestation on the landscape scale Navigating trade‐offs among agricultural production,.pdf
Input_Variables: Forest & shrub [%] (Agentschap Informatie Vlaanderen, 2016); Pasture & grassland [%] (Agentschap Informatie Vlaanderen, 2016); Arable land [%] (Agentschap Informatie Vlaanderen, 2016); Forest & shrub [%] upstream catchment (Agentschap Informatie Vlaanderen, 2016); Distance btw. Riparian 100 m forest blocks [m] (Agentschap Informatie Vlaanderen, 2016); Urban-Industrial [%] upstream catchment (Agentschap Informatie Vlaanderen, 2016); Biophysical suitability food production [%] (Stevens et al., 2015; Van Gossum et al., 2014); Agricultural crop yield potential (Stevens et al., 2015; Van Gossum et al., 2014); Catchment size upstream [m] (VMM, 2018); Agricultural production potential (Stevens et al., 2015; Van Gossum et al., 2014)
Analysis_Resolution: 300 m long riparian segments (300 m × 100 m riparian corridor polygons)
Spatial_Method: Spatially explicit multi-objective optimization using NSGA‑II in CoMOLA across 489 river segments; regression-based predictive models of EPT, diatoms and cotton‑strip carbon processing against spatial predictors; Pareto‑front analysis with relative‑frequency mapping to identify priority riparian segments and dominant restoration actions.
Method_Validation: Cross-validation of the final model composition via an independent manual model simplification using linear mixed-effects models (S8); Hypervolume analysis of the Pareto fronts to evaluate optimization performance
Tool: CoMOLA (Constrained Multi-objective Optimization of Land-use Allocation, Strauch et al., 2019) ; NSGA-II (Deb et al., 2002) ; mco (Mersmann, 2014)
Tool_Source: CoMOLA: Landscape optimization tool used to optimize the placement and intensity of riparian forest management measures across 489 stream segments in the Zwalm catchment to produce multiple objective outcomes (EPT index, diatom functional diversity, riparian carbon processing and permanence, and agricultural production potential) and identify Pareto-optimal solutions.; NSGA-II: The multi-objective optimization engine integrated in CoMOLA to evolve and rank solutions via non-dominated sorting, generating Pareto-fronts for four objectives (population 250, 400 generations, genome every segment) to balance trade-offs among targets.; mco: Used to calculate the hypervolume of the Pareto fronts to evaluate convergence and diversity of the Pareto-optimal solutions and the suitability of the termination criteria.
Output: Priority map for riparian forest management (dominant measure per segment: DeFor20%, ReFor20%, ReFor40%, ReFor60%, ReFor80%, ReFor100%); Allocation map of average riparian forest share (across all Pareto‑optimal solutions); Map of absolute change in riparian forest share (reforestation gain per segment)
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: The NbS addressed riparian reforestation to balance agricultural production, biodiversity and ecosystem functioning in the Zwalm River catchment, Flanders, Belgium (117 km2; 22 km of river; 489 segments of 300 m). Key inputs included a 1 m land-cover map (Agentschap Informatie Vlaanderen, 2016), biophysical suitability for food production (Stevens et al., 2015; Van Gossum et al., 2014), upstream forest connectivity (distance between 100 m blocks), catchment/physiographic variables (catchment size, elevation gradient, urban-industrial share), and CROSSLINK data from 34 sites (2017–2018) measuring EPT, diatom functional diversity and cotton-strip decomposition; agricultural production potential from arable/pasture area and soil fertility. A four-objective optimization in CoMOLA (NSGA‑II) allocated seven reforestation measures across 489 segments (300 m) with 100 m buffers. Regression models predicted EPT, diatoms and cotton-strip decomposition (R2 0.37–0.61; adjR2 0.3–0.54); cross-validation with linear mixed-effects supported stability; a 4-D Pareto front yielded 4001 solutions. Outputs included 3423 maps; headwaters prioritized. Climate risk not explicit; economic trade-off via agricultural production potential.

File: Abd-el-Kader et al. - 2023 - Designating Appropriate Areas for Flood Mitigation and Rainwater Harvesting in Arid Region Using a G.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Check Dams; Drainage ditches; Bench-terraces; wadi terraced beds
Input_Variables: Elevation (DEM); Slope (DEM); Drainage density (drainage network); Direct runoff depth at 50-year return period (SCS-CN method); Topographic witness index (DEM); Curve Number (SCS-CN method); Land cover (land cover data); Stream order (drainage network); Lineaments density (lineaments density data); Average of annual max-24hr Rainfall (Kriging geostatistics approach for historical rainfall data); Rainwater harvesting potential layer (RWH potential layer); Drainage stream order layer (drainage stream order layer); Triangulated Irregular Network (TIN) produced from DEM (DEM-derived); Contour lines layer (DEM-derived); 20-km buffer layer (20-km buffer layer)
Spatial_Method: Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) integrated with GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis, combining pairwise-criteria weights with a raster-based weighted linear combination to map flash-flood hazard and rainwater-harvesting suitability.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR)
Tool_Source: HEC-HMS : used to generate hydrograph curves at the proposed dam sites to aid in hydraulic design for planned dams, in combination with SCS-CN rainfall–runoff calculations.
Output: Flash flood hazard map [very risky; dangerous; moderately dangerous; safe; very safe]; Rainwater harvesting suitability map [excellent; very good; moderate; poor; unsuitable]; Proposed dam sites (two proposed dam locations with coordinates)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They explicitly treat flood hazard (a climate-related risk) as a barrier to NbS effectiveness by mapping flash-flood hazard and overlaying it with the rainwater harvesting suitability map, demonstrating that the top RWH sites fall in hazard-prone zones and thus require risk-aware siting and protective measures.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS is targeted to reduce climate-related flood risks and enhance water security through rainwater harvesting and dam storage. The authors demonstrate this by producing hazard maps and NbS suitability maps and proposing dam sites, illustrating how NbS deployment would mitigate floods and improve water availability under climate variability.
Narrative: The NbS addressed was Rainwater Harvesting (RWH) and flood-hazard mitigation in Wadi Nisah, Saudi Arabia, including dam-site planning. Inputs comprised flash-flood criteria (elevation, drainage density, slope, direct runoff depth at 50-year return, topographic index, curve number) and RWH criteria (slope, land cover, stream order, lineaments density, annual max-24hr rainfall), implemented as raster layers; runoff depth was generated with the SCS-CN method and rainfall by Kriging using climate data from the Climate Atlas of Saudi Arabia (1988). The spatial approach integrated AHP with GIS, using pairwise weights in a weighted linear combination to produce five-class flood-hazard and RWH-suitability maps. Validation relied on AHP consistency checks and basin-level comparisons, reporting 21.55% highly dangerous and 65.29% moderate hazard, with 13.15% safe/very safe, and 15% very high, 27.7% moderate, 57.31% low/extremely low RWH potential. Outputs included two dam sites with profiles from 1-m DEM and coordinates, within a 20-km buffer; geographic scope: Wadi Nisah (23.5–24.5 N, 46–47 E). Climate risk included; no economic analysis due to data gaps.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The datasets generated during and/or analysed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

File: Adham et al. - 2018 - A GIS-based approach for identifying potential sites for harvesting rainwater in the Western Desert.pdf
Input_Variables: Runoff depth (CN using land-cover and soil-texture maps); Slope (DEM); Land use/cover (Landsat 8-2013); Soil texture (soil-texture maps); Stream order (stream order map)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based multi-criteria suitability analysis in ArcGIS 10.2 ModelBuilder integrating slope, runoff depth, land use, soil texture and stream order to generate a pixel-based suitability map (0–10 scores, five classes) for identifying suitable dam sites, followed by site identification via visual interpretation of satellite imagery.
Method_Validation: Expert review of scoring: scores discussed and adjusted with technical experts.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: RWH dam suitability map (very high / high / medium / low / very low); Map of identified potential dam sites (39 candidate locations); Reservoir inundation maps for three sample dams (water-level/depth classes showing inundation extent)
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: NbS addressed: rainwater harvesting (RWH) dams in the arid Western Desert of Iraq (wadi Horan). Main inputs and data sources: slope from a 30 m DEM; runoff depth estimated with the Curve Number method using land-use and soil-texture maps; land use from Landsat 8 (2013) at 30 m; soil texture and stream order maps; rainfall/runoff data; data sources included Landsat 8-2013, a 30 m DEM, and satellite-derived layers. Spatial method and how variables were combined: a GIS-based multi-criteria suitability model implemented in ModelBuilder in ArcGIS 10.2; each criterion was reclassified to a 0–10 scale (Table 1) and integrated with the raster calculator to produce an integrated suitability map with five classes (very high to very low). Validation and key results: validation relied on visual interpretation of satellite imagery and expert judgment; results identified 39 potential dam sites and produced a five-class suitability map; outputs included the suitability map and three example dam sites with cross-sections; resolution: 30 m; geographic scope: Wadi Horan watershed, Al-Anbar, ~450 km west of Baghdad, area 13,370 km2; climate risk considered via rainfall/runoff; socioeconomic criteria were not included.

File: Adham et al. - 2022 - Assessing Suitable Techniques for Rainwater Harvesting Using Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) Meth.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: runoff basin system; contour ridges; cisterns; eyebrow terrace; check dam; on-farm pond; bench terraces
Input_Variables: Annual rainfall (Rainfall station data); Runoff curve number (Shadeed and Almasri 2010); Land use (MoA database); Slope (DEM); DEM (not specified); Soil texture (not specified)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight rainfall, CN runoff, land use, slope and soil texture; Raster reclassification and map algebra in ArcGIS Spatial Analyst (ModelBuilder) to produce per-technique suitability maps.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Suitability maps for seven RWH techniques (runoff basin; contour ridges; cistern; eyebrow terrace; check dam; on‑farm pond; bench terraces) [classes: Low <20; Moderate 20–29; High 30–39; Very High >40]; Integrated suitability/allocation map showing the most suitable RWH technique per location (color-coded allocation of techniques across the West Bank)
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: The NbS addressed was rainwater harvesting techniques (RWHt) to alleviate water scarcity in the West Bank, Palestine. Five inputs were used: rainfall, CN-based runoff depth with CN maps from Shadeed and Almasri (2010), land use from MoA, slope from a 30 m DEM, and soil texture (Sandy loam, Loamy, Clay loam, Clay). Spatial prioritisation used GIS-based multicriteria analysis with AHP weights, reclassifying criteria to a four-class suitability score in ArcGIS 10.2 ModelBuilder. Outputs included seven RWHt maps (runoff basin system, contour ridges, cisterns, eyebrow terrace, check dam, on-farm pond, bench terraces) and an integrated WB map; rainfall was included, while socioeconomic aspects were not. Validation was not performed; calibration and pilot testing were recommended. Table 2 shows area shares by suitability class for each technique (e.g., runoff basin 64.4% moderate, 28.7% high) and outputs at the WB scale (~5860 km2) with 30 m slope data.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Some data in this manuscript were obtained from the Ministry of Agriculture and PWA, Palestine. The other data are from the fieldwork and previous studies.

File: Aghaloo and Chiu - 2020 - Identifying Optimal Sites for a Rainwater-Harvesting Agricultural Scheme in Iran Using the Best-Wors.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Ponds and Pans; Check Dams; Percolation Tanks
Input_Variables: Rainfall (IRIMO; Monte Carlo simulation; EBK); Slope (ASTER DEM; USGS Earth Explorer); Soil type (FAO databases); Land use/cover (Geographic data center 2); Drainage density (Geographic data center 2); Distance to roads (Geographic data center 2); Distance to rivers (Geographic data center 2); Distance to faults (Geographic data center 2); Distance to urban centers (Geographic data center 2)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based spatial multicriteria decision analysis using the linear Best-Worst Method to weight criteria; Fuzzy logic to fuzzify the criteria and integrate them; raster overlay with a Boolean constraint to produce suitability maps for the three rainwater-harvesting types.
Method_Validation: Sensitivity analysis (OAT) comparing the proposed method with the traditional AHP+WOP; BWM consistency ratio check (CR = 0.07 < 0.1) confirming reliability; Comparison of the general suitability maps with the existing farming/land-use map.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: General suitability map for rainwater‑harvesting (RWH) agriculture (suitability classes 1–5); Suitability map for ponds and pans RWH (suitability classes 1–5; key areas highlighted: classes 4–5); Suitability map for check dams RWH (suitability classes 1–5; key areas highlighted: classes 4–5); Suitability map for percolation tanks RWH (suitability classes 1–5; key areas highlighted: classes 4–5)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: The authors explicitly treat rainfall variability and drought as climate-related risk, incorporating probabilistic rainfall exceedance into the NbS site-suitability outputs and conducting sensitivity analysis to test robustness under climate-related uncertainty.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The study targets rainwater-harvesting NbS to mitigate climate-related water scarcity and groundwater depletion in arid Tehran, and demonstrates this via scenario-based priority mapping that accounts for rainfall variability/exceedance to identify where NbS deployment most reduces climate risk.
Narrative: The study addressed rainwater-harvesting (RWH) agriculture as a nature-based solution to groundwater overexploitation in arid/semi-arid Tehran Province, Iran. Main input variables included biophysical criteria (annual rainfall from 12 IRIMO stations 2005–2014 with Monte Carlo-derived exceedance probabilities at 70% and spatially interpolated rainfall; slope from ASTER DEM; land use/cover; soil texture from FAO databases; drainage density) and socioeconomic factors (distance to roads, rivers, faults, and urban centers), with data sourced from IRIMO, USGS Earth Explorer, FAO, and national/geographic data centers. The spatial method integrated a GIS-based decision support system that first used Monte Carlo rainfall analysis and Empirical Bayesian Kriging to produce rainfall rasters, then applied linear Best-Worst Method (BWM) to derive weights, fuzzified all criteria in GIS, and combined them via raster calculator/overlay with a Boolean constraint map; a sensitivity analysis compared BWM+Fuzzy against AHP+WOP. Outputs were general suitability maps and three type-specific maps (ponds/pans, check dams, percolation tanks) plus a constraint map, at raster-based, multi-criteria resolutions. The geographic scope was Tehran Province (12,981 km2) in Iran. Climate risk was addressed through rainfall exceedance probabilities, and economic considerations were included via biophysical and socioeconomic criteria.

File: Ahmad et al. - 2024 - An integrated new approach for optimizing rainwater harvesting system with dams site selection in th.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope (USGS); Stream orders (DEM-derived (USGS)); Drainage density (Derived from stream networks); Soil texture (The Pipette Method (PM)); Land use/cover (Sentinel-2A); Rainfall (GPM-v06 via Google Earth Engine); Runoff (LULC; Soil map; Rainfall data); Roads (World Imagery-GIS base map); Residential area (World Imagery-GIS base map); Stream width (ArcGIS base map imagery); Geological Formations (Iraqi Geological Survey (GEOSURV-IRAQ)); Construction Materials (Geology map); Lineament density (Sentinel-2A); Population density (Ministry of Planning, Kurdistan Region Statistics Office); Archaeology (Iraqi Department of Antiquities; QDRAP); Farmland (Sentinel-Hub Sentinel Playground)
Spatial_Method: RS- and GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis using Analytical Hierarchy Process and Weighted Sum Method to create suitability index maps for rainwater harvesting and dam-site selection, with proposed dam sites ranked by Weighted Product Model.
Method_Validation: Segmentation accuracy assessment around reference points (three dams) with buffers of 250 m, 500 m and 1000 m to evaluate suitability index maps; ROC/AUC validation for dam-site selection maps by comparing map predictions with existing dams (AHP: AUC = 1.00; WSM: AUC = 0.78).
Tool_Source: PCI Geomantic : Used to automatically extract lineaments from Sentinel-2A imagery to generate a lineament density map, informing dam-site selection by highlighting geological weaknesses that affect dam construction feasibility.
Output: Rainwater harvesting suitability index map (classes: very high, high, moderate, low, very low); Dam site selection suitability map for dam construction (classes: very high, high, moderate, low); Proposed dam sites map (11 proposed dam locations); Ranked proposed dams (WPM ranking of 11 sites; top-ranked: Dam #10, Dam #2)
Climate_Benefit: No
