Economics: Yes: Economic aspects appear in the OUTPUT through socio‑economic criteria used to rank dam sites (proximity to roads, residential areas, and farmlands to reduce transportation and pumping costs; proximity to construction materials to cut material transport costs; and dam height/storage effects on construction costs), integrated via the AHP/WSM/WPM outputs with notes that Dam 10 has the lowest height and thus lower costs; livelihood implications are touched as proxies (population density, archaeology), but explicit monetary metrics (ROI, NPV, cost‑benefit, cost‑effectiveness, or payments for ecosystem services) are not reported.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Dewana watershed; Sub-national: Sulaymaniyah Governorate; Sub-national: Iraqi Kurdistan Region; National: Iraq
Narrative: An integrated rainwater harvesting (RWH) and dam-site prioritisation approach was applied in the 605 km2 Dewana Watershed, Kurdistan Region, Iraq. Sixteen thematic layers of biophysical and socio-economic data were used, including slope (USGS 30 m DEM), rainfall (GPM via GEE, 0.1°), land-use/cover (Sentinel-2A, 10 m), runoff (SCS-CN), geology (GEOSURV), lineaments, population density (KRSO 2019), archaeology maps (DoA; QDRAP), and distances to roads, settlements, farmland, and construction materials. Rainfall inputs provided climate context, while socio-economic criteria addressed cost considerations. AHP and WSM produced suitability index maps for RWH, and dam-site selection integrated scores with geology, lineaments, stream width, and proximity to roads and farmland to identify 11 proposed dams ranked by WPM. Validation used segmentation accuracy (WSM 69.22%; AHP 62.22%; overall 50.50% vs 52.78%) and ROC/AUC (AHP 1.00; WSM 0.78). Outputs include 30 m resolution maps; highly suitable areas 236.89–267.15 km2 and 11 dam sites; total storage 250.97 million m3.

File: Ahmad et al. - 2024 - Remote sensing and GIS based multi-criteria analysis approach with application of AHP and FAHP for s.pdf
Input_Variables: Rainfall (PMD & WAPDA); Slope (RS data & DEM); LULC (Esri Global Land Use Land Cover); Drainage Density (RS data & DEM); Soil Texture (FAO Global Soil Map)
Spatial_Method: Remote sensing and GIS-based multi-criteria analysis using AHP and FAHP with weighted overlay in ArcGIS to derive rainwater harvesting structure suitability by integrating rainfall, slope, drainage density, LULC and soil texture.
Method_Validation: Ground-truth validation with IMSD guidelines; LULC accuracy assessment (101 random points with kappa 66%, overall accuracy 82.2%); proximity/overlay validation against LULC and 2nd–3rd order stream networks; validation of percolation tanks and check dams by overlaying on AHP/FAHP maps and IMSD guidelines; cross-validation by comparing AHP and FAHP potential maps; sensitivity analysis to weights; AHP consistency ratio check (CR ≤ 0.1).
Tool_Source: NA
Output: AHP rainwater-harvesting (RWH) potential sites map (excellent, good, moderate, poor, unsuitable); FAHP RWH potential sites map (excellent, good, moderate, poor, unsuitable); Percolation tanks suitability map (unsuitable, poor, moderate, good, excellent) — 40 sites; Check-dams suitability map (unsuitable, poor, moderate, good, excellent) — 12 sites; Final combined suitability map for RWH structures (AHP + FAHP; excellent, good, moderate, poor, unsuitable)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: they explicitly target locations for rainwater harvesting (NbS) to reduce flood risk and enhance groundwater recharge, demonstrating this with final NbS suitability maps that show excellent/good zones for percolation tanks and check dams and by stating these configurations would significantly reduce small floods and increase groundwater recharge.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Lai Nullah catchment; Sub-national: Islamabad; Rawalpindi; National: Pakistan
Narrative: The NbS tackled Rainwater Harvesting (RWH) structures, specifically percolation tanks and check dams, for Lai Nullah in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, to support watershed management and flood mitigation. Main inputs comprised rainfall data from PMD and WAPDA (25 years, 1995–2020, six stations: Saidpur, Golra, PMD, Bokra, RAMC, Chaklala), slope derived from a 30 m DEM, Land Use Land Cover from Esri Global LULC (10 m, 2021), soil texture from the FAO World Soil Map, and drainage density from RS data/DEM; analyses were executed in ArcGIS 10.5, with LULC accuracy 82.2% overall and a Kappa of 66%. The spatial method combined AHP and FAHP within a GIS-based MCA, using weighted overlay to fuse five criteria (rainfall, slope, drainage density, LULC, soil texture) after determining weights via pairwise comparisons, with CR ≤ 0.1; results included RWH potential maps for percolation tanks (40 sites) and check dams (12 sites), and final IMSD-guided suitability maps. Outputs used 10 × 10 m cells over the Lai Nullah catchment (235 km2; coordinate system WGS 1984/UTM Zone 43N). Validation relied on ground truth LULC/stream order and cross-checks between AHP and FAHP; FAHP produced a 4% increase in the good zone, and sensitivity analysis highlighted rainfall and drainage density as critical. The study did not explicitly include climate risk or economic analyses.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data will be made available on request; Supplementary data available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.uclim.2024.101817

File: Ahmed et al. - 2023 - Using Geographic Information Systems and Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis to Determine Appropriate L.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Medium dam; Check Dam; Farm Pond
Input_Variables: Rainfall (KRG meteorological stations, 2014–2023, IDW interpolation); Soil Texture (FAO-UNESCO DSMW 2008); LU/LC (Landsat 8 OLI 2023); Runoff Depth (CN values from USDA-NRCS National Engineering Handbook, LU/LC and HSG integration); Drainage Density (DEM-derived stream network from DEM, SRTM); Slope (SRTM-DEM); Topographic Wetness Index (TWI) (DEM data, ArcMap 10.8.2)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based MCDA using Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight seven criteria; rainfall interpolated by Inverse Distance Weighting (IDW); runoff estimated with the SCS-CN method; LU/LC derived from Landsat 8 imagery; soil texture/Hydrologic Soil Groups (HSGs); slope derived from DEM; drainage density computed from flow accumulation/DEM; and a weighted overlay in ArcMap to produce four suitability classes.
Method_Validation: Overlay validation with existing rainwater harvesting structures from the Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources (KRG) (11 farm ponds, 11 check dams, 1 medium dam) to assess suitability class via spatial overlay; agreement analysis showing the distribution of structures across very high/high/moderate/low suitability and noting that all existing structures were classified as “successful.”
Tool_Source: NA
Output: RWH suitability zone map (very high, high, moderate, low); Map of proposed RWH structure sites (medium dams [3 locations], check dams [6 locations], farm ponds [27 locations])
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The study frames rainwater harvesting as a climate-change–driven adaptation strategy to reduce water scarcity and drought risk, and it demonstrates this by generating a regional RWH suitability zone map aimed at minimizing risk and maximizing NbS benefits, with validation showing many existing RWH structures fall within highly suitable areas.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Erbil Province, Iraq; Sub-national: Kurdistan Region, Iraq; National: Iraq
Narrative: Seven thematic layers—rainfall, runoff depth, land use/land cover, soil texture with Hydrologic Soil Groups, slope, drainage density, TWI—were used to prioritise rainwater harvesting (RWH) in Erbil Province locating medium dams, check dams, and farm ponds. Input data included rainfall from 23 KRG stations (2014–2023), runoff estimated with SCS-CN using USDA-NRCS CN values, LU/LC from Landsat 8 OLI (2023), FAO-UNESCO DSMW soil data (2008), and a SRTM DEM (30 m) for DD, slope and TWI. AHP-MCDA applied: rasters were reclassified to a 1–5 scale and combined with a weighted overlay in ArcMap 10.8. Validation overlaid 11 farm ponds, 11 check dams, and 1 medium dam; results: 13.04% very highly suitable, 60.87% highly suitable, 21.74% moderately suitable, 4.35% lowly suitable; all existing structures were deemed successful. Outputs include a four-class map and 36 sites (3 medium, 6 check, 27 farm ponds) over 14,837 km2. Climate risk or economic factors were not explicitly included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Landsat 8 OLI satellite image publicly available at https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/ (accessed 14 April 2023) and global soil data at https://www.fao.org/soils-portal/data-hub/soil-maps-and-databases/faounesco-soil-map-of-the-world/en/ (accessed 10 July 2023).

Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS addresses climate risks by revitalizing indigenous rainwater harvesting to mitigate drought and flash-flood impacts and enhance water security. The authors demonstrate this through suitability maps that identify high-potential areas for RWH deployment and expert validation confirming the risk-reduction potential.
Economics: Yes: Economic considerations are included as Economic Framing by treating six socioeconomic constraints (proximity to urban areas, roads, water wells, dams, wadis, and open sewage passage) as Boolean exclusions with buffer thresholds (e.g., urban >250 m, roads >75 m, wells >50 m, dams >500 m, sewage >1000 m) within the output analysis; there are no economic outputs reported (no cost-benefit, ROI, NPV, or economic suitability scores), though the authors note that a cost–benefit analysis and livelihood/payments for ecosystem services could be considered in future work.
Narrative: The NbS addressed were indigenous rainwater harvesting (RWH) systems, specifically terraces, check dams, ponds, and spate irrigation in Sana’a Basin, Yemen. Main inputs included biophysical criteria (precipitation from WorldClim v2 30s; soil type from HWSD v1.2; land cover from Esri World Land Cover 30 m; slope and drainage from SRTM DEM 1" with Arc Hydro delineation) and six socioeconomic criteria (proximity to urban areas, roads, water wells, dams, wadis, and open sewage passage) using data from 2007 Sana’a land use, NWRA wells (2007), WEC dams (2007), SWSLC sewage data, and road datasets, all harmonized to WGS84/UTM38N at 30 m. The spatial method was a GIS-based MCA employing Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) with Boolean exclusions, with Relative Importance Weights derived from Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and validated via a consistency ratio (CR 0.03–0.07). Validation used local experts, literature, and existing RWHs; sensitivity analysis compared equal and relative weights, highlighting slope sensitivity and rainfall as key factors. Outputs were 30 m resolution suitability maps (SLI) for terraces (33% in high/very high), check dams (35% suitable), ponds (33% high/very high), and spate irrigation (32% suitable) over the 3200 km2 basin (22 sub-basins). Climate risk and economic considerations were included through rainfall and socioeconomic constraints.

Tool_Source: NA

File: Al-Hasani et al. - 2023 - Integrated geospatial approach for adaptive rainwater harvesting site selection under the impact of.pdf
Input_Variables: Digital Elevation Model (USGS SRTM); Slope (USGS SRTM); Land cover/Use (ESRI ArcGIS Living Atlas); Drainage density (USGS SRTM DEM); Rainfall (Iraqi Meteorological Department; NASA Power Project); Hydrologic soil groups (USDA 2009); Soil texture (USDA 2009); Curve number CN (USDA 2020 SCS-CN); Runoff depth (SCS-CN; USDA 2020); Surface runoff potential (SCS-CN; USDA 2020); Stream order (ArcGIS-derived from DEM); Rainfall projections (LARS-WG 7.0)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multicriteria decision analysis using Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) to derive weights; Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) to fuse rainfall, runoff depth, slope, soil texture, drainage density, and land cover into RWH suitability maps.
Method_Validation: Rainfall–runoff validation using LARS-WG 7.0 with daily station data; K–S test for seasonal wet/dry distributions; Empirical CDF normality test for rainfall data; rainfall–runoff correlation validation (R2 = 95% historical, 96.83% future).
Tool: LARS-WG 7.0 (Khalaf RM et al. 2022; Projections of precipitation and temperature in Southern Iraq using a LARS-WG Stochastic weather generator. Phys Chem Earth 128:103224; DOI:10.1016/j.pce.2022.103224)
Tool_Source: LARS-WG 7.0 : used as a stochastic weather generator to downscale and generate daily rainfall (and related climate variables) for Kirkuk across historical (1980–2022) and projected future (2031–2100) periods, calibrating distributions from observed data, generating three site-variable files (wgx, stx, tst) with CO2 input for verification, and providing downscaled rainfall scenarios for use in the RWH site-suitability GIS–MCDA framework under CMIP6.
Output: RWH potential/suitability map (historical & future projections) [very high, high, moderate, low]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They treat climate hazards as a risk to NbS viability, showing that projected declines in rainfall and runoff under future climate scenarios reduce high-suitability RWH zones and threaten long-term effectiveness; they demonstrate this with scenario-based future-versus-historical suitability comparisons to assess risk.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors frame climate change–driven water scarcity as a climate hazard and target NbS (rainwater harvesting sites) to enhance adaptation. They demonstrate this with scenario-based mapping of historical and future RWH suitability, showing how NbS placement would mitigate future water shortages under projected climate conditions.
Narrative: A geospatial approach addressed rainwater harvesting (RWH) as an NbS to identify sites in Kirkuk Governorate, northern Iraq. Inputs included surface runoff, slope, land cover, drainage density, rainfall data (1980–2022 observed from Iraqi Meteorological Department and NASA Power; future via LARS‑WG 7.0), soil texture, and hydrologic soil groups (USDA)—from USGS SRTM DEM (30 m), ESRI land cover (10 m), USDA soils, NASA meteorology, CMIP6 projections. The spatial method combined Analytical Hierarchy Process weights with a Weighted Linear Combination to yield RWH suitability maps, using S = sum RiWi SLi, with standardization and consistency checks. Validation used LARS‑WG 7.0 downscaling and rainfall–runoff correlation (R2 ≈ 0.95; 0.9683 for future). RWH zones were 8.2% very high, 22.6% high, 37.4% moderate, 31.8% low; future 6.1%, 18.3%, 31.2%, 44.4%. Outputs were historical and future four-class RWH maps and three site files (wgx, stx, tst) over 9,679 km2. Climate risk included; no explicit economic analysis.

File: Al-Hasani et al. - 2025 - Rainwater Harvesting Site Assessment Using Geospatial Technologies in a Semi-Arid Region Toward Wat.pdf
Input_Variables: Runoff depth (USDA NRCS TR-55 SCS-CN); Slope (SRTM 30 m; USGS); Drainage density (DEM-derived; SRTM 30 m); Stream order (DEM-derived; ArcGIS Stream Order); Soil type (USDA NRCS Hydrologic Soil Groups); Soil texture (USDA NRCS HSG-based texture classification); Land use/land cover (ESRI 2021; 10 m); Rainfall (Iraqi Meteorological Organization and Seismology Department; NASA Power Project); Constraint layer (Alene et al. 2022)
Spatial_Method: An integrated GIS and RS framework combined with MCDA using AHP weights to evaluate slope, rainfall/runoff, drainage density, soil type, and land use, paired with the Soil Conservation Service Curve Number runoff model to generate a rainwater harvesting suitability map.
Method_Validation: Validation with existing functional rainwater harvesting structures (check dams) located within highly suitable areas; Expert review / stakeholder validation through consultations with local university professors and domain experts; AHP consistency ratio check (CR calculated); Sensitivity analysis by perturbing criterion weights ±10% to assess robustness
Tool_Source: NA
Output: RWHSA potential sites suitability map (Very High; High; Moderate; Low); Runoff depth map (Very good >400 mm; Good 350–400 mm; Moderate 290–340 mm; Poor 200–250 mm; Very poor ~190 mm)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: they explicitly target rainwater harvesting as an NbS to mitigate climate-driven water scarcity by prioritising sites that maximise runoff capture and storage in a semi-arid region, and they demonstrate this through an RWH suitability map (weighting runoff depth, slope, soil texture, stream order, and land use) and validation with existing check dams, framing the results as enhancing resilience to climate-change–driven water stress.
Narrative: Rainwater harvesting for sustainable agriculture (RWHSA) in Kirkuk province, Iraq, was prioritised. The study used RS, GIS and Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) within an MCDA framework, with the Soil Conservation Service Curve Number (SCS-CN) method. Main inputs were a 30 m DEM (SRTM, USGS/NASA), land use/land cover (10 m, ESRI, 2021), rainfall data (1980–2020 from Iraqi Met Organization), soil texture mapped as Hydrologic Soil Groups A–D (FAO/USDA), drainage density and stream order from the DEM, and CN values derived by overlaying LULC with HSGs per NRCS TR-55. Criteria included rainfall–runoff depth, slope, soil texture, stream order and land cover; weights were derived with AHP in ArcGIS 10.8.2. The RWHSA suitability map classified areas into Very High (8.2%), High (22.6%), Moderate (37.4%), and Low (31.8%) suitability; four check dams validated high-suitability zones. Outputs were produced at cell-level resolution defined by inputs. Area: ~9,679 km2. Socioeconomic factors were not included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data will be made available on request.

Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria suitability analysis: rainfall (interpolated by spline), slope and stream order (from DEM), distance to roads (Euclidean distance), land use (maximum-likelihood Landsat classification) and NDVI (Landsat-derived) were reclassified to a common scale and combined in ArcGIS raster calculator to generate suitability maps, with two runs comparing land use versus NDVI criteria.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper

Data sources included USGS Landsat, DEM (SRTM), FAO guidance, ArcGIS 10.4.1. Method: criteria (rainfall, slope, stream order, distance to roads, land use or NDVI) were reclassified to scores and combined in the raster calculator to yield two suitability maps, with three classes. Validation not described; results: land use yielded 26% low, 58% moderate, 16% high; NDVI yielded 29% low, 57% moderate, 14% high, with eastern Diyala most suitable. File: Al-Sababhah - 2023 - The Application of the Analytic Hierarchy Process and GIS to Map Suitable Rainwater Harvesting Sites.pdf
Input_Variables: Rainfall intensity (Jordan Meteorological Department); Runoff (Soil Map); Slope (ASTER DEM); Flood susceptibility (Derived from multiple factors); Soil texture (Soil Map); Geology (Geology Map); LULC (Landsat-8); Elevation (ASTER DEM); Rivers (Landsat-8); Faults (Geology Map); Settlement centers (LULC); Roads (LULC); Wells (Landsat-8)
Spatial_Method: Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) integrated with Geographic Information System (GIS) where 13 factors are pairwise-weighted and combined as a weighted overlay in a GIS-based MCDM to identify suitable rainwater harvesting sites.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.021; CR = 0.023); Sensitivity analysis
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Final RWH suitability map (Very High; High; Moderate; Low; Very Low)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They explicitly treat flood susceptibility as a climate-related risk that could threaten the feasibility and long-term effectiveness of rainwater harvesting sites. They demonstrate this by including flood risk as a contributing factor in a multi-criteria spatial decision framework and by classifying areas into five risk levels to exclude high-risk zones from the final suitability outputs.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly frame rainwater harvesting as a climate-resilient NbS to alleviate water scarcity and reduce flood risk in Jordan, and demonstrate this by integrating flood susceptibility with rainfall/runoff factors to produce a spatial prioritization map of high-suitability NbS sites aimed at risk reduction.
Narrative: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) was addressed as a nature-based solution in the semi-arid Hasa Basin, southwest Jordan. Thirteen factors—rainfall intensity, runoff (SCS-CN), slope, flood susceptibility, soil texture, geology, LULC, elevation, rivers, faults, settlement centers, roads, and wells—were integrated using Landsat‑8 (30 m, USGS, 2020), ASTER DEM (30 m, NASA, 2020), a soil map, a geology map, and climate records (1990–2021). The GIS–AHP approach (ArcGIS 10.4.1) used a pairwise matrix and a weighted sum (Equation 10) to create a final suitability map. Validation yielded CR = 0.021 (CI 0.034; λmax 13.41). Outputs included a five-class map with area allocations: Very High 1.17% (30.90 km2); High 11.14% (293.22); Moderate 31.91% (840.09); Low 46.09% (1,213.46); Very Low 9.68% (254.93) over 2,632.6 km2. Scope: Hasa Basin (2,632.6 km2; 2.95% of Jordan); climate factors included; settlements and roads excluded for environmental/economic reasons, and wells avoided.

File: Al-Shamiri and Ziadat - 2012 - Soil-landscape modeling and land suitability evaluation the case of rainwater harvesting in a dry r.pdf
Input_Variables: Soil depth (Field observations); Soil texture (Field observations); Surface stoniness (Field observations); Slope (percentage) (DEM); Slope (degree) (DEM); Aspect (DEM); Mean curvature (DEM); Upslope flow accumulation area (DEM); Compound topographic index (CTI) (DEM)
Spatial_Method: Two approaches were used: (1) IDW interpolation of field-observed soil attributes (depth, texture, surface stoniness) across slope units to derive suitability classes; (2) a soil-landscape prediction model that derives terrain attributes from a DEM (slope, aspect, mean curvature, upslope contributing area) to compute CTI and predict soil attributes via class-specific regression, then matches predicted attributes to rainwater-harvesting requirements to map suitability.
Method_Validation: Independent test dataset (65 field observations) with RMSE; Field verification/ground-truthing; Agreement between field-observed suitability and map-derived suitability; Comparison with published soil map (scale 1:10,000) for validation of soil depth.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Suitability map for rainwater harvesting placement (interpolation model, IDW) [classes: Field crops — runoff strips; Field crops — contour ridges; Range crops — runoff strips; Range crops — contour ridges; Not suitable]; Suitability map for rainwater harvesting placement (soil‑landscape prediction model) [classes: Field crops — runoff strips; Field crops — contour ridges; Range crops — runoff strips; Range crops — contour ridges; Not suitable]
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: An NbS assessment addressed rainwater harvesting to improve water productivity in a rangeland in Jordan. Inputs included 108 borehole observations and 65 verification points, soil depth, texture and stoniness, and terrain attributes from a 20 m DEM and maps. Two spatial approaches were used: (i) inverse distance weighted interpolation of soil attributes overlaid with slope; and (ii) a soil-landscape prediction model that partitioned the watershed into sub-watershed facets, used regression to predict soil depth from terrain attributes, produced 20 m pixel maps, and matched predicted soil attributes to rainwater-harvesting requirements. Validation with 65 points yielded RMSEs of 27.2 cm (soil depth) and 16.5% (stone cover) for the soil-landscape model vs 29.9 cm and 17.1% for IDW; runoff-strip map–point agreement was 95% and 98%. Outputs were 20 m resolution suitability maps for a 26 km2 area ~55 km southeast of Amman. Climate risk or economic considerations were not included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Supplementary data available online at doi:10.1016/j.jag.2012.01.005

Narrative: The study addressed water harvesting as a NbS by locating optimum water-harvesting pond sites in the Azraq Basin, Jordan (≈11,052 km2). It used six physical criteria—Rainfall, Slope, Drainage Density, Lineament Density, Geology, Soil Clay Contents—and seven socio-economic factors (border, wadis, roads, urban areas, faults, wells, farms). Narrative: The NbS addressed rainwater harvesting by identifying potential sites for water harvesting in the Wadi Hammad basin, Jordan, via Indigenous Knowledge integrated with GIS-based MCDA. Six criteria were used—rainfall, slope, soil clay content, drainage density, lineament density, and geology—using data from the Council for Science and Technology (rainfall and drainage, 1:250k), Royal Jordanian Geographic Centre (geology, faults, 1:250k), Jordan Ministry of Agriculture soil (1:750k), and ASTER DEM (30 m) for slope. File: Alene et al. - 2022 - Identifying rainwater harvesting sites using integrated GIS and a multi-criteria evaluation approach.pdf

Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation (MCE) using a weighted overlay; Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) for weighting the criteria; SCS-CN runoff-depth estimation integrated with rainfall data; Landsat-8 land-use/land-cover classification; DEM-derived slope and drainage density analysis; proximity to roads and settlements constraints via raster calculations.
Method_Validation: Ground-truth validation using existing rainwater harvesting sites (functional and non-functional) with coordinates and overlay to validate the suitability map; AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 2%, below the 0.1 threshold).
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Potential rainwater harvesting suitability map (S1 highly suitable; S2 moderately suitable; S3 marginally suitable; S4 less suitable; S5 not suitable); Proposed rainwater harvesting allocation map — farm ponds (47 sites) and check dams (12 sites)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They target rainwater harvesting to reduce climate-driven drought risk, treating it as an adaptation NbS, and they demonstrate this by identifying highly suitable RWH sites and proposing 47 farm ponds and 12 check dams to mitigate drought impacts (risk-reduction outputs).
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Wag Himra zone;Amhara state;Tekeze basin;National: Ethiopia
Narrative: The NbS addressed rainwater harvesting (RWH) in semi‑arid Ethiopia, identifying viable sites for RWH structures (farm ponds and check dams) in the Wag Himra zone. Main inputs included Landsat 8 OLI/TIS land use/land cover at 30 m resolution and a Landsat/ground‑truth based LU validation, SRTM‑derived 30 m slope and drainage density, soil maps from the Amhara design supervision works enterprise, rainfall data from nine weather stations (2008–2018) interpolated by inverse distance weighting, and proximity constraints for roads and settlements; all data were harmonised to 30 m resolution. The spatial method combined a GIS‑based multi‑criteria evaluation (MCE) with Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) weights, deriving Runoff depth via SCS‑CN with CN per pixel computed from the soil map and LU/LC, and integrating slope, soil texture, drainage density, and proximity constraints in ArcGIS 10.4 through weighted overlay; a constraint map was applied to exclude restricted areas. Validation used ground truth from 12 sites, yielding an overall accuracy of 80.1% and a kappa of 76.2%, with a consistency ratio of 2%. Outputs comprised a final RWH suitability map with classes S1–S5 at 30 m resolution, indicating 0.02% highly suitable, 2.59% moderately suitable, 12.26% marginally suitable, 61.76% less suitable, and 21.1% not suitable (plus 2.29% restricted); 47 farm ponds and 12 check dams were proposed. The study area covers about 9,004 km2 in the Wag Himra zone, Amhara, Ethiopia (coordinates ~ 12°07′–13°18′ N, 38°20′–39°18′ E). Climate risk was addressed indirectly through rainfall/runoff assessment; no explicit economic analysis was reported.

Input_Variables: Flow Accumulation (DEM); No-Sink Flow Accumulation (DEM); Sink Flow Accumulation (DEM); No Sinks Channel Density (Derived from No-Sink Flow Accumulation); Sinks Channel Density (Derived from Sink Flow Accumulation); Relative Slope Position (SAGA GIS); Valley Depth (SAGA GIS); Topographic Wetness Index (SAGA GIS); Plan Curvature (SAGA GIS); Cross-Sectional Curvature (SAGA GIS); Longitudinal Curvature (SAGA GIS); Flow Line Curvature (SAGA GIS); Profile Curvature (SAGA GIS); Tangential Curvature (SAGA GIS); Slope (DEM); DEM (ASF/ALOS PALSAR 12.5 m); Total Insolation (SAGA GIS); Curve Number (GCN250; Jaafar et al. 2019); Depth to Bedrock (SoilGrids250m; Hengl et al. 2017); Estimated Ksat (Rosetta pedotransfer function; Zhang & Schaap 2017); Soil (FAO data); Rainfall (TerraClimate); Runoff (TerraClimate); Actual Evapotranspiration (TerraClimate); Potential Evapotranspiration (TerraClimate); Soil Moisture (TerraClimate); MSAVI (Qi et al., 1994); Sheep (GLW4); Goats (GLW4); Land Cover/Land Use (Esri ArcGIS Living Atlas; Esri 2024); NDWI (Sentinel-2)

Tool_Source: SAGA GIS: Used to derive terrain-derived factors (valley depth, Topographic Wetness Index, Relative Slope Position, curvature) and to compute insolation from a high-resolution DEM for MCDA; Channel Density tool (SAGA GIS): Used to generate two flow-accumulation–based channel density rasters (Sinks Channel Density and No Sinks Channel Density) representing drainage under different interception scenarios for MCDA; Rosetta Pedotransfer Function: Used to estimate Saturated Hydraulic Conductivity (Ksat) from FAO soil data (texture, bulk density, water content) and adjust for fine material to feed soil-hydrology criteria in MCDA; ClimateEngine: Used to access TerraClimate-derived climate variables (Rainfall, Runoff, Actual Evapotranspiration, Potential Evapotranspiration, Soil Moisture) at ~4 km resolution over 1958–2023 to inform the climate-related criteria in the MCDA.
Output: Suitability index map (index range 0–0.55; >0.3 = moderately suitable); Insolation and Topographical Index map (fine-scale suitability highlighting highly suitable zones); Proposed rainwater-harvesting pond locations map (52 proposed sites with per-site suitability index)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: climate hazards are treated as a risk to NbS performance, with high insolation driving evaporation losses that could threaten pond persistence; the authors demonstrate this by incorporating an insolation criterion into their MCDA and presenting an Insolation and Topographical Index map and a suitability output that favors low-insolation sites to mitigate evaporation.
Climate_Benefit: "Yes: The NbS (rainwater harvesting ponds) are spatially targeted to mitigate climate-associated drought risk by increasing stored surface water, supporting rangeland and livestock resilience, and reducing desertification in Hadalat Basin; the authors demonstrate this through a priority/suitability output that identifies 52 optimal pond sites and discusses how implementing these ponds would enhance water security and vegetation/livestock livelihoods under climate stress."
Economics: Yes: It incorporates economic framing by treating livelihoods and livestock demand (rangeland availability, livestock density, including sheep and goats) as a 31% weighted MCDA objective (Goal II) and by prioritizing cost efficiency (minimizing evaporation and construction/maintenance costs in Goal III; the discussion also notes financial viability and calls for economic feasibility studies), though no explicit monetary outputs (ROI/NPV/benefit–cost) are reported.
Narrative: The NbS addressed were rainwater harvesting ponds (hafayer) to improve water security, rangeland management, and livelihoods in the 13,202 km2 Hadalat Dam watershed in northeastern Jordan. The study integrated six data groups—soil (FAO data; Curve Number from GCN250; Rosetta Ksat; depth to bedrock), topography (12.5 m DEM from ASF/ALOS PALSAR; valley depth; TWI; slope position; curvature), climate (TerraClimate rainfall, runoff, ET, PET, soil moisture at ~4 km), land cover/use and livestock (MSAVI; Esri LCLU; sheep/goats from GLW4), channel density, and insolation (NDWI from Sentinel-2 2018–2022). A geospatial MCDA with adaptive weighting and Weighted Combination combined three objectives (Water Quantity 45%; Justification 31%; Cost/Retention 24%), using two flow-accumulation rasters to produce No-Sinks and Sinks channel densities. Outputs at 12.5 m resolution included a Suitability Index map, Insolation–Topography index, and 52 proposed ponds (existing 41; total 93). Validation used rainfall vs GHCN (r>0.9) and runoff vs 587 basins (r=0.80), ET vs FLUXNET (r=0.77).

File: Alkaradaghi et al. - 2022 - Geospatial Technique Integrated with MCDM Models for Selecting Potential Sites for Harvesting Rainwa.pdf
Input_Variables: Rain (Directory of Sulaymaniyah weather forecasting); Geology (Iraq Geological Survey and Mining; Jassim & Goff, 2006); Stream (USGS Earth Explorer and DEM); Lineament (Iraq Geological Survey and Mining); LULC (USGS Earth Explorer; Landsat 8 OLI); CN (Iraq Geological Survey and Mining; USGS Earth Explorer and DEM); Soil (Ministry of Agriculture—Iraq); DEM (USGS Earth Explorer); Slope (DEM); Villages (UNOCHA)
Spatial_Method: A GIS‑based multi‑criteria decision‑making framework integrating Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP); Simple Additive Weighting Method (SAWM); and fuzzy‑based index (FBI) to weight and combine thematic layers via a weighted overlay/map algebra to identify suitable rainwater harvesting sites.
Method_Validation: ROC/AUC validation; Field verification/ground-truthing (seven field-check locations); Prediction rate curve/accuracy assessment; Comparison with existing dams/reservoirs; Sensitivity analysis; AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.027 < 0.1)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Rainwater-harvesting suitability/priority map (Unsuitable; Relatively suitable; Suitable; Most suitable) ; Proposed dam/pond locations with coordinates and estimated storage volumes (7 sites — small dams and ponds; total storage 377,260.8 m3)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS (rainwater harvesting) is spatially targeted to reduce climate-change–driven drought risk by augmenting water supply in the semi-arid region. The authors demonstrate this through a suitability/index map for RWH sites and an estimated total harvested runoff of 377,260 m3, illustrating how prioritized NbS locations would mitigate drought impacts.
Narrative: NbS addressed: rainwater harvesting (RWH) structures, specifically three farm ponds and four small dams, to augment water supply in Qaradaqh basin, Iraq. Main inputs: ten thematic maps from Rain (Directory of Sulaymaniyah weather forecasting), Geology (Iraq Geological Survey), Stream (USGS Earth Explorer/DEM), Lineament (Iraq Geological Survey), LULC (USGS Landsat 8 OLI), CN (USGS/DEM), Soil (Iraq MoA), DEM, Slope, and Villages (UNOCHA); data reprojected to UTM‑WGS84 with 12.5 m pixels. The spatial method combined AHP, SAWM, and FBI weights in GIS via buffered criteria and a Weighted Overlay to produce a suitability index Si = sum Wj×Gij, with a fuzzy overlay for reconciliation. Validation used ROC‑AUC: 0.72 (AHP), 0.57 (SAWM), 0.59 (FBI); seven proposed sites yielded total harvested runoff of 377,260 m3. Outputs include four-class suitability maps at 12.5 m resolution, and seven candidate sites with area/volume data. Geographic scope: Qaradaqh basin, Iraq; climate risk and economic considerations were included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The datasets generated during and/or analysed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

File: Alrawi et al. - 2023 - Insights of dam site selection for rainwater harvesting using GIS A case study in the Al- Qalamoun.pdf
Input_Variables: LULC (MODIS MCD12Q1); Soil texture (HWSD); Slope (SRTM DEM); Rainfall (TRMM 3B43–V7); Curve Number (CN) (HEC-GeoHMS); Stream order (DEM-derived); Distance to faults (Syria tectonic map); Distance to roads (GORS roads shapefile); Distance to residential areas (GORS residential areas shapefile)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based MCDA using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight nine criteria; Weighted Overlay Process (WOP) to combine rasters into a suitability map; SCS-CN model to derive curve number (CN) for runoff potential; IDW interpolation to map rainfall distribution.
Method_Validation: Comparison with existing NbS sites (validation against two existing earth dams); Proximity-based validation using a 1000 m buffer around the dams; AUC-ROC validation of the RWH map (AUC = 70.18%); AHP consistency ratio (CR) check (CR = 0.046 < 0.1)
Tool_Source: HEC-GeoHMS: Used to generate the Curve Number (CN) map by integrating DEM, LULC, and Hydrologic Soil Groups (HSGs) within the SCS-CN framework to estimate runoff potential for identifying rainwater harvesting sites.
Output: RWH potential suitability map (unsuitable; less suitable; moderately suitable; suitable; most suitable); Proposed dam sites map (4 candidate dams with locations and storage capacities); Proposed farm pond locations map (14 ponds with locations, areas, depths, volumes)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS (rainwater harvesting via dam sites) is spatially targeted to mitigate climate-driven water scarcity by prioritizing zones for rainwater harvesting to augment storage and reduce groundwater reliance, demonstrated by a dedicated RWH suitability map and the proposal of four dam sites with substantial storage to support irrigation and domestic use (validated against existing dams).
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis includes economic framing through a cost-minimization objective in selecting dam sites (minimizing dam length and optimizing reservoir depth/capacity to reduce construction costs and evaporation) and by incorporating socioeconomic considerations such as proximity to roads to lower transport costs and distance from residential areas to protect livelihoods; the narrative also frames Syria's decision context as aiming to save money and time in site identification.
Narrative: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) dam-site prioritization in Al-Qalamoun Basin, Syria, used a GIS-based MCDA anchored in AHP. Nine criteria—LULC, soil texture, slope, rainfall, CN, stream order, distance to faults, distance to roads, and distance to residential areas—were drawn from MODIS MCD12Q1 (LULC), HWSD (soil), SRTM/DEM (CN, slope, stream order), TRMM 3B43–V7 (1998–2019 rainfall; IDW interpolation), a Syrian tectonic map (faults), and GORS (roads, residences). All layers were resampled to 30 m in UTM 37N. Weights via Saaty’s AHP with a CR check, followed by Weighted Overlay (WOP) in ArcGIS 10.8 to produce an RWH suitability map with five-class categories. Validation against dams gave AUC 70.18%; Dam1 and Dam2 aligned at 85.27% and 86.88%. Outputs include a 30m RWH map, four proposed dam sites with storages of 100.66, 23.77, 2.4 and 1.4 million m3, plus 14 farm ponds; area ~3366 km2. Economic considerations (cost minimization) were included; climate risk was not explicitly modeled.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data included in article/supp. Material/referenced in article.

File: Alwan et al. - 2020 - Potential Water Harvesting Sites Identification Using Spatial Multi-Criteria Evaluation in Maysan Pr.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope (DEM); Stream order (DEM); Precipitation (TRMM); Evaporation (GLDAS NOAH025-M-2); NDVI (Landsat 8); Soil (FAO); Roads (Shapefile)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based Multi-Criteria Evaluation (MCE) with fuzzy membership standardization; Fuzzy Gamma overlay to combine seven criteria (slope, stream order, soil, precipitation, evaporation, roads, NDVI) to identify suitable rainwater-harvesting sites.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Rainwater-harvesting suitability map (5 classes; 0–56% suitability); Proposed potential RWH sites map (11 point locations)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS (rainwater harvesting) is framed as climate adaptation to reduce drought-related water stress under changing climate, and the authors demonstrate this by deriving a suitability map and identifying high-potential sites to mitigate climate risks and enhance water security in the semi-arid region.
Narrative: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) was the NbS addressed. The study identified optimum RWH sites in Maysan province, south-east Iraq (≈16,072 km2). Seven criteria were used: slope (from a 30 m SRTM DEM), stream order (D8/Strahler from DEM), soil type (FAO), precipitation (TRMM 2000–2019, 0.25°; Kriging), evaporation (GLDAS NOAH025-M-2, 0.25°; Kriging), roads (Euclidean distance to roads), and NDVI (from Landsat 8, Mar 2019). All layers were processed in ArcGIS 10.5 (WGS84/UTM38N). The approach applied GIS-based Multi-Criteria Evaluation with Fuzzy Linear Membership standardization and Fuzzy Gamma overlay (0.9) to produce a rainwater-harvesting suitability map (0–56%, five classes). NW Maysan was identified as suitable, yielding eleven sites with coordinates given in Table 2 and shown in Figure 12–13. Validation was not described; climate data informed the analysis (precipitation and evaporation); no economic considerations were reported.

File: Amdihun et al. - 2014 - Suitability and scenario modeling to support soil and water conservation interventions in the Blue N.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Alley cropping; Bench Terraces; Grass Strips; Level bund; Level fanya Juu; Graded bund; Graded Fanya Juu; Controlled grazing; Revegetation; Cutoff drain; Area Closure; Tree planting; Must be changed to forestland; Must be changed to grassland; Waterways
Input_Variables: Soil erosion risk (Amdihun et al. 2014); Land use/land cover (ARBIDMPP 1998); Agroecology (Amdihun et al. 2014); Slope (SRTM DEM Version 4)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based spatial data integration and overlay using a layer-combination framework for multi-criteria analysis (overlaying slope, land use/cover, agroecology, soil erosion risk) to delineate 160 landscape units and assign suitable SWC measures.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Proposed SWC allocation/suitability map (classes: Bench terraces/Grass strips; Level bund/Level Fanya Juu; Graded bund/Graded Fanya Juu; Controlled grazing/Revegetation/Cutoff drain; Area closure/Tree planting; Must be changed to grassland/Forest land; Waterways); Proposed support-practices map (support practices paired with major SWC measures); Conservation scenario map (‘without’ vs ‘with’ SWC intervention); Net soil-loss-reduction map (pixel-wise soil loss reduction with proper SWC intervention)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: It treats economics qualitatively—notes that SWC measures are costly and labor-intensive, mentions financing needs and potential short-term economic benefits to farmers (e.g., integrating fruit trees), and cites economic viability as a selection criterion, but provides no explicit economic metrics (no CBA/ROI/NPV) in the output.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Blue Nile Basin (Abbay Basin), Ethiopia
Narrative: NbS addressed: landscape SWC in the Blue Nile Basin, Ethiopia, applying six measures—bench terraces/grass strips, level bunds, graded structures, controlled grazing/revegetation/cutoff drains, area closure/tree planting, and must-change-to-forest/grassland. Main inputs: layers on soil erosion risk, land use (ARBIDMP 1998), slope and agroecology (SRTM DEM v4), plus EHRS 1986, CBPWMG 2005, ARBIMPP 1998; 160 landscape units used; erosion reductions from Herweg & Ludi 1999. Spatial method and combination: GIS-based layer-combination with a multi-criteria analysis assigning SWC types to each unit; NSLR calculated pixelwise SLAI = SLWOI − SLWI for 'with' vs 'without' SWC. Validation and results: parameterization from plot studies; 46% NSLR in 5–10 years and up to 600 million tons soil saved; four zones yield about 60% of total reduction. Outputs: scenario map contrasting 'without' and 'with' SWC, NSLR raster, and zonal statistics across 160 units; Geographic scope: Blue Nile Basin, about 200,000 km2. Climate risk not explicit; economic viability and social acceptance noted.

File: Arshed et al. - 2023 - Effective management of the watershed in response to historical climate change using a GIS-based mul.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: water harvesting; vegetative cover (VC) for water and soil management
Input_Variables: Rainfall (WAPDA/PMD); Runoff (SWAT); Slope (SRTM-DEM); LULC (Landsat 7/8); Soil type (FAO); Elevation (DEM); Aspect (DEM); Temperature (WAPDA/PMD)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) using Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weigh criteria and prioritize alternatives; GIS-based weighted overlay analysis (WOA) for site suitability mapping of water harvesting structures and vegetative cover.
Method_Validation: SWAT model calibration and validation against observed streamflows at Dhok Pathan using SWAT-CUP SUFI-2 (calibration/validation periods RC1: 1988–1989 calibration and 1990–1991 validation; RC2: 2006–2007 calibration and 2008–2009 validation) with NSE, R2 and PBIAS; sensitivity analysis of input parameters; AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.08).
Tool: SWAT (Arnold et al., 1998; doi:10.1111/j.1752-1688.1998.tb05961.x); SWAT-CUP (Thavhana et al., 2018; doi:10.1016/j.pce.2018.03.012); Analytic Hierarchy Process (Saaty 1970; Saaty 1994); Weighted Overlay Analysis (Durbude & Venkatesh 2004; doi:10.1007/BF03030865)
Tool_Source: SWAT: Used to simulate hydrological processes in the Soan River Basin and quantify the impacts of climate change and LUCC on runoff and evapotranspiration across four scenarios, with SWAT outputs feeding the MCDA; SWAT-CUP: Used to calibrate and validate the SWAT model and assess simulation uncertainty via the SUFI-2 algorithm, reporting p-factor and r-factor for model performance; Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP): Used to weight and prioritize watershed management criteria and alternatives through pairwise comparisons, generating overall priority scores and checking consistency (CR); Weighted Overlay Analysis (WOA): GIS-based site suitability analysis that combines the AHP-derived weights with spatial criterion layers to produce suitability maps for water harvesting structures and vegetative cover.
Output: Water harvesting structures suitability map (Highly suitable; Moderately suitable; Low suitable; Unsuitable); Vegetative cover for soil and water management suitability map (Highly suitable; Suitable; Moderately suitable; Unsuitable; Highly unsuitable)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They treat climate change as a risk to NbS performance by quantifying climate-driven declines in runoff and increases in ET under multiple scenarios, and they embed these projections in the MCDA and site-suitability outputs to select climate-adaptive NbS (water harvesting structures and vegetative cover) and demonstrate their feasibility under changing conditions.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS (water harvesting structures and vegetative cover) are explicitly targeted to counter climate-change–driven reductions in runoff and increases in evapotranspiration, i.e., climate risks, and the authors demonstrate this by prioritizing WHS and VC as the top management options under climate-change scenarios and by identifying suitable areas for their implementation to support climate adaptation.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis includes economic framing via criteria such as "Contribution to Economy" and "Sustainable and profitable agriculture" in the MCDA, with the economy criterion weighted at 15.92%, shaping the overall priority—WHS and vegetative cover rank highest due in part to economic considerations—though no explicit monetary outputs (costs, ROI, NPV, etc.) are reported.
Narrative: Within Soan River Basin (SRB), Pakistan, NbS addressed were water harvesting structures (WHS) and vegetative cover (VC) for soil and water management. The spatial prioritisation combined SWAT hydrology under four climate–LUCC scenarios with a GIS-based MCDA using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to rank ten watershed-management alternatives; inputs included daily rainfall and temperatures (1981–2020) from WAPDA and PMD, soil maps (FAO) and land-use maps (2000, 2020), SRTM slope, streamflow at Dhok Pathan, and expert weights. AHP weights and a GIS weighted overlay produced site-suitability maps at 30 m resolution for WHS and VC. SWAT calibration/validation against observed flows yielded NSE up to 0.81 and R2 up to 0.82 (RC2), with PBIAS ~3.3. Outputs showed WHS: 63.61% moderately, 16.56% highly, 12.12% low, 7.64% not suitable; VC: 72.68% suitable, 26.75% moderate, 0.22% high, 0.36% not suitable. The study covered ~6,540 km2; climate risk was explicit, and economy was an AHP criterion (weight 11.83%).
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data cannot be made publicly available; readers should contact the corresponding author for details.

File: Ashraf et al. - 2024 - Ascertainment of the most suitable water harvesting sites in a data-scarce region via an integrated.pdf
Input_Variables: Rainfall (Pakistan Meteorological Department); DEM (ALOS PALSAR); LULC (Landsat 8); Soil (FAO Digital World Soil Map); Runoff depth (SCS CN derived from LULC and soil); Drainage density (DEM-derived; Arc Hydro); Lineament density (Lineament map; ArcGIS); Slope (DEM-derived; ArcGIS); Drainage order (Drainage network map; Strahler)
Spatial_Method: GIS and RS-based MCDA using AHP for weights; PROMETHEE-II for ranking; Weighted Overlay Analysis to produce the suitability map and identify priority water harvesting sites.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.08 < 0.1); LULC map accuracy assessment with Kappa = 77.83% (Substantial Agreement)
Tool: PROMETHEE-II (Nasiri et al., 2013, Environmental Monitoring and Assessment 185, 707–718) ; Analytic Hierarchy Process (Saaty 1988 What is the Analytic Hierarchy Process?, Springer)
Tool_Source: PROMETHEE-II : Used to rank the 16 identified potential water harvesting sites (WHS) and establish a priority order for site selection based on multiple criteria, with weights provided by Analytic Hierarchy Process. Analytic Hierarchy Process : Used to derive weights for six criteria (Runoff depth 34%, LULC 10%, Drainage density 31%, Lineament density 3%, Slope 15%, Soil 8%) (CR = 0.08) that feed the PROMETHEE-II ranking.
Output: Suitability map for rainwater-harvesting site placement (classes: very low–very high; 69 potential sites; 16 most suitable/ranked sites); Ranked water-harvesting-site map with per-site dam storage capacity at NCL (m3) and reservoir area (m2) [sites S1–S16]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS targeting rainwater harvesting dams is used to reduce climate-driven floods and droughts by increasing storage and attenuating runoff, and the authors demonstrate this through a suitability map and a ranked list of candidate sites based on their potential water conservation capacity and flood/drought mitigation benefits.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Vidore Hill Torrent catchment; Sub-national: D.G. Khan District; Sub-national: Rajanpur District; Sub-national: Punjab Province; Sub-national: Baluchistan Province; National: Pakistan
Narrative: The NbS addressed rainwater harvesting by identifying and ranking suitable small-dam water harvesting sites (WHS) in the Vidore Hill Torrent catchment of D.G. Khan, Punjab, Pakistan. The main inputs were slope, runoff depth, land use/land cover (LULC), soil texture, drainage density, and lineament density, derived from PMD rainfall data, a 12.5 m ALOS PALSAR DEM, FAO Digital World Soil Map, and Landsat 8 imagery (August 2021) with runoff estimated via the SCS CN method; socioeconomic criteria were not considered. The spatial approach integrated GIS/RS and MCDA, computing runoff depth with CN, assigning AHP-derived weights (Runoff depth 34%, LULC 10%, Drainage density 31%, Lineament density 3%, Slope 15%, Soil 8%; CR = 0.08), and combining layers via Weighted Overlay Analysis before outranking alternatives with PROMETHEE-II to rank 16 top sites from 69 candidates. Outputs included a suitability map, 69 identified sites, and 16 top WHS (S1–S16); EACCs were generated for the 16 sites; the highest-ranking site (S12) showed storage 480,031 m3, dam length 89 m, at coordinates 30.149784° N, 70.297164° E. The study area is the Vidore Hill Torrent catchment, DG Khan District, with raster inputs at ~12–12.5 m resolution. Climate risk was incorporated via rainfall/runoff; economic considerations were not included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data cannot be made publicly available; readers should contact the corresponding author for details.

File: Aziz et al. - 2023 - Water Harvesting in the Garmian Region (Kurdistan, Iraq) Using GIS and Remote Sensing.pdf
Input_Variables: Rainfall (Kalar and Darbandikhan meteorological stations; Kifre directory of agriculture and water resources); Slope (USGS); Land Use/Land Cover (Landsat 8, NASA); Soil Texture (Harmonized World Soil Database); Drainage Density (Drainage network data)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria analysis (MCA) using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and fuzzy-AHP (FAHP) to weight criteria, followed by Weighted Linear Combination (WLC) and fuzzy gamma overlay to produce rainfall harvesting suitability maps from rainfall, slope, land use/cover, soil texture, and drainage density, with fuzzy membership (FLM) for reclassification and NPRC rainfall classification.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR < 0.1)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Potential RWH suitability map (AHP + WLC; classes: very high / high / moderate / low / very low); Potential RWH suitability map (FAHP + Fuzzy Gamma; classes: very high / high / moderate / low / very low)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: they explicitly target rainwater harvesting (NbS) to address climate-change–driven drought and water scarcity, and demonstrate this by producing spatially explicit RWH suitability outputs (rainfall-driven, slope, drainage, land use) and NPRC-based scenario maps that prioritize high-potential areas for NbS adoption as climate adaptation.
Narrative: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) in the Garmian region of Kurdistan, Iraq was framed as an NbS spatial prioritisation problem using GIS and remote sensing. The main inputs included rainfall data for 2001–2020 from Kalar, Darbandikhan and Kifre; a 30 m USGS DEM for slope; Landsat 8 imagery for land use/cover; the Harmonized World Soil Database (HWSD); and drainage density derived from the data, with rainfall interpolated by Kriging. Five criteria—rainfall (climate), drainage density (hydrology), slope (topography), land use/cover (agronomy), and soil texture—were weighted with AHP and FAHP; layers were combined by Weighted Linear Combination and a fuzzy gamma overlay after standardising with Fuzzy Membership. Validation showed FAHP overlays to be more realistic, aided by a demonstration on the Awa Spi dam reservoir. Outputs were five-class RWH suitability maps at 30 m resolution for the Garmian region; NPRC FAHP/FGamma yielded about 25.3% very high, 21.9% high, 26.6% moderate, 15.6% low, and 10.6% very low. Climate risk was included via rainfall; economic considerations were not.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: All data supporting this study’s findings are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

File: Bera and Mukhopadhyay - 2023 - Identification of suitable sites for surface rainwater harvesting in the drought prone Kumari River.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: check dams; percolation tanks; earthen dams; farm ponds; contour bundh; nala bundh; gulley plug structures; gully plugs; terracing
Input_Variables: Slope (SRTM DEM); Land use/land cover (Landsat 8); Surface runoff (SWAT); Drainage density (SRTM DEM); Soil texture (NBSS and LUP soil data); Rainfall (IMD); Geology (GSI); Curvature (DEM/ArcGIS); Lineament density (NRSC Bhuvan thematic data); Geomorphology (GSI); Topographic wetness index (DEM); Groundwater level (shallow tube wells + IDW interpolation)
Spatial_Method: SWAT-based runoff estimation; GIS-based analytic hierarchy process (AHP) weighted-overlay multicriteria decision analysis across 12 geo-environmental factors; Jenks natural breaks classification; ROC validation.
Method_Validation: ROC validation using 52 existing check dam sites (AUC = 0.874); field verification/ground-truthing at the sites; AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.066 < 0.1).
Tool_Source: SWAT : Used to calculate yearly runoff for Kumari basin (sub-basin wise for 2003–2013) and to compute the annual mean runoff across 11 years, providing runoff input for the surface rainwater harvesting suitability analysis. ; ArcSWAT : Used as an ArcGIS extension to generate the runoff map (runoff map) needed for the study’s surface rainwater harvesting site suitability assessment.
Output: Surface rainwater harvesting suitability zones (highly suitable; moderately suitable; less suitable; unsuitable); Proposed check dam sites (32 sites); Proposed SRWH structure sites — earthen dams (17); farm ponds (24); percolation tanks (35); gully plugs (19)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS is spatially targeted to mitigate climate-driven drought and water scarcity by prioritising highly to moderately suitable zones for rainwater harvesting structures in the Kumari basin, treating climate risk reduction as an explicit output; the authors demonstrate this via a zoned SRWH suitability map and proposed site allocations (check dams, percolation tanks, farm ponds, gulley plugs) intended to reduce dry-season water shortfalls and enhance resilience to monsoon variability.
Narrative: The NbS addressed were surface rainwater harvesting (SRWH) structures, including check dams, earthen dams, percolation tanks, farm ponds and gulley plugs, implemented in the drought-prone Kumari River basin, India. Twelve factors (slope, LULC, surface runoff, drainage density, soil texture, rainfall, geology, curvature, lineament density, geomorphology, topographic wetness index, groundwater level) were prepared from data sets such as a 30 m SRTM DEM, Landsat 8 LULC, NBSS-LUP soil map, GSI geology/geomorphology maps, 54 shallow wells, 52 check dams, IMD rainfall (2001–2020, 0.25°), NRSC Bhuvan lineaments, and SWAT-derived runoff (2003–2013), all reclassified to 30 m cells. An Analytic Hierarchy Process–multicriteria decision analysis (AHP-MCDA) weighted overlay combined the layers to produce the SRWHSZ map, classified by Jenks natural breaks into four classes. Validation used a Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve with 52 check dams, yielding AUC 0.874. Outputs include a 30 m SRWHSZ map and proposed sites: 32 check dams, 17 earthen dams, 35 percolation tanks, 24 farm ponds, 19 gulley plugs across 1976.15 km2 in West Bengal. Climate risk or economic considerations were not explicitly included.

File: Bojer et al. - 2024 - Rainwater Harvesting Site Selection for Drought-Prone Areas in Somali and Borena Zones, Oromia Regio.pdf
Input_Variables: Rainfall (Ethiopian Meteorological Service EMI); Slope (ASTER DEM; SRTM); Elevation (ASTER DEM; SRTM); Drainage Density (DEM; ArcGIS 10.8); Soil Texture (FAO; ISRIC); LULC (Ethiopian Sentinel-2 LULC 2016); Hydrologic Soil Group (HSG) (SCS guidelines; FAO/ISRIC soil data)

Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS is spatially targeted to drought-prone areas to mitigate climate-related water scarcity and drought risk; the authors demonstrate this by identifying and prioritizing highly suitable zones for rainwater harvesting to reduce drought impacts in the Somali and Borena zones.
Economics: Yes: Economic aspects appear in the OUTPUT analysis by including socio-economic criteria (water needs and land ownership) in the AHP weightings and by framing the MCDA to reflect environmental, economic and social conditions; these socio-economic factors are integrated into the GIS-based weighted overlay to produce the rainwater harvesting site suitability map, with weights derived from pairwise comparisons (AHP) and consistency checks; however, the study does not report explicit economic outputs (cost-benefit, ROI, NPV, cost-effectiveness ratios, or economic suitability scores) in its results, and it only mentions cost-benefit analyses and economic viability as future work.

Narrative: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) site selection was the NbS addressed in drought-prone Ethiopia (Borena zone, Oromia, and Somali region). Inputs were rainfall (means 2012–2021 from 14 EMI stations), slope, drainage density (derived from 30 m ASTER/SRTM DEMs via ArcGIS hydrology tools), soil texture (FAO Soil Grids 250 m), and land use/land cover (Sentinel-2 LULC 2016). Data were processed in ArcGIS 10.8/ArcGIS Pro 2.9 and QGIS 3.4. The approach used a GIS-based MCDA with Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight factors, followed by a weighted linear combination (WLC) to yield four suitability classes: highly suitable, moderately suitable, low suitability, and unsuitable. Validation used AHP consistency checks (CR). Results: highly suitable 3288 km2 (1%), moderately 37,498 km2 (12%), low 242,170 km2 (75%), unsuitable 41,000 km2 (13%); 18 suitable sites (13 highly, 5 moderately). Spatial_Method: Remote sensing–GIS analysis; AHP-based multi-criteria decision analysis to weight and integrate runoff depth (computed via the SCS-CN method using soil and LULC), slope and drainage (from DEM), and land use/land cover to produce a rainwater harvesting suitability map and zones.

Tool_Source: NA

The authors demonstrate this by producing a runoff-depth–based suitability map and selecting optimal sites for farm ponds and check dams, explicitly framing the outputs as adapting to climate change and drought in Kirkuk.
Narrative: The NbS addressed was rainwater harvesting (RWH) site selection for farm ponds and check dams in Kirkuk, Iraq, using remote sensing and GIS integrated with multi-criteria decision analysis (AHP). Main inputs were four thematic layers—runoff depth, slope, drainage density, and land use/land cover—derived from Landsat 8 (30 m), a 30 m SRTM DEM, an Iraqi soil map, and 2000–2014 rainfall data from the Iraqi Meteorological Organization; runoff depth was estimated from CN-based calculations per pixel, with rainfall interpolated by inverse distance weighting. Climate risk or explicit economic factors were not included; the approach was described as cost-effective.

File: Darabi et al. - 2021 - Efficient rainwater harvesting planning using socio-environmental variables and data-driven geospati.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Check dams; bench terraces; farm and storage ponds; contour ridges; bunds
Input_Variables: Elevation (Forest, Range and Watershed Management Organization of Fars province); Slope (DEM 30 m; Forest, Range and Watershed Management Organization of Fars province); Aspect (DEM 30 m; Forest, Range and Watershed Management Organization of Fars province); Precipitation (IRIMO; Fars Water Authority); Temperature (IRIMO; Fars Water Authority); Distance from river (not specified); Curve Number (CN) (CN runoff extension in ArcGIS 10.5; Darabi et al., 2014); Land use/land cover (LULC) (Landsat 8 OLI; USGS); Geology (not specified); Soil type (not specified); Population density (FAO 2003); Distance from road (Li et al., 2015; ArcGIS 10.5); Distance from lake (not specified)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based suitability mapping using AI algorithms (SVM; MaxEnt; GARP) and an ensemble model, built from socio-environmental rasters, with probability curves used to derive thresholds and optimum variable ranges.
Method_Validation: Train-test split (70% training, 30% testing) using 167 existing RWH structures; model performance evaluated with ROC-AUC and Kappa on training and testing datasets.
Tool_Source: e1071 : Implemented SVM with an RBF kernel (via the e1071 package in R) as one of the AIAs to model RWH suitability and compare performance with other models; GARP : A genetic algorithm–based rule-set model used to identify environmental-condition relationships for RWH suitability, applied in Maharloo-Bakhtegan basin; MaxEnt : Maximum entropy model used to estimate the geographical distribution and suitability of RWH sites from occurrence data and environmental variables.
Output: RWH ensemble suitability map (very low; low; moderate; high; very high)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The study explicitly treats rainwater harvesting as a nature-based solution to climate-change adaptation by aiming to reduce flood and drought risks and improve water security, and demonstrates this through basin-scale RWH suitability mapping and explicit discussion that these maps can be used in risk-reduction strategies and adaptation planning.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Maharloo-Bakhtegan basin; Fars province; Iran
Narrative: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) was treated as a nature-based solution to address water scarcity in the Maharloo‑Bakhtegan basin, southern Iran. The main inputs combined topographic, climatic, hydrological, land‑cover, geological/soil and social variables: elevation, slope and aspect; mean annual precipitation (1989–2019) and temperature from 29 IRIMO and Fars Water Authority stations; distance from river and curve number (CN); Landsat 8 land-use/land-cover; geology and soil type; population density; and distances from roads and lakes, with existing RWH structures (167) from field surveys and local data informing the calibration. A GIS‑based AI ensemble approach integrated support vector machines (SVM), MaxEnt and GARP, with an ensemble model selected based on ROC‑AUC and Kappa. Probability curves defined optimum ranges and thresholds; results yielded five-class suitability maps (very low to very high) showing 9.7% (3070 km2) of the basin in very high suitability, concentrated in the south/southwest. The basin (31,511 km2) was studied at a large scale; climate variables were included; no explicit economic considerations were reported. Validation: ROC‑AUC ensemble training 0.957, testing 0.865; Kappa ensemble 0.922 training, 0.901 testing.

File: Debebe et al. - 2022 - Remote sensing and multi-criterion analysis for identifying suitable rainwater harvesting areas.pdf
Input_Variables: Annual rainfall (CRU); Slope (USGS EarthExplorer); Aspect (USGS EarthExplorer); LULC (Landsat 8); Soil texture (FAO Soil Data Base); Soil moisture index (Landsat 8); Stream order (DEM/ArcGIS Hydrology tool); Distance to road (DIVA-GIS); Distance to river (DIVA-GIS)

Tool_Source: NA
Output: Rainwater-harvesting suitability map [highly suitable; suitable; moderately suitable; less suitable] (AhP-weighted); Rainwater-harvesting suitability map [highly suitable; suitable; moderately suitable; less suitable] (equal-weighted)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic considerations are included in the OUTPUT analysis by treating labour and cost of rainwater harvesting as sub‑criteria in the AhP weighting and mentioning cost/labour in ranking of sub‑criteria, thereby integrating economic aspects into suitability; however, there are no explicit economic metrics (ROI, NPV, cost‑benefit, or economic suitability scores) reported in the outputs—the results are area-based suitability classes and their coverage.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Abraha Atsbeha; Sub-national: Kilte Awlaelo district; Tigray region; National: Ethiopia
Narrative: The study addressed rainwater harvesting (RWH) as a nature‑based solution to water scarcity and soil erosion in Kilte Awlaelo district, eastern Tigray, northern Ethiopia. Key inputs included biophysical factors (annual rainfall 2011–2020 from CRU; slope/aspect from a 90 m DEM; Landsat 8 land use/land cover; FAO soil texture; Landsat‑based soil moisture index; stream order) and socio‑economic factors (distance to road and distance to river) with road/river data from Diva GIS. A GIS‑based weighted overlay using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) weighting was applied, standardizing maps to a 1–9 scale and computing S = Σ WiXi; two cases were run: Case I with AhP weights and Case II with equal weights, plus a sensitivity analysis. Validation used field visits and high‑resolution Google Earth/ArcGIS ground truth; Case I yielded 8.6% highly suitable, 56% suitable, 30.8% moderately suitable, 4.46% less suitable (area ~1001 km2). Outputs were 90 m resolution suitability maps with four classes and recommendations for micro‑ and macro‑catchment RWH options.

Input_Variables: Rainfall (NMA); Runoff (SWAT); Drainage density (DEM); Slope (DEM); Lineament density (Sentinel-2 A); Lineament proximity (Sentinel-2 A); Lithology (Geology map/Orr and Associates); Clay content (%) (Soil data MOA/Kulumsa HWSD); LULC (Satellite image/Sentinel-2 A); Settlement proximity (Harka et al. 2020); Road proximity (Harka et al. 2020)
Spatial_Method: GIS/RS-based analysis integrating SWAT runoff estimation; Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) for weighting criteria; fuzzy logic for standardizing inputs; gamma fuzzy overlay for combining criteria; constraint masking to derive the Rainwater Harvesting suitability map.

Tool_Source: SWAT: Used to estimate runoff in the Keleta watershed by simulating monthly streamflow at the HRU level; implemented via ArcSWAT 2012 with 31 sub-basins and 458 HRUs over 1988–2017, calibrated and validated against gauged flow data (1988–2016) using SUFI-2 in SWAT-CUP, and evaluated with NSE and R2 to support rainwater harvesting site assessment.

Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors frame climate variability and dry-season drought as a risk to agriculture and target Rainwater Harvesting (NbS) sites to reduce water scarcity for irrigation, demonstrated by generating and validating an RWH suitability map that identifies very-high/high-potential areas and corroborates them with existing RWH structures.
Economics: Yes: Economic considerations are included as socio-economic criteria—proximity to settlements and proximity to roads— integrated via AHP weights (Socio-economic main criterion 0.15; Settlement proximity 0.67; Road proximity 0.315) and gamma fuzzy overlay to produce the Rainwater Harvesting suitability map, with road and settlement proximity used to reflect implementation cost and economic context, and the analysis explicitly notes balancing biophysical with socio-economic factors to enhance RWH site viability.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Keleta watershed; Awash river basin; Arsi zone; Ethiopia
Narrative: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) for irrigation was studied in Keleta watershed, Arsi zone, Ethiopia, in Awash basin. The approach integrated GIS/RS, SWAT, fuzzy logic and Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to locate RWH sites. Inputs were rainfall (1988–2017; NMA), SWAT runoff, drainage density, slope, clay content, LULC (Sentinel-2A, 10 m), lithology, lineament density, and distances to settlements and roads; data from MWE, NMA, MOA/Kulumsa/HWSD, 12.5 m DEM, Sentinel-2A, and geology (Orr Associates). Runoff was estimated with SWAT; weights were combined with fuzzy logic and a gamma overlay (ℽ=0.9). Validation used SWAT-CUP SUFI-2 (calibration NSE 0.77, R2 0.79; validation NSE 0.75, R2 0.81). The final RWH map covered 811.39 km2 (31 sub-basins, 458 HRUs): very high 16.91%, high 27.6%, moderate 20.23%, low 13.1%, not suitable 6.43%, constrained 15.73%. Farm ponds (11) and micro dams (3) were proposed; existing ponds validated as 57.14% very high, 28.6% high.

File: Farhan et al. - 2018 - Prioritization of Promising Wadi Wala Watershed (Southern Jordan) Using GIS-Based Morphometric Analy.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: check dams; terrace farming; contour stone terraces; bench terraces
Input_Variables: Topo sheets (Royal Jordanian National Geographic Centre); ASTER DEM (30 m resolution) (ASTER); Drainage networks (Arc Hydro from ASTER DEM) (ASTER/Arc Hydro); Land use/land cover (LANDSAT 8; ERDAS IMAGINE 2015); Soil map (National soil survey maps, 1994); Slope map (generated from ASTER DEM) (ASTER)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based morphometric analysis using DEM and ArcGIS to delineate watersheds and extract drainage networks; calculation of linear (Rb, Dd, Fs, Tr, Lo) and shape (Rf, Bs, Re, Cc, Rc) morphometric parameters; computation of a compound parameter Cp by ranking and summing parameter scores to prioritize sub-watersheds; and validation of priority classes with Discriminant Analysis.
Method_Validation: Discriminant Analysis
Tool_Source: Arc Hydro (Esri) : Used within ArcGIS to extract drainage networks from the ASTER DEM, enabling watershed delineation and assignment of stream order (Horton–Strahler) for morphometric analysis.
Output: Priority map of 23 sub‑basins (high, moderate, low)
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was soil and water conservation measures in the Wadi Wala watershed of southern Jordan, prioritizing sub-basins for erosion control and related conservation works. The main inputs were the 2063.6 km2 Wadi Wala catchment and 23 fourth‑order sub-basins (areas 18–184.99 km2); data sources included ASTER DEM (30 m) and ArcGIS/Arc Hydro, 1:50,000 topo sheets from the Royal Jordanian National Geographic Centre, Landsat 8 land use/land cover (July 2017) classified by Maximum Likelihood, a digitized 1994 national soil map, and slope derived from the ASTER DEM; morphometric variables comprised five basic parameters (Area, Basin length, Perimeter, Stream order, Stream length), five linear (Rb, Dd, Fs, Tr, Lo) and five shape parameters (Rf, Bs, Re, Cc, Rc). Validation used Discriminant Analysis (F = 45.7, Wilks Lambda; p < 0.001) showing complete separation of the three priority classes (Functions 1 and 2 explaining 81.7% and 18.3%, respectively). Geographic scope is the Wadi Wala catchment (2063.6 km2) with sub-basins at ~30 m resolution; climate risk or economic considerations were not explicitly included.

Tool_Source: NA

Economics: Yes: Economic considerations are integrated in OUTPUT via an economic criterion set (economic benefits, profitability, job opportunities) used in the participatory workshop and encoded in the GIS-based MCA with AHP weighting (e.g., Profitability 0.162; Crop production 0.191; Land rehabilitation 0.177) to rank pre-selected WHTs, with quantitative AHP scores for the top options (e.g., T4 Percolation ponds 0.114; T5 Check dams 0.113; T1 hillside cisterns on bench terraces 0.112; T7 soil-improvement 0.108).
