The MCA combined mapped indicators with weights to produce a composite suitability score S per cell, classed as highly/moderately/unsuitable; separate analyses were run per WHT. Validation compared against 80 check dams and 92 percolation ponds, yielding 48% and 63% highly suitable placements. Outputs included suitability maps at ~90 m resolution and a final stakeholder-ranked shortlist; climate risk and economic factors were included via ecological, economic, and adaptation criteria. Top four WHTs proposed: T4, T5, T1, T7.

File: Haile and Suryabhagavan - 2018 - GIS-based approach for identification of potential rainwater harvesting sites in Arsi Zone, Central.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Check dam; Percolation tank; Farm pond
Input_Variables: Land-use/land-cover (Landsat 8 OLI); Runoff depth (SCS CN model); Drainage density (flow direction/flow accumulation from DEM/SRTM); Elevation (DEM USGS EarthExplorer); Slope (DEM USGS EarthExplorer); Geology (CSA; Geological Survey of Ethiopia); Lineament proximity (Geomatica 2015); Fault proximity (CSA; Geological Survey of Ethiopia); Soil texture (World Soil Information Center Harmonized Soil Database); Towns Proximity (CSA settlements); Major Road Proximity (Road network)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis using Analytic Hierarchy Process with fuzzy logic (Triangular Fuzzy Numbers) to derive weights; Weighted Linear Combination to aggregate standardized criteria into a rainwater harvesting suitability map; SCS-CN runoff model to estimate runoff depth as one of the criteria.
Method_Validation: Comparison with existing rainwater harvesting structures (ground-truthing) using existing data and literature (KOICA 2008; Girma 2009; MoA 2015), confirming 90% model validity
Tool_Source: IDRISI Silva : Used for decision support and uncertainty management of weighting criteria, fuzzy standardization, and extensive criteria aggregation based on weighted linear combination.
Output: Rainwater-harvesting suitability map (not suitable; less suitable; suitable; very suitable; extremely suitable); Check-dam suitability map; Percolation-tank suitability map; Farm-pond suitability map; Proposed RWH implementation sites (check dams: 19; percolation tanks: 21; farm ponds: 60)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly frame rainwater harvesting as a climate adaptation measure to address precipitation variability and drought linked to climate change, and they demonstrate this by mapping and classifying zones from not suitable to extremely suitable for RWH and proposing NbS interventions (check dams, percolation tanks, farm ponds) in the prioritized areas to enhance water security under climate variability.
Narrative: The NbS addressed rainwater harvesting by identifying potential sites for farm ponds, percolation tanks and check dams in Arsi Zone, Central Ethiopia. Main inputs included 11 thematic layers spanning environmental, hydrological and socio-economic factors, with data from Landsat 8 LU/LC (30 m), SRTM/DEM (30 m), Harmonized Soil Database (ISRIC), National Meteorological Agency rainfall data (1990–2015), Geological Survey of Ethiopia, CSA and road/settlement layers; runoff depth was estimated with the SCS CN model. The spatial method combined Analytic Hierarchy Process with fuzzy logic (Triangular Fuzzy Numbers) and a Weighted Linear Combination to produce a final suitability index; a constraint layer (distance to settlements/roads and faults) was multiplied with the final map. Validation against existing RWH structures yielded about 90% consistency. Outputs were a five-class suitability map and proposed sites: 19 check dams, 21 percolation tanks and 60 farm ponds; area shares: Not suitable 27.88%, Less suitable 15%, Suitable 27.52%, Very suitable 19.8%, Extremely suitable 9.8% over a 20,694.41 km2 zone; climate risk was not explicitly included, while socio-economic factors were.

File: Harka et al. - 2020 - Modelling rainfall runoff for identification of suitable water harvesting sites in Dawe River waters.pdf
Input_Variables: Runoff depth (SWAT model); Slope (DEM); Soil texture (Harmonized World Soil Database); Land use/land cover (Landsat 8, USGS); Stream order (DEM); Stakeholders' priority (Discussions with farmers and community representatives)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation (MCE) using a weighted linear combination of six criteria (runoff depth, slope, stakeholder priority, soil texture, stream order, and land use/land cover) with weights determined via Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP), integrating SWAT-derived runoff and remote sensing/GIS data to identify suitable rainwater harvesting sites.
Method_Validation: SWAT model calibration and validation against observed runoff (monthly calibration: R2=0.81, NSE=0.76; monthly validation: R2=0.79, NSE=0.72) with scatter plots of simulated vs observed flows; AHP consistency ratio check (CR=3% < 10%) for the six-criterion weighting; SWAT-CUP sensitivity analysis (26 parameters; t-test and p-value) to assess parameter influence; stakeholder/expert validation through incorporation of stakeholders’ priority into the criterion weighting.
Tool: SWAT (Arnold J.G. et al. 2012. SWAT: Model use, calibration, and validation. Transactions of the ASABE. DOI:10.13031/2013.42256); SWAT-CUP (Abbaspour K.C. et al. 2015. Continental-scale hydrology model for Europe: Calibration and uncertainty of a high-resolution large-scale SWAT model. Journal of Hydrology. DOI:10.1016/j.jhydrol.2015.03.027); ArcSWAT (Winchell M., Srinivasan R., Di Luzio J.M. 2009. Arc SWAT 2.3.4 Interface for SWAT2005: User’s guide manual)
Tool_Source: SWAT: Core hydrological model used to estimate runoff depth and simulate daily streamflow in the Dawe River watershed (HRU-based sub-watershed partitioning) to support runoff estimation for rainwater harvesting site assessment, with calibration/validation against observed data; SWAT-CUP: Calibration and uncertainty analysis tool used to calibrate/validate SWAT with Latin Hypercube sampling, providing NSE and R2 performance metrics and enabling parameter sensitivity analysis (t-test and p-value) for ranking; ArcSWAT: GIS-based interface used to configure and run SWAT within ArcGIS; in this study ArcSWAT 2012 (revision 664) was used to calibrate and validate SWAT with Latin Hypercube sampling, integrating GIS data for HRU delineation and input preparation.
Output: Suitable water harvesting site map (suitable, moderately suitable, not suitable); Stakeholders’ priority water harvesting site map (suitable, moderately suitable, not suitable)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The study targets rainwater-harvesting NbS to mitigate climate-driven water scarcity by identifying and prioritising areas with favorable runoff, slope, soil texture and land cover for harvesting, and demonstrates this with a spatial suitability prioritisation that highlights central to north-eastern sub-watersheds as most suitable.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Dawe River watershed, Ethiopia; Sub-national: Wabe Shebelle River basin, Ethiopia
Narrative: The NbS addressed rainwater harvesting (RWH) site identification in the Dawe River watershed, Wabe Shebelle basin, Ethiopia. Main input variables and data sources included SWAT-derived surface runoff depth; soil texture from laboratory pipette analysis; Landsat 8 land use/land cover (USGS); slope from a 30 m DEM; stream order; rainfall data from Ethiopian Meteorological Agency stations (1992–2013) with areal rainfall estimated by Theissen polygon; soil maps (HWSD); and socioeconomic input as stakeholders’ priority, processed in ArcGIS 10.5, Landsat 8 data in ERDAS, with SWAT/SWAT-CUP for calibration and Penman–Monteith evapotranspiration. Spatial method combined these in a six-criterion MCE, weighting via Analytic Hierarchy Process and a weighted linear combination to produce a rainwater-harvesting suitability map; weights were Runoff depth 0.38, Slope 0.25, Stakeholders priority 0.16, Soil texture 0.10, Stream order 0.07, LULC 0.04. Validation used SWAT calibration/validation at Gara Muleta (1995–2005, 2008–2013): R2 0.82/0.79 and NSE 0.77/0.73; base-flow runoff fractions were 47% and 59.9%. Outputs include a 30 m resolution suitability map for 25 sub-watersheds and 321 HRUs over a 368 km2 area; central to northeast parts were identified as suitable. Climate risk was not explicitly analyzed; socioeconomic factors were included via stakeholders’ priority.

File: Hashim and Sayl - 2020 - Detection of suitable sites for rainwater harvesting planning in an arid region using geographic inf.pdf
Input_Variables: Runoff depth (M.S. climatological data); Slope (ASTER DEM; NASA); Soil texture (Laboratory tests); Land use/land cover (Landsat 8 image, June 2019); Distance from irrigated lands (NDVI from Landsat 8, April 2019); Distance from residential areas (Landsat 8 image, June 2019); Distance from roads (Landsat 8 image, June 2019); Stream order (ASTER DEM; NASA); Distance from faults (tectonic map; G.D.)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation using a weighted linear combination of seven criteria (runoff depth, slope, soil texture, land use/land cover, distance from irrigated lands, distance from residential areas, distance from roads) followed by a Boolean overlay (stream order and distance from faults); the two rasters are multiplied to produce a final suitability map, with AVE-curve analysis used to rank the proposed dam sites.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: Watershed Modeling System (WMS 11.0) : used to determine morphometric parameters and delineate the watershed for each site; employed with DEM to generate AVE curves, calculate basin area, storage (million m3), surface area (million m2), dam height (m), and estimate evaporation losses after the dry season for proposed rainwater harvesting dams.
Output: Final RWH suitability map (highly suitable / moderately suitable / least suitable); Proposed RWH dam locations and AVE-derived reservoir inundation/capacity maps (6 sites; storage [million m3], surface area [million m2], dam height [m], storage after dry season [million m3])
Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS (rainwater harvesting) is targeted to reduce drought risk and water scarcity in an arid region, addressing climate-related hazards; the authors demonstrate this by producing a final suitability map that identifies highly suitable RWH sites and by using AVE-curve analysis to maximize storage while minimizing evaporation losses, linking NbS deployment to adaptation outcomes.
Economics: Yes: Economic aspects included are the stated cost-effectiveness of the methodology and the influence of financial resources on selecting earthen dams, which frame the outputs.
Narrative: The NbS study addressed rainwater harvesting (RWH) by locating earthen-dam sites in Iraq’s western desert (Haditha; ~1953 km2 in Al-Anbar; Fahamy, Hijlan, Zgadan). Seven weighted MCDA criteria were used: Runoff depth 9, Slope 8, Soil texture 7, Land use/land cover 6, Distance from irrigated lands 5, Distance from residential areas 3, Distance from roads 3. Data included Landsat 8 for LULC/NDVI, ASTER DEM for slope/AVE, precipitation data (1989–2019), 120 soil samples, tectonic map, stream order, and distance from faults, projected to UTM-WGS84 37N. The approach combined WLC (S = sum WiXi) with a Boolean overlay on stream order and fault distance, producing a final raster by multiplication. AVE-curve validation evaluated six dam sites; results classified 6% highly suitable (117 km2), 4% moderately suitable (78 km2), 90% least suitable (1758 km2). Outputs included three classes and six proposed sites; climate data were used; economic criteria were not, though the method was cost-effective.

File: Hassan et al. - 2025 - GIS-based multi-criteria decision making for identifying rainwater harvesting sites.pdf
Input_Variables: Rainfall (Center for hydrometeorology and remote sensing (CHRS)); Runoff depth (Depended on soil, LULC, CN, rainfall data of study area); Slope (DEM from United States Geological Survey (USGS)); Soil texture (FAO-UNESCO soil map); LULC (Environmental systems research institute (ESRI) website); Stream order (DEM from United States geological survey (USGS)); Elevation (DEM from United States geological survey (USGS)); Groundwater depth (General Administration of groundwater in the Karbala Governorate and previous studies); Distance from lake (Open Street Map)
Spatial_Method: GIS‑based multi‑criteria decision making (MCDM) using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight nine criteria; weighted overlay (Map Algebra/Raster Calculator) of raster layers in ArcGIS to produce a rainwater harvesting suitability map; consistency ratio validation and one‑at‑a‑time sensitivity analysis.
Method_Validation: Consistency ratio (AHP) validation; Field verification/ground-truthing with field survey and expert input; One-at-a-time sensitivity analysis; Comparison with existing studies/maps
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Rainwater harvesting suitability map (very low; low; medium; high; very high); Sensitivity‑scenario rainwater harvesting suitability maps (AHP one‑at‑a‑time tests S1–S9; very low–very high)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: they describe climate hazards—climate change and rainfall variability—as threats to the feasibility and performance of rainwater harvesting by reducing groundwater recharge and rainfall reliability. They demonstrate this by conducting a rainfall-weight sensitivity analysis and by discussing future precipitation scenarios that could shift the identified suitable areas.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS rainwater harvesting is spatially targeted to areas where climate-change–driven water scarcity and groundwater depletion pose risks, and the authors demonstrate this climate-adaptation prioritization by producing a suitability/ranking map that highlights sites with high groundwater recharge and drought-mitigation potential, supported by sensitivity analysis and field validation.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Kerbala Desert; Kerbala Province; Iraq; National: Iraq
Narrative: The NbS addressed was rainwater harvesting (RWH) site identification to mitigate water scarcity in the arid western Kerbala region of Iraq. Nine criteria—rainfall, elevation, slope, stream order, soil texture, land use/land cover, groundwater depth, distance from Al-Razzaza Lake, and runoff depth—were sourced from CHRS rainfall data, USGS DEM for elevation and slope, FAO-UNESCO soil map, ESRI LULC, USGS stream order, the General Administration of Groundwater, and OpenStreetMap distance to the lake, with runoff depth estimated via the SCS-CN method. A GIS-based MCDM approach using Analytic Hierarchy Process weights (ArcGIS 10.8) combined the nine raster layers with a weighted overlay (Map Algebra) to produce a five-class suitability map; the weights yielded a consistency ratio of 3.16%. Validation included a CR check, one-at-a-time sensitivity analyses highlighting soil texture and slope as most influential, and field surveys with local farmers. Outputs comprised a 246 m resolution suitability map (very high to very low) with area allocations: 286, 498, 636, 462, and 305 km2 (13, 23, 29, 21, 14%), with over 65% of the study area deemed suitable. The study area is the Kerbala Desert, west of Kerbala, Iraq (2187 km2; ~118 km SW of Baghdad). Climate risk or economic factors were not explicitly included beyond rainfall; socioeconomic factors were not separately modeled.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: The codes used in this work are available from the corresponding author by request; Data: All data used in this work are available from the corresponding author by request.

File: hc et al. - 2020 - Prioritization of sub-watersheds of the Kanakapura Watershed in the Arkavathi River Basin, Karnataka.pdf

Tool_Source: NA
Output: Sub‑watershed prioritization map for NbS placement (high / medium / low / very low); Conservation and management allocation map showing recommended check-dam, percolation tank, and recharge-well locations

Narrative: The NbS practices addressed included groundwater recharge and water conservation via check dams, harvesting structures, and recharge sites. Inputs included rainfall from Karnataka rain gauges, lithology from GSI maps, drainage density and hydrogeomorphic units from a merged LISS III + PAN dataset and topographic sheets, slope and lineaments from DEMs, with LULC from Landsat TM and IRS‑1D LISS III FCC; watershed areas ranged from 3,000 to 25,100 ha each. Spatial prioritization used a weighted overlay analysis; parameters were classified into four infiltration categories with weights: rainfall 5, lithology 20, drainage density 15, slope 15, lineament density 10, hydrogeomorphic units 20, LULC 15. File: Ibrahim et al. - 2019 - Suitable Site Selection for Rainwater Harvesting and Storage Case Study Using Dohuk Governorate.pdf
Input_Variables: Runoff potential (SCS-CN model; derived from land use and hydrological soil groups); Slope (DEM); Land use/land cover (Landsat 8 OLI; USGS); Drainage (DEM-derived drainage layer); Stream order (DEM-derived); Soil types (soil map); Hydrological soil groups (HSG map; [39]); Rainfall data (Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources of the Kurdistan Region; 2001–2017)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation using Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) weighting and a weighted linear combination; integration of SCS-CN runoff modeling with inputs from slope, land use/cover (Landsat classification), drainage, soil hydrologic groups, and rainfall data to map rainwater harvesting suitability.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Rainwater harvesting suitability map (excellent; good; moderate; poor; unsuitable); Proposed dam locations map with storage capacity (9 potential sites; Dam 1–4 evaluated with per-dam storage capacities by elevation)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: It includes economic framing by prioritizing dam sites to minimize construction costs (stated as choosing locations where drainage is narrow/straight to acquire the lowest cost), integrated via the weighted linear combination/MCE approach for site selection; no explicit financial metrics (ROI/NPV/cost-benefit) are reported.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Dohuk Governorate; Sub-national: Kurdistan Region; National: Iraq; National: Turkey; National: Iran; National: Syria; National: United States; National: Sweden
Narrative: NbS addressed were rainwater harvesting and dam construction to relieve water scarcity in the Dohuk, Iraq. Inputs included Landsat 8 OLI land-use data (2018, 30 m), a DEM for slope and drainage, soils with hydrological groups, and rainfall data from 15 stations. Data sources included USGS Landsat and the Kurdistan Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources. The spatial approach combined an SCS-CN runoff-depth model with a Weighted Linear Combination (MCE); weights from Analytic Hierarchy Process and rainfall interpolated by IDW. Outputs included a 30 m resolution suitability map (Excellent 15%, Good 13%, Moderate 21%, Poor 27%, Unsuitable 24%) and nine dam sites; four dams (Dam1: 30 m; Dams 2–4: 25 m) with storage capacities from 308,887 to 4,536,311 m3. The area spans 4,151.43 km2; northern areas received up to 949 mm rainfall. Climate risk was addressed via rainfall; economic considerations were not included. No explicit validation was described.

File: Jha et al. - 2014 - Rainwater harvesting planning using geospatial techniques and multicriteria decision analysis.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Farm ponds; Check dams; Percolation tanks along the streams; Percolation tanks on the ground
Input_Variables: Rainfall map (Three raingage stations; Kangsabati Canal Division Nos. IV and V offices); Land use/land cover map (ERDAS Imagine); Soil map (National Bureau of Soil Survey and Land Use Planning, Nagpur); Slope map (SRTM DEM); Drainage density map (Drainage network; GIS); Hydrologic soil group map (Soil map; National Bureau of Soil Survey and Land Use Planning, Nagpur); Runoff coefficient map (Rainfall; Land use/land cover; Soil); Runoff potential map (Rainfall; Land use/land cover; Hydrologic soil group); Drainage network map (Drainage network map; GIS-derived)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multicriteria decision analysis (AHP with Saaty weights) performing a weighted overlay of runoff coefficient, slope and drainage density to map rainwater harvesting potential; distributed SCS-CN runoff modeling using rainfall estimated by Thiessen polygons; and identification of suitable zones/sites for RWH structures by overlaying the RWH potential with land-use/land-cover, hydrologic soil group data, stream buffers and proximity to settlements.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR < 0.1); Field verification/ground-truthing recommended to confirm results.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Rainwater harvesting potential map (good; moderate; poor); Zones suitable for rainwater harvesting structures (farm ponds; percolation tanks on-ground); Suitable sites for recharge structures (check dams and in-stream percolation tanks) [83 sites; 32 sites near settlements]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS (rainwater harvesting) is explicitly used as an adaptation to climate-driven water scarcity and rainfall variability, with the study aiming to secure water supply and groundwater recharge under climate change. They demonstrate this by generating runoff potential and rainwater harvesting potential maps across normal, wet, and dry years and identifying zones and sites for RWH structures to reduce climate-related water risk and enhance resilience.
Economics: Yes: The output analysis is framed as cost-effective, using GIS-based MCDA (AHP and WLC) to map rainwater harvesting potential zones and suitable sites for structures; however, there are no explicit economic performance metrics reported (ROI, NPV, cost-benefit ratios, economic suitability scores).
Geographic_Scope: National: India; Sub-national: West Bengal; West Medinipur district; Binpur-I; Binpur-II
Narrative: Rainwater harvesting planning using geospatial techniques and MCDA addressed RWH in Binpur-I and Binpur-II, West Bengal, India (area 1006.5 km2). Inputs included rainfall from three raingauges (Tarafeni Barrage, Lalgarh, Chandra) 1999–2009 data; Thiessen polygon mean rainfall; RS land use/land cover from IRS-P6 LISS-IV (5.4 m); slope from SRTM DEM (90 m); soil and hydrologic soil groups; and drainage, road, canal maps. Runoff was estimated with distributed SCS-CN, producing annual runoff potentials and coefficients; three layers (runoff coefficient, slope, drainage density) were weighted in AHP (CR < 0.10) and combined in ArcGIS via Weighted Linear Combination to yield Rainwater Harvesting Potential Index (RWHPI) = RCwt*RCwf + SLwt*SLwf + DDwt*DDwf. Outputs include maps of good (241), moderate (476), and poor (287) km2 zones, farm ponds (30) and ground recharge tanks (27) km2; 83 recharge sites identified, 32 inhabitants. Validation used consistency ratios; climate variability via wet/dry/normal-year assessments.

File: Jhariya et al. - 2018 - Watershed prioritization based on soil and water hazard model using remote sensing, geographical inf.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Bench Terraces; Contour Trenching; Contour Bunding; Gully Plugs; Check Dams; Gabion Check Dam; Percolation Tank; Boulder Bunds; Contour Cropping; Strip Cropping; Farm Ponds
Input_Variables: Rainfall (Water Resource Department); Land use / land cover (Landsat 8 ETM+; USGS Earth Explorer); Soil type map (National Bureau of Soil Survey and Land Use Planning, Nagpur); DEM (SRTM; USGS Earth Explorer); Slope (DEM-derived) (SRTM; USGS Earth Explorer); Drainage density (DD) (SOI topo sheets); Upstream catchment area (A) (drainage network); Curve Number (CN) (SCS-CN method); Soil erodibility factor (K) (Soil map); Rainfall erosivity factor (R) (Rainfall data); Slope length factor (LS) (DEM-derived); Cropping management factor (C) (Land use / land cover); Conservation practice factor (P) (land management practices); Soil loss (SL) (RUSLE model); Sediment yield (SY) (Hunink et al. 2012; Bagdi et al. 2015; Ganasri & Ramesh 2015; Jaiswal 2015a); Sediment transport index (STI) (Hunink et al. 2012; Bagdi et al. 2015; Ganasri & Ramesh 2015; Jaiswal 2015a); Runoff potential (RP) (SCS-CN method); Land capability class (LCC) (Randhir et al. 2001; Kaur et al. 2004; Makwana et al. 2016; Rahmati 2016)
Spatial_Method: Remote sensing and GIS to generate and overlay thematic layers of SL, SY, STI, RP and LCC; AHP-based MCDA to weight these factors and produce the Soil and Water Hazard Rate Index (SWHRI) for prioritizing sub-watersheds.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR < 0.1 threshold)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Sub-watershed priority map (very high, high, medium, low, very low); Map of proposed locations for soil and water conservation structures (bench terraces; contour trenching/bunding; gully plugs; check dams; gabion check dams; percolation tanks; boulder bunds); Technique suitability map by slope and land capability class (allocation of suitable conservation measures)
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was watershed prioritization for soil and water conservation measures within the Bindra watershed in Chhattisgarh, India. The main inputs were remote-sensing and GIS data including LANDSAT 8 land-use maps (30 m), a SRTM DEM (30 m) for slope, a soil map from the National Bureau of Soil Survey and Land Use Planning upgraded with satellite imagery, drainage layers from SOI top sheets (1:50,000), and daily rainfall data from the Water Resource Department; these were integrated with sub-watershed boundaries to derive drainage density and a GIS-based framework for analysis. The spatial method combined RS, GIS and multi-criteria decision analysis using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight five soil and water hazard factors—soil loss (SL) via RUSLE, sediment yield (SY), sediment transport index (STI), runoff potential (RP) from SCS-CN, and land capability class (LCC)—into a soil and water hazard rate index (SWHRI) via SWHRI = SLw SLwi + SYw SYwi + STIw STIwi + RPw RPwi + LCCw LCCwi, with pairwise comparison matrices and consistency checks (kmax = 5.12, CI = 0.037, RI = 1.20, CR = 0.033). Delineated into 16 sub-watersheds (SW-1 to SW-16); results classified priorities with thresholds (>0.67 very high; 0.47–0.54 high; 0.38–0.47 medium; 0.27–0.38 low; <0.27 very low). Three sub-watersheds (SW-11, SW-12, SW-16) totaled 107.36 km2 as very high, three (SW-10, SW-13, SW-14) totaled 208.13 km2 as high, and two (SW-01, SW-04) totaled 173.52 km2 as very low (total area 1274.48 km2). Outputs comprised sub-watershed priority maps and area statistics at the 16-watershed scale. The geographic scope was the Bindra watershed (1274.40 km2) in India, and climate or economic considerations were not explicitly modeled beyond rainfall/runoff and resource counts.

File: Kadam et al. - 2012 - Identifying Potential Rainwater Harvesting Sites of a Semi-arid, Basaltic Region of Western India, U.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Farm pond; Check dam; Percolation tank; Gully plug
Input_Variables: Land Use/Land Cover (Landsat Thematic Mapper imagery, 16 October 2006); Soil Type (USDA soil classification system; National Bureau of Soil Science and Land Use Planning); Slope (DEM from contour data; Survey of India); Elevation/DEM (Contour-derived DEM; Survey of India toposheets); Drainage (Toposheets-derived drainage map; ArcSWAT); Geology (Geological Survey of India); Rainfall Data (India Meteorological Department; Saswad rainfall station 1998–2007); AMC (Antecedent Moisture Condition; 5-day antecedent rainfall from Saswad station; Geetha et al. 2007); Curve Number (CN) (USDA NRCS TR-55, 1986); Stream Order (Horton method); Catchment Area (Upper Karha watershed boundary)
Spatial_Method: SCS-CN runoff estimation using ArcGIS ArcCN-Runoff to compute weighted CN runoff; GIS-based overlay/intersection of soil and land-use layers followed by intersection with slope, drainage and IMSD specifications to delineate potential rainwater harvesting sites; ground-truth verification of the derived map.
Method_Validation: Ground-truth verification / field verification; Overlay-based accuracy assessment comparing derived sites with ground-truth data and existing structures (75–100% matching; farm ponds, check dams, percolation tanks, gully plugs); Independent test dataset validation via Dive village watershed ground-truth field survey.
Tool: ArcSWAT (https://swat.tamu.edu/software/arc-swat/) ; ArcCN-Runoff (Zhan X, Huang ML 2004; ArcCN-Runoff: an ArcGIS tool for generating curve number and runoff maps. Environ Model Softw 19:875–879)
Tool_Source: ArcSWAT: Used to generate and update the drainage map of the study area by integrating topo data, Landsat-derived layers, and hydro-geomorphology within the ArcSWAT framework. ; ArcCN-Runoff: Used to compute runoff and derive a runoff-potential map by intersecting soil and land-use/land-cover data, assigning curve numbers with ArcCN-Runoff, and calculating weighted CNs for the watershed.
Output: Potential rainwater-harvesting site map (suitability: suitable vs unsuitable; recommended structures: farm pond, percolation tank, check dam, gully plug); Runoff potential map (3 classes: High / Moderate / Low runoff potential); Dive watershed validation map (analytically derived vs ground-truth validated potential sites for farm ponds, check dams, percolation tanks, gully plugs)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: It includes economic framing through notes that agriculture is the main livelihood and that harvested water could improve crop yields and regional economy, and it discusses funding options (government funding, NGOs, private sector) for implementation, but there are no explicit economic outputs or metrics (CBA, ROI, NPV, etc.) reported in the output analysis.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Upper Karha watershed; Pune district; Maharashtra; India
Narrative: The NbS addressed rainwater harvesting by identifying potential sites for farm ponds, percolation tanks, check dams and gully plugs in the Upper Karha watershed, a semi-arid basaltic region of western India. Main inputs included Landsat TM land-use/land-cover data (1:50,000, 16 Oct 2006), soil maps (USDA classifications reclassified to A–D), Geological Survey of India maps, toposheets, a digital elevation model, drainage data (Arc SWAT), and climate data from the India Meteorological Department (Saswad rainfall 1998–2007); antecedent moisture conditions II were assumed. The spatial method used the SCS-CN runoff approach, with CNs weighted by area (CNw), derived by intersecting soil and land-use polygons and assigning CNs via ArcCN Runoff, then overlaying with drainage and IMSD specifications to select favorable sites. Validation employed ground truth in the Dive village watershed (54 km2): 16 farm ponds (4 existing, 12 potential), 40 check dams (9 potential), 5 existing and 4 potential percolation tanks, and 8 gully plugs; land-use accuracy 89% producer, 91% user, and overlay accuracy 75–100% (average 86.25%). Outputs included a potential rainwater harvesting sites map and a runoff-potential map at ~30 m resolution over 546 km2, with about 84% of the area deemed suitable. Geographic scope was the upper Karha basin in Maharashtra, India. Climate data were used but no explicit climate risk or economic analysis was reported.

File: Khan et al. - 2022 - Identifying Potential Sites for Rainwater Harvesting Structures in Ghazi Tehsil, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa,.pdf

Input_Variables: Surface slope (ASTER GDEM); Drainage network (Arc Hydro Tool); Settlement proximity (Topographic sheets, Soil Survey of Pakistan); Road proximity (Topographic sheets, Soil Survey of Pakistan); Land cover (SPOT 2.5 m, December 2007); Soil data (Soil Survey of Pakistan); Geological data (Geological Survey of Pakistan); Rainfall data (Pakistan Meteorological Department); Hydrological soil group (HSG) map (Soil Survey of Pakistan; NRCS); Curve Number (CN) grid map (HEC-GeoHMS); Runoff volume (SCS-CN method)

Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic aspects are incorporated only qualitatively in the output through a statement that the structures (farm ponds, check dams, gully plugs, and Nigarims) are cost-effective because they use locally available materials, but there are no quantitative economic metrics (no ROI, NPV, cost-benefit or economic suitability scores) reported in the analysis outputs.

Narrative: NbS addressed: rainwater harvesting structures—farm ponds, check dams, gully plugs, and Nigarims—in Ghazi Tehsil, Pakistan. Key inputs: slope/elevation from ASTER GDEM 30 m; landcover from SPOT 2.5 m; soils and hydrological soil groups from the Soil Survey of Pakistan; geology maps from the Geological Survey of Pakistan; drainage from Arc Hydro; rainfall data (1981–2002) from PMD. The approach produced a curve-number grid with HEC-GeoHMS by merging landcover and hydrological soil groups, then estimated runoff with the SCS-CN method; eight factors—slope, drainage, settlements, roads, land cover, soil, geology, runoff—were reclassified and combined via weighted overlay to identify sites for four NbS structures. Validation used spatial correlation with the 2004 irrigation survey, showing high consistency for check dams and gully plugs. Outputs included a composite suitability map (Figure 14) and NbS maps with shares: 20% suitable, 52% less suitable, 29% not suitable; farm ponds 10%, check dams 5.74%, Nigarims 21.5%, gully plugs 8.9%. Scope: Ghazi Tehsil (~348 km2) using 30 m and SPOT 2.5 m data; climate input via rainfall.

File: Krois and Schulte - 2014 - GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation to identify potential sites for soil and water conservation tech.pdf
Input_Variables: Rainfall (SENAMHI; rainfall-altitude relation (Celleri et al. 2007); 33%-exceedance probability of maximum daily rainfall); Runoff coefficient (NRCS 2004); Slope (ASTER-DEM); Land use (Rohde 2012); Soil texture (Landa et al. 1978; ONERN 1975; Poma-Rojas 1989; Poma-Rojas & Alcántara-Boñón 2010; Poma-Miranda & Poma-Miranda 2001); Soil depth (Landa et al. 1978; ONERN 1975; Poma-Rojas 1989; Poma-Rojas & Alcántara-Boñón 2010; Poma-Miranda & Poma-Miranda 2001)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation (MCE) using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight rainfall, runoff, slope, land use, soil texture and depth, and then a weighted overlay (WOP) to produce suitability maps for terraces and bund systems.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.008, CR < 0.1); Comparison/validation of hydrological outputs with independent study data (runoff coefficients compared with Krois et al. 2013).
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Suitability map for terraces (classes: highly suitable, moderately suitable, marginally suitable, not suitable/restricted); Suitability map for bund systems (classes: highly suitable, moderately suitable, marginally suitable, not suitable/restricted)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Ronquillo watershed; Sub-national: Cajamarca; National: Peru
Narrative: The NbS spatial prioritisation addressed soil and water conservation techniques (SWCTs), specifically terraces and bund systems, in the Ronquillo watershed, located in the northern Peruvian Andes. Main input variables and data sources included rainfall from five SENAMHI gauges (La Victoria, Augusto Weberbauer, UNC-Cajamarca, Chamis, Ronquillo) with mean annual rainfall 475–1003 mm, mean seasonal rainfall 396–879 mm, maximum daily rainfall 30–58 mm, and 33% exceedance probabilities of 15–27 mm; rainfall-altitude relations to generate area-wide rainfall, digital elevation model (ASTER, 30 m resolution) for slope, land-use maps from Rohde (2012) with seven classes, soils from Poma-Rojas and colleagues, and CN-based runoff computations using Hydrologic Soil Groups. The spatial method combined a four-step GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation (MCE): data transformation to criteria maps, reclassification to suitability levels (SL), determination of relative importance weights (RIW) via Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP; CR = 0.008), and a weighted overlay process (WOP) to produce terraces and bunds suitability maps. Validation/outputs: AHP CR indicated acceptable judgments; results showed 44% of catchment highly suited for terraces and 24% for bunds (64% combined for either). Outputs were terraces- and bunds-suitability maps at 30 m cell size for the 42 km2 Ronquillo watershed. Climate data (rainfall) fed the SL; no explicit economic analysis or climate-risk assessment was reported.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The data sets are partly available through the SENAMHI website (http://www.senamhi.gob.pe/).

Spatial_Method: Remote sensing–GIS based multi-criteria analysis: creation of thematic maps (geomorphology, land use/land cover, geology, lineaments with buffers, drainage, roads/villages); knowledge-based weighting and ranking of classes; GIS weighted overlay/aggregation (union/intersection) to compute a composite suitability score and classify areas into excellent/good/moderate/poor.

Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Bakhar watershed; Sub-national: Mirzapur District; Uttar Pradesh; National: India
Narrative: NbS addressed: delineation of potential sites for rainwater harvesting structures (check dams, contour bunding, contour trenching, recharge pits, wells) in Bakhar watershed, Mirzapur district, Uttar Pradesh, India. Inputs included thematic maps of geomorphology, land use/land cover, lineaments, drainage, geology and roads/villages derived from IRS LISS-III imagery, 1:50,000 maps, SOI topo sheets, NRSA guidelines, and field validation (136 villages). The spatial method used a GIS-based weighted overlay: ranks 1–4 multiplied by theme weights (geomorphology 20, geology 15, landuse 18, lineaments 25, drainage 25, roads/villages 0); final scores classified as Excellent (>200), Good (121–200), Moderate (81–120), Poor (<80). Validation involved field checks; outputs included a map (Fig. 6) and a table of proposed structures, with the layer comprising 24,236 polygons and 53 suitable sites (22 check dams, 14 contour bundings, 5 recharge pits, 12 contour trenchings) across 136 villages. Bakhar area 560 km2 at 1:50,000; climate risk or economic considerations were not included.

Narrative: The NbS spatial prioritisation addressed water-harvesting structures and flood management. Core inputs included ASTER-DEM derived basin boundary, drainage networks and slope, together with Landsat data (USGS) for land use/cover (2005, 2010, 2015), validated by Google Earth and GPS (Trimble Juno-3B). A Weng (2001) transition matrix quantified changes; Horton’s law of Nu and Lu validated geometric similarity. Outputs comprised a morphometric table (Table 1), a stream-order map (Fig. 5a), drainage-density map (Fig. 5b), LULC maps for 2005, 2010 and 2015 (Fig. 6) and a 2005–2015 transition matrix at ~30 m resolution over the 6698.5 km2 Lower Kosi basin in Bihar, India. File: Mahmoud and Alazba - 2014 - The potential of in situ rainwater harvesting in arid regions developing a methodology to identify.pdf
Input_Variables: Soil texture (Mahmoud et al. 2014b); Land cover/use (Landsat 5/7 TM/ETM image 2000; KACST; ERDAS Imagine 2013); Slope (KACST DEM); Rainfall surplus (NASA TRMM Monthly Global Precipitation Data 1998–2010; World Data Center for Meteorology; Meteorological Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Water and Electricity rainfall/ET data); Runoff coefficient (Mahmoud et al. 2014b)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based decision-support system applying Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight criteria; followed by a weighted-overlay multi-criteria evaluation (MCE) to delineate suitable in situ water harvesting areas.
Method_Validation: Field verification / ground-truthing through field survey; Proximity-based validation using ArcGIS proximity analysis comparing existing IWH structures to the suitability map; AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.02, CR < 0.1)
Tool_Source: Watershed Modeling System (WMS): Used to simulate the runoff in the watersheds. ; IDRISI Selva: Used to calculate/derive the weights for criteria via the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) in the GIS-based suitability model.
Output: In situ water-harvesting suitability map (excellent; good; moderate; poor; unsuitable)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They treat in situ rainwater harvesting as a climate-change–related adaptation to drought and water scarcity in arid regions, and they demonstrate this by producing a suitability prioritization for IWH that targets areas with rainfall surplus and runoff potential and by validating the approach against existing structures to show potential risk reduction through enhanced water availability.
Narrative: NbS addressed: in situ rainwater harvesting (IWH), a nature‑based solution to increase water availability and groundwater recharge in Saudi Arabia, focusing on Al‑Baha. Main inputs and data sources: soil texture map (GPS survey, Mahmoud et al. 2014); land cover/use from Landsat TM/ETM imagery (unsupervised and supervised classification with field spectral signatures); slope from a DEM (KACST); rainfall surplus maps derived from P–ET data and TRMM (1998–2010); runoff coefficient (PRC) from hydrologic soil group. Spatial method: criteria (soil texture, land cover/use, slope, rainfall surplus, runoff) reclassified to levels and combined in a GIS‑based DSS; weights derived by AHP in IDRISI Selva and applied via Weighted Overlay in ArcGIS 10.1. Validation used proximity analysis with 25 dams; 99% of existing IWH structures lay in good/excellent areas. Outputs: five‑class IWH suitability map for Al‑Baha (~12,200 km2) with 1.5% excellent, 27.8% good, 45% moderate, 5.2% poor, 20.5% unsuitable; no economic factors included, climate input used.

File: Mahmoud et al. - 2014 - Delineation of potential sites for rainwater harvesting structures using a geographic information sy.pdf
Input_Variables: Soil map (GPS data); Land cover and land use (Landsat 5/7 TM/ETM images; 2000, KACST); Slope (Al-Baha DEM); Runoff coefficient (PRC derived from soil type, land use and slope); Rainfall surplus precipitation (World Data Center for Meteorology; TRMM NASA)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based decision support system employing a spatial multi-factor evaluation (SMFE) with Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight factors (soil texture, rainfall surplus, slope, land use/cover, and runoff coefficient) and a weighted overlay to generate rainwater harvesting suitability maps.
Method_Validation: Field verification / ground-truthing (field survey of 25 dams); Proximity-based validation with existing RWH dams (most 'successful' structures lie in good areas); AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.02 < 0.1); Sensitivity analysis by comparing weighted AHP results with an equal-weights scenario
Tool_Source: IDRISI : Used to calculate the weights of the input factors for the GIS-based suitability model via its WEIGHT module, implementing the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) with pairwise comparisons and consistency checks to produce a weighted overlay for identifying potential rainwater harvesting sites.
Output: Rainwater harvesting suitability map (AHP-weighted) [excellent; good; moderate; poor/unsuitable]; Rainwater harvesting suitability map (equal-weighted) [excellent; good; moderate; poor/unsuitable]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS is spatially targeted to areas where climate-driven water scarcity is most likely, aiming to provide adaptation benefits by increasing water availability, and the authors demonstrate this by generating a suitability map for rainwater harvesting that ranks areas by potential and by showing that most existing RWH structures lie within excellent or good zones, validating the approach.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Al-Baha Province; National: Saudi Arabia
Narrative: The NbS addressed was rainwater harvesting (RWH) structures in Al-Baha Province, western Saudi Arabia, to delineate potential sites and evaluate existing structures. Primary inputs were rainfall surplus, slope, runoff coefficient, land cover/use, and soil texture, derived from field GPS soil texture data, Landsat LULC (TM/ETM, 2000) via KACST, and a 30 m DEM; climatic data were interpolated from satellite precipitation (World Data Center for Meteorology; NASA TRMM) with MOA/MOWE sources, and no explicit economic considerations were described. A GIS-based DSS used Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) within a SMFE framework; five factors were combined by weighted overlay (ArcGIS/IDRISI): soil texture 36.063%, runoff 35.582%, rainfall surplus 15.996%, slope 7.676%, land cover 4.683%. Validation used proximity analysis with 25 dams; 72% of the structures fell in good areas, 24% in moderate, 4% in excellent. Outputs included a RWH suitability map (Excellent 12.2%, Good 22.2%, Moderate 34.7%, Poor/Unsuitable 30.9%) and a PRWH map at ~30 m resolution for Al-Baha.

File: Mbilinyi et al. - 2007 - GIS-based decision support system for identifying potential sites for rainwater harvesting.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: ndiva; stone terraces; bench terraces; borders

Spatial_Method: A GIS-based decision support system that integrates remote sensing and limited field data, uses Analytic Hierarchy Process to derive relative weights for rainfall, slope, soil texture, soil depth, drainage and land use, and applies weighted-overlay (multi-criteria evaluation) to generate suitability maps for various rainwater harvesting technologies.
Method_Validation: Comparison with existing NbS sites or known locations; Expert review or stakeholder validation (consensus with farmers' indigenous knowledge, 81.4%); Independent test dataset; AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.02)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Suitability map of potential sites for rainwater harvesting technologies (ndiva, stone terraces, bench terraces, borders) [very high, high, moderate, low, very low]
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Bangalala; Mwembe; Makanya watershed; Sub-national: Kilimanjaro Region; Same District; Northern Tanzania; National: Tanzania
Narrative: The study addressed rainwater harvesting (RWH) by developing a GIS-based decision support system to identify potential sites for RWH technologies—ndiva, stone terraces, bench terraces and borders—in the Makanya catchment, Northern Tanzania, at Bangalala and Mwembe villages. Inputs included rainfall, slope, soil texture, soil depth, drainage and land use/cover, sourced from 1990–1992 rainfall records, soil samples, DGPS coordinates/elevations, aerial photographs (1983) and Landsat TM (2003), and drainage/topography maps with a DEM. The spatial method used Model Builder in ArcView GIS 3.2 to perform a weighted overlay (MCE); relative weights were technology-specific and derived via Analytic Hierarchy Process (CR=0.02). Suitability values (1–9) fed equations to produce output grids/maps for each technology. Validation showed Bangalala with 81.4% agreement with farmers, and Mwembe with similar patterns. Outputs include maps and area proportions by technology overlain on a DEM. Scale: village-level Makanya; climate risk/economic factors were not included (socio-economic factors suggested for future work).

File: Mendonça et al. - 2024 - Watershed’s spatial targeting Enhancing payments for ecosystem services to scale up agroecosystem r.pdf
Input_Variables: Watershed delineation (Wm) (SWAT); DEM (Pissarra et al., 2013) (Pissarra et al., 2013); ALOS DEM (ASF) (Alaska Satellite Facility); Slope (Sl) (ALOS DEM (ASF)); Drainage density (Dd) (ALOS DEM (ASF)); Roughness Number RN (RN) (ALOS DEM (ASF)); Lithologic fragility (Geology) (Geological Map of the State of São Paulo, CPRM); Soil erosion susceptibility (Soil erosion) (Soil Map of the State of São Paulo, Instituto Florestal); Land capability UP (UP) (Araújo Costa et al., 2019); Actual land use UA (MapBiomas – Land Cover and Land Use Maps 2020, Collection 06); Environmental land use conflict (ELUC) (Valle Junior et al., 2014); Water availability (Wa) – Q7,10 flows (DAEE); Hydrological services flow HSflow (DAEE)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multicriteria decision analysis (MCDA); Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) weighting to combine four components—watershed management, landscape vulnerability, water availability, and land degradation—by overlaying factor maps (SWAT-based watershed units, lithologic fragility and soil erosion, water-flow proxy Q7,10, and environmental land-use conflicts) to identify priority areas and project three scenarios.
Method_Validation: Overlay with PES-enrolled rural properties to validate scenario outcomes; Sensitivity analysis using counterfactual PES-signer scenarios (and trade-offs) to test robustness.
Tool: PES-Catchment (10.1016/j.ecoser.2024.101679); SWAT (Neitsch et al., 2011); Analytic Hierarchy Process (Saaty, 1987); SIGRH2001 (DAEE) http://www.daee.sp.gov.br/
Tool_Source: PES-Catchment : A watershed-based protocol that targets strategic restoration areas and optimizes payments for ecosystem services (PES) by integrating four factors (watershed management, landscape vulnerability, water availability, land degradation) in a GIS-based MCDA framework, producing three priority scenarios (SI: multiple ES conservation; SII: hydrological services; SIII: land degradation neutrality) to guide governance, targeting, and resource allocation for agroecosystem restoration. ; SWAT : The Soil and Water Assessment Tool used to demarcate the UPSR watershed into sub-basins and hydrological units based on topography and drainage networks, enabling hydrological delineation and flow calculations (e.g., Q7,10) that inform the water-availability component of PES-Catchment. ; Analytic Hierarchy Process : The Analytic Hierarchy Process employed as the MCDA method to weight criteria and components (e.g., Wm, Lv, Wa, Ld) via pairwise judgments, producing local and overall priorities that rank the SI, SII, and SIII scenarios and integrate with GIS layers for spatial targeting. ; SIGRH2001 : A deterministic hydrological tool used by DAEE to estimate river flow metrics (Q7,10, Q98, Q95, Q90, Qm) for regionalizing water availability and supporting HSflow calculations within the PES-Catchment framework.
Output: SI priority map for multiple ecosystem services conservation (Low/Average/High/Extreme); SII priority map for hydrological services provision (Low/Average/High/Extreme); SIII priority map for land degradation neutrality (Low/Average/High/Extreme); Map overlay of PES‑enrolled private rural properties on scenario priority classes (distribution across Low/Average/High/Extreme)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS targeting is explicitly framed to reduce climate-related risks by prioritizing restoration and hydrological/soil services in water-short and erosion-prone basins, thereby strengthening adaptation and resilience to climate variability. The authors demonstrate this with scenario-based prioritisation (SI, SII, SIII) that identify high-priority hydrological and land-degradation-neutral areas for NbS deployment and PES, i.e., mapping priority catchments/headwaters and linking compensation to areas where NbS can best secure water supply and soil conservation under climate stress.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis integrates economics through PES payments and investments (GEF funded ~US$31.5 million with ~US$16.5 million paid to PES across 9,900 ha preserved and 11,972 ha enrolled on 640 rural properties; Table 1 shows planned US$3,953,867.66 vs paid US$2,310,515.24 and 62.69% implemented), with remuneration tied to scenario priority (SI/SII/SIII) to optimize water/soil benefits, and the framework references cost‑benefit analysis and contingent valuation to quantify benefits and ensure incentives are proportional to outputs, signaling explicit ROI considerations in the output.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Upper Paraíba do Sul River Basin (UPSR); Paraíba do Sul River Basin (PSRB); São Paulo State; Brazil
Narrative: This study addressed Nature-based Solutions (NbS) via agroforestry restoration in the Brazilian Atlantic Forest, implementing a watershed-based PES-Catchment prioritisation protocol. Four MCDA components—watershed management (SWAT-based UPSR delineation from DEM), landscape vulnerability (lithology from CPRM and soil erosion from IF), water availability (Q7,10 flows via DAEE regionalization), and land degradation (Environmental Land Use Conflict from RN using ALOS DEM and MapBiomas land use)—were fused in GIS. AHP weighting (Wm, Lv, Wa, Ld) produced three priority scenarios SI, SII, SIII; outputs were 30 m raster priority maps across UPSR (12,605.6 km2). Validation overlaid rural PES participants, with a sensitivity analysis using counterfactuals. Results showed 22–26% of the area at high degradation across scenarios; SI was most responsive; about 25% of the area and 21% of private properties fell in high-priority zones, with 50% in medium. Climate risk was not modeled as a separate scenario, while PES payments represented economic considerations.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Supplementary data available online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecoser.2024.101679; Data will be made available on request.
Contacts_Email: gislaine.costa@unesp.br; maria.nogueira@sp.gov.br; lm.costa@unesp.br; renata.criscosta@gmail.com; fpacheco@utad.pt; milton.c.ribeiro@unesp.br; laura.borma@inpe.br; teresa.pissarra@unesp.br

File: Mosase et al. - 2017 - Assessment of the Suitability of Rain Water Harvesting Areas Using Multi-Criteria Analysis and Fuzzy.pdf
Input_Variables: Rainfall distribution (Department of Meteorological Services; AMESD project); Soil texture map (Ministry of Agriculture); Soil depth map (Ministry of Agriculture); Soil drainage map (Ministry of Agriculture); DEM (AMESD/ASTER DEM); Slope map (ASTER DEM)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based Multi-Criteria Evaluation using Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP); Fuzzy AHP (FAHP) integrated in GIS/RS to weight and combine reclassified thematic layers via overlay to identify suitable macro rainwater harvesting areas.
Method_Validation: Field verification/ground-truthing; Validation with existing water bodies by overlaying with the final suitability map (independent data); Error matrix with percent correct and Kappa (Kappa = 0.604); AHP consistency ratio check (CR < 0.1); Sensitivity analysis via alpha-cut (0.6) and Lambda values (0, 0.5, 1); Proximity-based validation/overlay with water bodies to assess spatial agreement.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Macro RWH suitability map (AHP) [S1 highly suitable; S2 moderately suitable; S3 marginally suitable; N1, N2 unsuitable]; Macro RWH suitability maps (Fuzzy AHP, α=0.6; λ = 0 / 0.5 / 1 sensitivity) [S1 highly suitable; S2 moderately suitable; S3 marginally suitable; N1, N2 unsuitable]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS (macro rainwater harvesting) is spatially targeted to mitigate rainfall variability, the main climate risk cited, with climate factors explicitly included as a criterion and weights in the MCA and climate-weighted suitability maps showing where NbS would reduce climate risk.
Narrative: NbS spatial prioritisation addressed RWH sites in the South East District of Botswana. Inputs included climate/rainfall data (Department of Meteorological Services; AMESD), hydrology, topography, soils, land cover, and socioeconomic factors, with data from the Ministry of Agriculture (soil map), AMESD DEM, LANDSAT and aerial photographs, and validation data. AHP and Fuzzy AHP were integrated in GIS/RS to prioritise criteria in a four-level hierarchy, deriving weights from pairwise comparisons, fuzzifying them into triangular fuzzy numbers, and applying fuzzy extent analysis with alpha-cut 0.6 and a lambda index. GIS aggregation used reclassified rasters at 30×30 m via weighted overlay to produce final suitability maps. Validation used existing water bodies and checks, yielding 57.14% overall correct (Kappa 0.604); FAHP and AHP indicated over 80% of the area suitable, with 87.1% (AHP) and 92.2% (FAHP). Outputs were 30 m resolution suitability maps and area statistics. Climate risk via rainfall criteria, socioeconomic data included.

Validation relied on AHP consistency and a pixel-validity assessment; outputs included a suitability map and three proposed dams with storage capacities of 37,359,680.5 m3, 76,273,409.9 m3, and 9,690,685.6 m3, located at Dam 1: 35°39′5.8196″N, 42°42′26.8565″E; Dam 2: 35°47′20.5545″N, 42°42′13.8538″E; Dam 3: 35°45′45.4550″N, 42°45′31.4739″E. Economics: Yes: Economic framing appears—the analysis marks land uses as Not economically feasible and notes potential livelihood improvement and income generation from rainwater harvesting; integration occurs via the MCE weighting including land-use feasibility and explicit references to farmer capacity and livelihood benefits, but no explicit numeric economic metrics (ROI, NPV, cost-benefit ratios, etc.) are reported.

Outputs were raster suitability maps at 30 m resolution, classified into five levels, indicating 12,797.3 ha (8.2%) extremely suitable; 25,906.7 ha (16.6%) very highly suitable; 98,302.8 ha (63.5%) suitable; and 19,040 ha (7.5%) not suitable, across the 156,064.72 ha Daro Labu District in Oromia, Ethiopia. File: Mussa et al. - 2020 - Open-Source Software Application for Hydrogeological Delineation of Potential Groundwater Recharge Z.pdf
Input_Variables: Lithology/Hydrogeology (Figure 5); Lineament density (Figure 6; Eq. 1); Drainage density (Figure 7; Eq. 2); Land Use/Cover (Landsat 8 image; USGS Earth Explorer; 2018-09-17); Rainfall Distribution (Figure 9); Soil (Figure 10); Slope (Figure 11)
Spatial_Method: A weighted overlay (multi-criteria decision) analysis in open-source GIS (QGIS) by rasterizing, reclassifying and weighting seven thematic layers and summing them to produce groundwater recharge potential zones; complemented by a seven-factor recharge equation (Re = 0.21Ld + 0.17Lt + 0.15Lu + 0.15So + 0.13Rf + 0.11SL + 0.08Dd).
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Groundwater recharge potential/suitability map [very good; good; intermediate; poor; very poor]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors explicitly target areas for artificial groundwater recharge (an NbS) to counter climate-change–driven reductions in natural recharge. They demonstrate this by producing a groundwater recharge potential map that designates zones as very good/good for artificial recharge and rainwater harvesting, tying NbS outputs to climate-risk adaptation.
Narrative: An NbS-oriented effort delineated groundwater recharge zones to support artificial recharge via rainwater harvesting in Singida semi-arid, fractured crystalline basement aquifer in Tanzania. Inputs were lithology/hydrogeology, soil, land-use/cover (Landsat 8 OLI), slope, lineament density, drainage density and rainfall distribution, with climate metrics including precipitation, PET and aridity indices. The spatial approach rasterized and reclassified seven thematic layers to a 1–5 scale, applied weights from Table 4, and combined them with a two-stage weighted overlay in QGIS using SAGA/GRASS, producing a final Re value via Re = 0.21Ld + 0.17Lt + 0.15Lu + 0.15So + 0.13Rf + 0.11SL + 0.08Dd. Outputs comprised a groundwater recharge potential map categorized as very good, good, intermediate, poor, and very poor. Results indicate very good zones align with high lineament density, cultivated/grassland, and flat to gentle slopes, with low drainage density also present. Validation was not described; climate factors were included; no explicit economic analysis.
