Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to assign weights to eight thematic layers, followed by a weighted overlay in GIS to derive suitability/priority maps for water harvesting structures (IMSD guidelines).
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio (CR) check (CR < 0.1)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Site suitability map for water harvesting/conservation structures (classes: suitable, highly suitable; drainage-line suitable sites for check dams, gully plugs/bori bandhan, stop dams, boulder check/gabion)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS targets water harvesting structures to mitigate climate-driven water scarcity by increasing recharge and moisture retention, and the authors demonstrate this through a spatial prioritisation that identifies suitable zones for implementing water harvesting/conservation structures to maximize recharge under changing rainfall.
Economics: Yes: Economic viability is incorporated as an IMSD guideline criterion—catchment area >25 ha for economical design—used in site selection, but there are no explicit economic outputs (cost-benefit, ROI, NPV, cost‑effectiveness ratios, or economic suitability scores) reported; the output comprises GIS-based suitability maps derived from AHP-weighted watershed factors rather than economic metrics.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Mandri river watershed, Kanker district, Chhattisgarh, India
Narrative: The NbS addressed were water harvesting structures within Mandri watershed, India, to identify suitable sites for structures such as check dams, gully plugs and stop dams to enhance recharge and watershed management. Main inputs comprised eight GIS/RS thematic layers—Hydrological Soil Group, Soil Depth, Land Use/Land Cover (1:50,000), Slope (from DEM), CN Runoff potential, Drainage Density, Lithology, and Design Discharge; rainfall data were used, compiled from GPS surveys and government sources, with soils at 1:250,000 scale. Spatial method combined these via Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to assign weights (scale 1–9) and a weighted overlay in GIS, with Consistency Ratio checked (<0.1) and weights normalized between 0 and 100. The outputs were zone map identifying suitable drainage areas; results indicate most areas were suitable for check dams. Outputs were produced in ArcGIS at Mandri watershed, India 66.70 km2; climate risk via rainfall and economic considerations via socio-economic and cadastral data were included.

File: Sayl et al. - 2020 - GIS-based approach for rainwater harvesting site selection.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope (ASTER DEM); Land use / land cover (Landsat 8); Soil texture (Soil samples and laboratory tests); Drainage network (Topographic maps); Runoff depth (SCS-CN method; rainfall data and hydrological soil map); Contour lines (Area elevation curve from ArcGIS)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis using a weighted overlay (ArcGIS ModelBuilder) with weights determined by Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) on remote-sensing derived layers (slope, land use/land cover, soil texture, drainage, runoff depth) to identify suitable rainwater-harvesting sites.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Rainwater-harvesting potential/suitability map (5 classes: high → low suitability); Proposed rainwater-harvesting dam locations (6 selected sites with estimated storage capacities and cross-sections)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: Economic framing is present—the study includes socio-economic criteria in the GIS weighting and aims to minimize capital costs by selecting dam sites with narrower drainage to reduce structure costs, and it asserts the approach is cost- and time-efficient; however, it does not report explicit economic outputs such as cost-benefit, ROI, NPV, or economic suitability scores.
Narrative: The NbS addressed rainwater harvesting site selection in the Haqlan valley basin, western Iraq. Key inputs were meteorological data (daily/monthly precipitation 1980–2013), Landsat 8 imagery (30 m), an ASTER DEM and SRTM (30 m) provided by USGS, and soil samples georeferenced to UTM-WGS‑84 zone 38. An ArcGIS Model Builder workflow integrated five criteria—runoff depth (0.42), slope (0.26), soil texture (0.16), drainage (0.10), and land use (0.06)—via a weight overlays approach controlled by Analytical Hierarchy Process. The multi-criteria map yielded a rainwater-harvesting suitability map with six sites identified; overall suitable area was 28% of 452.6 km2, with 21% moderately suitable. Outputs included a 30 m-resolution suitability map and dam dimensions—length from the DEM and height from the area-elevation curve. Validation was not described. Climate data informed rainfall/runoff; economic considerations appeared as cost minimization for dam structures.

File: Shadeed et al. - 2019 - Developing GIS-based water poverty and rainwater harvesting suitability maps for domestic use in the.pdf
Input_Variables: Rainfall depth (records of rain gauges); Curve number (Shadeed and Almasri, 2010); Surface slope (digital elevation model); Land use (MoLG); Time to collect water (PWA, PCBS, water service providers); Losses in water networks (PWA, PCBS, water service providers); Population served by water networks (PWA, PCBS, water service providers); Productivity (PWA, PCBS, water service providers); Citizens above poverty line (PWA, PCBS, water service providers); Illiteracy (PWA, PCBS, water service providers); Average unit price of water (PWA, PCBS, water service providers); Population connected to sewer networks (PWA, PCBS, water service providers); Contaminated water samples by coliform (PWA, PCBS, water service providers); NO3 concentrations in groundwater (PWA, PCBS, water service providers); Per capita domestic water supply (PWA, PCBS, water service providers); Per capita domestic water consumption (PWA, PCBS, water service providers)
Spatial_Method: Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight criteria; GIS-based weighted overlay summation (WOSP) to develop DWP and DRWHS suitability maps; spatial intersection (combined mapping) of DWP and DRWHS maps to identify hotspot priority areas.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR < 0.1; CR = 0.04 for DWP and 0.01 for DRWHS); Validation with independent DRWH activity data (1994–2017) from PHG demonstrating hotspots correspond to observed DRWH implementations.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Domestic rainwater harvesting suitability map (DRWHS) [very low, low, moderate, high, very high]; DWP–DRWHS intersection hotspot priority map [very high poverty–very high suitability, very high poverty–high suitability, high poverty–very high suitability, high poverty–high suitability]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: Rainwater harvesting is targeted to areas with high domestic water poverty to mitigate climate-driven drought and water scarcity, and the authors demonstrate this by mapping DWP and DRWHS and intersecting them to identify hotspot regions for prioritizing DRWH deployment.
Narrative: The study addressed domestic rainwater harvesting (RWH) as a NbS to reduce domestic water poverty in the West Bank, Palestine. It used 12 DWPI criteria spanning five components (Access, Capacity, Environment, Resources, Use) with data from the Palestinian Water Authority (PWA), the Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics (PCBS) and water service providers; DRWHS inputs included rainfall depth (RD), curve number (CN), surface slope (SS) and land use (LU), with CN maps (Shadeed and Almasri, 2010), LU from MoLG, a 25 m DEM, and rainfall gauges interpolated by IDW. Weights were derived with Analytical Hierarchy Process (Tables 2–3) and combined in a GIS-based weighted overlay summation (WOSP) to produce the Domestic Water Poverty Index (DWPI) and the Domestic Rainwater Harvesting Suitability Index (DRWHSI) at 100 m resolution. Validation relied on DRWH activity data from 1994–2017 to identify hotspot zones; results showed 57% of the West Bank in high–very high DWP, about 60% highly suitable for DRWH, and a DWP–DRWHS intersection hotspot covering ~31% of the territory with DRWH activities concentrated in Nablus, Jenin and Tubas (~74%). Outputs included DWP, DRWHS and their intersection maps at 100 m across 11 governorates (~5860 km2). Economic considerations were included via DWPI (e.g., average unit price of water); climate risk was not explicitly treated as a separate criterion.

File: Shalamzari et al. - 2019 - Runoff Harvesting Site Suitability Analysis for Wildlife in Sub-Desert Regions.pdf
Input_Variables: Precipitation map (This study); 33% exceedance rainfall (This study); Elevation (ASTER DEM); Slope (ASTER DEM); Drainage density (ArcHydro/DEM); Runoff coefficient (SCS-CN); Land cover (RESDC LULC); Soil texture map (Semnan Province Environmental Protection Head Office); Infiltration map (Semnan Province Environmental Protection Head Office); Soil salinity map (Semnan Province Environmental Protection Head Office); Wildlife distribution map (Semnan Province Environmental Protection Head Office)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis using Analytic Hierarchy Process for weighting; fuzzy membership normalization of thematic layers; weighted linear combination to integrate weighted layers into a final suitability map with soil-salinity and wildlife-distribution constraints.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR < 0.1); expert-based weighting (weights derived from five experts).
Tool_Source: Expert Choice Software 11.0 : used to compute the AHP weights from expert pairwise comparisons to weight the runoff coefficient, slope, and drainage density when forming the final suitability index.
Output: Runoff harvesting suitability map (5 classes: not suitable → highly suitable); Runoff potential map (5 classes: very poor → very good; collectible runoff ~30–135 m3·ha−1 per event); Runoff coefficient map (5 classes: very low → very high); Mapped candidate catchments for check‑dams (11 sites) with estimated collectible runoff (m3) and priority ranking
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: National: Iran; Sub-national: Kavir National Park; Central Kavir Area; Tehran Province; Semnan Province; Kerman Province; Golestan Province; Yazd Province; Khorasan Province
Narrative: NbS addressed: runoff harvesting to provide wildlife drinking water in Kavir National Park, central Iran. Inputs: precipitation from 12 surrounding stations; design rainfall mapped from altitude using 33% exceedance; 30 m ASTER-DEM slope; ArcHydro drainage density; digitized soil texture, infiltration and salinity maps; wildlife distribution for Gazella dorcas and Ovis orientalis; literature water requirements. Method: SCS-CN runoff estimation with CNs based on soil hydrological groups and land cover and AMC I; slope, drainage density, and runoff coefficient were fuzzified; weighted via Analytic Hierarchy Process and combined with Weighted Linear Combination to create RHSI (0–255). Two constraints—soil salinity and wildlife territory—produced the final SI map (SI = RHSI × EC × WD). Outputs: 30 m resolution final map; 846 km2 (38%) suitable; 11 catchments; per-event runoff 52 m3; annual total ≈257 m3 under five storms (4% of 6500 m3 demand). Scope: Kavir NP (~6,800 km2). Climate risk/economic considerations: not explicitly included.

File: Shashikumar et al. - 2018 - ANALYTICAL HIERARCHY PROCESS FOR IDENTIFICATION OF SUITABLE WATER HARVESTING SITE IN GEOSPATIAL ENVI.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Check dam; Farm pond; Percolation tank
Input_Variables: Soil Texture (NBSS&LUP soil database); Slope (ASTER DEM); Stream Order (ASTER DEM); Curve Number (LULC and HSG maps)
Spatial_Method: Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) in GIS where weights for soil texture, slope, stream order and curve number are derived by pairwise comparison and then a weighted overlay is used to identify suitable sites.
Method_Validation: Comparison with existing NbS sites or known locations; Proximity-based validation (proximity analysis to known features)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Check dam site suitability map (Less suitable; Suitable; Highly suitable); Land use / land cover change maps [1989 vs 2017] showing vegetation increase
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Hatni watershed; Sub-national: Jhabua district; Madhya Pradesh; National: India
Narrative: The study addressed NbS practice of water harvesting structures, specifically check dams, in Hatni watershed, Madhya Pradesh, India. Inputs included soil texture from NBSS&LUP (1:250,000); slope and stream order from ASTER DEM. Curve number was calculated by crossing LULC (Landsat 4–5 TM 1989; Landsat 8 OLI 2017) with hydrologic soil groups. Spatial method used analytic hierarchy process (AHP) to assign weights to soil texture, slope, stream order and curve number; weights were derived from IMSD and FAO guidelines and pairwise comparisons, followed by reclassification and weighted overlay in ArcGIS to produce a suitability map, categorized as less suitable, suitable, and highly suitable; a score range 150–171 defined highly suitable areas. Validation compared mapped suitability with dam locations via proximity analysis and showed dams fell in highly suitable sites. Outputs include a 30 m resolution suitability map for check dams in Hatni watershed; climate risk or economic considerations were not described.

File: Singh et al. - 2016 - Multi-criteria analysis and GIS modeling for identifying prospective water harvesting and artificial.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Farm pond; Percolation tank on the ground; Percolation tank along the streams; Check dam
Input_Variables: Rainfall map (Climate Forecast System Reanalysis; IMD raingauge stations); Land use/land cover map (Regional Remote Sensing Centre-East, NRSC, ISRO); Soil map (NBSS&LUP); Hydrologic soil groups map (NBSS&LUP-derived); DEM (SRTM) ( CGIAR Consortium for Spatial Information); Slope map (SRTM DEM); Drainage network (SRTM-derived ArcHydro; 2nd-3rd order streams); Drainage density map (derived from drainage network); Post-monsoon groundwater level map (CGWB; SWID); Mean post-monsoon groundwater level map (CGWB; SWID); Groundwater fluctuation map (CGWB; SWID); Water demand map (Census 2011; 18th Livestock Census 2007)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) weights; Weighted Linear Combination to compute Rainwater Harvesting Potential Index (RWHPI) and Rainwater Harvesting Demand Index (RWHDI); Boolean logic to delineate suitable/ranking zones and sites.
Method_Validation: Consistency Ratio (CR) check for AHP weights (CR < 0.1); Expert review/validation of weights based on opinions of hydrology/hydrogeology experts and local experience.
Tool_Source: ArcHydro (ArcGIS) : Used to derive the drainage network map from the SRTM DEM, delineate drainage order/length, and compute drainage density to identify streams for siting rainwater harvesting and groundwater recharge structures.
Output: Rainwater harvesting potential map (classes: very high, high, moderate, poor); Rainwater harvesting demand map (classes: very high, high, moderate, low); Rainwater harvesting prioritization map (16 priority zones, codes 11–44); Suitability map for RWH/recharge structures (farm ponds; percolation tanks on-ground; percolation tanks along streams; check dams); Identified site locations for percolation tanks and check dams (69 percolation tank sites; 33 check dam sites along streams)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: the NbS is spatially targeted to mitigate climate-change–driven water scarcity by identifying high-potential rainfall runoff zones and high-demand areas and prioritizing locations for rainwater harvesting and groundwater recharge; this is demonstrated through the Rainwater Harvesting Potential Index and Rainwater Harvesting Demand maps and the Rainwater Harvesting Priority Map that guide implementation.
Narrative: NbS addressed: rainwater harvesting (RWH) and artificial groundwater recharge. Main inputs included rainfall data (normal year 2004; 14 IMD gauges; Climate Forecast System Reanalysis), runoff coefficient, slope, drainage density, land use/land cover, soils (Hydrologic Soil Groups), DEM (SRTM 90 m), drainage network, post-monsoon groundwater levels (1990–2014), mean groundwater fluctuation, and water demand from Census 2011 and CGWB/SWID. The GIS-based MCDA used Analytic Hierarchy Process weights to combine layers; RWH potential was mapped with Weighted Linear Combination of runoff coefficient, slope and drainage density to yield Rainwater Harvesting Potential Index (RWHPI), while RWHDI combined post-monsoon groundwater level, groundwater fluctuation and water demand. Validation showed Consistency Ratio <0.10; results segmented the area into four RWH zones (high 47%, moderate 38%) and four RWHDI demand zones (very high 29%, high 26.4%, moderate 21.3%, low 23.6%). Outputs included RWHPI, RWHDI maps, and a 16-zone rainwater priority map; 2314 km2 for farm ponds; 42 km2 for percolation tanks; 69 tanks and 33 check dams. Location: Damodar Canal Command, upper Damodar River basin, West Bengal, India (~7470 km2 across four districts). Climate risk addressed via rainfall and groundwater data; no explicit economic factors.

File: Singh et al. - 2023 - GIS integrated RUSLE model-based soil loss estimation and watershed prioritization for land and wate.pdf
Input_Variables: Rainfall erosivity factor (IMD); Soil erodibility factor (FAO); Slope length and steepness factor (ALOS PALSAR DEM); Cover/crop management factor (Sentinel-2A via Google Earth Engine); P factor (USDA 1972)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based RUSLE modelling; creation of raster layers for R (rainfall erosivity from IMD), K (soil erodibility from FAO), LS (slope length/steepness from DEM-derived flow accumulation and slope), C (LULC from Sentinel-2), P (conservation practices); pixel-wise multiplication A = R × K × LS × C × P; reclassification into soil-loss severity classes; watershed prioritization by average soil loss to identify priority conservation areas.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool: RUSLE (Renard et al. 1991; J. Soil Water Conserv. 46, 30–33)
Tool_Source: RUSLE : An empirical soil-erosion model used with GIS to estimate and map average annual soil loss by computing the R, K, LS, C, and P factors for each cell, enabling identification of erosion-prone hotspots and prioritization of watersheds for land and water conservation in the study area.
Output: Soil loss (erosion severity) map [very low 0–1; low 1–5; medium 5–10; high 10–50; extreme >50 t·ha⁻¹·yr⁻¹]; Watershed priority ranking map [ranks 1–25 by average annual soil loss]
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: The study addressed NbS-type land and water conservation practices, focusing on watershed prioritization to implement erosion-control measures within the Banas River Basin of Rajasthan, India. Main input variables and data sources included the rainfall erosivity (R) factor from 1990–2020 IMD rainfall data, the soil erodibility (K) factor from a 2012 FAO 30‑arc‑sec soil map, the slope length–steepness (LS) factor derived from a 12.5 m ALOS PALSAR DEM (resampled to 10 m), and the cover/management (C) and support/conservation practices (P) factors based on Sentinel-2A LULC maps processed in Google Earth Engine (2021); together these formed the RUSLE A = R*K*LS*C*P equation within a GIS. The spatial method used raster-based GIS overlay (map calculator) to combine the five factors at 10 m resolution (LS at 12.5 m but resampled); watershed delineation yielded 25 watersheds (area 113.0–7,626.8 km2) within a 68,207.82 km2 basin, allowing computation of an average annual soil loss per pixel and subsequent prioritization. Validation is not described; results include a total soil loss of 21,766,048.8 t, a basin-wide erosion severity distribution (Very Low 24.2%, Low 66.8%, Medium 7.3%, High 0.9%, Extreme 0.7%), and the highest watershed average soil loss in WS18 (84.9 t ha-1 year-1) with WS10 (38.4), SW25 (34.7), and WS23 (17.9) also notable. Outputs comprise a 10 m × 10 m soil-loss map and a watershed priority ranking map (Figure 10, Figure 11) at the 25-watershed level, with outputs presented at the watershed scale and per-watershed area data (Table 5–6). The geographic scope is the Banas Basin, Rajasthan, India, at basin and sub-watershed scale (25 watersheds). Climate risk was incorporated through the R-factor data; economic considerations were not explicitly included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The raw data supporting the conclusion of this article will be made available by the authors, without undue reservation.

File: Singhai et al. - 2017 - GIS-based multi-criteria approach for identification of rainwater harvesting zones in upper Betwa su.pdf
Input_Variables: Land use land cover (Landsat ETM+ satellite image and other secondary published maps); Lineament (Landsat ETM+ satellite image and other secondary published maps); Drainage (Landsat ETM+ satellite image and other secondary published maps); Surface runoff (modified SCS-CN)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA); supervised classification of Landsat ETM+ land use/land cover; edge enhancement-derived lineaments and drainage; modified SCS-CN runoff estimation.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Rainwater harvesting suitability/priority map (probable RWH locations)
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: The NbS addressed rainwater harvesting (RWH) zones in the upper Betwa sub-basin of Madhya Pradesh, India. The main inputs included land use land cover (LULC) derived by supervised classification of Landsat ETM+ imagery; lineaments and drainage were derived by edge enhancement of Landsat ETM+ and other secondary published maps; and surface runoff was assessed with a modified SCS-CN approach. A GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) framework was used to integrate these variables, with spatial themes derived from the LULC (via supervised classification) and from lineament/drainage (via edge enhancement), while surface runoff came from the modified SCS-CN method. The abstract did not report a validation approach or results. The main outputs were the identification of probable RWH locations, though specific spatial resolution was not stated. Geographic scope was the upper Betwa sub-basin, Madhya Pradesh, India. Climate risk or economic considerations were not mentioned.

File: Srivalli and Singh - 2019 - Identification of potential sites for water harvesting structures in Gadela watershed using remote s.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Check dams; farm ponds; nala bunds; percolation tanks; contour trench; gully plug
Input_Variables: Elevation (Bhuvan 30m DEM); Slope (Bhuvan 30m DEM); Soil (NBSSLUP); Land use/Land cover (Not specified); Geomorphology (Bhuvan); Runoff (Rainfall data from WRD Rajasthan); Transmissivity (Pumping test); Geology (Not specified)
Spatial_Method: Remote sensing-derived thematic maps (elevation/slope, land use/land cover, geomorphology, soil, transmissivity, runoff) were combined in GIS using a weighted overlay with pairwise-comparison (AHP) weights, after reclassifying rasters to integers, to produce the final suitability/priority map.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Site suitability map for water-harvesting structures (low / medium / high priority); Proposed sites allocation map for water-harvesting structures (check dams, farm ponds, nala bunds, percolation tanks, contour trenches, gully plug)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS is spatially targeted to reduce climate-related drought and flood risks by prioritizing sites for water harvesting structures that enhance recharge and storage; the authors demonstrate this via a weighted overlay prioritization that classifies areas into high/medium/low priority for NbS deployments (check dams, ponds, percolation tanks, etc.).
Geographic_Scope: Local: Gadela watershed;Sub-national: Udaipur district;Sub-national: Rajasthan;Sub-national: Meghalaya;Sub-national: Telangana;National: India
Narrative: Water harvesting structures in Gadela watershed were identified as the NbS addressed. Inputs included Aster DEM-derived Elevation and Slope, Bhuvan satellite imagery, NBSSLUP soil map, land use/land cover, geomorphology (Bhuvan), a transmissivity map from pumping tests, and runoff estimated from 20 years of rainfall data (SCS-CN) from the Rajasthan Water Resources Department, with SOI topo sheets 1:50,000 (45H-13,14; 45L-1,2,9). A GIS-based weighted overlay was applied using seven thematic maps (Geomorphology, LU/LC, Soil, Slope, Elevation, Transmissivity, Runoff); weights were set by pairwise comparison and rasters reclassified to integers before overlay. Outputs include a final suitability map with low/medium/high priority zones. Geographic scope: Gadela watershed, 418.33 km2 in Udaipur, Rajasthan, India, at 1:50,000; no economic analysis.

File: Syarifuddin et al. - 2024 - A GIS-based approach to determine the priority area for rainwater harvest in Kupang.pdf
Input_Variables: Administrative map (Peta RBI) (BIG); Watershed Delineation Map (Benain-Noelmina Watershed) (BPDAS Benain-Noelmina); Factual of Flood and Drought events in the City of Kupang (last five years) (BPBD Kota Kupang); Runoff vulnerability map (Benain-Noelmina) (BPDAS Benain-Noelmina); Drought Potency Map (Inarisk) (Inarisk); Rainfall Data and Number of Rainless Days (NRD) (BMKG); Land Use and Land Cover Map (Ministry of Environment and Forestry) (Ministry of Environment and Forestry); Population data (BIG) (BIG); River network map (BIG) (BIG); 24-hour average accumulated rainfall (0.1° resolution) (GPM-IMERG, NASA) (GPM-IMERG); Digital Elevation Model (DEM) (SRTM) (SRTM); Soil Type data (Benain-Noelmina) (BPDAS Benain-Noelmina); Building distribution data (OSM) (OSM)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based weighted overlay (multi-criteria decision analysis) to map flood vulnerability and drought priority zones; a six-indicator RWHS suitability scoring and overlay (dry spells, rainfall intensity, vegetation cover, surface runoff, water use index, population density) to identify RWHS priority areas.
Method_Validation: Comparison with existing drought studies/maps (consistency with SPI-based drought assessment showing SPI < -2); corroboration with BPBD Kota Kupang disaster reports for flood susceptibility.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Drought priority map (drought mitigation priority — all wards classified as top-priority); Flood priority map (flood mitigation priority — high/very-high priority zones); RWHS quantity potential map (estimated RWHS units per sub-district; e.g., Liliba >15,000; Oesapa ≈13,000)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: drought and flood hazards are treated as risks that could constrain the viability and performance of rainwater harvesting, and the authors demonstrate this by generating hazard overlays (flood vulnerability, drought severity, historical disaster events) and integrating them into a RWHS suitability framework to identify priority areas and reveal where hazard conditions could limit NbS effectiveness.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They spatially target rainwater harvesting to reduce drought and flood risks, and the outputs include risk-reduction maps and sub-district RWHS deployment potential to demonstrate NbS benefits in mitigating climate hazards.
Economics: Yes: The economic aspects are embedded in the OUTPUT analysis through RWHS indicators—Water Use Index (WUI) and population density—that tie water-demand feasibility to economic considerations, and the text notes potential economic savings from rainwater harvesting; no monetary metrics such as ROI/NPV/Cost-benefit are reported, and poverty is treated as uniform in the analysis.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Kupang; Benain-Noelmina Watershed; Timor Island; East Nusa Tenggara Province; Indonesia
Narrative: NbS addressed: rainwater harvesting (RWHS) to mitigate drought and flood risk in Kupang, Indonesia. Data included priority maps, climatology, land use, runoff, population, and building data from RBI, BPDAS Benain-Noelmina, BPBD Kupang, Inarisk, BMKG, GPM-IMERG rainfall, MoEF, BIG, SRTM DEM, soils, and OpenStreetMap, reprojected to WGS84 UTM 51S, cropped to Kupang, and resampled in R. A weighted overlay mapped flood vulnerability and drought priority zones, then RWHS suitability was scored on six indicators (DS, I, PVC, R, WUI, P) with Poor/Good classes; rooftop area was aggregated per sub-district to estimate RWHS units. Outputs include drought/flood priority maps and RWHS potential per sub-district, totaling over 12,000 units (1500 L barrels) at 51 wards across six districts. Validation shows consistency with SPI drought assessments and BPBD data; climate and economic indicators were integrated. Rooftop storage up to 12.42 m3 per month for a 30 m2 roof.

File: Terêncio et al. - 2017 - Improved framework model to allocate optimal rainwater harvesting sites in small watersheds for agro.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: in-field RWH (IRWH); ex-field RWH (XRWH); domestic RWH (DRWH)
Input_Variables: Rainfall (APA); Curve Number (SNIRH); Soil Texture (European Soil Portal); Soil Depth (European Soil Portal); Population Density (DGT); Agriculture Areas (DGT); Water Quality COD (SNIRH); Water Quality BOD5 (SNIRH); Wildfire Risk (ICNF); Protected Areas (ICNF); Stream Banks (DGT); Terrain Slope (DGT)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based multi-criteria analysis (MCA) that normalizes and weights physical, socio-economic and ecological factors with Boolean constraints to produce generic and project-specific suitability maps, followed by a project-oriented ranking/allocation analysis to identify the best sub-catchment (watershed delineation with ArcHydro to define sub-catchments).
Method_Validation: Validation by comparison with long-term river flows (V = Q × A); sub-catchment is considered competent when V > V0.
Tool: Map Algebra tool of ArcMap (ESRI, 2010); ArcHydro software (ESRI, 2012)
Tool_Source: Map Algebra tool of ArcMap (ESRI, 2010): Used to process raster files for normalization (task b of MCA) and to produce the RWH suitability maps after converting vector maps to rasters; ArcHydro software (ESRI, 2012): Used for watershed delineation to identify potential sub-catchments and to derive the minimum dam wall height needed to store the harvested rainwater (V0).
Output: Generic RWH suitability map [suitability index 12–60]; Project‑oriented RWH suitability map [project‑weighted suitability index 66–330]; Allocation map showing rainfall collection catchment, application area and ranked sub‑catchments with selected RWH site (sub‑catchment 6) [selected site: centroid ≈3.05 km from application area; annual harvestable volume ≈12.07 Mm3/yr; required dam height ≈8 m]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They treat climate hazards as risk by (i) incorporating Wildfire Risk as an ecological-context factor in the site suitability analysis, which can constrain where rainwater harvesting is feasible, and (ii) discussing long-term rainfall declines under climate change and suggesting prioritizing highly suitable catchments to maintain irrigation viability.
Climate_Benefit: "Yes: They explicitly target rainfall-harvesting sites to bolster drought resilience and reduce reliance on polluted surface water, providing adaptation and mitigation benefits through improved water supply and reduced nutrient risks. The demonstration comes from a two-stage planning and allocation framework that identifies best sub-catchments for harvesting (e.g., sub-catchment 6) and discusses climate-change–driven rainfall declines as a scenario that could recalibrate site prioritization."
Economics: Yes: The output analysis uses a project-oriented MCA that incorporates economic framing by emphasizing socio-economic indicators (reflecting demand and livelihoods) and cost-related constraints (water-transport distance and dam/installation costs) to shape the RWH suitability index and sub-catchment rankings, producing a project-specific suitability map and a ranked list of sub-catchments, though no explicit monetary metrics (ROI/NPV/cost-benefit) are reported.
Narrative: NbS addressed: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) for agro-forestry, irrigation and wildfire control, in Ave basin, Portugal. Main inputs and data sources: rainfall (APA); Curve Number CN (SNIRH); soil texture and depth (European Soil Portal); population density and agriculture areas (DGTerritório/INE; CORINE); water quality COD/BOD5 (SNIRH); wildfire risk and protected areas (ICNF); stream banks and terrain slope (DGTerritório). GIS rasters fed the MCA. Spatial method and combination: planning workflow—a GIS-based MCA with equal weights to generate a generic suitability map; allocation workflow applied project-specific weights and a weighted aggregation with Boolean constraints; sub-catchments delineated; V0–A0 via Dutch method. Validation and results: V0 = 2.69e6 m3/yr; catchment could harvest 12 Mm3/yr (~4.5× V0); six sub-catchments; best is sub-catchment 6 (score 19), ~3 km from application. Outputs: planning and allocation maps and six sub-catchments (A0 ≈ 277.6 ha). Geographic scope: Ave basin (~1391 km2) with a 400 ha site. Economic factors included; climate risk not explicit in MCA.

File: Thakuriah - 2023 - Geospatial and Analytical Hierarchical Process approach for potential sites of water harvesting in l.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Farm pond; Percolation tank; Boulder check dam; Stop dam
Input_Variables: Geomorphology (Geological Survey of India); Soil texture (NBSS & LUP); Geology (Geological Survey of India); Lineament density (Geological Survey of India); Slope (Survey of India); Drainage density (Topographic sheets, Survey of India); River density (Topographic sheets, Survey of India); Stream order (Topographic sheets, Survey of India); Drainage order (Topographic sheets, Survey of India); Land use/land cover (IRS LISS IV, NRSC Hyderabad); Rainfall distribution (Regional Meteorological Centre, Guwahati); Runoff depth (SCS-CN method; Soil Conservation Service 1972)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based Analytical Hierarchical Process (AHP) for multi-criteria decision analysis; GIS-based weighted overlay to integrate geomorphology, soil, geology, lineament density, slope, drainage order, land use/land cover, rainfall, and runoff depth into a water-harvesting suitability map.
Method_Validation: Validation against observed water-harvesting structures (farm ponds and stop dams) using government records with 82.53% and 72.752% highly suitable results; field verification / ground-truthing; AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0); LULC map accuracy assessed with Kappa = 0.828.
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Farm‑pond suitability map (classes: highly suitable; moderately suitable; less relevant); Percolation‑tank suitability map (classes: highly suitable; moderately suitable; less relevant); Boulder (stone) check‑dam river‑segment suitability map (classes: highly suitable; moderately suitable; less relevant); Stop‑dam suitability map (classes: highly suitable; moderately suitable; less relevant); Map of suggested most‑potential water‑harvesting sites (point allocations: farm ponds n=113; percolation tanks n=35; boulder check‑dam segments n=95; stop dams n=34).
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly frame rainwater harvesting structures as NbS to reduce climate-related floods and water scarcity (adaptation/mitigation). They demonstrate this with outputs that map runoff, groundwater recharge, and spatially prioritize NbS sites (farm ponds, percolation tanks, check dams, stop dams) and validate them against observed structures, indicating high-suitability areas correspond to real deployments and potential risk reduction.
Narrative: NbS addressed: water harvesting structures (farm ponds, percolation tanks, check dams, stop dams) in the lower Kulsi basin, Assam, India. Inputs included geomorphology, soil texture, soil depth, geology, lineament density, slope, drainage density, stream order, land use/land cover, rainfall distribution, and runoff depth, from SOI topographic sheets (1:50,000), GSI (1:50,000), NBSS&LUP soil map (1:250,000), IRS LISS IV 2018/Google Earth for LULC, RMC Guwahati rainfall data and RSRS Boko data, and a 20 m DEM. AHP-based GIS analysis used weights (CR=0) and a weighted overlay to delineate suitability; runoff depth was estimated by the SCS-CN method. Validation used observed farm ponds (63 total; 52 highly suitable, 11 moderate) and stop dams (11; 8 high); accuracies 82.53% and 72.75%. Outputs include suitability maps for structure type and 113 farm ponds, 35 percolation tanks, 34 check dams, and 95 stop-dam sites over 1956 km2. Climate risk and economic considerations were not explicitly included.

File: Tiwari et al. - 2018 - GIS-based Methodology for Identification of Suitable Locations for Rainwater Harvesting Structures.pdf
Input_Variables: Elevation/DEM (USGS 2016); Slope (ASTER-DEM); Landuse/Landcover (IRS Resourcesat 2, LISS III; Bhuvan NRSC); Soil type (Survey of India Alwar district map); Drainage network (DEM-derived); Depression depth (DEM-derived depression); Catchment area (Drainage map/DEM); Rainfall data (RWRD 2016); Average precipitation (10-year) (RWRD 2016); Curve Number (CN) (NRCS 2004); Hydrologic Soil Group (HSG) (NRCS 2004)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based method identifying depressions along the drainage network from DEM within a 200 m buffer, merging contiguous depressions by volume, delineating their catchments and estimating runoff with the SCS-CN method using landuse/landcover, soil, and rainfall data, then selecting sites based on area, volume, and runoff criteria.
Method_Validation: Field verification / ground-truthing; Google Earth validation
Tool_Source: SCS-CN method : Used to estimate runoff by computing Runoff Depth from rainfall using CN values tied to Hydrologic Soil Groups and landuse/landcover; CN values are weighted by watershed area to obtain a weighted CN, and Runoff Volume is calculated as Runoff Depth × Catchment Area, enabling estimation of annual runoff and assessment of depressions’ storage capacity for locating rainwater harvesting sites.
Output: Selected rainwater-harvesting sites map (sites 1–7) [Suitability: Excellent: 5,6; Good: 1,3,7; Not suitable: 2,4]; Catchment-area maps for RWH sites (sites 1–7); Spatial allocation of runoff capture volume per RWH site (sites 1–7) [m3: S1=7,211,641; S2=137,061; S3=45,673,076; S4=62,068; S5=646,849; S6=545,100; S7=218,918]
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The output analysis includes economic framing by excluding sites near built-up areas to avoid higher land-acquisition costs, highlighting time- and cost-saving, cost-effective planning, and potential positive impacts on the local economy (agriculture) and mentioning indirect economic effects, though no explicit economic metrics (ROI/NPV/Cost-benefit) are reported.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Khushkhera-Bhiwadi-Neemrana Investment Region (KBNIR), Alwar district, Rajasthan, India
Narrative: Rainwater harvesting structures were the NbS addressed, identified via GIS-based spatial prioritisation in the 162 km2 Khushkhera–Bhiwadi–Neemrana Investment Region (KBNIR), Alwar, Rajasthan. Inputs included ASTER-DEM for surface elevation and drainage; seven rainfall gauges from RWRD; Land-use/LULC from IRS Resourcesat-2 LISS III via Bhuvan; soil data from the Survey of India Alwar map with field verification; and NRCS CN values weighted by sub-area. Runoff was estimated with the SCS-CN method using 603.6 mm average annual rainfall over 10 years. Depressions within a 200 m buffer of drainage were extracted, merged into units, and ranked by volume, area, and catchment runoff. Seven sites met criteria; Sites 5 and 6 were Excellent, 1,3,7 were Good, 2,4 Not Suitable. Runoff potential was 54.49 million m3; outputs included depressions, catchments, and runoff volumes (validated by field data and Google Earth). Economic considerations excluded depressions near built-up areas; climate risk was not explicitly included.

File: Umugwaneza et al. - 2022 - Integrating a GIS-based approach and a SWAT model to identify potential suitable sites for rainwater.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Check dams; Farm ponds; Bench terraces
Input_Variables: Elevation (USGS, Earth Explorer); Distance to roads (RTDA); Distance to rivers (DIVA-GIS); LCLU (Landsat-8 OLI); Rainfall temperature (Rwanda Meteorological Agency); Soil properties (DSMW compiled by FAO); Slope (SRTM DEM); Soil texture (DSMW FAO); Runoff potential (SWAT); Sediment yield (SWAT); Distance to settlement (Settlements dataset)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based multi-criteria decision-making approach using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight factors and a weighted overlay to identify suitable rainwater harvesting sites; integration with SWAT to estimate runoff and sediment yield for site prioritization.
Method_Validation: SWAT model calibration and validation using a split-sample approach (calibration 2011–2012; validation 2013) with R2 and NSE; AHP consistency check (CR = 0.07 < 0.1); Rating curve validation with R2 = 0.93 and SI = 0.25; Validation of sediment yield by comparing SWAT-MUSLE outputs to RUSLE estimates; Sensitivity analysis of SWAT parameters.
Tool: SWAT (Neitsch et al. 2011); SWAT-CUP (Abbaspour et al. 2004)
Tool_Source: SWAT: A physical-based watershed model used to simulate surface runoff, soil erosion, and sediment delivery; in this study it estimated runoff and sediment yield in the Nyabugogo catchment, delineated the basin into sub-basins and HRUs, and provided water balance outputs for calibration and for identifying rainwater harvesting sites. SWAT-CUP: A calibration/uncertainty analysis framework for SWAT; in this study it performed SUFI-2-based calibration with 2,500 runs in five iterations to calibrate flow and sediment yield against observed data.
Output: Potential areas for rainwater harvesting suitability map (5 classes: most to least suitable); Potential zones for RWH structures (bench terraces; farm ponds; check dams) [bench terraces 25.9% / 423 km2; farm ponds 6% / 98.5 km2; check dams 1.6% / 26.1 km2]; Proposed RWH recharge sites map (50 sites; 29 located in most suitable areas)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The authors frame rainwater harvesting as an adaptation measure to climate change, targeting areas with high runoff and erosion to enhance water storage and flood control, and they demonstrate this by mapping runoff potential and sediment yield and identifying suitable RWH sites with discussion of their potential to mitigate flood risk and water scarcity.
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was rainwater harvesting (RWH) structures in the Nyabugogo catchment, Rwanda. Main input variables and data sources included GIS-derived layers at 30 m resolution for elevation, slope, distance to roads, rivers and settlements; Landsat-8 OLI land cover and soil properties from the DSMW (FAO); rainfall and temperature records from the Rwanda Meteorological Agency; observed discharge data from the Nemba station via the Rwanda Water Resource Portal (with rating-curve-derived discharges); and topographic inputs from SRTM 30 m, compiled in ArcGIS 10.7 and ArcSWAT. The spatial method combined GIS-based multi-criteria decision making using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) weights with a weighted overlay to identify suitability for three RWH structures, integrating SWAT outputs of surface runoff potential and sediment yield, calibrated/validated with SUFI-2 (SWAT-CUP). Validation yielded calibration R2=0.90, NSE=0.73 and validation R2=0.86, NSE=0.70; results classified suitability from 1 (not suitable) to 5 (highly suitable), with highly suitable 4.8%, suitable 16.35%, moderately suitable 36.5%, marginally suitable 39.9%, not suitable 0.3%; bench terraces 423 km2 (25.9%), farm ponds 98.5 km2 (6%), check dams 26.1 km2 (1.6%), and 50 proposed sites (29 in the most suitable area). Geographic scope: Nyabugogo catchment, 1,661 km2. Climate data were included; explicit economic considerations were not.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: All relevant data are included in the paper or its Supplementary Information.

File: Vema et al. - 2019 - Fuzzy inference system for site suitability evaluation of water harvesting structures in rainfed reg.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: check dams; farm ponds; percolation tanks
Input_Variables: Slope (SRTM DEM); Soil permeability (Department of Rural Development, Andhra Pradesh; pedo-transfer functions Saxton and Rawls 2006); Runoff potential (SCS-CN method; 67% dependable rainfall)
Spatial_Method: Fuzzy inference system (Mamdani type) applied to 30 m raster layers of slope, soil permeability and run-off potential to produce suitability maps for water harvesting structures; run-off potential was estimated using the Soil Conservation Service-Curve Number (SCS-CN) method.
Method_Validation: Comparison with existing NbS sites or known locations; Sensitivity analysis of MF parameters (including Monte Carlo perturbations of MF parameters).
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Check dam suitability map (not suitable; low suitability; medium suitability; highly suitable); Farm pond suitability map (not suitable; low suitability; medium suitability; highly suitable); Percolation tank suitability map (not suitable; low suitability; medium suitability; highly suitable)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Kondepi watershed; Sub-national: Prakasam district; Andhra Pradesh; National: India
Narrative: The NbS addressed were rainwater harvesting (RWH) structures—check dams, farm ponds, and percolation tanks—within a watershed management context to boost water availability in rainfed regions. The main inputs were slope, soil permeability and run-off potential, derived for Kondepi watershed, Andhra Pradesh: 30 m DEM (SRTM) for slope, soil maps from the Department of Rural Development, pedo-transfer functions for soil permeability (Saxton and Rawls), land use from WaterBase, and run-off estimated via the SCS-CN method. The spatial approach used a Mamdani fuzzy inference system with trapezoidal membership functions, three inputs each with low/medium/high classes, 27 IF-THEN rules, equal weightage, and max–min aggregation with defuzzification by maximum membership to produce crisp suitability. Applied to 30 m raster data, it generated site-suitability maps for check dams, farm ponds, and percolation tanks, validated by comparison with existing structures. Outputs are 4-class (not suitable, low, medium, highly suitable) maps; check dam ~94% and farm pond ~99% of the watershed were highly suitable; percolation tanks were not suitable. The study area is Kondepi watershed (4157 ha) near Kondepi, Mandal, Prakasam, Andhra Pradesh, India (15°23′–15°25′ N, 79°48′–79°53′ E). Climate risk or economic considerations were not included in the FIS; biophysical factors were used, with socio-economic inputs handled in participatory management.

File: Worku et al. - 2020 - Prioritization of watershed management scenarios under climate change in the Jemma sub-basin of the.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Terraces; Trenches; Microbasins; Soil bunds; Fanya Juu; Tie-ridging; Ponds; Farm dams; Filter strips
Input_Variables: Rainfall (SWAT outputs); Surface runoff (SWAT outputs); Slope (SRTM); Land use (Landsat 2008); Soil texture (WLRC; MoWIE)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to weight criteria; GIS-based weighted overlay analysis to map suitability for in-situ and ex-situ water harvesting and related soil/vegetation management options.
Method_Validation: SWAT hydrological model calibration/validation with NSE and PBIAS (multi-site calibration/validation; uncertainty assessed via SUFI-2 with P-factor and r-factor); AHP/MCDA consistency checks with Consistency Ratio (CR ≈ 0.08–0.09, ≤0.1); Validation of in-situ water harvesting suitability maps against observed terrace layer under baseline climate.
Tool: SWAT (Arnold et al., 2012) ; SWAT-CUP (Abbaspour and Johnson, 2004) ; Analytic Hierarchy Process (Saaty, 1990)
Tool_Source: SWAT : Used to simulate hydrological processes in the Jemma sub-basin (discretizing into HRUs) under baseline and future climate scenarios and to evaluate the effectiveness of prioritized watershed management scenarios by adjusting SWAT inputs to reflect terraces and in-situ/ex-situ water harvesting structures, thereby examining changes in surface runoff, soil water, and total water yield. ; SWAT-CUP : Used for multi-site calibration and validation of SWAT via the SUFI-2 approach, with model performance evaluated by NSE and PBIAS and simulation uncertainty quantified using the P-factor and r-factor. ; Analytic Hierarchy Process : Used to prioritize watershed management alternatives and weigh criteria through expert-driven pairwise comparisons, producing overall priority scores (Pi) with Consistency Ratio checks to ensure decision consistency.
Output: In-situ water harvesting suitability map (Restricted; Marginally suitable; Moderately suitable; Highly suitable; Optimally suitable); Ex-situ water harvesting suitability map (Restricted; Marginally suitable; Moderately suitable; Highly suitable; Optimally suitable); Filter strips (vegetative) suitability map (Restricted; Marginally suitable; Moderately suitable; Highly suitable; Optimally suitable); Surface-runoff benefit map (mean annual surface runoff depth under baseline vs. observed terrace and in-situ/ex-situ water-harvesting scenarios); Soil-water benefit map (mean annual soil water under baseline vs. observed terrace and in-situ/ex-situ water-harvesting scenarios)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They explicitly describe climate change as a risk that could limit NbS outcomes, showing reduced rainfall and watershed suitability for water harvesting under future scenarios, demonstrated through scenario analyses that integrate climate projections, hydrological impact assessment, and MCDA-based evaluation of NbS effectiveness.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target NbS such as water harvesting structures, terraces, and filter strips to adapt to climate-change–driven changes in rainfall and runoff, and they demonstrate this with scenario-based prioritization outputs and maps showing where NbS can reduce surface runoff and increase soil moisture (soil water) under near-term and long-term climate scenarios.
Economics: Yes: It integrates economic factors in the OUTPUT through MCDA criteria including "Contribution to economy" (weight 0.174) and "Cost (labor and availability & cost)" (weight 0.073), producing an overall priority ranking for alternatives (Table 7) that reflects economic framing, though it does not report explicit ROI/NPV/Cost-benefit figures.
Narrative: The NbS spatial prioritisation addressed watershed management interventions, notably in-situ water harvesting structures (terraces, trenches, micro-basins, fanya juu) and ex-situ structures (ponds and dams) plus soil and vegetation management in the Jemma sub-basin, Upper Blue Nile Basin, Ethiopia. Main inputs included observed climate data from nine stations (1981–2014) and daily streamflow from MoWIE; CMIP5 projections downscaled by RCMs under RCP4.5 and RCP8.5, bias-corrected with distribution mapping; biophysical data (SRTM slope, Landsat land use, WLRC soils); Google Earth data; qualitative inputs from farmers and experts; SWAT calibration/validation (NSE, PBIAS). Spatial prioritisation used GIS-based MCDA with AHP weights (rainfall 31.2%, runoff 24.1%, slope 19%, land use 17.9%, soil texture 7.9%), combined by weighted overlay. Validation showed 4592 km2 (70%) of terraces aligned with in-situ suitability; outputs included in-situ and ex-situ suitability maps and SWAT-derived changes in surface runoff, soil water and total water yield over ~15,000 km2. Climate risk was included via near-term and long-term scenarios; economic considerations were embedded in AHP weights.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Supplementary material online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ejrh.2020.100714

File: Zhang et al. - 2011 - Web-Based Spatial Decision Support System andWatershed Management with a Case Study.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: infiltration systems; bio-cells; storm water ponds
Input_Variables: Land use/cover (Iowa DNR); DEM (Iowa DNR); Slope (Iowa DNR); Distance to water body (Iowa DNR); Water bodies (Iowa DNR); Rivers (Iowa DNR); National Wetlands Inventory (USFWS); Road network (Iowa DNR); Soil (SSURGO database)
Spatial_Method: A raster cell-based multi-criteria overlay (WMPI) in which each cell is ranked per input layer (3/2/1/0) by its influence on water quality, the layers are weighted and summed to produce CPI, RPI, and SMPI priority scores, identifying conservation, restoration, and stormwater priority areas.
Method_Validation: Field verification / ground-truthing
Tool: Watershed Management Priority Indices (WMPI) (Barten and Ernst, 2004) ; WebWMPI (http://geotree2.geog.uni.edu/webwmpi) ; Watershed Forest Management Information System (WFMIS) (doi:10.1016/j.envsoft.2008.10.006)
Tool_Source: Watershed Management Priority Indices (WMPI) : A raster cell–based overlay method that identifies and ranks land cells into CPI (positive influence on water quality), RPI (negative influence from agriculture/barren land), and SMPI (areas needing stormwater management), assigning weights and overlaying layers to produce a total score per cell to prioritize conservation, restoration, and stormwater-management actions; uses widely available biophysical data, is not site-specific, and provides detailed results beyond subwatershed models, used in the Source Water Stewardship project and as the core WMPI analysis within the Watershed Forest Management Information System (WFMIS). ; WebWMPI : A web-based decision support system implementing WMPI that enables public and stakeholder interaction via a client/server GIS, permitting watershed delineation, land-use classification into CPI/RPI/SMPI, parameter/weight settings, and generation of maps and scores to evaluate management scenarios; demonstrated on Dry Run Creek and designed to scale to larger areas with browser-based access. ; Watershed Forest Management Information System (WFMIS) : An ArcGIS extension that hosts WMPI as a desktop SDSS, offering a user-friendly GUI for decision-making based on the WMPI model and easily adding extra factors, thereby centralizing data and tools for watershed management (not site-specific) and facilitating broader adoption.
Output: Watershed Management Priority Indices map (CPI, RPI, SMPI; percentile thresholds 70/80/90%); Management chessboard allocation map (zonal grid parcels)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Dry Run Creek watershed; Cedar Falls, Iowa; USA
Narrative: NbS addressed: watershed management using nature-based approaches, which prioritized Conservation Priority (CPI), Restoration Priority (RPI), and Stormwater Management Priority (SMPI) land categories to protect water resources (conservation of forests/wetlands, riparian restoration, BMPs). Main inputs and data sources: land use/cover, hydrological data, soils, slope, roads, and proximity to water bodies; data were derived from Iowa DNR (primary source), with a 30 m DEM used for delineation and slope, land cover for 2002, SSURGO soils, National Wetlands Inventory, roads, rivers, and water bodies; references to USGS/USDA data clearinghouses noted. Spatial method and combination: WMPI overlay-based raster analysis; each input cell was scored high/medium/low (3/2/1/0), multiplied by layer weights, and summed to yield CPI/RPI/SMPI scores per cell; outputs included maps of the three indices, percentile summaries (70th/80th/90th), and an optional chessboard, with boundary defined by the user. Validation and outputs: demonstrated on Dry Run Creek, Cedar Falls, IA (61.5 km2); hot spots for BMPs were identified. Climate/economic: not included.

File: Zhang et al. - 2020 - Identification of Priority Areas for Soil and Water Conservation Planning Based on Multi-Criteria De.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope gradient (DEM); Precipitation (China Meteorological Data Service Center and Hydrological Data of Yellow River Basin, Annual Hydrological Report, PRC); NDVI (MOD13Q1, LP DAAC); Land use (Landsat TM 2015; RESDC); Soil texture (RESDC); Slope aspect (DEM)
Spatial_Method: A Choquet integral-based MCDA that normalizes and aggregates six criteria (slope gradient, precipitation, NDVI, land use, slope aspect, soil texture) with expert-defined interactions to produce a soil erosion risk map, which is then intersected with slope gradient and land-use maps to identify high-priority soil and water conservation areas.
Method_Validation: Field investigations; Expert review or stakeholder validation
Tool_Source: Choquet integral : An aggregation operator used in the MCDA framework to combine the six erosion-risk criteria (slope gradient, precipitation, NDVI, land use, soil texture, slope aspect) while capturing interactions among criteria (synergic and redundant effects) through a non-additive measure, enabling integration of expert judgments with objective data and producing a soil erosion risk score to identify priority conservation areas.
Output: Soil erosion risk map (very low; low; medium; high; very high); Priority areas for soil and water conservation (high & very high risk classes)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Shanxi; Sub-national: Xinshui River watershed; Local: Liugou watershed; Sub-national: Loess Plateau; National: China
Narrative: The NbS spatial prioritisation addressed soil erosion risk for soil and water conservation planning in the Xinshui River watershed on the Loess Plateau. Six inputs were used: slope gradient and aspect from a 30 m DEM; precipitation (2006–2015, 29 stations; 1000 m co-kriging); Landsat TM 2015 land use; MODIS NDVI (2015); RESDC soil texture; and 2015 socio-economic data. The spatial method was a Choquet-integral MCDA that normalized numerical and categorical criteria to 0–100, used expert-derived coalition scores to represent synergistic/redundant effects, and aggregated via Choquet integral to produce a soil erosion risk score and a five-class map. Validation relied on agreement with local experts; key results showed very high/high risk areas concentrated in farmland on 15–25° and 25–35° slopes, with 44.32% medium risk. Outputs were SWCP-scale risk maps for a ~4326 km2 watershed, with classes from very low ≤5000 to very high >8000; climate risk included via precipitation; no economic criteria used.
