File: Zheng et al. - 2023 - Rainwater harvesting for agriculture development using multi-influence factor and fuzzy overlay tech.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Micro-Watershed; Water pond; Water reservoir; Check Dam; gully plugs
Input_Variables: LULC (USGS EarthExplorer); Slope (DEM/USGS EarthExplorer); Geology (gsp.gov.pk); Soil texture (soilconservation.kp.gov.pk); Rainfall (Pakistan Meteorological Department); Lineament (Landsat data); Drainage density (DEM-derived)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based Multi-Influence Factor (MIF) multicriteria decision analysis with weighted overlay to integrate seven biophysical/socioeconomic factors and produce a suitability map; followed by a fuzzy overlay (fuzzy linear membership) to reclassify and fuse the layers into a final rainwater harvesting suitability map.
Method_Validation: ROC curve analysis (AUC) for validating MIF and fuzzy overlay; ground-based validation by cross-verifying predicted rainwater harvesting sites with existing interventions in District Karak using GPS coordinates (MIF accuracy ~87%, fuzzy overlay accuracy ~89%).
Tool_Source: ArcSDM : Used to compute and plot ROC curves and calculate the area under the curve (AUC) to validate and compare the predictive accuracy of the MIF and fuzzy overlay models for rainwater harvesting site suitability in District Karak.
Output: MIF-based rainwater-harvesting suitability map (very high; high; moderate; poor); Fuzzy-overlay rainwater-harvesting suitability map (very high; high; moderate; poor); Proposed RWH implementation sites map (point locations with GPS coordinates)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS is targeted to mitigate climate-driven water scarcity by locating rainwater harvesting sites to reduce drought risk and enhance agricultural resilience. The authors demonstrate this by producing ROC-validated MIF and fuzzy overlay–based suitability maps that identify high-potential rainwater harvesting areas and cross-validate them with existing interventions, thereby illustrating potential climate-risk reduction.
Economics: Yes: Economic framing is embedded in the OUTPUT through treating economic viability as a selection criterion—prioritizing RWH sites that minimize dam dimensions and costs and favor economical structures (e.g., check dams) using readily available materials, integrated into the MIF/fuzzy overlay workflow to produce five-category suitability maps and area (km2) outputs, with no explicit monetary metrics (ROI/NPV/ cost-benefit) reported.
Narrative: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) for agricultural development in Karak District, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan, was the NbS addressed. Seven input factors—LULC, slope, lithology, soil texture, rainfall, lineaments, and drainage density—were drawn from Landsat 8 (USGS), DEM 30 m (USGS), KP soil and lithology maps, PMD rainfall data (Kohat and Bannu), and Geomatica lineament densities. Data were preprocessed in ArcGIS 10.8 and reclassified. The approach combined Multi-Influence Factor (MIF) with weighted overlay and a separate fuzzy overlay (FLM) to yield two suitability outputs; MIF computed a composite score from major/minor weights, while FLM normalized inputs to 0–1 and classified into five classes. Validation used ROC curves (AUC): 87% for MIF and 89% for FLM; cross-verification with existing interventions supported results. Outputs were rainwater suitability maps and GPS coordinates for proposed sites at 30 m resolution. Scope: Karak district (~2662 km2; 32°48′–33°23′ N, 70°40′–71°28′ E). Climate risk or economic factors were not explicitly included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data will be made available on request.

File: Ziadat et al. - 2012 - A Participatory GIS Approach for Assessing Land Suitability for Rainwater Harvesting in an Arid Rang.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Vallerani rainwater harvesting technique (mechanized semi-circular bunds); Contour ridges; Contour bench terraces; Gradoni; Runoff strips; Small basins; Inter-row system; hafair (small ponds); earth dams
Input_Variables: Slope (Topographic maps); Soil depth (Field survey); Soil texture (Field survey); Vegetation cover (Field observations); Stoniness (Field observations); Farm size (Cadastral map); Land tenure (Cadastral map)
Analysis_Resolution: 20 m pixel size (400 m2 per cell) for the raster-based analysis; polygon-based analysis used slope-unit polygons with no fixed grid cell size.
Spatial_Method: GIS-based biophysical suitability analysis using (1) raster-based pixelwise analysis with IDW-interpolated soil depth, soil texture, vegetation cover, and stoniness classified against rainwater harvesting criteria (IF statements); (2) polygon-based slope-unit analysis (union of slope units with averaged land characteristics) classified against criteria; (3) overlay with cadastral/land tenure and farm size and application of the maximum limiting factor rule to obtain final suitability.
Method_Validation: Field verification / ground-truthing (field visits to match predictions with field suitability); Independent test dataset (108 independent field observations) used to assess accuracy of raster- and polygon-based maps; Expert review / validation after visiting random sites; Stakeholder validation (participatory validation with farmers and landowners).
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Rainwater‑harvesting suitability map (multi‑class: suitability for various RWH interventions per mapping unit; cadastral/farm‑size integrated); Selected implementation sites map (preliminary + additional farmer‑selected sites; 41 farms, 62.9 ha)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT analysis embeds economic framing by integrating socio-economic criteria (land tenure/cadastral ownership, farm size classifications, community participation) with biophysical suitability to guide site selection and implementation, and it reports economic-like outputs such as increased water productivity (kg/m3) and implementation across 41 farmers on 62.9 ha within two years while aiming for feasible costs and time, though no explicit cost-benefit metrics (ROI/NPV) or economic suitability scores are provided.
Narrative: The study addressed rainwater harvesting (RWH) interventions as a nature-based solution for arid rangelands in the Mharib watershed, eastern Amman, Jordan. Main inputs were biophysical factors—slope from a 20 m DEM, soil depth, soil texture, vegetation cover, and stoniness—plus land tenure/farm size from cadastral maps, with data from 1:50,000 topographic maps, field surveys (268 samples), GPS, and satellite imagery. The approach used raster (400 m2) pixels and slope-unit polygon analyses; best and second-best options were applied via a maximum-limitation rule, then overlaid with cadastral data to include farm size. Validation used 108 field observations; raster accuracy was 71% and polygon 70%. Outputs included biophysical suitability maps for 26 RWH interventions at pixel and slope-unit resolutions. Climate risk was not included; socio-economic factors (land tenure, farm size) were integrated. In two years, four RWH types were implemented on 62.9 ha for 41 farmers, with fourfold water productivity and fivefold erosion reduction.

File: Aguirre-Salado et al. - 2017 - Improving Identification of Areas for Ecological Restoration for Conservation by Integrating USLE an.pdf
Input_Variables: R factor (Mean annual precipitation; 51 meteorological stations; ordinary kriging; ArcGIS); K factor (Soil erodibility; INEGI soil map 1:250,000; FAO erodibility values); LS factor (Slope length and steepness; DEM from INEGI; flow accumulation and slope); C factor (Cover management; land use/land cover map from Landsat 8 OLI; C values by cover type from Figueroa et al.; training fields Series V); Bare soil map (Constraint for MCDA; Landsat 8 OLI spectral data; supervised classification using SVM; training fields Series V); Landsat 8 OLI imagery (data layer; USGS Glovis; 2016); Training fields (Series V; INEGI); DEM (Digital Elevation Model; INEGI); Town data (337 neighboring towns; INEGI Marco Geoestadístico Nacional); Distance to town (Town distance; 337 towns; 30 m); Road data (National Road Network; INEGI roads); Distance to road (Road distance; 30 m)
Spatial_Method: Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE) to estimate soil erosion rate; Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) with distance to town and distance to road, standardized by monotone decreasing membership functions and a weighted linear combination to determine feasibility; cross-tabulation of USLE and MCDA outcomes to identify priority restoration areas; Landsat 8 OLI-based bare soil mapping via Support Vector Machine (SVM) as a constraint.
Method_Validation: Cross-validation of the rainfall erosivity (ordinary kriging) interpolation (RMSE reported: 283.9 mm); Ground-truth validation of the Landsat 8 OLI bare-soil map using a contingency matrix with 100 sampling sites (overall accuracy = 0.90, Kappa = 0.86).
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Soil erosion rate (USLE) map [very low; low; middle; high; very high]; Feasibility-to-restore (MCDA) map [very low; low; middle; high; very high]; Priority areas for restoration (USLE + MCDA cross-tabulation) map [low; middle; high]
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They describe climate change as causing drought and more intense rainfall that increase soil erosion and threaten restoration suitability and persistence, and they demonstrate this by presenting erosion risk maps and overlaying them with restoration feasibility to show how hazard interacts with feasibility in selecting priority areas.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They frame ecological restoration as a NbS for climate change adaptation (reducing erosion and preserving watershed function) and mitigation (increasing carbon capture), and they demonstrate this with erosion-risk mapping and a prioritized restoration plan that targets urgent, feasible sites.
Geographic_Scope: Local: Priority Region for Conservation Xilitla; Xilitla; Huehuetlán; Aquismón; Sub-national: San Luis Potosí; Querétaro; Huasteca Potosina; Sierra Madre Oriental; Northern Mexico; National: Mexico
Narrative: Ecological forest restoration and revegetation in the Priority Region for Conservation Xilitla (PRCX), Mexico, were the NbS practices addressed to restore watershed function and reduce erosion. Inputs and data sources included USLE factors at 30 m, with R (rainfall erosivity) interpolated from 51 stations by ordinary kriging; K from INEGI soils; LS from a 30 m DEM; C from Landsat 8 OLI land cover; P was set to 1; a bare soil map from Landsat 8 OLI (2016). The spatial method computed soil loss rate SLR = R×K×LS×C×P; MCDA used two proximity factors (distance to town and distance to road), standardized to 0–1 with equal weights, and was combined by a weighted sum constrained by the bare soil map; erosion classes were cross-tabulated with feasibility to restore to define priority areas in four quadrants. Validation showed RMSE for rainfall erosivity interpolation of 283.9 mm and bare-soil classification accuracy of 0.90 with Kappa 0.86. Outputs were erosion and restoration-priority maps at 30 m; the study area totaled 34,022.8 ha with 4,226.7 ha bare soil, of which 88.2% were urgent and feasible. The geographic scope was PRCX, Mexico; climate risk was via R, and economic via proximity to towns/roads.
Contacts_Email: carlos.soubervielle@uaslp.mx; liliana.miranda@uaslp.mx; jorge.cano@uaslp.mx; heriberto.mendez@uaslp.mx; mpgarcia@ujed.mx; humberto.reyes@uaslp.mx; carlos.aguirre@uaslp.mx

File: Bourne et al. - 2016 - A Socio-Ecological Approach for Identifying and Contextualising Spatial Ecosystem-Based Adaptation P.pdf
Input_Variables: Water production (Surveyor General of South Africa; ProEcoServe); Stream flow augmentation (Surveyor General of South Africa; ProEcoServe); Flood attenuation (Surveyor General of South Africa; ProEcoServe); Erosion control (Surveyor General of South Africa; ProEcoServe); Water quality (Surveyor General of South Africa; ProEcoServe); Level of transformation (SANBI Updating National Landcover 2009); Aquatic priorities (South African National Biodiversity Assessment [48]); Critical biodiversity areas (National Estuary Biodiversity Plan [49]); Presence of threatened ecosystems (National Freshwater Ecosystem Priority Areas [50]); Ecosystem protection levels (Namakwa District Biodiversity Sector Plan [51]); Protected area expansion needs (National Protected Areas Expansion Strategy [52,53]); Level of transformation (SANBI Updating National Landcover 2009); Coastal corridors (Vegetation of South Africa, Lesotho, and Swaziland [32]); Riparian corridors and buffers (Regions of floristic endemism in South Africa [54]); Temperature, rainfall and altitudinal gradients (Layers developed by Holness for National Protected Areas Expansion Strategy [52]); Areas with high biotic diversity (Vegetation of South Africa, Lesotho, and Swaziland [32]); Centres of floristic endemism (Regions of floristic endemism in South Africa [54]); Local species refugia (Layers developed by Holness for National Protected Areas Expansion Strategy [52]); Large unfragmented landscapes (Layers developed by Holness for National Protected Areas Expansion Strategy [52]); Level of transformation (SANBI Updating National Landcover 2009); Population densities (National Census data collected in 2011 [74]); Population location (Location of buildings from Eskom data); Proportions of low income households (National Census data collected in 2011 [74]); Levels of dependency (National Census data collected in 2011 [74]); Access to services (National Census data collected in 2011 [74]); Ownership of goods (National Census data collected in 2011 [74]); Dependency on groundwater (not piped) (National Census data collected in 2011 [74]); Dependency on communal rangelands (National Census data collected in 2011 [74]); Dependency on wood for fuel (National Census data collected in 2011 [74]); Dependency on natural building materials (National Census data collected in 2011 [74]); Level of transformation (SANBI Updating National Landcover 2009)
Spatial_Method: MaxEnt-based climate envelope modelling to map future biome stability; standard multivariate GIS multi-criteria overlay of equally weighted layers for water infrastructure, biodiversity priorities, climate-resilient natural features, and socio-economic vulnerability to produce EbA priority areas.
Method_Validation: MaxEnt model validation against current biome distributions (hindcasting) with 86.02% accuracy.
Tool: MaxEnt (Elith J, Phillips SJ, Hastie T, Dudík M, Chee Y, Yates CJ. A statistical explanation of MaxEnt for ecologists. Divers Distributions. 2010; Warren DL, Seifert SN. Ecological niche modeling in MaxEnt: the importance of model complexity and the performance of model selection criteria. Ecol Appl. 2011; Fourcade Y, Engler JO, Rodder D, Secondi J. Mapping species distributions with MAXENT using a geographically biased sample of presence data: A performance assessment of methods for correcting sampling bias. PLoS One. 2014)
Tool_Source: MaxEnt: used to develop biome distribution (climate envelope) models to predict current and future biome distributions under multiple climate scenarios, producing biome stability maps and informing EbA priority areas and local decision-making; described as industry-standard habitat modelling software and validated at 86.02% accuracy for current distributions.
Output: Biome stability map (projected biome climatic-envelope stability: more stable / less stable under medium- and long-term scenarios); EbA priority areas map (integrated EbA suitability/priority for implementation: high to low)
Climate_Barrier: "Yes: they explicitly frame climate change as a risk to NbS outcomes by showing that future shifts in biome suitability could undermine EbA effectiveness and by identifying socio-economic vulnerability hotspots where climate risks threaten resilience; they demonstrate this through scenario-based biome stability analyses and by overlaying climate risk with social vulnerability to guide NbS prioritization and persistence."
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target EbA/NbS priority areas where ecosystems can reduce climate risks and bolster adaptation by overlaying climate-change projections with ecological resilience and social vulnerability to identify where NbS actions should be concentrated; they demonstrate this through biome-stability and EbA-priority-area maps produced within a scenario-planning framework that links projected climate impacts to local decision-making.
Economics: Yes: Details Economic framing is integrated in the OUTPUT by treating poverty, income, access to services, ownership of assets, and direct dependence on ecosystem services as socio-economic vulnerability and environmental dependency layers that are overlaid with ecological data to produce EbA priority maps; these layers are equally weighted and scored on a 0–10 scale to guide decisions, reflecting an aim to maximize returns on investment in biodiversity, ecosystem services, and local livelihoods, but no explicit monetary economic outputs are reported (no ROI, NPV, cost‑benefit, or cost‑effectiveness metrics).
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Namakwa District Municipality; Alfred Nzo District Municipality; South Africa
Narrative: The NbS approach addressed ecosystem-based adaptation (EbA) prioritisation at the sub-national level in South Africa. It produced EbA priority maps by integrating ecological and social indicators in two case studies, Namakwa District Municipality (126,860 km2) and Alfred Nzo District Municipality (11,119 km2), spanning six biomes. Main inputs included present-day climate from 1960–1999 rainfall and temperature; future projections from three downscaled GCMs (MIROC3.2-medres, ECHAM5, CSIRO 3.5) via CCAM; biome distributions; water infrastructure and biodiversity data from SANBI sources; land cover (SANBI 2009); and socio-economic indicators from the 2011 Census and Eskom buildings (poverty line ~ZAR9,600/year), thereby incorporating climate risk and economic vulnerability. The spatial method combined a MaxEnt biome stability model with four equally weighted composite maps (water infrastructure, biodiversity, climate-resilient natural features, socio-economic vulnerability), overlaid and rescaled 0–10 to yield EbA priority areas after removing transformed areas. Validation showed 86.02% accuracy for current biome distributions; outputs are district-scale biome stability maps and EbA priority maps.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: All relevant data are cited within the paper and its Supporting Information files.

File: Decleer et al. - 2016 - Mapping wetland loss and restoration potential in Flanders (Belgium) an ecosystem service perspecti.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Floodplain grasslands and forests restoration; Tidal marsh restoration
Input_Variables: Flemish Soil Map (ALBON 2014); Biological Valuation Map (Vriens et al. 2011, INBO 2015); Flood Hazard Map of 2014 (VMM 2014b); POTNAT model habitat maps (Wouters et al. 2013); Tidal marsh maps (De Keersmaeker et al. 2001); Historic forest cover (De Keersmaeker et al. 2001); Current land use maps (De Keersmaeker et al. 2001)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-layer overlay of historical/current wetland maps with soil, drainage, flood-hazard, and POTNAT restoration‑potential maps rasterized to 20×20 m, normalizing indicators to 0–100 and combining two restoration-scenario overlays to derive changes in ecosystem-service supply and identify priority restoration areas; multi-scale Topographic Position Index (TPI) corrected for soil permeability to generate a seepage intensity map for denitrification-related assessments.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool: POTNAT model (Wouters et al. 2013); Topographic Position Index (TPI) extension for ArcView 3.x (tpi_jen.avx) (Jenness 2006)
Tool_Source:
POTNAT model: Used to model restoration/creation potentials for 18 wetland habitat types and map restoration opportunities under open- and forested-landscape scenarios, underpinning wetland restoration potential and ecosystem-service assessments in Flanders.

Topographic Position Index (tpi_jen.avx): Used to identify multi-scale infiltration-seepage patterns by calculating TPI across radii 250–2000 m, correcting for soil permeability to produce seepage intensity maps, and informing landscape-level nitrate leaching and denitrification (water quality regulation) calculations.
Output: Wetland restoration opportunity map (open vs forested scenarios); Soil organic carbon stock / climate regulation map (spatial SOC and scenario change); Water quality regulation map (spatial avoided nitrate leaching / denitrification); Flood risk regulation map (flood-hazard / scenario benefit for flood reduction)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They frame climate change as a risk that could undermine wetland restoration feasibility and the long-term effectiveness of NbS by noting projected warming, more extreme heat, droughts, and sea-level rise that alter hydrology and flood dynamics, and they support this through climate-change scenario discussions and explicit statements that restoration success depends on how climate change reshapes local hydrological conditions.
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT includes economic considerations: monetary valuation of a broad set of ecosystem services (water quantity regulation, water quality regulation, carbon storage/climate regulation, agricultural production, timber production, energy crops) with annual euro values; scenarios are compared to actual land use using a cost-benefit framing (Environmental Costing Model for nitrate reduction and avoided flood damages), with explicit monetized benefits and costs to illustrate socio-economic relevance and potential trade-offs of wetland restoration.
Narrative: Wetland restoration and creation were the NbS addressed. The study used historical wetland extents from the Flemish Soil Map (ALBON 2014), current wetlands from the Biological Valuation Map (Vriens et al. 2011; INBO 2015), a Flood Hazard Map (2014, VMM), and POTNAT restoration potentials for 18 wetland categories. Wetlands were reclassified into seven categories (Table 1) and overlaid with ES maps from the Flanders Regional Ecosystem Assessment (Jacobs et al. 2014a, 2015; Stevens et al. 2015). All maps were resampled to 20 m grids; watercourses constant. Two restoration scenarios were evaluated: open landscape and forested landscape, with protections respected. ES were normalized to 0–100 and aggregated to supply; monetary estimates used ECOPLAN data for services. Outputs included historic, current and potential wetlands maps, ES profiles (Fig. 1) and tables 3–5 at 20 m resolution over 13,522 km2 of Flanders. Climate risk and economic aspects were incorporated via climate regulation and monetized ES.

File: Drexler et al. - 2023 - A prioritization protocol for coastal wetland restoration on Molokaʻi, Hawaiʻi.pdf
Input_Variables: Depth to groundwater (Rapid field assessment); Groundwater salinity (Rapid field assessment); Groundwater discharge rate / springs mauka (Stearns & Macdonald 1947); Distance to nearest upland road (rapid field assessment); Elevation relative to mean sea level (Molokaʻi DEM; Sweet et al. 2022); Sea-level rise projection 2050 (Sweet et al. 2022); Sea-level rise projection 2100 (Sweet et al. 2022); Flat land availability (GIS); Soil texture (Kealia silt loam; Soil Survey Staff 2021); Soil organic carbon content (% OC) (Costech ECS 4010 CHNS/O; EPA Method 440.0 modified); Proportion native wetland plant species (rapid field assessment; Table 4; Supplementary Table S11); Native wetland plant species richness (rapid field assessment; Table 4; Supplementary Table S11); Bird habitat value for threatened/endangered waterbirds and migratory birds (rapid assessment; Supplementary Table S11); Average T&E bird count (Molokaʻi 2010–2020 dataset); Species richness of all T&E/migratory birds (Molokaʻi 2010–2020 dataset); Community support ranking (Pūlama Lima; Molokaʻi Wetland Partnership); Restoration status (rapid assessment); Area of site (Table 1); Proximity to other wetlands (Table 3); Hazards (unfenced roads, powerlines, contamination) (Table 3)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based site suitability analysis in ArcGIS Pro using a weighted multi-criteria approach across six sub-models (hydrology, resilience to sea-level rise, soils, vegetation, bird habitat value, community support), with all data rasterized to 3 m, a multiplier weighting scheme to combine criteria, and three weighting runs (equal, SLR+community 2×, SLR+community 3×) to rank the 12 Molokaʻi coastal wetlands.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: Site Suitability Modeler : Used in ArcGIS Pro to perform a weighted, multi-criteria site suitability analysis that combines six sub-model rasters (hydrology, resilience to sea-level rise, soils, vegetation, bird habitat value, and community support) into an overall suitability score for prioritizing restoration of 12 Molokaʻi coastal wetlands, with alternative weighting schemes (equal, 2x, 3x) to test sensitivity and identify top sites.
Output: Wetland restoration suitability map (equal-weighted sub-models; priority classes); Wetland restoration suitability map (SLR & community-support weighted 2x; priority classes); Wetland restoration suitability map (SLR & community-support weighted 3x; priority classes)
Climate_Barrier: "Yes: climate hazards such as sea-level rise and drought-driven hydrology are treated as risks that could threaten NbS feasibility and persistence, and the authors demonstrate this by overlaying future SLR scenarios and hydrologic constraints into a GIS site-suitability framework to screen and rank restoration sites, showing projected elevations and groundwater salinity trends that could undermine long-term effectiveness."
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target NbS—coastal wetland restoration—to address climate risks by prioritizing sites with groundwater-fed hydrology and higher resilience to sea-level rise and inland migration, and they demonstrate this in outputs through scenario-based prioritization that weights hydrology, SLR resilience, and bird habitat value under 2050 and 2100 projections, identifying top sites for restoration as climate-adaptation benefits.
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was coastal wetland restoration on Molokaʻi, Hawaiʻi. Main input variables and data sources included rapid field assessments of hydrology (groundwater depth and salinity), soils (texture and % organic carbon), vegetation (native vs non-native species and richness), and birds (habitat value for threatened/endangered and migratory birds; Molokaʻi data from 2010–2020), site spatial characteristics (site boundaries from high-resolution imagery and tax parcels), sea-level rise projections for 2050 and 2100 from Sweet et al. (2022), elevation data (Molokaʻi DEM), and Native Hawaiian community preferences collected by Pūlama Lima. The spatial method was a GIS site suitability analysis in ArcGIS Pro 3.0.2 using six sub-models (hydrology, resilience to sea-level rise, soils, vegetation, bird habitat value, and community support); datasets were rasterized to 3 m cells and combined with multiplier weights (three runs: equal weighting, 2x for SLR/community, and 3x for SLR/community) to generate 1–5 ranked scores. Validation relied on rapid field data, literature-derived bird habitat criteria, and cross-checking across weighting scenarios; results showed consistent top three sites (KOK, KNWR, OHI) and a final actionable six-site blueprint (KOK, KNWR, OHI, PUNA, KAMA, MOKU). Outputs comprised site rankings and suitability maps at 3 m resolution, focused on 12 coastal wetlands on Molokaʻi. Geographic scope was Molokaʻi Island, Hawaiʻi (12 sites). Climate risk was incorporated via SLR projections; economic considerations were not reported.

File: Heimann et al. - 2015 - Flood-inundation maps and wetland restoration suitability index for the Blue River and selected trib.pdf
Input_Variables: Basin slope (terrain model used in the study); Flow accumulation (terrain model used in the study); Flood frequency (HEC–RAS models and terrain model); Land use (2011 NLCD, USGS, 2014c); Stream buffer (National Hydrography Dataset, USGS, 2014d); Hydric soils (SSURGO, USDA NRCS, 2014)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based weighted overlay to compute a Wetland Restoration Suitability Index (WRSI) by integrating six hydrologic/topographic/land-use layers (basin slope, flow accumulation, flood frequency, land use, stream buffer, hydric soils) with 1–10 category scores and assigned weights to identify priority wetland-restoration areas.
Method_Validation: Hydraulic model calibration/validation against observed data: high-water marks from the June 14, 2010 flood and stage–discharge measurements at USGS streamgages (differences ≤0.65 ft for high-water marks; ≤0.54 ft for water-surface elevations); plus cross-evaluation of the Wetland Restoration Suitability Index with NLCD wetland data showing WRSI values of 5–10 align with wetlands.
Tool: HEC-RAS (U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, 2010); FST2DH (Froehlich, 2003); Surface Water Modeling System (SMS) (Aquaveo, 2012); HEC-GeoRAS (U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Hydrologic Engineering Center, 2009); Wetland Restoration Suitability Index (WRSI) (modified from WPST; Weller, 2008; http://www.dnr.mo.gov/env/wrc/docs/WPSTGrantFinalReportforWeb.pdf); Wetland Potential Screening Tool (WPST) (Weller, 2008; http://www.dnr.mo.gov/env/wrc/docs/WPSTGrantFinalReportforWeb.pdf)
Tool_Source: HEC-RAS: Used to develop one-dimensional steady-state hydraulic models to compute flood profiles for multiple reaches, calibrate against USGS stage–flow data and high-water marks, and generate water-surface profiles; FST2DH: Used as the two-dimensional depth-averaged flow and sediment-transport model run within SMS to update previous models and produce 2-D velocity maps and water-surface profiles for an 8.2-mile Blue River reach; Surface Water Modeling System (SMS): Provided the graphical-user interface to run FST2DH steady-state simulations and manage hydraulic-model outputs for flood-inundation mapping; HEC-GeoRAS: Used with GIS to delineate flood-inundation extents from hydraulic-model outputs and produce shapefile polygons representing flood areas; Wetland Restoration Suitability Index (WRSI): A GIS-based, weighted index (1–10) computed from six hydrologic/topographic/land-use layers to identify lands along the Blue River and tributaries most suitable for wetland restoration or mitigation; Wetland Potential Screening Tool (WPST): Provided the baseline wetland-suitability methodology on which the WRSI was based (this study used a modified WPST approach).
Output: Flood-inundation maps for the Blue River and selected tributaries (15 reaches; 1-ft stage increments to 0.2% AEP); Wetland Restoration Suitability Index map (WRSI; suitability classes 1–10, 5–10 most suitable)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS is targeted where wetland restoration could most reduce flood risk and support riparian wetlands, and the authors demonstrate this by presenting a Wetland Restoration Suitability Index map alongside flood-inundation and velocity analyses to guide restoration prioritization and flood-mitigation planning.
Narrative: NbS spatial prioritisation addressed wetland restoration along the Blue River in Kansas City, Missouri, using a Wetland Restoration Suitability Index (WRSI). Inputs included hydrologic data from 15 USGS streamgages (0.2% AEP), LiDAR topography, NLCD 2011 land use, SSURGO hydric soils, flood-frequency data, flow accumulation, basin slope, stream buffers, and NHD/NWI. The approach combined 1D steady-state HEC-RAS and 2D FST2DH modeling to produce water-surface profiles at 1-ft increments across 15 reaches and delineate flood-inundation polygons with depth grids. WRSI used six layers (slope, accumulation, frequency, land use, buffers, soils) with weights in ArcMap, using 3 m inputs and 30 m NLCD, clipped to 0.2% AEP. Validation showed elevations within 0.54 ft at gages and 0.65 ft for 8.2-mile reach. Outputs include flood maps for 39.7 miles (15 reaches), velocity maps for 8.2-mile reach, and WRSI map at 3 m resolution. Climate risk via flood-frequency/AHPS forecasts; economic considerations not explicit.

File: Higginbottom et al. - 2018 - High-resolution wetness index mapping A useful tool for regional scale wetland management.pdf
Input_Variables: Digital Elevation Model (Environment Agency LiDAR-derived DTMs); Slope (DEM-derived); Flow Direction (DEM-derived; TauDEM); Flow Accumulation (DEM-derived; TauDEM); Up-slope contributing area α (DEM-derived; TauDEM); Water Retention Layer (Soils NSM; LCM2007); Soils (NSM); Land Cover (LCM2007); Drainage potential (Soils NSM; LCM2007)
Spatial_Method: CTI-based wetness mapping: compute Compound Topographic Index from a 4 m LiDAR DEM using flow direction (D8) and flow accumulation to derive upslope contributing area and slope, apply CTI = ln(alpha/tan beta), aggregate drainage potential from soils and land cover to form a water-retention layer, and identify high-CTI areas as wetland restoration priorities.
Method_Validation: PHI-based validation using the Priority Habitat Inventory as reference wetland classes; statistical validation with ANOVA and post-hoc Tukey’s HSD comparing CTI values between wetland classes and non-wetland samples.
Tool_Source: TauDEM: used to generate flow direction (D8) and flow accumulation from the LiDAR DEM to derive the upslope contributing area, which combined with slope yields the Compound Topographic Index (CTI) wetness metric for regional wetland potential mapping.
Output: Compound Topographic Index (CTI) wetness-potential suitability map (percentile classes 1–10)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS (wetland restoration) is spatially targeted to deliver climate mitigation (carbon sequestration/storage) and adaptation (flood regulation). The authors demonstrate this by deriving CTI-based wetness maps to identify high-potential restoration sites and by highlighting restoration opportunities and carbon/storage/flood-prevention benefits in their outputs and case studies.
Geographic_Scope: Sub-national: Northwest England;Sub-national: Greater Manchester;National: United Kingdom;Local: Carrington Moss;Local: Risley Moss;Local: Wigan Flashes
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was restoration and creation of wetland habitats within the Greater Manchester Local Nature Improvement Area under the Great Manchester Wetlands Partnership. Main input variables and data sources included high-resolution LiDAR-derived elevation data (Environment Agency; 2 m DTM aggregated to 4 m), soils from the National Soil Resources Institute’s Soil Map (NSM; Mayr and Palmer 2006) with six drainage categories, land cover from the UK Land Cover Map 2007 (LCM2007; Morton et al. 2011) aggregated to four drainage classes, and known wetlands from the Priority Habitat Inventory (PHI; Natural England 2016) for validation. The spatial method used was a Compound Topographic Index (CTI) approach, computing CTI_i = ln(α_i / tan β_i) from a DEM-derived upslope contributing area α_i and slope β_i (D8 flow direction; flow accumulation), with an aggregated water-retention layer derived from soil and land-cover drainage potentials (Table 1) to weight retention versus drainage. Processing used TauDEM and raster in R; validation used 3,000 random points and ANOVA with Tukey HSD. Results: CTI ranged 0–28 (x̄ = 8.30, SD = 2.51); significant separation between wetland and non-wetland sites (F = 268.5, P < 0.05; some PHI classes not differing). Outputs were a high-resolution CTI layer (4 m) and CTI percentile maps, plus case-study maps for Carrington Moss, Risley Moss and Wigan Flashes. Geographic scope covered the Greater Manchester/Northwest England region (~48,000 ha). Climate risk or economic considerations were not explicitly included in the modelling.

File: Howie et al. - 2024 - Seas the opportunity multi-criteria decision analysis to identify and prioritise blue carbon wetlan.pdf
Input_Variables: Maximum flooding extent (Cooper 2003; Rotzoll and Fletcher 2013; Yunus et al. 2016); Present-day inundation extent (Cooper 2003; Rotzoll and Fletcher 2013; Yunus et al. 2016); Inundation extent 2050 (Cooper 2003; Rotzoll and Fletcher 2013; Yunus et al. 2016); Inundation extent 2100 (Cooper 2003; Rotzoll and Fletcher 2013; Yunus et al. 2016); Potential tidal blockages (Howie et al. 2024); Land-use (Supplementary Material, Table 1); Land tenure (Supplementary Material, Table 1); Cadastral parcels (Supplementary Material, Table 1); LiDAR DEM (South Australian Department of Environment and Water Coastal Saltmarsh Monitoring Program, personal communication); Elevation bands mapped to vegetation types (South Australian Department of Environment and Water Coastal Saltmarsh Monitoring Program, personal communication); Pre-intervention relative carbon values by vegetation type (Lovelock 2021; Russell et al. 2024; expert elicitation); Post-intervention relative carbon values by vegetation type (Lovelock 2021; Russell et al. 2024; expert elicitation)
Analysis_Resolution: Variable flood cells (not a fixed raster/grid); cell sizes ranged from 633 ha to 153,398 ha.
Spatial_Method: GIS-based spatial MCDA integrating tidal inundation under present-day and sea-level rise scenarios (bathtub model), identification of tidal blockages (point and linear intersections), and layers of land-use, land tenure, cadastral parcels and patch size to compute project-complexity, carbon sequestration potential, and blockage scores and hence identify and rank priority blue-carbon restoration sites.
Method_Validation: Qualitative verification of tidal blockages using aerial imagery, local knowledge and on-ground imagery, with a binary Yes/No verification and field verification for sites not assessable from imagery.
Tool: BlueCAM (Lovelock et al., 2022; Clean Energy Regulator, 2022) ; Tidal Reconnection Method (Clean Energy Regulator, 2022)
Tool_Source: BlueCAM : Approved Australian framework for calculating and verifying the net carbon abatement potential of blue carbon projects and for assessing the cost-effectiveness of potential blue carbon initiatives; in this study it is cited as the evaluation step that would follow site identification to inform investment decisions (though not applied across all sites due to complexity). ; Tidal Reconnection Method : Methodology that defines restoration activities to reintroduce tidal flows to coastal blue carbon ecosystems and to establish eligibility for carbon credits under the Australian framework; in this study it provided the criteria used to identify, map, and prioritize potential restoration sites via MCDA for eligibility under blue carbon credit schemes.
Output: Blue carbon project suitability/prioritisation map (scores 1–5; 64 sites; 32 high-priority ≥3); Post-intervention spatial carbon sequestration potential map (relative carbon values; scenarios 2020, 2050, 2100)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: climate hazards—specifically sea-level rise and related coastal flooding/storm surge—are treated as risks that could constrain NbS feasibility and long-term effectiveness; the authors explicitly incorporate present-day, 2050, and 2100 inundation scenarios (including a 1% AEP storm surge) into their MCDA to overlay hazard exposure with site suitability and perform future-risk screening.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: NbS is targeted because blue-carbon wetland restoration is framed as a climate change mitigation and adaptation strategy, and the authors demonstrate this by applying scenario-based prioritisation that links future inundation/sea-level rise to projected carbon-sequestration gains and maps high-priority restoration sites.
Economics: Yes: The output prioritisation intentionally incorporates economic framing by weighting patch size to optimise cost-benefit of project development, and the approach is embedded in a cost-benefit/feasibility context with references to substantial implementation/monitoring/verification costs and to cost-effectiveness evaluation via BlueCAM to inform investment decisions and enable subsequent detailed cost–benefit feasibility analyses.
Narrative: The NbS addressed was tidal restoration of blue‑carbon coastal wetlands (mangroves and tidal marshes) in South Australia, identified and prioritised with a spatial MCDA under the Tidal Reconnection Method. The three inputs were: (i) predicted flooding after reconnection and sea‑level rise for present day, 2050 and 2100; (ii) project complexity from land tenure, land use, cadastral parcels and patch size; and (iii) potential carbon sequestration from post‑intervention vegetation extents using vegetation‑type–relative carbon values. Data included bathtub‑model inundation layers (−0.2 m AHD to 2100 MHWS +1 m SLR +1% AEP), 1 m LiDAR DEMs, post‑intervention vegetation maps, land tenure/land use data, cadastral parcels, Saltmarsh Monitoring Program data, aerial imagery, and SA Department for Environment and Water inputs. The MCDA normalised criteria to 0–100 and combined four components with a weighted mean, giving patch size double weight: Score_i = (Tenure_i + LandUse_i + CadParc_i + 2×Size_i)/5. Validation used qualitative checks of tidal blockages; 64 sites were identified, 32 high priority (≥3), totalling 21,114 ha. Outputs mapped site boundaries and 1 m resolution post‑intervention vegetation extents for 2020, 2050 and 2100 along a 5,000 km SA coastline. Climate risk (SLR, 1% AEP) was included; economic considerations were reflected in the complexity score and BlueCAM feasibility was discussed for follow‑up.

Tool_Source: NA
Output: Machine-learning wetland restoration priority map (priority classes / probability); Wetland classification map (beneficial / all wetlands / excluded)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: The authors treat climate change as a risk that could threaten NbS effectiveness by altering wetland hydrology and vegetation outcomes, and they demonstrate this through a scenario-informed approach that evaluates restoration performance under different climatic conditions and by integrating climate-adaptive risk screening into their prioritization outputs.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly frame wetlands restoration as a climate adaptation and mitigation NbS by prioritizing sites whose restoration would maximize flood control and carbon sequestration, and they demonstrate this through scenario-based prioritization of locations under changing climatic conditions to project climate-benefit outcomes.
Economics: Yes: It includes economic framing in the OUTPUTs—the priority mapping is said to have ecological and economic implications, results will be shared with landowners to create incentives for lower-priority parcels, and the policy discussion envisions payments for ecosystem services and mechanisms like greenhouse gas accounting/offset registries as downstream economic instruments, though no explicit numeric ROI/NPV or cost‑benefit metrics are reported in the outputs.

Main inputs included six national priority wetland attributes, twelve local wetland attributes, global data sets with 48 wetland attributes, and the universal hydro index, combined with Earth observation data, satellite imagery, hydrological field data, ecological parameters, climate models, and socioeconomic data. The MLBDSS integrated these multi-scale attributes to generate a spatial priority map of restoration sites, and results indicated that the mapped priority areas generally align with current restoration project locations. Validation: no explicit validation approach described. Outputs: a priority-area map; resolution not reported. Geographic scope: applied at a watershed scale using national, local, and global data; potential national-scale application in U.S. contexts mentioned. Climate/economic: it framed restoration within climate adaptation/mitigation and noted ecological and economic implications; explicit climate-risk modeling was not detailed.

File: Malekmohammadi and Blouchi - 2014 - Ecological risk assessment of wetland ecosystems using Multi Criteria Decision Making and Geographic.pdf
Input_Variables: Change in natural habitats (land-use map); Water pollution (source pollution data and entrance points to the wetland); Over exploitation of natural resources (buffer extension GIS map); Salinity of wetland water (electrical conductivity data); High temperature and high evaporation (temperature and evaporation data; water depth in freshwater zone used as index)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based, multi-criteria decision analysis; weights derived from Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP); standardized risk-layer maps are combined with a Weighted Linear Combination (Raster Calculator) to produce a final risk zoning map identifying priority areas.
Method_Validation: Sensitivity analysis (weight variation and layer elimination); AHP consistency ratio check.
Tool_Source: Expert Choice software : Used to perform Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) pairwise comparisons and compute weights for the risk factors, enabling consistency checks and producing the priority ranking of wetland ecological risks.
Output: Ecological risk‑zoning map for Shadegan Wetland (very low, low, moderate, high, very high); Change in natural habitat risk map (very low–very high); Water pollution (wastewater/oil) risk map (very low–very high); Over‑exploitation of natural resources risk map (very low–very high); Salinity of wetland water risk map (very low–very high)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: They treat climate-related hazards such as drought/low water and high temperature/evaporation as risks that threaten wetland persistence and the effectiveness of NbS-oriented management, and they demonstrate this via an ecological risk assessment that scores severity, probability and consequences of these hazards and by producing GIS-based risk zoning maps with corresponding mitigation strategies.
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: An ecosystem-based wetland risk assessment and spatial zoning (NbS) was applied to Shadegan Wetland, Iran, to identify ecological risks and guide management. Key inputs included ecological endpoints linked to wetland values from IUCN Behan Dam materials and risk factors—drought/low water, high temperature/evaporation, salinity, sedimentation, over-exploitation, wastewater from agriculture/industry/rural-urban, oil pollution, flow-change, and habitat change—with data from aerial photos, historical maps, field observations, electrical conductivity (salinity), and reports (Pandam 2002; Behan Dam 2010); Jarahi basin (24,310 km2) and wetland area (537,731 ha). Fifteen experts evaluated endpoints and weights via Analytic Hierarchy Process in Expert Choice; ArcGIS 9.3 Spatial Analyst produced a raster Weighted Linear Combination to overlay standardized risk layers. Stepwise, endpoints were identified, risks characterized, and prioritized; results yielded a risk map (Fig. 5) with five layers and categories Very High–Very Low, validated by 30% weight-variation sensitivity and Consistency Ratio. Outputs included management strategies (Table 10).

File: Martin et al. - 2022 - Comparing normative and descriptive methods for multi-criteria decision analysis A case study evalu.pdf
Input_Variables: Total nitrogen (TN) (Chesapeake Assessment Scenario Tool (2019)); Total phosphorus (TP) (Chesapeake Assessment Scenario Tool (2019)); Agricultural land use (AG) (Chesapeake Conservancy, 2013/2014 High-Resolution Land Use and U.S. Department of Agriculture 2019 Cropland Data Layer); Ecohydrologically active area (EHA) (The Nature Conservancy); Floodplain (FP) (Flood Emergency Management Agency, 100-Year Effective Floodplain); Water storage potential (WS) (Natural Resources Conservation Service); Climate flow (CF) (Anderson et al., 2016)
Spatial_Method: Spatially delineated 964 potential restorable wetland areas using GIS by screening land-use/land-cover data for contiguous, non-tidal patches that meet a minimum size of 121 ha and contain at least 61 ha of ecohydrologically active area, with agricultural land use and non-tidal natural land cover mapped (excluding tidal wetlands) to define alternatives for MCDA.
Method_Validation: Sensitivity analysis; Overlap analysis between PCA groupings and ranking method groupings
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Potential wetland restoration alternatives (delineated restorable patches)
Climate_Barrier: Yes: Climate hazards are treated as a risk factor that could limit NbS outcomes by incorporating climate resilience criteria (water storage potential and climate flow) that reflect climate-change pressures on restoration alternatives. They demonstrate this by comparing rankings under risk vs riskless contexts and performing sensitivity analyses on weights and data transformations to account for climate-related uncertainty.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly target wetland restoration to deliver climate adaptation by maximizing climate resilience through climate-flow and water-storage criteria, i.e., addressing climate change pressures; they demonstrate this with scenario-based prioritisation that emphasize CF and WS and by mapping restoration opportunities to show where high climate-resilience NbS benefits can be achieved.
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was wetland restoration to improve water quality and climate resilience in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, focusing on Delaware and Maryland. Seven criteria spanning water quality and climate resilience were evaluated for 964 wetland alternatives delineated as 121 ha, 61 ha EHA. Data sources included TN and TP loads from the Chesapeake Assessment Tool, land use from Chesapeake Conservancy and USDA Cropland Data Layer (2019), EHA from The Nature Conservancy, floodplain data from the 100-Year Floodplain, water storage potential from NRCS, and climate flow from Anderson et al. (2016). Spatial prioritisation used normative MCDA (value function under risk and riskless contexts; distance function with p = 2) with seven weighting scenarios, plus PCA. Outputs were ranking groupings (100; 50), a PCA plane explaining 99.9% of variation, and landscape maps. Monetary valuation was not included; climate risk was incorporated via WS and CF; study area spans 165,759 km2.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Supporting data are available on request: David.Martin@tnc.org.

Tool_Source: NA

Climate_Benefit: Yes: The study targets wetland restoration to improve climate resilience (an adaptation framing) with explicit climate-resilience objectives and criteria (storage capacity, climate flow, and species movement) used to evaluate options, and outputs include maps and prioritized regions showing where NbS yields the greatest climate-resilience benefits under different weighting scenarios.
Narrative: Wetland restoration opportunities in the Chesapeake Bay were pursued as NbS to improve water quality and climate resilience. The study delineated 964 restorable alternatives in Delaware and Maryland's Eastern Shore, requiring patches at least 121 ha (300 acres) with at least 61 ha (150 acres) of ecohydrologically active area. Inputs included TN and TP loading rates from the Chesapeake Scenario Assessment Tool under 2019 Progress and 2025 scenarios, land use from Chesapeake Conservancy's 1 m HLUD with USDA Cropland Data Layer, SSURGO hydrologic soil groups, ecohydrologically active areas from LiDAR/topography and ArcHydro, FEMA 100-year floodplain, and climate-flow from a permeability model. SDM combined seven criteria into two objectives (water quality and climate resilience) using MAVT and compromise programming, scaled to 0–1 with weights and seven sensitivity iterations; PCA yielded Z1 and seven regions. Outputs included 184 alternatives and two nutrient-loading maps across seven regions. Climate risk included; considerations were non-monetary.

File: Medland et al. - 2023 - A multi-Criteria Wetland Suitability Index for Restoration across Ontario’s Mixedwood Plains.pdf
Input_Variables: Agriculture (Agricultural Resource Inventory (ARI)—Ontario Ministry of Agriculture, Food, and Rural Affairs; 1983–2010); Built-up Area (Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources—OMNR; 2013); Roads (Major Roads Network—DMTI Spatial; 2018); Soil Drainage (Canadian Land Inventory—Detailed Soil Survey (DSS) Compilations; 2010); Groundwater Level (Provincial Groundwater Monitoring Network (PGMN)—Ministry of Environment; 2016); Slope (DEM90 Digital Elevation Model—EarthEnv; 2014); Stream Proximity (Stream Network—OHN; 2010); Major Waterbodies (Waterbodies Region—DMTI Spatial; 2018); DEM (DEM90 Digital Elevation Model—EarthEnv; 2014)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis: seven criteria (agriculture, built-up, soil drainage, groundwater, slope, stream proximity, major waterbodies as constraint) are normalized to 0–10 and weighted by Analytical Hierarchy Process to produce a weighted Wetland Suitability Index (WSI) raster; groundwater depth interpolated by kriging to a continuous layer; best sites identified as high-WSI cells; Getis-Ord Gi* (and General G) hotspot analysis used to locate statistically significant clusters of high-suitability areas.
Method_Validation: AHP consistency ratio check (CR = 0.0771 < 0.1); overlay validation using Jaccard similarity between WSI best sites and historic wetlands (Jaccard = 0.231) and between WSI best sites and existing wetlands (Jaccard = 0.028)
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Wetland Suitability Index (WSI) map [continuous 0.00–9.999]; WSI "Best sites" map [WSI > 8.35]; Hot‑spot priority maps (Getis‑Ord Gi*) [census subdivisions & quaternary watersheds; hot spots 90–99%]; Overlay map of WSI best sites with presettlement wetlands (Ducks Unlimited Canada) [intersection]; Overlay map of WSI best sites with existing wetlands (Land Information Ontario) [intersection]
Climate_Benefit: Yes: The NbS is spatially targeted to maximize flood risk reduction and resilience through wetland restoration, demonstrated by identifying high-suitability restoration sites in flood-prone areas and discussing potential flood-mitigation and ecosystem-service gains from restoring these wetlands.
Narrative: NbS addressed: wetland restoration/reconstruction as a nature-based solution to restore ecosystem services in Ontario’s Mixedwood Plains. Seven criteria—agriculture, built-up, soil drainage, groundwater, slope, stream proximity, with major waterbodies as constraint—used in a raster multi-criteria index via Analytical Hierarchy Process (weights: Sd 0.482, Ag 0.218, Bu 0.123, Sp 0.102, Gw 0.047, Sl 0.028). Inputs from ARI (Ontario MAFRD), OMNR, DMTI Spatial, PGMN, CLI DSS, OHN, LIO, and DUC wetlands; all layers resampled to 50 m. Groundwater depth kriged from 367 PGMN points. The WSI (0–10) had mean 6.40 and SD 1.96; best sites (>8.35) covered 14.529% of pixels or 993,299.25 ha. Validation with historic wetlands (DUC) yielded Jaccard 0.231 and existing wetlands Jaccard 0.028. Getis-Ord G and Gi* revealed hotspots near Ottawa, Niagara, and St Clair–Erie. A 50 m WSI raster, best-sites map, and hotspot overlays were produced. Scope: 81,134 km2 in Southern Ontario; climate risk not included; economic considerations via agriculture.

File: Ponnambalam et al. - 2002 - Wetlands Management using GIS and Multi-Criteria Evaluation Tools.pdf
Input_Variables: Urban areas (ORCA landuse map); Wetlands (ORCA landuse map); Road network (ORCA landuse map); Rivers (ORCA landuse map); Road buffers (ORCA landuse map); River buffers (ORCA landuse map)
Spatial_Method: Fuzzy logic map overlays for multi-criteria evaluation: fuzzification of raster layers, aggregation using fuzzy operators (min, max, product, gamma), and defuzzification (optional) to identify suitable/priority areas.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Fuzzy suitability map for development (0 = unsuitable — 1 = suitable)
Climate_Benefit: No
Economics: Yes: The economic aspect is incorporated through a "cost" criterion in the Multi-Criteria Evaluation Tool, integrated with fuzzy logic weighting across layers to influence development suitability, producing outputs as suitability maps that reflect cost considerations.
Narrative: The NbS practice addressed was wetlands management using GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation. Main inputs were wetlands locations, urban areas, rivers, highways/roads, and buffer zones derived from the Grand River Conservation Authority ORCA land-use map for the Kitchener–Waterloo to Guelph region, with data implemented in ArcView Version 8 and membership values computed in MATLAB Version 6. The spatial method was a fuzzy logic multi-criteria evaluation tool (MCET), assigning fuzzy membership functions to layers (urban, wetlands, distance to roads, proximity to rivers) and combining them per pixel with fuzzy operators such as min, max, fuzzy algebraic product/sum, and a gamma operator with y = 0.05; no defuzzification was required. Validation used a case study with a single pro-environment decision maker, yielding a per-pixel 0–1 fuzzy suitability map (Figures 13.2–13.3). Outputs are per-pixel rasters at the study area scale, centered on the ORCA region between Kitchener–Waterloo and Guelph; climate risk was not included, but cost was among the criteria.

Input_Variables: Topographic saturation (National Fundamental Geographic Information System); Soil characteristics (Soils); Stream order (DEM data); Overland flow length (Flow length module in ArcGIS from DEM); Land use (Data Center for Resources and Environmental Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences); Reclamation history (Data Center for Resources and Environmental Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences); Grain yield density (County statistical yearbooks); Power density of agricultural machinery (County statistical yearbooks)
Spatial_Method: A GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation (MCE) using PCA-derived weights to combine eight natural and anthropogenic criteria into a Restorability Index (RESI) via a linear-weighted sum; rasterized factor layers are standardized, summed in ArcGIS to produce RESI maps, then RESI values are classified with Jenks natural breaks to identify priority/restoration areas.

Tool_Source: Restorability Index : A GIS-based composite index that integrates eight natural and anthropogenic criteria to produce a grid-cell Restorability Index (RESI), classify areas into five restoration priority levels, and guide spatial prioritization and planning of wetland restoration in the Sanjiang Plain.; SPSS (IBM SPSS Statistics) : Statistical software used to perform principal component analysis on standardized factor values to derive component loadings and weights, which are then combined to calculate factor weights for RESI and thus drive the restorability assessment.

The main inputs were eight criteria representing natural (topographic saturation, soil characteristics, stream order, overland flow distance) and anthropogenic (land use, reclamation history, grain yield density, power density of agricultural machinery) factors, with data from the DEM-derived hydrology, ArcGIS modules, RESDC land-use maps and yearbooks. A GIS-based Restorability Index (RESI) was produced by rasterizing factors, standardizing rankings, and combining them with PCA-derived weights: RESI = sum wi fi. The RESI map was classified into five levels via Jenks natural breaks, enabling restoration prioritization. Validation used a sensitivity analysis; results showed RESI 5 areas of 14,973 km2 (14%) and RESI ≥4 areas of 40,934 km2 (38%). File: Ruangpan et al. - 2020 - Incorporating stakeholders’ preferences into a multi-criteria framework for planning large-scale Nat.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: Wetland restoration; Floodplain enlargement/restoration; Reconnection of oxbow lakes/Re-meandering
Input_Variables: Type of measures (Table 3); Hazard type (Table 3); The affected area (Table 3); Potential location (Table 3); Project type (Table 3); Land surface (Table 3)
Spatial_Method: Filter-based preliminary spatial screening (hazard type; affected area (urban vs non-urban); potential location within the river basin (upper/middle/lower course); land surface type; project type) followed by a weighted additive Multi-Criteria Analysis (MCA) using stakeholder weights to score and rank measures.
Method_Validation: Not adressed in paper
Tool_Source: NA
Output: NA
Climate_Barrier: Yes: climate hazards and climate-change–driven future uncertainty are framed as risks that could limit NbS performance and long-term resilience, and the authors demonstrate this by embedding hazard types in the MCA framework and applying hazard-based screening and weighted scoring to compare measures.
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They target river basins to reduce climate-related flood risks with NbS and demonstrate this by prioritising measures based on their flood-risk reduction performance and co-benefits (e.g., water quality, habitat, and human well-being) across two case-study basins, with floodplain enlargement/restoration ranking highest.
Economics: Yes: Economic considerations are incorporated in the OUTPUT analysis via the Socio-economic goal with sub-goals like “Stimulate/increase economic benefits,” weighted by stakeholders and embedded in the weighted-sum MCA framework to influence final rankings, though no explicit ROI/NPV/Cost-benefit/price metrics or economic suitability scores are reported.

The spatial method combined a preliminary screening with a weighted-sum MCA (MAVT): 25 criteria across six goals and 19 sub-goals were stakeholder-weighted; sub-goal scores were based on indicators, normalised to 0–5, and final scores mj = Scriteria_normalised × Wj. Outputs were ranked measures at river-basin scale (18 Tamnava, 12 Nangang; Table 4; Figs. 5–6). Climate risk was addressed via hydro-meteorological risk reduction, and economic considerations were included through socio-economic and human-well-being co-benefits.

Climate_Benefit: Yes: They explicitly frame paludiculture on rewetted peatlands as a climate-change mitigation/adaptation NbS and demonstrate this by estimating potential greenhouse gas emission reductions and presenting a scenario-based net-zero CO2 pathway (1.5°C) alongside a spatial eligibility framework to show where these climate benefits can be realized.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT includes economic aspects by conducting an economic viability assessment of paludiculture with per-hectare estimates of costs, revenues and profits (Table 3) across unfavourable, moderately favourable and highly favourable scenarios, incorporating agri-environmental payments (AES) and other revenue sources to illustrate how costs and incomes drive profitability and feasibility and to argue for public incentives for large-scale deployment.

Validation relied on literature‑based GHG data (GEST meta‑analysis) with expert input; the geographic scope covers German peatlands at state and parcel scales; climate risk and economics were incorporated via emission factors, GWP and AES‑inclusive scenario costs and revenues.

File: White and Fennessy - 2005 - Modeling the suitability of wetland restoration potential at the watershed scale.pdf
Input_Variables: Hydric soils (NRCS MUIR); Land use type (Landsat TM 1994); Slope (DEM-derived) (1:24,000-scale DEM/ DL G); Overland flow length (DEM-derived flow path) (DEM); Strahler stream order (drainage network derived from DEM) (DEM); Saturation index (without permeability) (TOPMODEL-based calculation using α and β from DEM); Saturation index (with permeability) (TOPMODEL-based calculation using α, β and soil permeability from NRCS MUIR); Soil permeability (NRCS MUIR); PDA (Proportion of stream miles meeting Ohio aquatic life-use standards) (Ohio stream water quality standards); Land use constraint (Urban, water, or transportation) (Landsat TM 1994)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation using a linear-weighted summation (weighted sum) of binary constraints (hydric soils; land use) and continuous factors (stream order; flow distance to streams; PDA attainment; topographic saturation index with and without soil permeability) to produce restoration-potential maps; hydrologic modeling using flow accumulation and the topographic saturation index to derive hydro-criteria; a two-phase site identification and prioritization workflow.

Narrative: The NbS addressed was wetland restoration at the watershed scale to improve water resource integrity in the Cuyahoga River watershed (CRW), a 2107 km2 area with 1965 km of perennial streams. Main inputs and data included hydric soils (NRCS MUIR), Landsat Thematic Mapper 1994 land-use/cover, topography with flow-paths from a 1:24,000 DEM (DLG-derived), overland-flow length to the nearest stream, Strahler stream order, and a topographic saturation index (SI, with/without soil permeability); subwatershed attainment of Ohio aquatic-life standards (PDA) was also used. Data sources: NRCS MUIR soils; Landsat TM 1994; Ohio Wetlands Inventory; DEM/stream network. The spatial method was a GIS-based multi-criteria evaluation using linear weighted summation; criterion scores were standardized into an effectiveness matrix (Ef) and combined with expert weights from pairwise comparisons on the Saaty scale to yield restoration potential RP via RP = Ef × w (scaled 0–100). Three model versions (base, alternative weights, transmissivity variation) at 25 m output produced RP maps with classes 0–15, 15–30, 30–45, 45–60, 60–100; validation showed 73–87% agreement across model pairs, with top-RP area from 0.9% to 3.1% depending on version. Climate risk was not included; economic costs were discussed only as potential auxiliary constraints.

File: Worley et al. - 2022 - Balancing multiple stakeholder objectives for floodplain reconnection and wetland restoration.pdf
NbS_Subpractice: wetland restoration; floodplain reconnection; forest buffer
Input_Variables: Elevation (Vermont Center for Geographic Information); Land cover (National Land Cover Database; Homer et al., 2015); Manning’s roughness (Arcement & Schneider 1987, 1989; Chow 1959; Trueheart et al., 2020); Inundation probability (Diehl et al., 2021); Channel slope (Diehl et al., 2021); Upstream drainage area (Diehl et al., 2021); Floodplain width divided by channel width (Diehl et al., 2021); Incision ratio (Diehl et al., 2021); Cross-section data (Dubois & King Inc; 2017); USGS gage data (USGS); Conserved land (Vermont Protected Lands Database); Peak flow estimates (USGS StreamStats; Olson 2014)
Spatial_Method: Multi-objective spatial prioritization using an n-dimensional objective function (based on RiverSET-extracted 2D HEC-RAS flood metrics at candidate locations) to rank floodplain restoration scenarios.
Method_Validation: Model calibration/validation using observed high-water marks from Tropical Storm Irene, with Nash–Sutcliffe efficiency (NSE) of 0.94 at the downstream boundary.
Tool_Source: RiverSET: A Python wrapper used to semi-automatically extract flood Evaluation parameters (depth, duration, percent time inundated, stream power, velocity) at user-defined locations from 2D HEC-RAS model runs to compare, visualize, and rank restoration scenarios; 2D HEC-RAS: A 2D hydraulic model used to simulate unsteady flood hydraulics for the Mad River under multiple restoration scenarios across design storms (Q2, Q25, Q50, Q100), calibrated with Tropical Storm Irene, producing depth, duration, inundation, and velocity outputs for RiverSET analysis.
Output: Map of 11 proposed floodplain/wetland modification locations (NbS placement); Scenario allocation maps showing combinations of modifications for Scenarios A–G [A: baseline; B–G: intervention scenarios]; Spatially-explicit phosphorus storage by modification (P storage increase, 40-year totals per site); Spatially-explicit phosphorus credit by modification (TMDL P credits per site); Spatially-explicit inundation volume change per scenario at modification footprints (increase in floodplain inundation volume for Q2, Q25, Q50, Q100 storms)
Climate_Benefit: Yes: They frame floodplain reconnection and wetland restoration as adaptation to climate-change–driven flood risk and show this in outputs via scenario-based ranking that links NbS modifications to changes in inundation volume and peak flows across multiple design storms plus phosphorus storage/crediting to demonstrate flood-resiliency and water-quality benefits.
Economics: Yes: The OUTPUT includes economic framing and outputs—an explicit cost component in the multi-objective ranking (initial construction costs, annualized costs over 40 years at 6% interest, and lost commercial revenue), plus monetized water-quality benefits via phosphorus credits/storage; the n-dimensional objective minimizes costs while maximizing water quality and flood-resiliency gains (e.g., Scenario B/C cost about $234k/$340k annually, Scenario G higher costs but greatest P storage/credits), and the analysis discusses cost-effectiveness/benefit-cost considerations.
Narrative: Balancing stakeholder objectives for floodplain reconnection and wetland restoration in the Mad River watershed, Vermont, study applied nature-based flood mitigation with nutrient storage. It used 11 restoration modifications evaluated as six scenarios (baseline A plus B–G) in a 2D HEC-RAS model on 0.7 m lidar terrain and RiverSET metrics at 75 locations (depth, duration, percent time inundated, stream power, velocity). Water quality used phosphorus storage (boosted regression tree; Diehl et al., 2021) and phosphorus credits under the TMDL; flood resiliency and socioeconomic impacts used inundation volume and costs. An n-dimensional objective function with equal weights minimized the sum of squared deviations from targets for objectives. Eleven modifications ranked across six scenarios; outputs included scenario footprints (0.5–9.2% of the 500-year floodplain) and P reductions, with Irene validation (0.94). Geographic scope: 41.8 km modeled; upstream 31.3 km2, downstream 373 km2. Climate risk via design storms Q2, Q25, Q50, Q100; economic considerations included.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data will be made available on request; Supplementary data available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvman.2022.116648

File: Wu et al. - 2023 - Identification of wetland conservation and restoration priorities in regions of oil extraction in th.pdf
Input_Variables: Land use/land cover (Landsat TM 1991; Landsat TM 2014; GF-1 2019); Oil wells (GF-1 2019); Rivers and water bodies (not specified); Roads (not specified); Ditches (not specified); Soil types (not specified); DEM (not specified)
Spatial_Method: GIS-based circuit theory modeling (Circuitscape) to generate resistance surfaces and electric current density; identification of corridors, pinch points and barriers via least-cost path/flow analysis; and Linkage Mapper to delineate corridors and ecological nodes for prioritization.
Method_Validation: Field verification/ground-truthing of land-use classification accuracy (>80% against field points); validation of oil-well delineation by random sampling of 150 wells achieving >99.9% precision.
Tool_Source: Circuitscape 5.0 : GIS-based circuit theory model used to quantify landscape connectivity by assigning resistance to land-cover features and computing electric current density to identify corridors, pinch points, and barriers and to assess how oil wells alter wetland connectivity ; Linkage Mapper : Tool used to detect potential corridors and key ecological nodes from current-density maps to promote or constrain species movement, enabling planning to improve connectivity in oil-well-disturbed wetlands.
Output: Potential corridors (Least Cost Paths, with/without oil wells); Pinch areas (pinch points promoting species movement, with/without oil wells); Barrier areas (areas containing barriers to movement — restoration priority, with/without oil wells); Electric current density map (spatial current density of species movement by wetland type, with/without oil wells)
Climate_Benefit: No
Narrative: NbS oriented spatial prioritisation targeted wetland conservation and restoration to maintain connectivity in the Yellow River Delta under oil development. Inputs included Landsat imagery from 1991 and 2014 classified into mudflat, saline marsh, shrub wetland and forest wetland; GF-1 imagery 2019 to update land use; a 90 m DEM; oil-well locations. A GIS circuit-theory approach (Circuitscape 5.0) computed resistance surfaces and electric current density, with source patches defined as wetlands unchanged 1991–2019 or area >0.8 km, and Linkage Mapper identifying corridors and key ecological nodes; pinch points extracted with 5000 m threshold, and barriers mapped. Validation showed land-use accuracy >80% and oil-well interpretation accuracy >99.9%. Outputs included LCP corridors, pinch areas and barriers; corridor length rose by 126 km, barrier area by 51 km2, pinch areas fell by 1178 km2. The study covered the Yellow River Delta Nature Reserve (N_YRDNR, S_YRDNR); climate risk not included; no economic analysis.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: Data will be made available on request. Supplementary data: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecolind.2023.110621
Contacts_Email: Email not provided in the text.

File: Zhang et al. - 2024 - Dynamic monitoring and restorability evaluation of alpine wetland in the eastern edge of Qinghai–Tib.pdf
Input_Variables: Slope (DEM); TWI (DEM); Stream network density (Hydro network data); Water abundance (Landsat SMA); Soil type (HWSD); Soil erodibility (Institute of Soil Science, CAS); Soil abundance (Landsat SMA); Relative humidity (Meteorological CMA/remote sensing); Vegetation type (Chinese vegetation type map); Vegetation abundance (Landsat SMA); Habitat suitability of black-necked crane (Fang et al., 2020); Village interference (Land use RESDC); Road interference (Road network data); Land use type (RESDC land use)
Spatial_Method: Linear spectral mixture analysis to quantify water, vegetation and soil abundances from Landsat data; Change Vector Analysis to quantify multi-temporal changes in wetland elements; a precedence-chart weighting approach to compute the restorability index (DLRW) from multiple factors; a Bayesian network model to map restorability levels and delineate spatial priority zones for restoration.
Method_Validation: RMSE evaluation for spectral mixture analysis (overall RMSE ≤0.026; 95% RMSE ≤0.058; majority of pixels RMSE <0.1); Bayesian network model validation via confusion matrix and error ratio using 3000 random validation points (error ratio 25.61%).
Tool_Source: NA
Output: Alpine wetland restorability/suitability map (unsuitable; slightly unsuitable; less suitable; slightly suitable; suitable); Spatial distribution of key state subsets (key factor state combinations linked to restorability classes: unsuitable; slightly unsuitable; less suitable; slightly suitable; suitable); Restoration priority / optimal restorability map (primary optimisation zone; secondary optimisation zone; tertiary optimisation zone)
Climate_Benefit: No
Geographic_Scope: Local: Zoige County;Zoige Wetland National Nature Reserve;Sub-national: Sichuan Province;National: China
Narrative: NbS spatial prioritisation addressed alpine wetland restoration in Zoige County, eastern Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, as a nature-based solution for hydrology and biodiversity. Core inputs combined Landsat-based endmember abundances for water, vegetation and soil via spectral mixture analysis across seven periods (1990–2020) with land use (RESDC, 100 m), precipitation (0.5° grid), evapotranspiration (MOD16A3, 1 km), soil type (HWSD, 1 km), vegetation type and black-necked crane habitat suitability. Additional factors included slope, TWI, stream density, relative humidity, soil erodibility, soil and vegetation abundances, village and road interference, and land-use type (F1–F14). Change vector analysis quantified inter-period changes. Restorability (DLRW) was derived by a precedence-chart weighted sum of F1–F14 (Eq. 5) and validated with RMSE mean ≤0.026 (95% ≤0.058). A Bayesian network produced restorability levels (lowest to highest) on 100 m grids over 10,155.55 km2, yielding a five-class map and zones; 63.69% of area fell in less/slightly suitable to suitable categories. Climate variables and crane habitat influenced restorability; economic factors were not reported.
Code_Data_Availability: Code: NA; Data: The authors do not have permission to share data.
